carrer.name: A, Carrer
carrer.descripcio: This is one of the most important streets in the area. The Urban Development Committee approved the Partial Arrangement Plan for the industrial estate of the Consortium of Barcelona's Zona Franca, where, with few exceptions, streets designated with letters run in the North-South direction, while streets designated with numbers run in the East-West direction.

carrer.name: Abadessa Olzet, Carrer de l'
carrer.descripcio: Sister Sovereign of Olzet, the first abbess of the Monastery of Pedralbes, was elected on May 3, 1327, and died on April 25, 1336. Fourteen Damianist nuns arrived at Saint Anthony convent, located near Saint Daniel gate in Barcelona's old city wall, and established in the new monastery.
carrer.anteriors: Abadessa d'Olzet, from 1929 to 1931; Sor Sobirana d'Olzet, 1922; Monjas, before 1888

carrer.name: Abaixadors, Carrer dels
carrer.descripcio: This street was home to the fullers guild, founded by a privilege bestowed upon them by Pere IV in Barcelona on March 8, 1386, who settled and built their guild house here after separating from the wool weavers guild. The first ordinances issued by the guild dates as far back as 1456.
carrer.anteriors: Dufort; Forn d'en Dufort, before the XIV century

carrer.name: Abat Escarré, Plaça de l'
carrer.descripcio: Aureli Maria Escarré i Jané (L'Arboç, Baix Penedès 1908 - Barcelona 1968), a Benedictine monk, who entered the Monastery of Montserrat in 1923, being ordained priest in 1933. After July 19, 1936, under the protection of the Generalitat, he was able to escape to Italy. After his return to the Monastery of Montserrat in January 1939, he was confirmed as prior, becoming Abbot Coadjutor of Abbot Marcet in 1941. His critical position towards the Government made of him a symbol and representative of the Catalan Church. In 1965, political circumstances obliged him to leave Catalonia for Italy, where he took up residence at the Monastery of Viboldone (Lombardy). In 1966, he had to renounce the title of Abbot of Montserrat. Deadly ill, the Abbot Cassià Just brought him back to Barcelona. He was buried at Montserrat.

carrer.name: Abat Odó, Carrer de l'
carrer.descripcio: Abbot of the Monastery of Sant Cugat del Vallès between 986 and 1010. Bishop of Girona. When the Monastery was attacked by Al-Mansur in 985, the Abbot Joan and twelve monks were killed, as the cloister was destroyed and the archive burnt. After the danger was over, the Abbot Odó with some monks who saved their lives because they had refuged in Barcelona, repaired the monastery and the patrimony, obtaining the global confirmation of its property from the Frank king Lothario (986) and from Pope Sylvester II (1002). It is known that in 995 he was the Bishop of Girona. He died in 1010 during the Battle of Guadeira, as a member of the Catalan expedition to Cordoba.
carrer.anteriors: Abat Odó, 1940; Otto, 1939; Abat Odó, 1934; Otto, 1907; Santa Eugènia, before 1900

carrer.name: Abat Safont, Carrer de l'
carrer.descripcio: Joan de Safont i de Ferrer (Besalú, Garrotxa 1789 - Barcelona 1847). Benedictine. Abbot of Sant Pau del Camp. Historian and philosopher. Lecturer of Philosophy at the College of Sant Pau del Camp until his expulsion in 1835. After his secularization, he became a professor and popularizer of physics sciences. He organized a remarkable museum and a library.

carrer.name: Abat Samsó, Carrer de l'
carrer.descripcio: According to some sources, Bernat Samsó (XV century) took part in the capitulation of Barcelona during the civil war against Joan II (1472). But it is more probable that this street name refers to friar Miquel Samsó, Abbot of San Salvador de Breda, deputy of the Generalitat in 1470.
carrer.anteriors: Abat Samsó, 1939; Bernat Cavaller, 1931; Abat Samsó, 1927; Bernat Cavaller, 1922; Santa Teresa, before 1888

carrer.name: Abd el-Kader, Carrer d'
carrer.descripcio: Abd el-Kader (Guetna, Mascara, Algeria 1808 - Damascus 1883). Emir of Algeria, who undertook the holy war against France (1832-1847). In 1837, he achieved recognition of Oran and a part of the Algiers province by the French. In 1843, Algeria was occupied completely by the French, and he had to flee to Morocco. He was defeated in the battle of Isly (1844). Three years later, he surrendered to the French, who kept him prisoner until 1852. After his liberation, he went to Bursa, and later to Damascus (1855), where he lived on an allowance granted to him by the French Government.

carrer.name: Abdó Terradas, Carrer d'
carrer.descripcio: Abdó Terradas i Pulí (Figueres, Alt Empordà 1812 - Medina Sidonia, Andalusia 1856). Writer and republican politician. In 1840, he moved to Barcelona, where he founded the Patriotical Society, and started to spread a republican ideology through a leaflet, which soon became the newspaper 'El republicano'. Mayor of Figueres in 1842; later imprisoned when he refused to swear loyalty to the regency of the Duke of the Victory (de la Victoria). While exiled in Perpignan, he submitted a famous "Revolution Plan". After returning to Figueres, he was deported to Sigüenza (1844), and decided to go back to exile in Paris, from where he launched a call on republicans on 1st July, 1848. After the Revolution of 1854, he was re-elected Mayor of Figueres, until Field Marshal Zapatero dismissed the City Hall. Already ill, he lived the rest of his life in Andalusia. Anselm Clavé dedicated him the choral composition 'The Revolution' (1868).

carrer.name: Abella, Carrer d'
carrer.descripcio: Village belonging to the borough of Vilallonga de Ter (Ripollès). All street names correspond to Catalan villages, as approved by agreement.

carrer.name: Acàcies, Carrer de les
carrer.descripcio: As acacias were planted short after this street was opened, at the beginning of the century, people called it "acacia street". This was later adopted as the official name.

carrer.name: Acadèmia, Plaça de l'
carrer.descripcio: Name derived from the Academy of Mathematics specially dedicated to the education of military engineers, founded 1739 in the porter's building of the old Convent of Saint Augustin. The latter was almost completely demolished between 1714 and 1718 to constitute the Ciutadella glacis.

carrer.name: Acer, Carrer de l'
carrer.descripcio: The Urban Development Committee of Barcelona approved the Partial Plan for the Gran Via South Sector, with grounds basically dedicated to industrial use. Therefore it was agreed that names of several streets should be chosen from industrial materials such as steel, bronze, iron, plumb, etc.

carrer.name: Açores, Carrer de les
carrer.descripcio: Named after the Portuguese archipelago.

carrer.name: Actor Morano, Carrer de l'
carrer.descripcio: Francisco Morano Moreno (Madrid 1876 - Barcelona 1933). Theater actor. Morano used to work with the Maria Tubau Company, acting at Barcelona's Principal Theater (1893-1894). 1903 he created his own company. As an important manager and theater director he toured all larger cities in Spain, and in Argentina.
carrer.anteriors: Lletra B de Can Ramis; Capitán Ferrandiz, 1933; Lletra B de Casa Ramis, 1939

carrer.name: Actriu Tubau, Carrer de l'
carrer.descripcio: María Álvarez Tubau (Madrid 1854 - 1914) taught at the School of Dramatic Arts of Madrid, and achieved her best performances as a Spanish dramatic actress in plays written by Echegaray, Marquina, and Dumas (Jr.). The year she retired, 1904, she was nominated Master of Dramatic Art. The street was named after Maria Tubau on the neighbors' request.
carrer.anteriors: Lletra G de Casa Ramis, before 1933; Capitán Bellés, 1933; Lletra G de Casa Ramis, 1939

carrer.name: Adolf Florensa, Carrer d'
carrer.descripcio: Adolf Florensa i Ferrer (Lleida, Segrià 1889 - Barcelona 1968). Architect and professor at Barcelona's School of Architecture. Municipal architect.

carrer.name: Adossat, Moll
carrer.descripcio: Called so because it runs along and attached to the Eastern dock.

carrer.name: Adrall, Carrer d'
carrer.descripcio: Village of the Hortó borough (Alt Urgell).

carrer.name: Adrià, Plaça d'
carrer.descripcio: Publio Elio Adriano (Itàlica, Bètica 76 - Baiae, Campania 138). Roman emperor. philosopher, action man, mainly known for his constructions. Under his orders, four towns and important buildings all over the Empire were erected, among others Villa Tívoli, the Pantheon - famous for its dome with a diameter of more than 40 meters - and Adrian's Mausoleum, called Castle of Sant Angelo since the VII century.

carrer.name: Adrià Gual, Avinguda d'
carrer.descripcio: Adrià Gual i Queralt (Barcelona 1872 - 1943). Playwright, stage director, painter, pedagogue. He founded the Teatre Íntim, and directed the Catalan School of Dramatic Arts. Art director of the producer Barcinógrafo (1913). An important document were his memoirs, 'Half a lifetime at the theater', published after his death (1960). In plastic arts, he concentrated on a typically esthetic modernism. Finally, he devoted himself to scenography of plays produced by him.

carrer.name: Adrià Margarit, Carrer d'
carrer.descripcio: Adrià Margarit i Coll (1851 - 1908). Notary Public. Co-founder, together with Doctor Andreu, of the 'Sociedad Urbanizadora del Tibidabo'.
carrer.anteriors: Núm. 7 (el Tibidabo S.A. residential area); Adrián Margarit, 20/07/1943

carrer.name: Afores, Carrer dels
carrer.descripcio: Located at the outskirts of the former villa of Sant Andreu de Palomar. The street most probably received its name when it was still distant from the main village center.

carrer.name: Àger, Carrer d'
carrer.descripcio: Borough of La Noguera. This street is in the Milans del Bosch housing estate, where streets are named after Catalan villages.

carrer.name: Aglà, Carrer de n'
carrer.descripcio: Probably named after the nickname of a celebrity who lived in this street, as no such family name could be found in genealogical documents.

carrer.name: Agramunt, Carrer d'
carrer.descripcio: Borough of Urgell.

carrer.name: Agregació, Carrer de l'
carrer.descripcio: This is to remember the Plan of 1897, according to which the villages of Sant Andreu, Sants, Les Corts de Sarrià, Sant Martí de Provençals, Sant Gervasi, and Gràcia were annexed to Barcelona.

carrer.name: Agrícola, Passeig de l'
carrer.descripcio: So named in memory of the Agricultural Society that drained the surrounding swamps.
carrer.anteriors: Álvarez de la Campa, 1960; Agrícola, 26/05/1925; Cº de la Agrícola, before 1925

carrer.name: Agricultura, Carrer de l'
carrer.descripcio: Name honoring the art of farming. During the same period (towards 1880), other streets of Sant Martí were named after business activities (work, trade, etc.).

carrer.name: Agudells, Carrer dels
carrer.descripcio: Name of the mountain range east from Collserola. Ancient place-name 'Acutellos' or 'montanea d'Agudellos', mentioned as one of the limits of a certain estate that the couple Bernat and Guilla mortgaged to Adabert, son of El·lesindo, as a warranty of debt of six ounces, which the latter had left them in 1046.
carrer.anteriors: Carreu (without effectiveness), 1913; Santa Amàlia; Ra. del Carmelo

carrer.name: Agudes, Carrer de les
carrer.descripcio: Named after one of the peaks of the Montseny mountain (1706 m).

carrer.name: Aguilar, Carrer d'
carrer.descripcio: In 1912, the urbanization of the real estate Casa Pujol, owned by Maria Montserrat de Casanovas i de Fargas, was approved. The street planned to run along the highest elevation, looking down on the urbanization, was called Águila (Eagle). To avoid duplicity with a street name at Hostafrancs, in 1929 this street was renamed Aguilar, due to its similarity with the original name, and for being one of the titles of the Marquis of Monistrol. As the aforementioned marquis had no relation whatsoever with these lands, 1980 the street was dedicated to Josep de Aguilar i d'Alòs (XVII-XVIII century), a politician and military who participated in the defense of Barcelona (1705, 1706, and 1714).

carrer.name: Agullana, Carrer d'
carrer.descripcio: Borough of the Alt Empordà. Street located at the hamlet of Ramon Albó, where all streets are named after Catalan villages.

carrer.name: Agullers, Carrer dels
carrer.descripcio: This street housed the needle and fishing toil makers. The first ordinances had been issued by this guild in 1786, shortly after it separated from the guild of locksmiths and gunsmiths. This street name dates back to before 1778.
carrer.anteriors: Mar y Cielo (joined to it), 1927; Ancha (added to it), 1927

carrer.name: Agustí Duran i Sanpere, Carrer d'
carrer.descripcio: Agustí Duran i Sanpere (Cervera, Segarra 1887 - Barcelona 1975). Historian, archivist, and archaeologist. Bachelor of Arts and Doctor of Law. Since 1912, he collaborated with the Archeological Research Service. In 1917 he started to organize the Municipal Archive, the Researchand Publishing Office and the City History Archive. Until 1957, he directed Barcelona's Institute of History. Member of the Academy of Fine Letters (1924), whose chair he occupied between 1961 and 1963, of the Institute for Catalan Studies (1942), and of the Sant Jordi Academy of Fine Arts (1968). He also organized Cervera's Ethnological Museum.

carrer.name: Agustí i Milà, Carrer d'
carrer.descripcio: Jaume Agustí i Milà (Sant Andreu de Palomar 1817 ? - 1905). Doctor of Theology and Jurisprudence, Bachelor of Philosophy and Arts, who achieved high positions in Puerto Rico. After the colonial disaster, he returned to his birthplace, where he contributed to restoration of the Sant Andreu church, which had been demolished due to construction failures.
carrer.anteriors: Asil; Sant Isidre; Santa Anna, before 1900

carrer.name: Agustina Saragossa, Carrer d'
carrer.descripcio: Agustina Raimunda Maria Saragossa i Domènec (Barcelona, March 4, 1786 - Ceuta, May 29, 1857). Heroin of the Independence War. She was born at the little Montcada square and was baptized at Santa Maria del Mar. Daughter of Pere Joan Saragossa and Raimunda Domènec.
carrer.anteriors: Agustína Zaragoza, 1939; Soler i Rebollar, 1933; Agustína Zaragoza, 1929; Núm. 20 from Les Corts, 1925

carrer.name: Aiguablava, Carrer d'
carrer.descripcio: This street is named after a cove of the Costa Brava. It is located at the borough of Begur (Baix Empordà), at the Trinitat Nova neighborhood, where many other streets are named after places of the Costa Brava, and is overlooked from the East by the Ses Falugues mountain.

carrer.name: Aiguafreda, Carrer d'
carrer.descripcio: Borough of the Vallès Oriental.
carrer.anteriors: Fornells (without effectiveness), 1913; Méjico, 1908; Recaredo, 1907; Ra. de San Agustín

carrer.name: Aiguallonga, Carrer d'
carrer.descripcio: Records of this place name date from in 1002. Old name of a small valley within the township of Sant Cugat del Vallès, next to Valldoreix. There used to be San Cebrián parish, destroyed in 1130 and later moved to the chapel of Saint Vincent of Valldoreix. Since then, this parish is known as San Cebrián de Valldoreix.

carrer.name: Aigües, Camí de les
carrer.descripcio: Walk leading to the road named de les Aigües.

carrer.name: Aigües, Carretera de les
carrer.descripcio: Road built by the Company Aigües de Barcelona, to convey the waters from the deposit of Sant Pere Màrtir to the Tibidabo substation.
carrer.districtes: LES CORTS (04) SARRIÀ-SANT GERVASI (05) GRÀCIA (06) HORTA-GUINARDÓ (07)

carrer.name: Aigüesmortes, Carrer d'
carrer.descripcio: Street named after a town in the French Languedoc, department of Gard, famous for its city wall and for the Constance Tower.

carrer.name: Ajuntament, Carrer de l'
carrer.descripcio: This name reminds us that the front of the old City Hall of Sant Andreu opened to this street, and also of the condition of an independent borough this village had before the Royal Order of April 20, 1897, date of its integration into Barcelona.

carrer.name: Àlaba, Carrer d'
carrer.descripcio: Region of the Basque Country.
carrer.anteriors: Álava, 07/07/1942; Igualdad (from Les Glòries square upwards); Núm. 44 (Cerdà plan)

carrer.name: Alacant, Carrer d'
carrer.descripcio: Named after the borough of Alicante, town conquered from the Saracens by Jaume I in 1265, yielded to Alphonso X of Castile, and finally integrated into the kingdom of Catalonia-Aragon by Jaume II in 1296.

carrer.name: Alarcón, Carrer d'
carrer.descripcio: Pedro Antonio de Alarcón y Ariza (Guadix, Granada 1833 - Madrid 1891). Postromantic writer, journalist, and theater critic. He was Member of the Parliament, and member of the Spanish Academy.
carrer.anteriors: Pedro Antonio de Alarcón, 19/07/1947; Alarcón, 05/09/1907; Clota; Rda. de la Clota

carrer.name: Alba, Carrer de l'
carrer.descripcio: Formerly, when Gràcia was an independent borough, there was a street named Alba also in Barcelona. The name of Barcelona's Alba street was changed for "Este" (East). So now the only street in town named Alba is the one at Gràcia.

carrer.name: Albacete, Carrer d'
carrer.descripcio: Town of Castile-La Mancha, capital of one of the two provinces of the ancient kingdom of Murcia.

carrer.name: Albània, Carrer d'
carrer.descripcio: Named after the country in the Balkans.

carrer.name: Albareda, Carrer d'
carrer.descripcio: Street originally dedicated to Francesc Albareda i Gibert (? - Martorell, Baix Llobregat 1875), owner of one 'mujada' (approximately one hectare) at this place, but later it was dedicated to Leandre Albareda i Petit (1852 - 1912), who projected the magnificent New Cemetery at Montjuïc, opened by Rius i Taulet in 1883.

carrer.name: Albercoquer, Carrer de l'
carrer.descripcio: Integrated in a group of streets named after trees and bushes.

carrer.name: Alberes, Carrer de les
carrer.descripcio: Named after the mountain range between the port of Li and the sea, in the Ampurdan Pyrenees. There also used to be a medieval castle of Albera on top of the Sant Cristau peak, at Vallespir.
carrer.anteriors: Corberas, 07/03/1939; Alberes, 1922; Corberas, 18/05/1927; Alberes, 25/09/1931; Ctra. del Tibidabo

carrer.name: Albert Badia i Mur, Plaça d'
carrer.descripcio: Born 1899 at Sant Andreu, died in 1971. Since he was a child, he was familiar with the problems of the working class, as his father was dismissed for actively partaking in strikes during 1917. 1950 he started working at the ENASA (Pegaso) factory. As a militant of PSUC, he actively participated in the tramway strikes of 1951. Several times in jail, he was court-martialed and banished to a village of Teruel. Unionist and tireless fighter for the rights of the working class.

carrer.name: Albert Bastardas, Avinguda d'
carrer.descripcio: Albert Bastardas i Sampere (Barcelona 1871 - 1944). Lawyer and politician. Member of the Autonomist Republican Party, first vice-mayor, and accidental mayor (1907-1909) of Barcelona's Town Hall. Provincial deputy, vice-president of the Catalonian Community, secretary of the 'Unió Federal Nacionalista Republicana'.

carrer.name: Albert Einstein, Carrer d'
carrer.descripcio: Albert Einstein Koch (Ulm 1879 - Princenton, New Jersey 1955). German physicist, winner of the Nobel Award in physics in 1921. Director of the Institute for Physics Kaiser Wilhelm and member of the Prussian Academy of Sciences. In 1933 he left Germany for the USA, where he lived at Princenton, becoming member of the Institute for Advanced Study. In 1916 he published his famous theory on relativity. In February, 1923, he visited Barcelona, invited by the organizers of the monographic courses of superior studies, by interchange with the Community, and by the University. He was honored by the Town Hall in the 'Saló de Cent'.

carrer.name: Albert Llanas, Carrer d'
carrer.descripcio: Albert de Sicilia Llanas i Castells (Barcelona 1841 - 1915). Play writer, representative of bohemian life towards the end of the XIX century. He published several successful vaudevilles, and adapted to Catalan plays written by Moratín, Calderón de la Barca, and Shakespeare. President of the Cooperative of Journalists, who built the urban area where this street is.

carrer.name: Albert Pinyol, Passatge d'
carrer.descripcio: Passageway named after Albert Pinyol i Domingo (Valls, Alt Camp 1841 - Barcelona 1919), gardener and owner of the land surrounding it. He acquired the lands, half by buying them from Mercè Saladrigas, half by inheriting them from his wife Teresa Jorba i Mateu. The lands were originally part of Corts estate owned by the Jerónimas Cloister. The passageway name was chosen by his sons Albert and Ignasi.

carrer.name: Albigesos, Carrer dels
carrer.descripcio: Named after a religious sect that emerged at Albi in the middle of the XII century, and was the cause of wars in South France, after having been condemned by the both the Laterano and the Albi Council. Fighting against Simon de Montfort in defense of the villages of southern France, the king of Aragon, Pere the Catholic, died during the battle of Muret (1213).

carrer.name: Alcalá de Guadaira, Carrer d'
carrer.descripcio: Fortress (now town) of Seville, conquered by Fernando III of Castile in the middle of the XIII century, in whose castle important celebrities were imprisoned. The street name dates back to 1925, in compensation for the street named Barcelona at Alcalá de Guadaira.
carrer.anteriors: Alcalá de Guadaira, 1925; Doctor Rizal, 1931; Alcalá de Guadaira, 1942; Carmen/Dr. Rizal, before 1925

carrer.name: Alcalde Baró de Viver, Plaça de l'
carrer.descripcio: Darius Rumeu i Freixa (Barcelona 1886 - 1970). Second marquis of Viver, Grandee of Spain, politician and financier. Leader of Catalan liberal monarchists. Mayor of Barcelona (1925-1929). Name given to this square on request of the town councilors, who really wished this name for a part of the Balmes street (between the Diagonal and the Sant Gervasi alley), which was due to the personal effort of that Mayor, as it was him who achieved to put the railway underground. Finally, this square was named after the Marquis of Viver, because urbanization of the last section of the Diagonal had been designed by him.
carrer.anteriors: Sin nombre; Alcalde Barón de Viver

carrer.name: Alcalde de Móstoles, Carrer de l'
carrer.descripcio: Andrés Torrejón (Móstoles, Madrid 1736 - 1812). Being a modest 'payés' (farmer from Catalonia), he was elected Mayor of this village near Madrid together with Simon Hernández. When receiving notice that the Napoleonic Army had entered Madrid on May 2, 1808, the War Council Prosecutor, Juan Pérez Villamil, who was then at Móstoles, issued a proclamation encouraging the village to stand up in arms to defend Madrid. Both mayors signed the proclamation, and rebellion soon spread over Extremadura and Andalusia.
carrer.anteriors: José Nonell, 1935; Marina (section above the military facilities of Girona)

carrer.name: Alcalde de Zalamea, Carrer de l'
carrer.descripcio: Street named after a play written by Calderón de la Barca.

carrer.name: Alcalde Miralles, Carrer de l'
carrer.descripcio: Ramon Miralles i Vilalta (Sarrià 1841 - 1909). Mayor of Sarrià, then a separate village, from 1878 to 1902. Named adoptive son of Sarrià, because he achieved administrative independence from Barcelona. He constituted what now is the District Council, creating the Municipal Archive. He put Vil·la Joana, which he owned, at the disposal of the poet Mosén Jacinto Verdaguer to make him recover his health, unfortunately in vain.

carrer.name: Alcamo, Carrer d'
carrer.descripcio: Town in Italy, in the Sicilian province of Trapani. According to the Partial Arrangement Plan for the area Southwest of the Besòs river, several streets were named after Italian towns.

carrer.name: Alcanar, Carrer d'
carrer.descripcio: Named after a borough of Montsià, the southernmost village located within the Principality of Catalonia.

carrer.name: Alcántara, Carrer d'
carrer.descripcio: Named after the Battle of Alcántara, won by the Duke of Alba, who defeated the Portuguese on August 25, 1580, thus opening the gates to Lisbon. As a consequence, Portugal was incorporated to the Spanish Crown, under which it remained until 1640. The document 1085/55 concerning street names at the Roquetes neighborhood does not explain the origin of such names. But it is almost certain that this name refers to the Battle of Alcántara, because the same document mentions Almansa, Garigliano -and also important facts of arms-, as well as names of Castilian 'conquistadors' such as Alvarado, Almagro, Ojeda, and Quesada, besides the 'Cuartel de Simancas', where Spain's general archive on military history is concentrated.

carrer.name: Alcoi, Carrer d'
carrer.descripcio: Borough of Alcoià.

carrer.name: Alcolea, Carrer d'
carrer.descripcio: Alcolea (Cordoba). Battle that took place on September 29, 1868, where General Serrano, Duke of the Tower, defeated the troops of General Pavia, Marquis of Novaliches. This victory made succeed the revolution, thus ending the reign of Queen Isabel (Elizabeth) II. This street name dates back to the Revolution of 1868.

carrer.name: Alcúdia, Carrer d'
carrer.descripcio: Borough of southern Majorca. Belongs to a group of streets named after Balear towns.

carrer.name: Aldana, Carrer d'
carrer.descripcio: Joan Aldana (Tortosa, Baix Ebre, XV-XVI century). Military under Ferran II of Catalonia-Aragon and Carlos (Charles) V. At Pavia (1525), he personally made prisoner the King of France, François I. Street included in Víctor Balaguer's proposal of October 25, 1863, who was charged by the Town Hall with giving names to the streets of the Eixample (new-built areas to fill free spaces between old Barcelona and the villages later integrated into the city).

carrer.name: Aldea, Carrer de l'
carrer.descripcio: Named after a former hamlet called Aldea, integrated in Tortosa until 1983. This street is located within the former estate of Can Móra, and its name was approved together with the name of Móra la Nova, belonging to the same urban area as the street named Móra d'Ebre.

carrer.name: Alella, Carrer d'
carrer.descripcio: Borough of Maresme. Marquee title conferred to Camil Fabra, Mayor of Barcelona in 1893.

carrer.name: Alexandre de Torrelles, Carrer d'
carrer.descripcio: Born in Barcelona, he fought at Lepanto (1571) under Lluís de Requesens. As Naval Division Commander, he captured the galley transporting the sons of the Great Turk Admiral.

carrer.name: Alexandre Galí, Carrer d'
carrer.descripcio: Alexandre Galí i Coll (Camprodon, Ripollès 1886 - Barcelona 1969). Pedagogue and historian. Director of Terrassa's Vallparadís School (1910). As a public officer of the Council for Pedagogy he organized summer schools (1915-1936). General Administrator of the Industrial School (1917). Director for normal studies within the Community (1920), and of the Montessori School (1922). Together with a group of teachers, he founded the Blanquerna School in 1924. He was named General Secretary of the Generalitat of Catalonia Culture Council. After his exile between 1939 and 1943, he returned to Barcelona, where he devoted himself to publishing works and cultural history. He was member of the Institute for Catalan Studies (1968).

carrer.name: Alfambra, Carrer de l'
carrer.descripcio: Named after a tributary of the Turia river, or either, a small village located 23 km from Teruel. This street name dates back to 1943, as well as other street names in memory of battles occurred during the Spanish Civil War (1936-1939), such as Belchite, Brunete, etc. The Battle of Alfambra (February 5, 1938), fought by forces under the command of the General Dávila and the General Monastery, constituted a turning point in the Battle of Teruel. This town had been occupied by the republican army at the end of 1937, and could thus be re-conquered by the 'nationalist' (Franco's) army.

carrer.name: Alfarràs, Carrer d'
carrer.descripcio: Named after a borough of Segrià. The street is in the Milans del Bosch housing estate, where all streets are named after Catalan villages.

carrer.name: Alfons el Magnànim, Carrer d'
carrer.descripcio: Alfons IV of Catalonia, called 'el magnànim' (1396 - Naples 1458). King of Catalonia and Aragon (1418-1458) and of Naples (1442-1458). Son of Ferran I and Elionor de Alburquerque. He reigned during forty years, twenty eight of which he spent at Naples, between wars and celebrations. By conquering Naples, the Kingdom of Both Sicilies was made certain of.

carrer.name: Alfons el Savi, Plaça d'
carrer.descripcio: Alfonso X (Toledo 1221 - Seville 1284), called the Wise, King of Castile, son of Ferran III and Beatriz (daughter of Felip, duke of Suabia), and son-in-law of Jaume I of Catalonia-Aragon. He personally instigated, directed and corrected literature works of a large group of Arab, Hebrew, and Christian specialists, giving a final impulse to Castilian prose. His works on law constituted a milestone in the evolution of ancient Castilian Law.

carrer.name: Alfons XII, Carrer d'
carrer.descripcio: King of Spain (Madrid 1857 - 1885), son of Isabel II and Francisco de Asís de Borbón. Exiled in France after the September Revolution of 1868. On January 9, 1875, he disembarked at Barcelona on his way to Madrid, after General Sagunto's Coup d'Etat (December, 1874). He overthrew the Republic and proclaimed himself king. During his reign, the Carlist War (1876) and the Cuban insurrection (1878) were brought to an end, and a new constitution (1876), much more moderate than that of 1869, was approved.
carrer.anteriors: Bélgica, 1931; Alfons XII, before 1879; Paloma (the lower section), before 1870; Colegio, 09/12/1874

carrer.name: Alfonso Comín, Plaça d'
carrer.descripcio: Alfonso Carlos Comín i Ros (Zaragoza 1930 - Barcelona 1980). Mechanical engineer, sociologist and publicist. Militant of the Catholic Secular Apostolic Movement.

carrer.name: Algarves, Carrer dels
carrer.descripcio: Named after a region in South Portugal (High and Low Algarve), also a title of the King of Spain. This territory was integrated in the Kingdom of Portugal by Alfonso III in 1249, after long-lasting disputes with Castile.
carrer.anteriors: Algarbes, 1939; Ginesta, 1931; Algarbes, 1927; Ginesta (Town Hall of Sarrià), 1921; Solidaridad

carrer.name: Alguer, Carrer de l'
carrer.descripcio: Named after Algheró, a town of Sardinia, in the province of Sassari, which was re-populated by Catalans in 1354, after the original inhabitants had been expelled. The language there spoken is Catalan.

carrer.name: Alhucemas, Carrer d'
carrer.descripcio: Named after the Alhucemas Islands (Peñón de Alhucemas, Isla de Tierra, and Isla de Mar). Approved together with the street name of Chafarinas, a town at the Alhucemas bay. The name also reminds of the battles Spanish troops fought against Morocco, after disembarking on September 8, 1925 under the command of General Primo de Rivera, to secure the fortress of the same name.

carrer.name: Alí Bei, Carrer d'
carrer.descripcio: Domènec Badia i Leblich (Barcelona 1767 - Damascus, 1818). Traveler and writer. Working as en explorer for the Spanish Government under Charles IV, he adopted the Arab name Alí Bei-el-Abbasí, claiming to be a descendant of the Prophet. Under this disguise, he traveled all over Morocco and other kingdoms, preparing projects for penetration, and writing stories about his travels and adventures. French invasion prevented him from continuing his mission. Under King Joseph, Napoleon's brother, he was designated Governor of Segovia. When the French left Spain, he had to emigrate, and died in Damascus.

carrer.name: Alí Bei, Passatge d'
carrer.descripcio: Passageway with entry from Tànger (Tangers) street, formerly Alí-Bei.

carrer.name: Àliga, Carrer de l'
carrer.descripcio: Means Eagle Street. Named after the crowned eagle symbolizing the city, which used to be exhibited and dance along the streets during Corpus Christi celebrations in the Middle Ages, until this was prohibited by a bishop of Barcelona around 1573.

carrer.name: Alighieri, Carrer d'
carrer.descripcio: Named after Iacopo Alighieri di Manetto (Florence 1291 - 1348). Italian poet, and Dante's son, who joined his father in exile until 1325, when he returned to Florence. He wrote the first resume in tercets of Dante's 'Divina' 'Comedia' (1322). As this street was near Dante street, it was named Alighieri, to keep the family together.

carrer.name: Alió, Passatge d'
carrer.descripcio: Francesc Alió i Brea (Barcelona 1862 - 1908). Composer. A pioneer of the Catalan Musical Renaissance. This passageway, situated near the place named Caputxins Vells (Old Capuchins) of Gràcia, had been the property of Romano de Grassot i Elías, where the former name of the passageway, Román, comes from, until it was replaced by Alió.

carrer.name: Allada-Vermell, Carrer de l'
carrer.descripcio: Originally two street names, now a composed name, as the house block separating both streets disappeared. Allada: garlic sauce. The reason for this name is unknown, but it already appears in documents dating from the XV century. The suffix -ada seems to suggest that 'allada' could refer to a garlic field. Vermell, which means 'red', seems to come from a red substance used by the tanners established at the nearby Comtal irrigation channel.

carrer.name: Alloza, Carrer d'
carrer.descripcio: Street named after Salvador Alloza i Alloza (Barcelona 1897 - 1976), postman of the neighborhood. As around 1930, this neighborhood consisted mainly of fields, and only a few disseminated farms and house blocks, to make his job easier, the postman made the correspondence going to his neighborhood mark with his last name, Alloza. Progressively, fields disappeared and the neighborhood grew in population, but people living there kept remembering their postman, whose name was written for a long time on a piece of wood hanging on a nail in this street. Finally, the postman's family name became the official street name.

carrer.name: Almacelles, Carrer d'
carrer.descripcio: Borough of Segrià. This street name was approved on Noemí Pascual's request, supported by hundreds of people and by Almacelles Town Hall.

carrer.name: Almagro, Carrer d'
carrer.descripcio: Diego de Almagro (Almagro, Ciudad Real 1475 - Cusco 1538). Castilian military, conquistador of Peru and Chile.

carrer.name: Almansa, Carrer d'
carrer.descripcio: Street named after a town of Castile-La Mancha, where a battle between troops of Philip V de Borbón and those of the Archduke of Austria (Succession War) took place on April 25, 1707, the consequence of which was the loss of political structure for the Catalan Countries and abolition of the Aragon Council (June 29, 1707).
carrer.anteriors: T. de la Fuente Cañellas (a section)

carrer.name: Almassora, Carrer d'
carrer.descripcio: Borough of Plana Alta.

carrer.name: Almenara Alta, Carrer d'
carrer.descripcio: Dukedom conferred to Joan Antoni Clasquerí, formerly Fivaller i Bru, by Fernando VII on January 24, 1830. The dukes of Almenara Alta would become proprietors of the surrounding lands, limiting with those owned by Carles de Puiggener Orís i Descatllar.

carrer.name: Almeria, Carrer d'
carrer.descripcio: East Andalusian town, Mediterranean port. During the VIII century, it was an important market place for interchanging goods between Al-Andalus, Africa, and the Middle East. During Muslim domination, it was the capital of one of the ancient kingdoms of Al-Andalus. In 892, the town was attacked with 15 ships by the Count Suñer II of Ampurias, who achieved to reach a business agreement. In 1147, it was conquered by Ramon Berenguer IV, Count of Barcelona, but it was recovered by the Muslims. Finally, in 1489 it surrendered to the Catholic Kings, who incorporated it to their crown.

carrer.name: Almirall Aixada, Carrer de l'
carrer.descripcio: Street named after Rafael Aixada, born at Sant Feliu de Guíxols, Baix Empordà, in the XVI century. Lieutenant-General of the galleys under Emperor Charles I. Memorable were his actions at Algheró, where he saved his King from great danger when the assaulting Spanish army, with two hundred ships and twenty thousand men, was defeated on October 13, 1541.
carrer.anteriors: Almirante Aixada, 07/03/1939; Pilot Cabré (not official), 1936; Almirante Aixada, 16/08/1927; Andalucía, 1927; Concòrdia, before 1865

carrer.name: Almirall Barceló, Carrer de l'
carrer.descripcio: Antoni Barceló i Pont de la Terra (Majorca 1716 - 1797). Lieutenant-General of the Navy. His most remarkable actions were the naval defeat of pirate Selim, whom he made prisoner (1763); the actions against Algheró (1755 and 1783); the naval blockades of Gibraltar (1779 and 1781), and the sea expedition of 1783 against the Sultan of Morocco, whom he obliged to raise the siege of Ceuta.

carrer.name: Almirall Cervera, Carrer de l'
carrer.descripcio: Pascual Cervera y Topete (San Fernando 1839 - Puerto Real, Cadiz 1909). Seafarer. Counter-Admiral when war broke out with the USA (1898), he was designated chief of the fleet of Cuba.

carrer.name: Almirall Churruca, Carrer de l'
carrer.descripcio: Cosme Damián Churruca y Elorza (Motriku, Guipúzcoa 1761 - Battle of Trafalgar 1805). Military and cartographer, who participated in the siege of Gibraltar (1781-1783), undertook several expeditions over the seas, and wrote stories containing interesting technical and geographical information. He also helped working out the American Sea Atlas.
carrer.anteriors: Almirante Churruca; Meer (a section); Santa Eulàlia

carrer.name: Almirall Okendo, Carrer de l'
carrer.descripcio: Antonio de Okendo (Donostia, 1577 - La Coruña, 1640). Basque seafarer. While General Commander of the Cantabrian squadron, he was designated General of the Fleet of New Spain, and Admiral General of the Oceanic Navy in 1623. Eight years later, Philip IV named him War Counselor. Also the father of the former, Mikel de Okendo, was a famous seafarer, whom Felipe II charged in 1587 with the command of the Guipuzcoan Fleet, which had to join the famous Invincible Navy under the Duke of Medina-Sidonia. This family name derives from a Basque place-name (Valle de Okendo, Okendo Valley).

carrer.name: Almirall Pròixida, Carrer de l'
carrer.descripcio: Olf de Pròixida (XIV century). Valencian aristocrat, military, and seafarer, descendant of the Sicilian Procida family.
carrer.anteriors: Núm. 2 (from the enlargement of Sant Andreu)

carrer.name: Almogàvers, Carrer dels
carrer.descripcio: Almogavers were professional warriors in the XIII century. Their Orient Expedition under Roger de Flor achieved to put a part of Greece under Catalan domination during almost a century (1311-1388).
carrer.anteriors: Las Glorias Catalanas (a section); Lletra S (Cerdà plan)

carrer.name: Aloi, Passatge d'
carrer.descripcio: Passageway named after Jaume Aloy i Romaní (1836 - 1898), landowner and famous tile maker, married with Antònia Robert i Soteras. According to Decree 78/1991 about the use of place-names, this family/place-name has been standardized together with the rest of Barcelona's place-names.

carrer.name: Alonso Cano, Carrer d'
carrer.descripcio: Street named after Alonso Cano (Granada 1601 - 1667). Sculptor, painter and baroque architect. 1638 he went to Madrid, where he received the influence of venetian painting from royal collections.

carrer.name: Alpens, Carrer d'
carrer.descripcio: Borough of Osona. Battle in which the Brigadier Cabrinetty was defeated by the Carlist Army.
carrer.anteriors: Crillón (a section); Carranza (without effectiveness); Pasteur; Padilla

carrer.name: Alsàcia, Carrer d'
carrer.descripcio: Region of France. Street name approved together with those of Lorena (Lorraine) and Marne.

carrer.name: Alsina, Carrer de n'
carrer.descripcio: Catalan family name, very common in the medieval town, probably dating back to the times when the street was opened, or related with properties there located. The street already existed under the same name in the XV century. Another version says that the street was named after a big oak planted in a garden nearby.

carrer.name: Alt, Carrer
carrer.descripcio: The high part of Trinitat Vella neighborhood.

carrer.name: Alt de Gironella, Carrer
carrer.descripcio: The origin of this name is an old tower with a public oratory, surrounded by a 14 mujadas (approx. 90,000 sq. meters) large estate, formerly property of the Gironella family.

carrer.name: Alt de Mariner, Passatge
carrer.descripcio: Passageway opening to the street of the same name.

carrer.name: Alt de Mariner, Carrer
carrer.descripcio: Street named after the landowner's family name, who owned a great part of Horta. Masía Alta d'en Mariné.

carrer.name: Alt de Pedrell, Carrer
carrer.descripcio: Street running along the top of the hill towards the Pedrell street.

carrer.name: Alt del Turó, Passatge
carrer.descripcio: Passageway along the medium and lower Turó, at an elevated area in the Southwest of the Guinardó Park.

carrer.name: Alta de Can Clos, Plaça
carrer.descripcio: Square in the middle of the housing estate called Can Clos.

carrer.name: Alta de les Roquetes, Carretera
carrer.descripcio: Road communicating the estate called Canyelles with the Baró tower. Takes its name from the surrounding neighborhood at the mountain side.

carrer.name: Altafulla, Carrer d'
carrer.descripcio: Borough of Tarragona.

carrer.name: Alts Forns, Carrer dels
carrer.descripcio: The South Gran Via Partial Plan contains many street names related to the industry, as this Plan made available large extensions of soil for industrial use.
carrer.anteriors: Altos Hornos; Pegaso; Géminis (not considered); Hogar

carrer.name: Alumini, Carrer de l'
carrer.descripcio: This street receives its name from the aluminum sector within which it is located.

carrer.name: Alvarado, Carrer d'
carrer.descripcio: Pedro de Alvarado (Badajoz, Extremadura 1485 - Mexico 1541). Castilian conquistador, Captain under Hernán Cortés. Conqueror of Guatemala and El Salvador (1523-1524), designated Governor of Guatemala. He died while fighting to subdue the inhabitants of Jalisco.
carrer.anteriors: Cº Viejo de la Pedrera (a section)

carrer.name: Álvarez de la Campa, Moll d'
carrer.descripcio: Fernando Álvarez de la Campa y Arumí. Mayor of Barcelona in 1923. Retired Coroner of the Command in Chief. Royal Commissioner of the Free Port. He contributed to organize the Universal Exhibition of 1929, as well as to the prolongation of the Diagonal and the Count of Urgell street up to the Royal Palace, and to handing the Royal Palace over to the Kings of Spain.

carrer.name: Álvaro Cunqueiro, Plaça d'
carrer.descripcio: Square named after Álvaro Cunqueiro Mora (Mondoñedo 1911 - Vigo 1981). Galician writer, who started writing within the super-realist current, to change to neo-troubadourism later. After the Spanish Civil War, he worked as a journalist, and wrote his first books in prose. He decisively contributed to the cultural restoration of Galicia. In 1968 he won the Nadal Award of Literature. The street name was proposed by Manuel Fraga Iribarne (Minister during Franco's regime, now President of Galicia).

carrer.name: Alzina, Carrer de l'
carrer.descripcio: Street named after an oak tree planted in the lands where this street was opened.

carrer.name: Alzinar, Avinguda de l'
carrer.descripcio: Avenue leading to a group of oak trees at the foot of Sant Joan hill, at the town limits.

carrer.name: Amadeu Bagués, Passatge d'
carrer.descripcio: Amadeu Bagués i Cerqueda (Barcelona 1905 - 1981). Jeweler. President of Barna Centre and of the 'Associació de Veïns i Comerciants del Carrer de Sant Pau', as well as of the Jewelers Guild, and of the Federation of Jewelers and Watchmakers. Instigator and President of 'Amics de la Rambla'.

carrer.name: Amadeu Vives, Carrer d'
carrer.descripcio: Street named after Amadeu Vives i Roig (Collbató, Baix Llobregat 1871 - Madrid 1932). Composer, co-founder of the Orfeó Català. Author of 'L'emigrant '(1890).

carrer.name: Amarant, Carrer de l'
carrer.descripcio: Integrated in a group of streets named after trees and bushes.

carrer.name: Amargor, Carrer de l'
carrer.descripcio: Street located in lands formerly owned by the Marquis of Castellbell and later by Francesc Trinxant i Morera, near the street called 'del Sospir'. So named in memory of one episode of Jesus Christ's Passion, when Jesus meets his Mother on his way to Golgotha, carrying the cross on his shoulders. This is why people called this the street 'of bitterness' (de l'Amargor).
carrer.anteriors: Amargura; Lletra A (map of the Sant Martí enlargement)

carrer.name: Amargós, Carrer de n'
carrer.descripcio: This street, as many others around here, was probably named after the family that lived here an owned the lands where the street was opened, because it is already mentioned under this name in documents as far back as 1424. There is a mention of Jaume Amargós, merchant, dating from 1435.

carrer.name: Amer, Carrer d'
carrer.descripcio: Borough of La Selva. The street is located in Ramon Albó housing estate, where streets are named after Catalan villages.

carrer.name: Amèrica, Carrer d'
carrer.descripcio: Named after the continent discovered by Christopher Columbus for the Spanish Crown (1492), later visited by Amerigo Vespucci (Florence, Italy 1454 - Seville 1512).

carrer.name: Ametllers, Carrer dels
carrer.descripcio: Street called 'almond wood', forming a group with the streets called Avellaners (hazel wood) and Nogueres (nut wood).

carrer.name: Ametllers, Passatge dels
carrer.descripcio: Passageway crossing the street with the same name.

carrer.name: Amich, Plaça d'
carrer.descripcio: Square named after Miquel Amich, who urbanized these lands (1857-1861). Old family from the Sarrià neighborhood, there was also a Vicenç Amich, who built a house named Avió Plus Ultra (1850) in the Sant Salvador street, and Jaume Amich, who built houses in the Serrano street, Mayor of Sarrià (1886, 1888, 1890).

carrer.name: Amics, Carrer dels
carrer.descripcio: The origin of this street name is unknown. Maybe it refers to the friendship between landowners interested in urbanizing their real estates.

carrer.name: Amigó, Carrer d'
carrer.descripcio: Eduard Amigó de Lara (Barcelona 1833 - Buenos Aires 1902). Catalan pianist and composer. Famous harmonium player, awarded in 1865 by the Conservatoire of Paris.

carrer.name: Amílcar, Carrer d'
carrer.descripcio: Street named after Amilcar Barca (Carthage ? - Elche, Baix Vinalopó ? 228 b.Ch.). Carthaginian general, Hannibal's father. Tradition considered him the founder of Barcelona, because his family name, or place of origin, seems to have the same roots as Barcino, as Barcelona was called in the Antique, but this is very unlikely.

carrer.name: Amistat, Carrer de l'
carrer.descripcio: It reminds of the recreative society Amistat Catalana (Catalan Friendship), established in this street when it was given its name. The purpose of this society was to research into issues related with theater and to organize Catalan theater performances.

carrer.name: Amnistia Internacional, Carrer de l'
carrer.descripcio: Amnesty International (AI) is a voluntary organisation devoted to obtaining the freedom of prisoners of conscience, fair trials, help for political prisoners, the end of torture, and to denouncing the assassination of politicians and "disappearances", as well as the abolishment of the death penalty all over the world. It was founded in London by the British lawyer Peter Berenson in 1961. For over forty years, the work of the organisation has been carried out by individuals who dedicate part of their time to act in favour of other persons. It has more than one million members and subscribers in more than 160 countries and territories. In 1977, AI was awarded the Nobel Peace prize, and in 1978, the UN Human Rights prize. The name of this street, together with those of other thoroughfares in the area, refers to the struggle for peace and human rights.

carrer.name: Amor, Carrer de l'
carrer.descripcio: In June 1908, Jaume Duran i Torelló submitted the urbanization project for the lands around La Clota, the approval of which also meant the approval of the proposed street names. Joan Duran i Pujades, who died 1842, grand-grandfather of the latter, had bought the 3.48 hectares of land of the estate called Casa Mas, formerly known as "Alemany".

carrer.name: Ample, Carrer
carrer.descripcio: One of the main streets of the old town, then full of palaces built by Catalan aristocrat families. Specially mentioned for its width, wide enough to allow horse races.
carrer.anteriors: General Primo de Rivera; Antonio Maura; Mar y Cielo; Ancha, before 1919

carrer.name: Amposta, Carrer d'
carrer.descripcio: Borough of Montsià.

carrer.name: Amsterdam, Carrer d'
carrer.descripcio: Street named after the city located in southern Holland, for having been the organizer of the Olympic Games of 1928.

carrer.name: Amunt, Passeig d'
carrer.descripcio: Refers to the environment. 'D'amunt' means 'above', 'in the' 'high'. It seems that there was already an avenue before the area around the Montaña Pelada (Bare Mountain) was urbanized, called Passeig de Dalt.

carrer.name: Andalet, Passatge d'
carrer.descripcio: Located within the lands owned by Francesc Xinxó Marton until 1923, this street was later named after a house known as "Ca l'Andalet", on the way to Can Grasses. "Andalet" was the tenant farmer Eudald Bernat's nickname.

carrer.name: Andalusia, Passatge d'
carrer.descripcio: Passageway of the same name as the street nearby.

carrer.name: Andalusia, Carrer d'
carrer.descripcio: Autonomic region in the South of Spain, to which Barcelona dedicates this street.

carrer.name: Andana de l'Estació, Carrer de l'
carrer.descripcio: Street around the Clot railroad station, located on km 3 of the railroad from Barcelona to France (interior).

carrer.name: Andorra, Carrer d'
carrer.descripcio: Named after the Catalan territory, constituted as a Principality under the undivided rule of the Bishop of Urgell and the President of France, as established by a medieval agreement. Andorra's first Constitution was approved in 1993, and it is a member of the UNO.

carrer.name: Andrade, Carrer d'
carrer.descripcio: Juan Gil de Andrade. Naval Division Commander. He took part in the Battle of Lepanto, where John of Austria designated him Governor of the Royal Galley, the flagship. On the neighbors' request, in the 1980 nomenclature this dedication was changed in favor of Domingo Antonio de Andrade (Cée 1639 - Santiago de Compostela 1712), Galician architect and sculptor.

carrer.name: Andratx, Carrer d'
carrer.descripcio: Borough of West Majorca. In the Partial Plan for the Porta Neighborhood, many streets were named after Balear villages and towns.

carrer.name: André Malraux, Plaça d'
carrer.descripcio: Square named after André Malraux (Paris 1901 - Créteil 1976), French writer and politician, winner of the Goncourt prize. He participated in the Spanish Civil War. Member of the French Resistance and Minister under De Gaulle.

carrer.name: Andrea Dòria, Carrer d'
carrer.descripcio: Street named after Giovanni Andrea Doria (Genoa 1539 - 1606), second Prince of Melfi, admiral at the service of the Viceroys of Naples and Sicily. He participated in the Battle of Lepanto (1571) under John of Austria as Naval Division Commander. Son of Giovanni Doria (nephew and adoptive son of the Admiral Andrea Doria), who was killed during the Conspiracy of the Fieschi (1547). It is, therefore, not named after the Admiral Andrea Doria (1466 - 1560), who served in the Spanish Fleet in the Mediterranean under Charles V, but after his grand-nephew, as mentioned in the approved street index of that period.

carrer.name: Andreu Febrer, Carrer d'
carrer.descripcio: Andreu Febrer (Vic, Osona 1389 - 1440). Poet at the Court of Alfons V 'el magnànim', the jurist Jaume Callís' nephew. In 1398, he participated in the crusade against Barbaria. In 1418, Alfons 'el magnànim' designated him Sir of the Castle of Ursino in Catania (Sicily). Between 1429 and 1437 he lived in Barcelona.

carrer.name: Andreu Nin, Passeig d'
carrer.descripcio: Andreu Nin i Pérez (El Vendrell, Baix Penedès 1892 - Madrid 1937). Politician, militant of the workers' movement. Writer. This street was dedicated to him "for his merits, and for his intellectual capacity, as demonstrated in his writings and translations from Russian into Catalan, which are considered exemplary, and which have contributed to enrichen Catalonia's cultural patrimony".

carrer.name: Andreví, Passatge d'
carrer.descripcio: Francesc Andreví (Sanaüja, Segarra 1786 - Barcelona 1853). Composer. Choirmaster at Santa Maria del Mar between 1814 and 1819, at the cathedrals of Sogorb, Valencia, Seville, and at the Royal Chapel in Madrid. In France, he was choirmaster at the cathedral of Bordeaux (1836) and in Paris (1845). Back in Barcelona, he became choirmaster of the Mercè church. Before, this passageway had been named after Andreu Martí i Milà, landowner.

carrer.name: Andròmeda, Carrer d'
carrer.descripcio: The constellation, named after a figure out of Greek mythology. The agreement by which this name was approved included two more constellation names, Perseus and Orion.

carrer.name: Anemone, Passatge de l'
carrer.descripcio: Included in a group of streets named after plants and trees.

carrer.name: Aneto, Carrer d'
carrer.descripcio: Glacier and highest peak of the Pyrenees (3,404 meters) and within the former. Also a village of Alta Ribagorza. This street name was approved together with the names of other high mountains, such as Beret, Cadí, Teide, Canfranc, Montmajor, etc. (Turó de la Peira neighborhood).

carrer.name: Àngel, Carrer de l'
carrer.descripcio: Old street within the former village of Gràcia, near the Pere Serafí street, which has a large variety of suggestive street names.

carrer.name: Àngel, Plaça de l'
carrer.descripcio: Square named after the bronze angel standing on top of a marble pyramid, erected in 1618 at the city wall gate, pointing to an image of Saint Eulalia over the arch opening towards the downhill passageway to the prison (now 'baixada de la Llibreteria'), put there in 1456 to remember a miracle occurred at this place when Saint Eulalia's body was transferred from Santa Maria del Mar to the Cathedral in 879.

carrer.name: Àngel, Pas de l'
carrer.descripcio: Passageway named after the main street.

carrer.name: Àngel Guimerà, Carrer d'
carrer.descripcio: Àngel Guimerà i Jorge (Santa Cruz de Tenerife 1845 - Barcelona 1924). Playwright and poet. Already in March 1909, the Town Hall designated him adoptive son of Barcelona.

carrer.name: Àngel J. Baixeras, Carrer d'
carrer.descripcio: Àngel Josep Baixeras (Barcelona 1834 - 1892). In 1878, he submitted a law project to the Senate for an internal reform of the big cities. He also helped to write the Law on Compulsory Purchase of 1879. His Internal Reform Plan for Barcelona was approved in 1881, affecting a great part of the old town of Barcelona.

carrer.name: Àngel Marquès, Carrer d'
carrer.descripcio: Named after Àngel Marquès i Batllevell ( ? - Barcelona, November 20, 1958), a Catholic proselytist writer, as proposed by Frederic Udina Martorell on December 23, 1958, and on request of the Diocesan Parish Charity Exerciseson behalf of the Assembly of presidents of the Perseveration Leagues of Barcelona Diocese.

carrer.name: Àngel Pestaña, Plaça d'
carrer.descripcio: Àngel Pestaña i Núnez (Santo Tomás de las Ollas, Ponferrada 1886 - Barcelona 1937). Anarchist Union leader. Director of 'Solidaridad Obrera' (1918-1919). He traveled to France, Algiers and the USSR (1920). He created the Federació Sindicalista Llibertària in 1933, and edited the newspaper 'Mañana', Catalan organ of the Trade Union Party Federation.

carrer.name: Angeleta Ferrer, Plaça d'
carrer.descripcio: Square named after Angeleta Ferrer i Sensat (Barcelona 1904 - 1992). Ph.D. of Natural Sciences. Daughter of the illustrious pedagogue Rosa Sensat. Professor of Zoography of Vertebrates at the University of Barcelona, teacher at the Balmes Institute, at the Monturiol high school, at the Isabel la Católica Institute in Madrid, at the Institute of Reus, and director of the Infanta Isabel de Aragon high school (1966-1974).

carrer.name: Àngels, Plaça dels
carrer.descripcio: Square named after the Dominic Cloister of "La Vírgen de los Ángeles" (XVI century). The church was consecrated on January 13th, 1566.
carrer.anteriors: Felipe Cortiella (anarchist playwright); Ángeles; Anselmo Lorenzo; Company

carrer.name: Àngels, Carrer dels
carrer.descripcio: Named after the Convent of Nuestra Señora de los Ángeles (XV century), which in 1562 was moved to the square this street runs into.
carrer.anteriors: Ángeles, 1939; Felip Cortiella, 1937; Company, before 1562 (according to Víctor Balaguer)

carrer.name: Àngels, Camí dels
carrer.descripcio: Name given to this passage because it crosses the street named Mare de Déu dels Àngels.

carrer.name: Àngels Garriga, Carrer d'
carrer.descripcio: Àngels Garriga i Martín (Sant Vicenç de Calders, Baix Penedès 1898 - Barcelona 1967). Teacher and writer.

carrer.name: Anglesola, Carrer d'
carrer.descripcio: Old Catalan nobility, especially Ramon de Anglesola, Marquis of Bellpuig and Viscount of Vilamur (Ramon II of Vilamur). Old road opened in 1856 to connect Les Corts with the new avenue to Sarrià.

carrer.name: Anglí, Carrer d'
carrer.descripcio: Street planned to run partly through the estate called Mas Anglí, near the place known as "Fuente de n'Anglí" (Angli's Fountain), which belonged to Francesc Anglí Brichfeus, married with Maria Monnar, in the XVIII century. His son and heir, Francesc Anglí i Monnar, was one of the last owners of this estate, before it became the propriety of Joan Margenat i Salvany in the XIX century.
carrer.anteriors: Sant Lluís (above Bonanova avenue); Galvany (below Bonanova avenue)

carrer.name: Ànimes, Carreró de les
carrer.descripcio: There used to be here in the past an animal cemetery, so will-o'-the wisps could be seen during summer nights, which the population thought to be lost souls.

carrer.name: Anisadeta, Carrer de l'
carrer.descripcio: This street name is derived from the table that used to be in this place at ancient times, offering anisette and fresh water to the port workers to make the 'anisadeta' (a refreshing drink obtained mixing anisette with cold water).

carrer.name: Anna Frank, Plaça d'
carrer.descripcio: Square named after Anna Frank (Frankfurt, 1929 - Bergen-Belsen Concentration Camp, 1945), the Jewish girl who emigrated to Holland with her family in 1933, where she wrote her 'Diary' from 1942 to 1944, telling what happened to her and her family as they were hiding and trying to escape from Hitler's police. This 'Diary', an ingenuous, emotive testimony of a time of terror, had a big, worldwide success when put on stage by Frances Goodrich and Albert Hackett.

carrer.name: Anna M. Martínez Segi, Carrer d'
Anna Piferrer, Carrer d'
carrer.descripcio: Anna Maria Piferrer i Gualba inherited the lands around this street, which belonged to the estate called Manso Besora, from her mother, Rosa Gualba i Spigol, married to Joan Piferrer i Soler, who had inherited them from her father, Josep Gualba i Modollel. Anna Maria gave part of the lands away with the intention of enlarging the old road to Horta, from the beginning of the Rabassada road up to past the Orphanage Ribes.
carrer.anteriors: Tres Reyes; Anna Piferrer, 13/01/1933; Tres Reyes

carrer.name: Anna Rúbies, Passeig d'
carrer.descripcio: Promenade named after Anna Rúbies i Monjonell (El Port de la Selva, Alt Empordà 1881 - Barcelona 1963). Pedagogue. She had been Director of the Ramon Llull Group, and of Barcelona's Town Council School Patronage, and introduced the Decroly method in the Catalan Countries. Former member of the Generalitat's Culture Council, she took part in summer schools and in all manifestations contributing to pedagogical renewal.

carrer.name: Anníbal, Carrer d'
carrer.descripcio: Named after Hannibal (247 - Bitinia 183 b.Ch.), Carthaginian military, general and statesman. Son of Amilcar Barca, brother-in-law and successor of Hasdrubal. His army, with the help of people from the Catalan territory, defeated the Romans in the Battle of the Trasimenian Lake (217 b.Ch.) and at Cannes (216 b.Ch.). He reached Rome, but was unable to conquer it. Finally, he was defeated at Zama (202 b.Ch.).

carrer.name: Anoia, Carrer de l'
carrer.descripcio: Named after the right side tributary (the headwaters of which are called Riera d'Anoia) of the Llobregat river, which it comes to join at Martorell, after its course through the region it gives the name.

carrer.name: Anselm Turmeda, Carrer d'
carrer.descripcio: Street named after Anselm Turmeda (Majorca, 1352/55 - Tunis, 1423), Franciscan writer who abjured Catholicism to embrace the Mohammedan religion. As Fra Anselm, he wrote 'Llibre de bons amonestaments'. His books enjoyed a wide acceptance among Catalan-speaking countries.

carrer.name: Antàrtic, Carrer de l'
carrer.descripcio: Refers to the Antarctic Ocean. It is part of a group of streets around the Port of Barcelona, which are named after seas and oceans.

carrer.name: Antaviana, Passatge d'
carrer.descripcio: Antaviana is a word coined by one of the characters in a tale by the Catalonian writer Pere Calders. It was the name of an adaptation of that tale for the theatre by the Dagoll Dagom group in 1978.

carrer.name: Antequera, Carrer d'
carrer.descripcio: Andalusian town, conquered in 1410 by the Infante Ferran, later King Ferran I of Catalonia and Aragon, the first king of Castilian descent to take the crown of Aragon.

carrer.name: Antic de Bofarull, Carrer
carrer.descripcio: Antoni de Bofarull i de Brocà (Reus, Baix Camp 1821 - Barcelona 1892). Historian, poet, novelist and playwright.

carrer.name: Antic de Sant Joan, Carrer
carrer.descripcio: At the end of the XVIII century, the Town Hall, according to the permit given already by King Charles IV, authorized the Military Governor to build a few houses over the Comtal irrigation channel, between the salt mill and the fish market. These small houses were built at the beginning of the XIX century, filling during eighty years almost completely one side of the Sant Joan promenade, which had been created in 1796 by the Duke of Lancaster, Military Governor of Catalonia, and was used by the inhabitants of Barcelona as a recreation place until the present park was opened.

carrer.name: Antic de Sant Llàtzer, Camí
carrer.descripcio: Road between the Vall d'Hebron avenue and the Alta de les Roquetes road, in the Horta-Guinardó district.
carrer.anteriors: Antic de València, passatge; Antic de València, camí, 12/06/1980; Antiguo de València,

carrer.name: Antic de València, Camí
carrer.descripcio: Primitive road leading towards the ancient kingdom of Valencia.

carrer.name: Antic del Guinardó, Carrer
carrer.descripcio: The first street opened when the Mas Guinardó estate was urbanized.

carrer.name: antiga de Mataró, Carretera
carrer.descripcio: Old road leading to the borough of this name.

carrer.name: Antiga de Montjuïc, Carretera
carrer.descripcio: Old pathway that links the road leading to Montjuïc castle with the path to the Font Trobada.

carrer.name: Antiga d'Horta, Carretera
carrer.descripcio: Initial fragment of the road to Horta, near the northern city wall exit. The rest of the road disappeared when the Eixample Cerdà (new-built area to fill the free space between old Barcelona and Cerdà) was urbanized, and its course was only recovered when the present Freser street and Maragall avenue were built.

carrer.name: antiga d'Horta a Cerdanyola, Carretera
carrer.descripcio: This was the old Horta route.

carrer.name: Antilles, Carrer de les
carrer.descripcio: Important American archipelago between the Caribbean Sea and the Atlantic Ocean.

carrer.name: Antoni Alberdi, Carrer d'
carrer.descripcio: Antoni Alberdi Aguirrezabal (Durango, 21 de October de 1893 - Bilbao, November 5, 1986). Composer and organist. Son of Lope Alberdi. Disciple of the Barcelona's Municipal School of Music.

carrer.name: Antoni Costa, Carrer d'
carrer.descripcio: Street named after Antoni Costa (Sant Llorenç de Cerdans, Vallespir 1767 - Fredericia, Denmark, 1808). Military. At the outbreak of the French Revolution in 1789, he came to Barcelona, where he created a battalion of voluntaries. In 1794, he adopted the Spanish nationality, and was designated Commander of the Legion of Queen Maria Luisa. Later he fought in America against the English. Back in Europe, he went to Pomerania with the Spanish troops of the Marquis of la Romana. After having been defeated at Fredericia, he committed suicide.
carrer.anteriors: Antonio Costa; Lletra J (Santa Eulàlia avenue)

carrer.name: Antoni de Capmany, Carrer d'
carrer.descripcio: Antoni de Capmany de Montpalau i de Surís (Barcelona 1742 - Cádiz 1813). Historian, philologue and politician. Author of the 'Memòries de la indústria i' 'comerç de Barcelona al segle XVIII'. Deputy of the Parliament of Cadiz.

carrer.name: Antoni Gassol, Passatge d'
carrer.descripcio: The name of a landowner. It is located in the estate Manso Serra. The land where the passageway is situated was bought by Antoni Gassol i Civit and Vicenç Montal i Comellas in 1918.

carrer.name: Antoni Genescà i Corominas, Plaça d'
carrer.descripcio: Square named after Antoni Genescà i Corominas (Ripoll, Ripollès 1849 - Sabadell, Vallès Occidental 1927). Naval Engineer Number 1 of Spain, chief in charge of all works for the Spanish Navy at the company Maquinista Terrestre y Marítima, S.A. His most important works were the erection of the floating dock and of the western dock, as well as the portal cranes at the Barceloneta and Muralla dock. He was awarded with the Gold Medal for Work. Son of Llorenç Genescà i Rovira, first Catalan engine driver, who, instructed by English engine drivers, drove the first train from Barcelona to Mataró in 1848.

carrer.name: Antoni Gilabert i Bonet, Carrer d'
carrer.descripcio: (Cartagena 1920 - Barcelona 1985). Leader of the neighbors of the Verdum neighborhood. He arrived at Barcelona in the forties, and was militant of the Movimiento Católico Obrero (Catholic Workers Movement), and of the PSUC (Socialist Party of Catalonia). 1975 he entered the Verdum Neighbors Association. He was well-known and appreciated as a tireless fighter for the people's rights.

carrer.name: Antoni Maura, Plaça d'
carrer.descripcio: Square named after Antoni Maura i Montaner (Majorca, 1853 - Torrelodones, Madrid, 1925). Politician. Bachelor of Law in Madrid (1881), elected liberal deputy for Majorca. President of the 'Congreso de Diputados' (Parliament) (1886) and President of the Jury Commission (1887). Minister of Overseas Affairs between December, 1892 and March, 1894. He organized the visit of King Alfonso XIII to Barcelona and Majorca. In 1923, he condemned Primo de Rivera's Dictatorship, declaring himself in favor of a constitutional reform.

carrer.name: Antoni Pérez i Moya, Plaça d'
carrer.descripcio: Square named after Antoni Pérez i Moya (Valencia, Horta, 1884 - Barcelona 1964). Composer, organist, choir director. Author of many sardanas. In 1904, he was director of the 'Schola Cantorum de Sant Miquel Arcàngel'. He also directed a choir of prisoners at Barcelona's prison Model (1915-1925). Director of the Sants Choral Society (1925-1936) and of the Santa Llúcia Choral Society (1943-1955).

carrer.name: Antoni Puigvert, Jardins d'
carrer.descripcio: Gardens named after Antoni Puigvert i Gorro (Santa Coloma de Gramenet, Barcelonès 1905 - Barcelona 1990). Urologist. Director of the Urologic Station, and of the Urological Specialty School at Saint Paul Hospital. Lecturer of Urology at Barcelona's Universitat Autònoma. Among others, he published the works 'Atlas' 'de Urología' and 'Endoscòpia urinària'.

carrer.name: Antonio López, Plaça d'
carrer.descripcio: Square named after Antonio López y López de Lamadrid, Marquis of Comillas (Comillas, Cantabria 1817 - Barcelona 1883). Merchant, ship owner and banker.
carrer.anteriors: Capitán Biardeau, 06/09/1937; Antonio López, 22/05/1883; San Sebastián, before 1865; Fuente del Ángel; Vino, century XVI; Dressenal, before the XV century

carrer.name: Antonio Machado, Carrer d'
carrer.descripcio: Antonio Machado Ruíz (Seville, 1875 - Cotlliure, Roussillon, France, 1939). Poet. Republican, during the Spanish Civil War he took refuge in Valencia and Barcelona. In January, 1939, he exiled in France. As a follower of what he used to call "eternal poetry", he pleaded for a more intuitive than intellectual line in poetry.

carrer.name: Antonio Ricardos, Carrer d'
carrer.descripcio: Antonio Ramón Ricardos y Carrillo de Albornoz (Barbastro, Huesca, 1727 - Madrid, 1794). Military Governor of Catalonia in 1793, initially he commanded the forces which fought against France in the War of the first coalition, successfully invading the Vallespir, and penetrating up to the Conflent. The lack of vision of King Charles IV government, which missed to give impulse to the campaign by restituting the Roussillon and Sardinia, considerably reduced the possibilities of success, in spite of courage of the Catalans who participated in the war.

carrer.name: Anvers, Carrer d'
carrer.descripcio: Named after Antwerp, a town in Flanders (Belgium), capital of the Antwerp province, who organized the Olympic Summer Games in 1920.

carrer.name: Apel·les Fenosa, Carrer d'
carrer.descripcio: Apel·les Fenosa i Florensa (Barcelona, 1899 - Paris, 1988). Sculptor. Exhibitions in the most important cities of the world. Awarded with the Gold Medal of Catalonia (1982) and the French Legion of Honor (1983).

carrer.name: Apel·les Mestres, Carrer d'
carrer.descripcio: Apel·les Mestres i Oñós (Barcelona, 1854 - 1936). Sketcher, musician, poet, playwright (comedies) and writer.

carrer.name: Aragó, Carrer d'
carrer.descripcio: Named after Aragon, a region in northern Spain, ancient kingdom confederated with Catalonia. This street is included among the street names proposed by Víctor Balaguer, on request of the Town Hall.

carrer.name: Aragó, Passatge d'
carrer.descripcio: Passageway running into the street with the same name.

carrer.name: Arai, Carrer de n'
carrer.descripcio: Last name of family from Barcelona, probably related with the street when it was opened. It is known that this street had the same name already as far back as 1523. There is notice of a marriage of Johan Aray, wool weaver, with Eulàlia Soler, in the parish of Santa Maria, on May 25, 1528. Inside Santa Maria del Pi church, there is a glass with the name of Pere Aray, candlestickmaker, and his kin, dating from 1728.

carrer.name: Aral, Passatge d'
carrer.descripcio: Passageway in Barcelona's Port Area, named after the Aral Sea, situated between Kazakhstan and Uzbekistan.

carrer.name: Arbeca, Carrer d'
carrer.descripcio: Borough of Les Garrigues. The street is in the Milans del Bosch housing estate, in the Bon Pastor neighborhood, where many streets are named after Catalan villages.

carrer.name: Arboreda, Jardins de l'
carrer.descripcio: Public gardens located between the streets of Alts Forns, Mecànica, and Energia, within the Sants-Montjuïc district.

carrer.name: Arbós, Carrer d'
carrer.descripcio: Jaume Arbós i Tor (Sant Hipòlit de Voltregà, Osona, 1824 - Barcelona, 1882). Chemist. Inventor of the Arbós gas. He patented the first aspiration gas generator, and installed a gas factory at Mataró.

carrer.name: Arbúcies, Carrer d'
carrer.descripcio: Borough of the Selva.
carrer.anteriors: Cid (joined to Arbúcies); 11/03/1915; Arbúcias Norte, before 1900

carrer.name: Arc de Sant Agustí, Carrer de l'
carrer.descripcio: Street named after an arch at the street entrance, now demolished, that had belonged to the convent inhabited by Augustinian monks from 1750 to 1835.
carrer.anteriors: San Agustín, before 1865; Arco de San Agustín; Nou de Sant Agustí, 1750

carrer.name: Arc de Sant Cristòfol, Carrer de l'
carrer.descripcio: Named after a small chapel dedicated to Saint Christopher, that had been in this street. This chapel had been erected because after the pest in the XVI century, the population of Barcelona believed that the presence of an image of Saint Christopher would help them to have a good death.
carrer.anteriors: Arco de San Cristóbal; Graciamar; Muntarol (o Monterols?); Nou

carrer.name: Arc de Sant Martí, Passatge de l'
carrer.descripcio: Passageway so named because it runs into the street of the same name.

carrer.name: Arc de Sant Martí, Carrer de l'
carrer.descripcio: Street named after the first newspaper written in Catalan language ever published in the neighborhood.
carrer.anteriors: Arco Iris, 07/07/1942; Casualidad, 04/02/1931; Arco de San Martín, before 1921; Arch de Sant Martí, 1927

carrer.name: Arc de Sant Onofre, Carrer de l'
carrer.descripcio: Named after a small chapel dedicated to Saint Onuphrius.

carrer.name: Arc de Sant Pau, Carrer de l'
carrer.descripcio: Street with an arch, next to the Sant Pau del Camp. Originally, it was the path that leads to the kitchen garden of the monastery.
carrer.anteriors: Arco de San Pablo; Arco del Moro, before 1828

carrer.name: Arc de Sant Ramon del Call, Carrer de l'
carrer.descripcio: Street dedicated to Saint Raymond of Peñafort, from Barcelona, who had been the confessor of King Jaume I, and was canonized at the beginning of the XVII century. Dominican monks came to this street in 1222, and this was the residence of the future Saint Raymond.
carrer.anteriors: Arco de San Ramón del Call

carrer.name: Arc de Sant Sever, Carrer de l'
carrer.descripcio: Named after a hermitage dedicated to Saint Severin which had formerly been in this street.

carrer.name: Arc de Sant Silvestre, Carrer de l'
carrer.descripcio: Named after a small chapel dedicated to Saint Sylvester, which had been on this street until the end of the XIX century, and an arch at the street entrance, demolished around 1850. The street dates back to the XIII century, when the plain known as "de la Palma de Santa Caterina", near the Cloister of Saint Catherina, started to get filled with farms. In the same street also settled several guilds: druggists, passementerists, and galooners.

carrer.name: Arc de Sant Vicenç, Carrer de l'
carrer.descripcio: Name given to this street in memory of Saint Vincent Ferrer, canonized in 1456, who made a famous speech in the Born when living in Barcelona, achieving to comfort the citizens who lacked bread due to the shortage of wheat. As this street is not far from the place where this speech took place, it seems probable that the name was given as a sign of gratitude and veneration.

carrer.name: Arc de Santa Eulàlia, Carrer de l'
carrer.descripcio: Named after the Arch of Saint Eulalia, formerly "de la Volta", for the vault at the street entrance. According to an old legend, here was the prison where the saint woman had been confined.
carrer.anteriors: Arco de Santa Eulalia; Vuelta de Santa Eulalia, 1839

carrer.name: Arc del Mercat, Carrer de l'
carrer.descripcio: Leads to the Mercadal square.

carrer.name: Arc del Teatre, Carrer de l'
carrer.descripcio: In 1597, at the Holy Cross Hospital (Hospital de la Santa Creu), the 'Casa de Comèdies' (House of Comedies) was built in a back garden called "d'en Trenta Claus". A fire destroyed the building in 1787, but already the next year, the theater opened its doors again under the name of Santa Cruz, which later was changed to 'Principal'. In 1915, the historic theater burned down completely, and after being rebuilt, was called Principal Palace. In-built in the theater façade is the arch that serves as the entrance to this street.
carrer.anteriors: Arco del Teatro; Trenta Claus, before 1839; Gaspar

carrer.name: Arcs, Carrer dels
carrer.descripcio: The name of a place called "els Arcs" (the Arches) appears already in writings from 987, where it is referred to as Antique Arches in the suburbs of Barcelona. There is a possible relation with the arches of the aqueduct penetrating the Roman city wall next to this street.
carrer.anteriors: Archs; Cellers; Forn dels Archs, before 1348; Paso del Puente de la Moranta

carrer.name: Ardena, Carrer d'
carrer.descripcio: In the middle of the XVII century, Josep de Ardena, Count of Darnius, Military Governor of Catalonia, inherited some lands around this place. The last owner belonging to this family was Joan Baptista Martorell i de Fivaller, Count of Darnius, Duke of Almenara Alta.

carrer.name: Ardèvol, Carrer d'
carrer.descripcio: Village of Solsonès. Here the Carlist generals Benet and Rafael Tristany were born. The street is in the Milans del Bosch housing estate, where all streets are named after Catalan villages.

carrer.name: Arenes de Sant Pere, Carrer de les
carrer.descripcio: The name of this street, opened before the XV century, comes from the riverside sands on which it sits. Due to the water, later it became necessary to build a first sewer in the neighborhood, in the street named "carrer de la Claveguera".

carrer.name: Arenes dels Canvis, Carrer de les
carrer.descripcio: The foundations of the houses built on this street were laid in sands, near the street named Canvis Vells after the money changers that had their tables on this street.

carrer.name: Arenys, Passatge d'
carrer.descripcio: Passageway so named for running into the end of the street of the same name.

carrer.name: Arenys, Carrer d'
carrer.descripcio: Street named after Arenys de Mar and Arenys de Munt, boroughs of Maresme. Here Joaquim Taxonera was born, owner of the land where the street was opened.

carrer.name: Argensola, Carrer dels
carrer.descripcio: Bartomolé Leonardo de Argensola (Barbastro, 1562 - Zaragoza, 1631) and Lupercio Leonardo de Argensola (Barbastro, 1559 - Naples 1613). Writers.

carrer.name: Argenter, Carrer de l'
carrer.descripcio: Street dating back to the XIV century. Probably named after an owner established in this street as a silversmith.

carrer.name: Argentera, Carrer de l'
carrer.descripcio: Borough of Baix Camp. In memory of a railroad tunnel, at that time the longest of Spain, on the line Madrid-Barcelona.

carrer.name: Argenteria, Carrer de l'
carrer.descripcio: This street runs along the old road towards the sea, that began at the Portal Mayor (Main Gate) and ended at the beach. In 998, there already were buildings at both sides of the street, and even an own church, Santa Maria del Mar. This street had the greatest concentration of silversmiths, and its name was already the same as nowadays in 1423.
carrer.anteriors: Plateria; Argenteria; Santa Maria; Passamaners; Santa Maria; Mar; Arenas; Mar, XII-XIV centuries; Via del Mar, XI century

carrer.name: Argentinita, Passeig de l'
carrer.descripcio: Encarnación López Julves (Buenos Aires, 1905 - 1945). was the best dancer of her times. Together with her sister Pilar and other excellent dancers she created the 'Ballet Español', a show that was played all over the world. At her death, she was awarded with the Order of Alfonso X the Wise by the Spanish Government.

carrer.name: Argentona, Carrer d'
carrer.descripcio: Borough of Maresme. In memory of the fact that in 1480, this city made a petition to be integrated into Barcelona through a procedure known as 'carreratge', by which the borough is considered as a street of Barcelona. According to the terms of the petition, the inhabitants of the borough enjoyed the same rights and privileges as the inhabitants of the city.

carrer.name: Argimon, Carrer d'
