carrer.descripcio: Sanctuary of the Virgin of Argimon, belonging to the parish of Esparra, township of Riudarenes (La Selva). Ancient Argimon castle. The place where this street is was known as "Viña de Casa Don Joan", owned by Gaietà d'Amat, Marquis of Castellbell.

carrer.name: Argullós, Passatge d'
carrer.descripcio: Passageway so called because it runs into the street of the same name.

carrer.name: Argullós, Carrer d'
carrer.descripcio: Alexandre Argullós i Galiano was proxy of Teresa and Ramon Coberó Bernadas, owners together with Casals, Jaume Pinent, etc., of the lands where the streets, named after them, were built. This street is in a place called "pla de Fornells", former road to Casa Dragó.

carrer.name: Aribau, Carrer d'
carrer.descripcio: Bonaventura Carles Aribau i Farriols (Barcelona, 1798 - 1862). Writer, economist, stenographer, and politician.
carrer.anteriors: Aribau (2n, 3r, i 4r tram), 18/12/1928 Lanuza (4t tram), 05/09/1907, Bellini (2n tram), 05/09/1907, Prim (3r tram), abans 1900, Carmen (2n tram), abans 1883, Bosch (4r tram), 27/09/1876, Núm. 24 (Pla Cerdà)

carrer.name: Arimon, Carrer d'
carrer.descripcio: Located near the Torre de Arimon (Arimon Tower), formerly "de mossèn Gibert". Part of the street runs through the former property of Nicolau Sivilla i Girbau, first married with Josepa Arimon, and then with Isabel Raspall, widow of Josep Arimon, son of Genís the hatter. Nicolau Sivilla was the stepfather and uncle of Josep Antoni Arimon i Raspall. Nicolau Sivilla died in 1799. When new street projects were started at the beginning of the XIX century, Josep Antoni Arimon dedicated one street to his father, Josep Arimon, and another one to his stepfather, Nicolau Sivilla. Many years later, Genís Josep Arimon i Andarió became the owner by means of a legal acquisition title according to a sentence by the Territorial Court of March 17, 1843.

carrer.name: Ariosto, Carrer d'
carrer.descripcio: Filippo Ariosto, painter. In 1587-1588 he made several portraits of the Counts of Barcelona and Kings of Aragon to decorate the council hall of the General County Council. The most of the collection is in the Military Museum of Barcelona.

carrer.name: Arístides Maillol, Carrer d'
carrer.descripcio: Aristide Bonaventure Jean Maillol Rougé (Banyuls de la Marenda, Roussillon 1861 - 1944). Sculptor and painter. He learned painting at the École des Beaux-Arts de Paris (1885-1886). At Banyuls he opened a tapestry workshop. He worked as a ceramist and sculptor. In 1904, he opened a workshop at Marley-le-Roy. A selection of his work was made in bronze to be exhibited in the gardens of the Tuilleries in Paris.

carrer.name: Aritjols, Carrer dels
carrer.descripcio: A lilac plant between snow blossoms and new pinewood, to cheer up the street names of this neighborhood with a bit of botany.

carrer.name: Arizala, Carrer d'
carrer.descripcio: Named after Maria del Pilar Martínez de Arizala i de Sabater (Villafranca, Navarra, 1833 - Barcelona, 1891), owner of the surrounding lands at Sants. The street is partly situated within the estate called Can Mangala and properties of the Sentmenat family.

carrer.name: Arlet, Carrer d'
carrer.descripcio: Catalan family that had given several celebrities to the nation: Francesc d'Arlet was Counselor of Barcelona in 1252, and Arnau de Arlet in 1262.

carrer.name: Armada, Plaça de l'
carrer.descripcio: Square so named in honor of the Navy.

carrer.name: Armengol, Carrer d'
carrer.descripcio: Refers to Armengol or Ermengol, first-born sun of Sunyer I, third Count of Barcelona, who gave him the territory of Osona County and made him a Count, feudatory under the Count of Barcelona. He died in the battle field, probably assassinated, around 940-942.

carrer.name: Arnau, Carrer d'
carrer.descripcio: Arnau Vidal, rich man from Sant Andreu in the XI century, who donated the lands around the place called Vilapicina together with the Santa Eulalia church there established to the See of Barcelona when his son Pere entered there as a canon around 1054. The lands where this street is belonged to the estate of Manso Costa, at a place called "la Claveguera" and later "la Quintana".

carrer.name: Arnau Bargués, Carrer d'
carrer.descripcio: (? - Barcelona 1413). Master builder. Grand Master of the Cathedral (1397). Grand Master of the City (1399), author of the old main façade of the Town Hall on Ciutat street (1412).

carrer.name: Arnau d'Oms, Carrer d'
carrer.descripcio: Of the Oms branch, Barons or Valvassors of Montescot. The most important members of this family were Arnau de Oms, Prior of Messina and Catalonia, Knight Commander of the Order of Saint John, who died around 1332; Arnau de Oms, knight of the XIV and XV century, who participated in the sessions of the Catalan Parliament in the Interregnum of 1410-1412, as a member of the knighthood, which then existed besides the military class. In the XVIII century, the land where this street is was the property of Gaietà Amar de Rocabertí, Marquis of Castellbell. Arnau de Oms was not an ascendant of the Sentmenat-Oms branch, owners of the land limiting with the estate of the Marquis of Castellbell. Part of the street is on grounds that belonged to the estate Torre Can Sitjà, formerly Mas Riera, and to Maria Solà, in the XIX century.
carrer.anteriors: Arnaldo de Oms; Ramon Albó (second section)

carrer.name: Arnes, Carrer d'
carrer.descripcio: Borough of Terra Alta. The street is in the housing group Eduard Aunós, where streets are named after Catalan boroughs.

carrer.name: Arnold Schönberg, Carrer d'
carrer.descripcio: (Vienna, 1874 - Los Angeles, 1951). One of the most important composers in the history of music. He wrote very important didactical compositions, which decisively influenced the music of the XX century.

carrer.name: Arnús i de Garí, Carrer d'
carrer.descripcio: Named after the two founders of the Bank Arnús-Garí. Manuel Arnús i Fortuny (Barcelona, 1852 - 1916) and Josep Garí i Cañas (Mataró, Maresme, 1854 - Barcelona, 1925).

carrer.name: Aroles, Carrer de n'
carrer.descripcio: Important family, already known in the XV century. There is notice of Ramon Aroles, master builder (1451); Bartomeu Aroles, owner of a house in the Rauric street (1562); Francesc Aroles, Counselor in 1579, and micer Joan Aroles, elected by the Council of the Hundred (Consell de Cent), Royal Deputy (1612), and later Chief councilor (1616).
carrer.anteriors: Palau, century XV; Mayans; Spereneu (according to Víctor Balaguer)

carrer.name: Arquímedes, Carrer d'
carrer.descripcio: Named after Archimedes (Syracuse, 287 - 212 b.Ch.). Mathematician and physician of Magna Grecia. He defended his native town by means of devices of his invention when the Romans laid siege on it. Finally, the Roman invaders killed him in 212 b.Ch.

carrer.name: Arquitecte Martorell, Carrer de l'
carrer.descripcio: Joan Martorell i Montells (Barcelona 1833 - 1906). Master builder and architect, one of the first graduates (1876) of the School of Barcelona. His most important works are: Cloister of the Adoration nuns, Cloister of the Salesian nuns, monument in memory of Joan Güell, Sociedad de Crédito Mercantil in Ample street, school of the Jesuits at Sarrià.

carrer.name: Arquitecte Mas, Carrer de l'
carrer.descripcio: Josep Masía i Dordal (? - Barcelona 1808). Master builder. Architect of the guild of master builders, stonecutters, and crushers of Barcelona. Since 1758 he was the city builder for houses and fountains. He built the façade of the Mercè church, the Moja Palace on the Rambla, the present church of Sant Vicenç de Sarrià, and the Episcopal Palace of Barcelona.

carrer.name: Arquitecte Millàs, Passatge de l'
carrer.descripcio: José Carlos Millàs (Habana 1889 - ?). Cuban engineer and architect. Astronomer, director of the National Observatory of Cuba.

carrer.name: Arquitecte Moragas, Carrer de l'
carrer.descripcio: Antoni de Moragas i Gallissà (Barcelona 1913 - 1985). He graduated in 1941, renewing the Catalan architecture in the period after the Spanish Civil War. Founding member of Grup R. Doyen of the Association of Architects of Catalonia and the Balearic Islands (1964-1966 and 1972-1974). Founder and President of ADI-FAD. In 1982 he was elected member of the Catalan Sant Jordi Royal Academy of Fine Arts.

carrer.name: Arquitecte Sert, Carrer de l'
carrer.descripcio: Josep Lluís Sert i López (Barcelona 1902 - 1983). After graduating as an architect in Barcelona in 1928, he worked with Le Corbusier in Paris. Co-founder of GATCPAC. He was the main agglutinator of the rationalist movement in Catalonia. At the end of the war he went to the USA. Since 1953, he was the director of the Harvard School of Architecture as Gropius' successor.

carrer.name: Arquitectura, Carrer de l'
carrer.descripcio: Homage to one of the Fine Arts.

carrer.name: Arriassa, Passatge d'
carrer.descripcio: Passageway so named, because it crosses the Camp Arriassa street.

carrer.name: Art, Carrer de l'
carrer.descripcio: Homage to Fine Arts altogether.

carrer.name: Artà, Carrer d'
carrer.descripcio: Borough of East Majorca. The urbanization project for the Porta neighborhood included many streets named after villages and towns of the Balearic Islands.

carrer.name: Artemis, Passatge d'
carrer.descripcio: Passageway named after the Greek goddess Artemis, Apollo's sister. This chasing goddess is always depicted with an arc and a golden arrow, symbol of virginal beauty.

carrer.name: Artés, Carrer d'
carrer.descripcio: Borough of Bages. Non-official street near the Sant Joan mountain, in the North of town.

carrer.name: Artesa de Segre, Carrer d'
carrer.descripcio: Borough of Noguera.

carrer.name: Artesania, Carrer de l'
carrer.descripcio: Street going up-hills from the Llucmajor square delimiting the Verdum and Roquetes neighborhood in the West. Homage paid to artisan, handmade work.

carrer.name: Àrtic, Carrer de l'
carrer.descripcio: Named after the Artic Ocean. Integrated in the group of streets named after seas and oceans near the Port of Barcelona.

carrer.name: Artós, Plaça d'
carrer.descripcio: Delfí Artós i Mornau ( ? - Barcelona, 1903), jurist and philanthropist, was the man who urbanized this square in 1859 on the place where the Torre Artós was.

carrer.name: Artur Martorell, Plaça d'
carrer.descripcio: Square named after Artur Martorell i Bisbal (Barcelona, 1894 - 1967). Pedagogue. Director of the Schools belonging to the Domènec de Gràcia Organization, teacher at CADCI Schools. Technical Counselor of the Town Hall. Professor of 'l'Escola Normal' of the Generalitat. Director of the Municipal Institute for Education.

carrer.name: Ascó, Carrer d'
carrer.descripcio: Borough of Ribera d'Ebre. The street is in the estate Eduard Aunós, in the Zona Franca neighborhood, where streets are named after Catalan villages.

carrer.name: Ases, Carrer dels
carrer.descripcio: It seems that there had been a place in this street where the muleteers used to hire donkeys.

carrer.name: Assaonadors, Carrer dels
carrer.descripcio: This street and its name date back to before 1447. Here the fur or leather menders were established, whose guild already existed before 1257, lasting until shortly after 1836. They had a deputy in the Town Council created by King Jaume I.

carrer.name: Assemblea de Catalunya, Plaça de l'
carrer.descripcio: Square named in honor of the Congress of Catalonia, constituted on November 7, 1971, as a nationalist movement.

carrer.name: Astúries, Carrer d'
carrer.descripcio: Region of northern Spain. Kingdom created by Christians united around King Pelayo (Pelagius) of Asturias (719-725), who beated the Moors at Covadonga, thus alerting the neighboring Christian countries to unite and start the re-conquest. This street, together with others in this area, was built between 1827 and 1830, on request of the landowner Ágata Badia i Puigrodon de Trilla.
carrer.anteriors: Maragda (annexed to Asturias); San Antonio (a section), 1830; Esmeralda (a section), 20/09/1922

carrer.name: Ataülf, Carrer d'
carrer.descripcio: Athaulf ( ? - Barcelona, 415), King of Visigoths. He reached command over the Visigoths when he was still young, at the death of their leader Alaric in Italy, transforming Barcelona into the Court and Capital of his States.
carrer.anteriors: Ataulfo; Volta d'en Santcliment; Viladalls, before 1367; Bajada de los Leones (between Gignàs and Tomil)

carrer.name: Atenes, Carrer d'
carrer.descripcio: Named after Athens, Capital of Greece and of the Attica 'nomos'. Dukedom conquered in 1311 by almogavers of the Great Company, who occupied the city during seventy three years. The Catalan domination in Greece, initiated in the Dukedom of Athens in 1311, ended at Piada in 1460, lasting one and a half century. In 1896, Athens was the seat of the first Olympic Games of Modern Age.
carrer.anteriors: Atenas; Alfonso XII (2nd section), after 1879; Bèlgica (2nd section), 1931

carrer.name: Atlanta, Jardins d'
carrer.descripcio: Gardens named after Atlanta, the Capital of Georgia, in the USA. The Olympic Games of 1996 were celebrated there.

carrer.name: Atlàntic, Carrer de l'
carrer.descripcio: Refers to the Atlantic Ocean. Included in the group of streets named after seas and oceans near the Port of Barcelona.
carrer.anteriors: Lletra Y (from Zona Franca, a section)

carrer.name: Atlàntida, Carrer de l'
carrer.descripcio: Named after the epic poem written by 'mosén' Jacinto Verdaguer, winner of the Floral Games of 1877.

carrer.name: Àtom, Passatge de l'
carrer.descripcio: Refers to the atom, the smallest part of a chemical element. Passageway in the Rectoret neighborhood. This passageway was given this name by the urbanizers, and the name was later officially confirmed.

carrer.name: Auger, Carrer d'
carrer.descripcio: Sebastià Auger i Massanet (Barcelona 1879 - 1957). Real estate broker. In 1919, he associated with Gustau Jubany i Bergnes, founding the company Auger i Jubany, which promoted the urbanization of the area. Among the streets so opened, one was named after Auger and another one after Jubany.

carrer.name: August Font, Carrer d'
carrer.descripcio: August Font i Carreras (Barcelona 1845 - 1924). Architect, among others, of the Caixa d'Estalvis, of the Cathedral façade together with Oriol Mestres, of the Palau de Belles Arts (Palace of Fine Arts) at the Universal Exposition of 1888, and of the dome of the Cathedral.
carrer.anteriors: Ptge. d'August Font; Arquitecto Augusto Font, 03/05/1949

carrer.name: Augusta, Via
carrer.descripcio: Part of the name Barcino received when it achieved Roman citizenship. Around 215, the hamlet at the Táber so received the pompous name of 'Civitas Iulia Augusta' 'Paterna Faventia Barcino'.
carrer.anteriors: Augusta, 06/12/1931; Carril (in the whole), before 1877; Carril (in the district of Gràcia); Av. de Sarrià (in Gràcia), before 1889; FC de Sarrià, before 1900

carrer.name: Augusto César Sandino, Carrer d'
carrer.descripcio: Named after the Nicaraguan patriot (Niquinihomo, 1893 - Managua, 1934). Leader of the nationalist guerrillas that started fighting against the US domination in 1927. When the US Marines left the country, he came to an agreement with the Government and laid down arms (1933). He was assassinated on orders of the then Chief of the National Guard, Anastasio Somoza. Around 1961, the popular Sandinist movement became the Frente Sandinista de Liberación Nacional (Sandinist Front for National Liberation), using the guerrilla war against the Dictatorship. Finally, the Sandinist Front won in 1979, and the Dictator Somoza was removed.

carrer.name: Aulèstia i Pijoan, Carrer d'
carrer.descripcio: Antoni Aulèstia i Pijoan (Reus, Baix Camp, 1849 - Barcelona, 1908). Writer and historian. Author of a History of Catalonia.

carrer.name: Aurora, Carrer de l'
carrer.descripcio: This street was built at the beginning of the XIX century, when romanticism was paramount. Nonetheless, Aurora could also refer to the Mother of Our Lord.

carrer.name: Aurora Bertrana, Carrer d'
carrer.descripcio: Maria de la Aurora Narcisa Anna Bertrana i Salazar (Girona 1892 - Berga, Berguedà, 1974). Writer and musicologist. Daughter of Prudenci Bertrana. She was a fierce fighter for the women rights and women vote, which finally was granted by the Constitution of the Second Republic.

carrer.name: Ausiàs Marc, Carrer d'
carrer.descripcio: Or Ausies March (Gandia, ?, Safor ~1397 - Valencia, Horta, 1459). Poet. His 'Cant espiritual' is considered one of the most glorious songs of Catalan poetry. His poems had a considerable influence on Spanish lyrics of the XVI and XVII century.

carrer.name: Ausona, Carrer d'
carrer.descripcio: Latin name of Osona, from the Basque word 'auza' (village), translated by the Romans as 'Vicus' (now the town named Vic). Named after the region of the Principality with capital in Vic.

carrer.name: Autonomia, Carrer de l'
carrer.descripcio: General Blanco, who substituted the Spanish general Weyler in the War of Cuba, conferred autonomy to Cuba in the name of the metropolis. This fact was highly celebrated, as for the population it meant the end of the bloodshed. So they celebrated it naming this street 'Autonomy'.

carrer.name: Ave Maria, Carrer de l'
carrer.descripcio: Formerly a road crossing the parish cemetery of Santa Maria del Pi Church in front of the Ave Maria gate.

carrer.name: Avellà, Carrer dels
carrer.descripcio: This street already appears under this name in documents from the XIII century. The name probably comes from the aristocratic Abella or Avellà family, whose ancestral home was in this street, on the corner with Mercaders street. Street of the Avellà or Abellà.

carrer.name: Avenir, Carrer de l'
carrer.descripcio: Name shown in the official map of 1895 of Sant Gervasi (Porvenir), when the street crossed the properties of Maria de Parellada i Santaló and Salvador Sagués (1877), and was the borderline between the lands of Josep Castelló (1868) and Francesc Vilumara (1875). This was an area then enjoying a great future (porvenir), in view of the planned expansion of Sant Gervasi towards the future Diagonal and Eixample.
carrer.anteriors: Porvenir, 07/03/1939; Lluhí i Rissech, 10/02/1933; Porvenir, before 1895

carrer.name: Avet, Carrer de l'
carrer.descripcio: Named after a large monoic tree (which can grow up to 60 meters high), within a group of streets named after plants of all kinds.

carrer.name: Aviació, Carrer de l'
carrer.descripcio: Shows the interest for modern inventions existing in Barcelona during the first years of the XX century.

carrer.name: Aviador Duran, Carrer de l'
carrer.descripcio: Juan Manuel Durán y González (Jerez de la Frontera, 1899 - Barcelona, 1926). Aviator of the crew that flew from Seville to Buenos Aires in the aircraft called Plus Ultra, overflowing the Atlantic Ocean with seven stages between January 22, 1926, and February 10, 1926.

carrer.name: Aviador Franco, Carrer de l'
carrer.descripcio: Ramón Franco Bahamonde (Ferrol, La Coruña 1896 - Mediterranean Sea near the Balearics, 1938). Dictator Franco's elder brother. Aviator of the crew that flew the aircraft named Plus Ultra.

carrer.name: Aviador Ruíz de Alda, Carrer de l'
carrer.descripcio: Julio Ruíz de Alda y Miguélez (Astilla, 1897 - Madrid, 1936). Military and politician. Aviator of the crew that flew the aircraft named Plus Ultra.

carrer.name: Àvila, Carrer d'
carrer.descripcio: Named after the town of Castile-León, within a group of streets named after Province Capitals.
carrer.anteriors: Dos de Mayo (1st section); Núm. 45 (Cerdà plan)

carrer.name: Avinyó, Carrer d'
carrer.descripcio: Named after an old Catalan family, some illustrious members of which already appear in documents of the XIV and XV century.
carrer.anteriors: 18 de Julio (for a short time); Aviñó; Pou de l'Aldà; Calderes Velles

carrer.name: Avinyonet, Carrer d'
carrer.descripcio: Named after Avinyonet del Penedès, a borough of Alt Penedès. The street is located in Ciutat Meridiana. Approved together with other streets named after Catalan towns and villages.

carrer.name: Avió Plus Ultra, Carrer de l'
carrer.descripcio: Named after the aircraft that flew from Seville to Buenos Aires in seven stages, starting on January 22, 1926, with the crew integrated by the aviators Ramón Franco Bahamonde, Julio Ruíz de Alda, John Manuel Durán y González, and the engineer Pablo Rada.
carrer.anteriors: Avión Plus Ultra, 07/03/1939; Nicolàs Travé, 1939; Àngel Lloreda, 13/01/1933; Nicolàs Travé, 1931; Avión Plus Ultra, 18/05/1927; Nicolàs Travé, 1922; San Salvador, before 1888

carrer.name: Avis, Placeta dels
carrer.descripcio: This is how this small square is called among the neighbors.

carrer.name: Aymar, Passatge d'
carrer.descripcio: Named after the landowner, Agustí Aymar i Gelabert, lace maker in Barcelona, married with Dolors Rubió i Ors, died in 1871. Starting in 1847, he created a chain of establishments (25 of them mattress shops) on the side with access to the waters of the Llacuna irrigation ditch.

carrer.name: Azalea, Carrer de l'
carrer.descripcio: Belongs to a group of streets named after trees and plants.

carrer.name: B, Carrer
carrer.descripcio: The Urban Development Committee approved the Partial Arrangement Plan for the industrial estate owned by the Consortium of Barcelona's Zona Franca, where, with few exceptions, streets designated with letters run in the North-South direction, while streets designated with numbers run in the East-West direction.

carrer.name: Bac de Roda, Espigó de
carrer.descripcio: Breakwater of the Poblenou beach, named after the nearby street within the same district.

carrer.name: Bac de Roda, Carrer de
carrer.descripcio: Francesc Macià i Ambert (Roda de Ter, Osona, ? - Vic, Osona, 1713). Politician and guerrillero during the Spanish Succession War. One of the most popular military leaders and politicians of the war against Philip V of Castile. He was known as Bac de Roda.
carrer.anteriors: Felipe II; Bach de Roda; Comercio; Núm. 55 (Cerdà plan)

carrer.name: Bacardí, Passatge de
carrer.descripcio: Passageway named after Baltasar de Bacardí i Tomba (Barcelona, 1752 - 1822), owner who offered the passageway when the Plaça Reial (Royal Square) was finished. Finally, the passageway was opened in 1856 by Ramon Bacardí i Cuyàs (Barcelona, 1791 - 1866).

carrer.name: Bacardí, Jardins de
carrer.descripcio: Gardens named after Can Bacardí or Ermengol. Anna de Bacardí i Ribas was the owner until 1958.

carrer.name: Bacardí, Plaça de
carrer.descripcio: Square named after Alexandre de Bacardí i Janer (Barcelona, 1816 - Sant Pere de Premià, Maresme, 1905). Owner of the lands around. Lawyer and writer, author of several studies on military, mercantile, and maritime law.

carrer.name: Bacardí, Carrer de
carrer.descripcio: Street dedicated to Baltasar de Bacardí i Janer (Barcelona, 1814 - 1888), member of the land owner family.

carrer.name: Badajoz, Carrer de
carrer.descripcio: Town in Extremadura.

carrer.name: Badal, Passatge de
carrer.descripcio: Passageway named after the same family as the Rambla de Badal.

carrer.name: Badal, Rambla de
carrer.descripcio: In 1864, Josep and Oleguer Badal i Burés, of the company Badal Hermanos, got the flour mill, which had a waterfall named "del Lleonard", rented from the Community of Irrigators, Owners and Landowners of the Royal Channel of Infante Luisa Carlota de Borbón. The Badal brothers were the owners of the lands, which became the property of Josep Badal i Amigó and Oleguer Badal i Soley in 1894.

carrer.name: Badalona, Carrer de
carrer.descripcio: Borough of Barcelonès. The ancient Iberian town of 'Baetulo' ('Baitolo-Betulone'), located between the Canyet (or 'd'en Folc') and 'd'en Jornet' (or 'dels Frares') riversides, near a Roman military camp.

carrer.name: Badia, Carrer de
carrer.descripcio: Joan Badia, from Escané, Montanui, Alta Ribagorza, silversmith established at Lleida (XVIII century), husband of Rosa Puigrodon, from Tremp, Pallars Jussà. The reason why this street was named after him was this: Anton Trilla i Trilla, lawyer from Lleida, married Magdalena Escarabatxeras i Blanch in 1770, and had a son, Anton Trilla, also a lawyer. When Magdalena Escarabatxeras de Trilla died in 1794, Trilla, the father, asked misses Rosa, then widow after Badia and her second husband, Mirmi, for help, so misses Rosa and her children Joan and Àgata Badia i Puigrodon helped in the household, and in the parish Santa Maria del Pi. Years went by, Trilla the father and misses Rosa died, and in 1817, Anton Trilla i Escarabatxeras decided to marry Àgata Badia i Puigrodon. As he wrote, they had been living together more than 24 years in the same house, and as he was already 48 years old, to find more comfort and respect for his house, he wished to marry Àgata Badia "because most people think that the Supplicant is already married to the aforesaid lady..." The marriage took place at the church dedicated to the Saints Justo and Pastor in 1817. When Àgata Badia i Puigrodon de Trilla, who lived in the house called Torre del Simó, lost her husband, according to his last will she submitted an urbanization project for her lands at Gràcia. The final names given to the planned streets and square were: the Trilla square (which received several names) was named Sant Antoni square after her husband's first name, Antoni Trilla i Escarabatxeras (who used to sign with his mother's second last name, Blanch); two streets running from the sea towards the mountains were dedicated, one to the memory of her father-in-law, Anton Trilla i Trilla, and the other one to her father, Joan Badia; the street connecting the Trilla square with the Trilla street was dedicated to Saint Magdalene, in memory of her mother-in-law Magdalena Escarabatxeras i Blanch de Trilla; a street dedicated to Saint Rose in memory of her mother, Rosa Puigrodon, and finally a street dedicated to Saint Agate in memory of herself, Àgata Badia i Puigrodon de Trilla (Lleida, Segrià, 1770 - Barcelona, 1836).

carrer.name: Badosa, Carrer de
carrer.descripcio: Ramon Badosa i Campanyà (Barcelona 1877 - 1933), doctor of medicine, married to Rosa Gaspar i Laribal, owner of the lands that formerly had belonged to the estate of Casa Dragó de Dalt.

carrer.name: Bailèn, Carrer de
carrer.descripcio: Street belonging to the Cerdà project, so named in memory of the Battle of Bailén (small town in the Jaén province), that took place on July 19, 1808, where General Castaños fought against the French troops commanded by General Dupont.

carrer.name: Baix de Mariner, Carrer
carrer.descripcio: Near the Mariner watercourse there used to be two farms, respectively called 'Alta de Mariné' and 'Baixa de Mariné'. This street name is in memory of the lower of those farm houses, Baixa de Mariné. Name standardized as "Mariner".

carrer.name: Baix del Turó, Passatge
carrer.descripcio: Belongs to a group of three passages, Alt (high), Mig (middle), and Baix (low), at the eastern hillside of the Guinardó Park.

carrer.name: Baladre, Carrer del
carrer.descripcio: Evergreen bush giving pink flowers. Street in the Rectoret neighborhood, where a large number of streets is named after plants.

carrer.name: Balboa, Carrer de
carrer.descripcio: Vasco Núñez de Balboa (Jerez de los Caballeros, Extremadura, 1475 - Acla, Panama, 1517). Discoverer who participated in many expeditions in Venezuela. Colonizer and Governor of Darien (1511). In 1513, he crossed the Panama isthmus and discovered the Pacific Ocean. Governor of Panama in 1514. One street of many others named after seafarers and discoverers in the Barceloneta neighborhood.

carrer.name: Balcells, Carrer de
carrer.descripcio: Josep A. Balcells i Camps (Castellar del Vallès, Vallès Occidental, 1777 - Barcelona, 1857). Chemist and druggist. Lecturer of Physics and Chemistry at the School of Sant Victorià of Barcelona. He succeeded in coloring cotton using Adrianopolis red, a technique formerly known only by the Turks. He published many scientific articles and was member of several institutions.

carrer.name: Baldiri Reixac, Carrer de
carrer.descripcio: Baldiri Reixac i Carbó (Bell-lloc d'Aro, Baix Empordà, 1703 - Ollers, Gironès, 1781). Pedagogue. Presbyterian, Rector of Sant Martí d'Ollers, defender of the Catalan language, his opinion was that education should start using the mother tongue, not Latin.

carrer.name: Baldomer Girona, Carrer de
carrer.descripcio: Baldomer Girona i Constantí (Selva del Camp, Baix Camp, 1856 - Barcelona, 1936). Since 1898 he was owner of lands at Sant Genís dels Agudells, around the places known as "La Meca" and "La Vinya Vella".

carrer.name: Balears, Carrer de les
carrer.descripcio: Named after the islands in the Mediterranean.

carrer.name: Balears, Moll de
carrer.descripcio: Located outside the Industry Pier', on the way towards the Commerce Pier'.

carrer.name: Balenyà, Carrer de
carrer.descripcio: Borough of Osona. Street in the Torre Baró neighborhood, where many streets are named after Catalan towns and villages.

carrer.name: Baliarda, Carrer de
carrer.descripcio: Francesc Baliarda i Ribó (1813-1850). Known by his neighbors of Sant Andreu as "el Noi". A leader in the fight against recruitment, he died in 1850 in the street now named after him, during one of the revolutionary movements he participated in.

carrer.name: Baliarda, Passatge de
carrer.descripcio: Passageway named after the brothers Pere, Miquel and Andreu Baliarda i Mariné, who were the owners, in part until 1903, of some lands originally belonging to the Mas Vilar estate.

carrer.name: Ballester, Carrer de
carrer.descripcio: Joan Ballester Ayguals d'Izco (Vinaròs, Baix Maestrat, 1835 - Barcelona, 1868). Painter and scene painter.
carrer.anteriors: Riego, after 1907, San Antonio Abad, 1875, Riego, after 1861

carrer.name: Ballot, Carrer de
carrer.descripcio: Josep Pau Ballot i Torres (Barcelona, 1747 - 1821). Grammar teacher and pedagogue. Presbyter and defender of the Catalan language. Author of the first modern grammar printed in the Principality of Catalonia.

carrer.name: Balmes, Carrer de
carrer.descripcio: Jaume Llucià Balmes i Urpià (Vic, Osona, 1810 - 1848). Ecclesiastic, philosopher, politician, writer. Founder of a Catalan apologetic school.

carrer.name: Balsareny, Carrer de
carrer.descripcio: Borough of Bages.

carrer.name: Baltasar Gracián, Carrer de
carrer.descripcio: Baltasar Gracián y Morales (Belmonte de Calatayud, Aragon. 1601 - Tarazona, 1658). Writer. Jesuit. Introspective and critical, his works had a considerable influence on Spanish authors.

carrer.name: Baltasar Samper, Carrer de
carrer.descripcio: Baltasar Sampere i Marquès (Majorca, 1888 - Mexico, 1966). Musician and composer, disciple of Enrique Granados and Felip Pedrell. In 1939 he exiled to Mexico, where he worked as a teacher. Director of the 'Orfeó Català'.

carrer.name: Baluard, Carrer del
carrer.descripcio: Street leading towards the Southern bulwark that existed in Barcelona's city wall from 1527 until beyond 1843.

carrer.name: Baluard, Jardins del
carrer.descripcio: Gardens around the shipyard bulwark (Drassanes), between Paral·lel avenue and Portal de Santa Madrona street.

carrer.name: Banca, Passatge de la
carrer.descripcio: Passageway so named because of the savings bank established there, called 'Crédito Mutuo Fabril y Mercantil', known as "Caixa Vilumara".

carrer.name: Banyoles, Carrer de
carrer.descripcio: Borough and capital of Pla de l'Estany.
carrer.anteriors: Bañolas; Banyolas; Ptge. de Cervantes; Milà i Fontanals

carrer.name: Banys Nous, Carrer dels
carrer.descripcio: Named after the baths there had been on the corner with Boqueria street. Though they were known as Arab Baths, they really were Jewish. On June 5, 1160, King Ramon Berenguer IV came to an agreement with the Alfaqui (kind of mullah) Abraham to build public baths in the back garden near his new viscount castle. Those baths survived until 1716.

carrer.name: Banys Vells, Carrer dels
carrer.descripcio: When this street was built around 1350, it was called Sitjar street, after the chairmaker's workshop that used to be there. After the chairmaker moved to the Tallers (workshops) neighborhood, the street was renamed after some ancient baths there had been since the XIII century.

carrer.name: Barcelona, Moll de
carrer.descripcio: This pier close to the Maritime Station is the preferred place for boarding passenger ships.

carrer.name: Barceloneta, Moll de la
carrer.descripcio: Pier in front of the avenue named after John of Bourbon, Count of Barcelona.

carrer.name: Barceloneta, Parc de la
carrer.descripcio: Park named after the Barceloneta neighborhood.

carrer.name: Barceloneta, Platja de la
carrer.descripcio: Old beach of Barcelona, which includes the beaches called Sant Miquel and Sant Sebastià. Located between the breakwater and the Hospital del Mar, in front of the sea promenade.

carrer.name: Barceloneta, Plaça de la
carrer.descripcio: Square at the Barceloneta, a neighborhood originally inhabited by fishermen and seamen. It was urbanized by Cermeño and built under the direction of the military engineer Francisco Paredes.

carrer.name: Bàrcino, Via de
carrer.descripcio: Roman town corresponding to the current Barcelona. On old Iberian coins, the name of this ancient town is written as 'Barkeno', of Indo-European origin, later latinized into 'Barcino-onis'. 'Barcelona' in its present form comes from the accusative 'Barcinone(m)', after having changed a consonant and the final ''e'' to 'a'.

carrer.name: Barnola, Carrer de
carrer.descripcio: Hamlet within the borough of Lles (Baixa Cerdanya). The street is in the Milans del Bosch housing estate, where streets are named after towns and villages of Catalonia.
carrer.anteriors: Puigcerdà (when it belonged to Santa Coloma); Núm. 20

carrer.name: Barnola, Passatge de
carrer.descripcio: Passageway named after Maria Barnola i Grau, who married Manuel Castells i Juncosa on October 18, 1900, and was co-owner since 1913. The lands had been bought by her father-in-law, Manuel Castells i Carlos (1843 - 1904), in 1874.

carrer.name: Baró de Griñó, Passatge del
carrer.descripcio: Passageway named after Joan Miquel Griñó i Fargas, Piñol de Porta i Sagristà (Lleida, Segrià, 1883 - Madrid, 1964). Economist. Promoter of the Vil·la de la Salut de l'Aliança. Town Councilor of the City Hall (1929).

carrer.name: Baró de la Barre, Carrer del
carrer.descripcio: Josep de la Barre i de Taberner, Baron de la Barre and de Pechmann (=1855), married to Marianna Díaz de Manso, owner of the estate named Mas Falcó, with lands of an extension of 71 and a half 'mujadas' (approx. 460,000 sq. m); the property of this estate passed over to his children, Agustí and Maria del Pilar, in 1903.
carrer.anteriors: Barón de La Barre; Barre de Flandes

carrer.name: Baró de Sant Lluís, Carrer del
carrer.descripcio: Named after the owner of the old estate named Can Sampere, later Can Baró, originally consisting of 89 'mujadas' (approx. 58.000 sq. m), formerly property of Eulàlia Sampere, a relative of Josep Pasqual de Pascali i Sampere, who became the Baron of Sant Lluís in 1794.
carrer.anteriors: Barón de San Luis; Miguel Ascaso i Juan Alonso Flores; Núm. 2 B (Casa Baró residential area)

carrer.name: Baró de Viver, Plaça del
carrer.descripcio: Square located in the Baró de Viver neighborhood, named after the second Baron of Viver, Darius Rumeu i Freixa (Barcelona, 1886 - 1970), who had been Mayor of Barcelona.

carrer.name: Baró d'Esponellà, Carrer del
carrer.descripcio: Passageway named after Gaspar de Berart i de Cortada (XVII-XVIII century). Military. He participated in the defense of Barcelona in 1714 as Captain under the Colonel of the 2nd Company (artillerymen), dying on September 11, 1714, while breaking through the siege at the Eastern bastion.

carrer.name: Barra de Ferro, Carrer de la
carrer.descripcio: The 'Rúbrica de Bruniquer', a strange manuscript preserved in the Municipal Archive, and edited later, says: "A 22 de setembre de 1668 pagaren 32 lliures i 12 sous per les barres de ferro que posaren a la boca de la claveguera i també per a la barrera." (On September 22, 1668, 32 pounds and 12 solds were paid for the iron bars used in the sewer mouth and the barrier).

carrer.name: Barri Vermell, Carrer del
carrer.descripcio: Named after a red-painted fence that existed in this street long time ago.

carrer.name: Bartomeu Pi, Carrer de
carrer.descripcio: Named after Bartomeu Pi i Llaguna (1833 - 1916), a leatherware manufacturer once established in this street. He also had been the owner of the soil, inherited by sons Bartomeu and Joan Pi i Pujolà.

carrer.name: Bartrina, Carrer de
carrer.descripcio: Joaquim M. Bartrina i d'Aixemús (Reus, Baix Camp, 1850 - Barcelona, 1880). Writer and poet. He collaborated in local newspapers and was director of an amateur theater group. He took part in the Floral Games of 1876, winning an award with an epistle.
carrer.anteriors: Presidente Rumeu (joined to it); Concepción Arenal (a section); Barcelona (a section); Trav. or ctra. de Dalt (a section)

carrer.name: Bascònia, Carrer de
carrer.descripcio: The Basque Land.

carrer.name: Basea, Carrer de
carrer.descripcio: Named after Basea, also called Basilia. In a document of 1189, included in the 'Libri Antiquitatum' that can be found at the Cathedral of Barcelona, can be read: "in burgo barchinone in basilia subtus murus civitatis", this being the original form of the place-name 'basea'.

carrer.name: Bassegoda, Carrer de
carrer.descripcio: Ramon Enric Bassegoda i Amigó (La Bisbal d'Empordà, Baix Empordà, 1856 - Barcelona, 1921). Poet and journalist, founder of the weekly 'La Llar '(1874), and since 1880 director of 'La Il·lustració Catalana'.

carrer.name: Bassella, Carrer de
carrer.descripcio: Borough of Alt Urgell. The street is in the Milans del Bosch housing state, where streets are named after towns and villages in Catalonia.

carrer.name: Basses de la Peira, Plaça de les
carrer.descripcio: This is a reference to some large watering ponds, no longer in existence, which used to be in this place. They belonged to the old farmhouse Ca la Peira, formerly a property of the Marquis of Castellbell.

carrer.name: Basses de Sant Pere, Carrer de les
carrer.descripcio: Built on the place where the comtal irrigation channel, and also the flour mill ponds the abbess of Sant Pere allowed to open to be used by the neighbors.
carrer.anteriors: Balsas de San Pedro; Pl. del Capità Josep Mª Freire; Molinos de San Pedro

carrer.name: Basses d'en Barral, Plaça de les
carrer.descripcio: Barral is the name by which the house inhabited by the Rodó family was known. There is documented evidence of the house in Vallvidrera from the year 1803. Some watering ponds were constructed, and these ponds (basses) gave the name to the place.

carrer.name: Basses d'Horta, Carrer de les
carrer.descripcio: In memory of the many ponds and pools which exist around this place.

carrer.name: Bassols, Carrer de
carrer.descripcio: Ignasi de Bassols i de Foxà (Girona, 1818 - Barcelona, 1884). Landowner. Married to Joaquima de Cabanes i de Girona, who inherited from her parents, Josep Marià de Cabanes and Eulàlia de Girona i Ros, the estate named Manso Oller, located near the mills of the Clot. Later, her daughters Mercè and Pilar de Bassols i Cabanes inherited the lands.

carrer.name: Bateries, Passatge de les
carrer.descripcio: Passageway so named in memory of the old batteries, called Bonavista and Àlvarez de Castro, placed near the castle on top of the Montjuïc mountain. Passageway situated below the gardens around the Poble-sec Viewpoint, with entrance from the Montjuïc avenue.

carrer.name: Batet, Carrer de
carrer.descripcio: Named after Amàlia Batet i Gil (Rubí, Vallès Occidental, 1853 - Barcelona, 1921), married to Miquel Hortal i Arisó, who was the owner until 1921.

carrer.name: Batista, Carrer de
carrer.descripcio: Joan and Josep Batista i Molins bought the lands around the place called "Quatre Camins".

carrer.name: Batista i Roca, Carrer de
carrer.descripcio: Josep M. Batista i Roca (Barcelona 1895 - 1978). Historian, ethnologue and politician. He was one of the founders of the 'Arxiu d'Etnografia i Folklore de Catalunya' (1917). He also founded the Minyons de Muntanya Organization. Exiled to England in 1939, he continued working in divulging Catalan culture. Name proposed by The Anglo-Catalan Society.

carrer.name: Batlló, Passatge de
carrer.descripcio: Batlló Germans was a company represented by the brothers Jacint, Joan, and Fèlix Batlló i Barrera. After Jacint's death, Joan and Fèlix Batlló started to build a large yarn and textile factory. This factory was sold in 1909, and later became the Industry School. Fèlix Batlló i Barrera (Olot, Garrotxa, 1819 - Barcelona, 1878), Joan Batlló i Barrera) (Olot, Garrotxa, 1812 - Barcelona, 1892), and Jacint Batlló i Barrera (Olot, Garrotxa, 1803 - 1866).

carrer.name: Batllori, Carrer de
carrer.descripcio: Joan Batllori was the owner of the lands at the beginning of the XIX century. Joan Gallarda i Batllori and his wife Teresa Campañà i Campmany were the owners at the end of the XIX century.

carrer.name: Beat Almató, Carrer del
carrer.descripcio: Pere Almató i Ribera (Sant Feliu Sasserra, Bages, 1830 - Hai Duong, Tonking, now Vietnam, 1861). Martyr. Son of Salvi and Antònia. Dominican preacher monk, who took the habits following the advice of Saint Antonio Maria Claret. Ordained in Manila, Philippines. Missionary in Tonking. He was killed by cutting his head off. Canonized in 1988 by Pope John Paul II.
carrer.anteriors: Beato Almató; Suñer i Capdevila, 04/02/1931; Suñer, 30/07/1929; Francia (without effectiveness); Suñer i Capdevila, 05/09/1907; Santa Teresa, before 1900; Durán

carrer.name: Beat Domènec Savio, Carrer del
carrer.descripcio: Domènec Savio i Gajato, confessor (Riba di Chieri, Torino, Italy, 1842 - Mondonia, 1857). Son of Carles and Rosa Brigida. Secular brother when he was an adolescent, disciple of Saint John Bosch. He was scholar of the 'Oratorio Salesiano'. Canonized in 1954 by Pope Pius XII.

carrer.name: Beat Simó, Carrer del
carrer.descripcio: Known as Simón de Rojas (Valladolid, 1552 - Madrid, 1624). Trinitarian monk. Son of Gregori Ruíz de Navamuel y Constança de Roxas. Canonized in 1987 by Pope John Paul II.
carrer.anteriors: Beato Simón de Rojas; Monech o Monac; Calderers; Sagarra

carrer.name: Beates, Carrer de les
carrer.descripcio: This street leads to the square where the Pious Sisters of Saint Dominic, order founded by sister Joana Morell in 1532, built their cloister to teach girls of poor families.
carrer.anteriors: Beatas; Anarquistas; Beatas de Santa Catalina

carrer.name: Beates, Plaça de les
carrer.descripcio: Square named after the Pious Sisters of Saint Dominic.

carrer.name: Beatriu, Carrer de
carrer.descripcio: So named in memory of Beatrice, the personage out of Dante's 'Divina Comedia', idealized as a symbol of theology, as she led the poet to Paradise.

carrer.name: Bederrida, Parc de
carrer.descripcio: Park named after a party at Les Corts, which already appears in documents from 946, also known as Terrers Blancs. Etymologically, this name comes from the Liguria region in Italy, or from the Provence in France.

carrer.name: Bedoll, Carrer del
carrer.descripcio: Deciduous tree of the Betulaceae family.

carrer.name: Beethoven, Carrer de
carrer.descripcio: Ludwig van Beethoven Kehwerich (Bonn, 1770 - Vienna, 1827). German composer of Flemish origin, who had an enormous influence on future generations. He considerably contributed to the transformation of occidental music, and was one of the most significant composers of all times.
carrer.anteriors: Compositor Beethoven, 07/07/1942; Av. de Víctor Hugo, 13/01/1933

carrer.name: Begònia, Carrer de la
carrer.descripcio: Street in the Font Florida neighborhood, together with other streets named after flowers, such as Hortènsia, Gessamí, and Crisantem.

carrer.name: Begur, Carrer de
carrer.descripcio: Borough of Baix Empordà.

carrer.name: Béjar, Carrer de
carrer.descripcio: Small town in the Castilian province of Salamanca.

carrer.name: Belianes, Plaça de
carrer.descripcio: Borough of Urgell, limiting with Bellpuig and Les Garrigues. There is written reference of this village since 1041, as belonging to the Barony of Anglesola, to the Templar Order, and later to the hospitalarian 'encomienda' (holding) of Barbens. Iberian and Roman relics can be found here. It has a gothic church dating from the XV century, and the House of Common is a remarkable gothic building from the XVI century. Also of interest is the Renaissance palace of 'Cal Roc', the façade of which is reproduced at the Spanish Village (Poble Espanyol). Street name proposed by Felip Massot.

carrer.name: Belladona, Carrer de la
carrer.descripcio: Belongs to a group of streets named after trees and plants.

carrer.name: Bellafila, Carrer de
carrer.descripcio: Bellafila or Bellafilla. Johannis de Bellafilla, Bachelor in Law (1447); Joan Miquel de Bellafila, Third Councilor (1543); Miquel de Bellafila, Chief Councilor (1548), and Josep de Bellafila, Second Councilor (1601), prove how important this family was in the city.

carrer.name: Bellavista, Camí de
carrer.descripcio: Path located at Vallvidrera les Planes.

carrer.name: Bellavista, Escales de
carrer.descripcio: Stairs located at Vallvidrera les Planes.

carrer.name: Bellavista, Passatge de
carrer.descripcio: Passageway at Vallvidrera les Planes.

carrer.name: Bellavista, Plaça de
carrer.descripcio: Square situated near Can Caralleu and the road 'carretera de les Aigües', offers a panoramic view.

carrer.name: Bellcaire, Carrer de
carrer.descripcio: Named after Bellcaire d'Empordà, a borough of Baix Empordà. The street is within Ramon Albó housing estate, where the streets are named after Catalan villages and towns.

carrer.name: Bellesguard, Carrer de
carrer.descripcio: Former royal residence, built in 1408 at the Vallblanc Tower of Sant Gervasi de Cassoles, when it was acquired by King Martin.
carrer.anteriors: Camí del Cementiri, 1852, Cº Antiguo de Bellesguard, after 1852

carrer.name: Bellesguard, Rotonda de
carrer.descripcio: A road space named after the nearby royal tower of Bellesguard, built on the ancient tower called de Vallblanc, erected in the 12th century. In 1900, due to its bad state of conservation, it was totally rebuilt under the direction of Antoni Gaudí. The nearby gardens were designed by Pere Ballart.

carrer.name: Bellmunt, Carrer de
carrer.descripcio: Bellmunt del Priorat, borough of the Priorat. The street is within Milans del Bosch housing estate, where streets are named after Catalan towns and villages.

carrer.name: Bellprat, Carrer de
carrer.descripcio: Borough of the Anoia. Street in the Torre Baró neighborhood, where most streets are named after Catalan villages.

carrer.name: Bellver, Carrer de
carrer.descripcio: The castle of the City of Majorca, built around 1300 by the architect Ponç Descoll, at the order of Jaume II of Majorca.

carrer.name: Beltrán i Rózpide, Carrer de
carrer.descripcio: Ricard Beltrán i Rózpide (Barcelona, 1852 - Madrid, 1928). Writer and geographer. He was lecturer of the University of Madrid (1886) and member of the History Academy (1902).

carrer.name: Benavent, Carrer de
carrer.descripcio: Ignasi Benavent i Especier (Escaló, Pallars Sobirà, 1847 - Barcelona, 1902). Teacher for public instruction, founder and director of Sant Isidre School, then established in the neighborhood. Married to Antònia Benavent i Camon, owner of the lands.

carrer.name: Benedetti, Carrer de
carrer.descripcio: Giovanni Battista Benedetti (Venice, 1530 - Torino, 1590). Italian physician and mathematician, follower of Copernicus, who influenced Galileo Galilei at the court of the Duke of Saboya. Or, at least this is what the nomenclature of 1980 says. On the other hand, between 1940 and 1957, when the street name was approved, the owner of that place was Emili Benedetti i Benedetto (Richterswil, Zurich, 1889 - Barcelona, 1971).

carrer.name: Benet Mateu, Carrer de
carrer.descripcio: Pere Benet Mateu (XVI century). Herbalist and apothecary of Barcelona.

carrer.name: Benet Mercadé, Carrer de
carrer.descripcio: Benet Mercadé i Fàbrega (La Bisbal d'Empordà, Baix Empordà, 1821 - Barcelona, 1897). Painter. The most distinct feature of his eclectic and also realistic paintings is their soberness. Most paintings represent historical and religious scenes.

carrer.name: Benet XV, Plaça de
carrer.descripcio: Square named after Giacomo della Chiesa Migliorati (Genoa, 1854 - Rome, 1922), known as Pope Benedict XV (1914-1922). He decisively pleaded in favor of peace and human rights during World War I.

carrer.name: Benevent, Carrer de
carrer.descripcio: Town of the Campagna (Italy), province capital at the confluence of the Sabato and Calore rivers. The street lays South-West of the Besòs river, where a group of streets is named after Italian towns.

carrer.name: Benlliure, Carrer de
carrer.descripcio: Marià Benlliure i Gil (El Grau, Valencia, Horta, 1862 - Madrid, 1947). Prolific sculptor, author of a large number of monuments in Valencia. He was member of San Fernando Academy.

carrer.name: Berenguer de Palou, Carrer de
carrer.descripcio: (Palou, Vallès Oriental, ? - Barcelona, 1241). Royal Councilor. Chamberlain of the Crown. Bishop of Barcelona (1212). He took part in the conquest of Majorca.

carrer.name: Berenguer Mallol, Carrer de
carrer.descripcio: (XIII century). Admiral of Catalonia and Aragon (during the reign of Pere 'el Gran'). With the fleets of Roger de Llúria and Ramon Marquet he caused great harm to the French fleet near the Formigues islands (1285).

carrer.name: Beret, Carrer de
carrer.descripcio: A large plain at 1860 m height, at the Noguera Pallaresa headwaters, within the township of Cap d'Aran.

carrer.name: Berga, Carrer de
carrer.descripcio: Borough of Berguedà. Place-name of Indo-European origin.

carrer.name: Bergara, Carrer de
carrer.descripcio: Named after this Basque town, where the Maroto-Espartero Treaty was signed on August 31, 1839, thus putting an end to the Carlist Civil War.

carrer.name: Bergnes de las Casas, Carrer de
carrer.descripcio: Antoni Bergnes de las Casas (Barcelona, 1801 - 1879). Hellenist, editor, Rector of the University of Barcelona.

carrer.name: Berguedà, Carrer de
carrer.descripcio: Guillem de Berguedà (before 1138 - before 1196). Troubadour, eldest son and heir of the Viscount of Berga, Guillem. Adventurer and prolific author of important plays describing life in the medieval world. Streets dedicated to him and to Guillem de Cabestany and Guerau de Cabrera.

carrer.name: Bering, Passatge de
carrer.descripcio: Named after the strait that links the coasts of Alaska and Siberia, communicating the Chuckchi Sea with the Bering Sea. At its narrowest point, the strait is 85 km wide. The name of the strait is that of the first sailor who crossed it, the Dane Vitus Bering. This lane is located in the Area of Logistic Activities (Zona d'Activitats Logístiques, ZAL) in Barcelona harbor, where the thoroughfares are dedicated to the world's seas and oceans.

carrer.name: Berlín, Carrer de
carrer.descripcio: Street named after Berlin, the Capital of Germany. This name was given to the formerly second section of Paris street during Hitler's Third Reich. Berlin was seat of the Olympic Games of 1936.

carrer.name: Berlinès, Carrer del
carrer.descripcio: The name of this street, formerly Berlin street, was changed to 'Berliners' in order to avoid duplicate street names.

carrer.name: Bermejo, Carrer de
carrer.descripcio: Bartolomé de Cárdenas o Bermejo (Cordoba, ? - after 1498). Painter. Master of medieval Spanish painting, his style shows the influence of the Flemish school.

carrer.name: Berna, Carrer de
carrer.descripcio: Town in Switzerland, Capital of the Helvetic Confederation. The street was partly built on the soil of the Convent of Discalced Carmelites (Josepets).
carrer.anteriors: Consuelo (added to it between Pàdua and Ballester, 26/03/1931)

carrer.name: Bernardí Martorell, Passatge de
carrer.descripcio: Passageway named after Bernardí Martorell i Cortada, member of a well-known landowner family, who bought part of the lands formerly belonging to the Cloister and garden of the Calced Carmelites. Successively, the land property passed on to: Bernardí Martorell i Montells, his son; Bernardí Martorell i Falp, his grandson, chemical engineer, and Bernardí Martorell i Puig, architect.

carrer.name: Bernat Bransi, Carrer de
carrer.descripcio: Bernat Bransi i Plana, son of Marià Bransi i Pérez d'Arregui, grandson of Jeroni Bransi, Royal Notary. Bernat was a honest citizen, who refused to swear obedience to the French in 1808, when he was Councilor of the Town Council of Barcelona. Landowners. The street was opened on grounds belonging to the estate Mas Grau, owned by Tomàs Casals i Bartomeus (1845 - 1910).

carrer.name: Bernat Desclot, Carrer de
carrer.descripcio: (XIII century). Chronicler. Author of the chronicle known through the manuscript 'Llibre del rei En Pere d'Aragó e dels seus antecessors passats'. Possible identification with Bernat Escrivà (? - 1288), citizen of Barcelona.

carrer.name: Bernat Fenollar, Passatge de
carrer.descripcio: (Penàguila, Alcoià, 1438 - Valencia, Horta, 1516). Ecclesiast and poet. He was administrator and treasurer (1467) of the Cathedral of Valencia.

carrer.name: Bernat Martorell, Carrer de
carrer.descripcio: (Sant Celoni, Vallès Oriental, XIV century - Barcelona, 1452). Painter. He established in Barcelona in 1433, being considered one of the most important gothic painters of Catalonia and of the world.

carrer.name: Bernat Metge, Carrer de
carrer.descripcio: (Barcelona, 1340/1346 - 1413). Writer, the most elegant and savant medieval prose writer. He was notary and civil officer of the Chancellery of Queen Elionor. In 1390 he promoted to Royal Secretary of King Joan I.

carrer.name: Berruguete, Carrer de
carrer.descripcio: Pedro Berruguete (Paredes de Nava, 1450 - 1503). Castilian painter. He was an illustrious personality in Spanish painting of the second half of the XV century, under the influence of Flemish and Renaissance painting of the XIV century. The most famous was his son, Alonso Berruguete (Paredes de Nava, 1490 - Toledo, 1561), sculptor and painter.

carrer.name: Bertran, Carrer de
carrer.descripcio: Josep Bertran i Ros (Barcelona 1795 - 1855). Mayor of Barcelona in 1843, President of the Supreme Court in 1844, and Rector of the University in 1853. From his uncle, Francesc Tomàs Ros i Buscà, he inherited the lands of Putget. After his death, they passed on to his son Felip Bertran i Amat (Barcelona, 1835 - 1911), an eminent lawyer and historian, married to Elisa Musitu), who in his time was known in his neighborhood as Bertran. At the end of the XIX century, the streets in Bertran's and Elisa's properties were urbanized. Their son and heir, Josep Bertran i Musitu (Montpellier, France, 1875 - Barcelona, 1957), lawyer and important politician, was married to Maria Cristina Güell i López.

carrer.name: Bertrand i Serra, Carrer de
carrer.descripcio: Eusebi Bertrand i Sierra (Barcelona, 1877 - 1945). Owner of a cotton textile industry, and politician. His company was one of the most important of Catalonia. He was the son of Manuel Bertrand i Sales (1848 - 1911).

carrer.name: Bertrellans, Carrer de
carrer.descripcio: Named after an eminent family from Barcelona, probably owners of the properties around the street. The most famous family member was Ferran de Bertrellans (XIV century), outstanding man and honest citizen of Barcelona.

carrer.name: Besalú, Carrer de
carrer.descripcio: Borough of La Garrotxa. Since the XIII century, capital of the lowlands and of the ancient County of Besalú.

carrer.name: Besiers, Carrer de
carrer.descripcio: Named after Béziers, town in the Languedoc, Occitania, France, capital of the Viscounty in the X century. In the French Department of Erau.

carrer.name: Besòs, Carrer del
carrer.descripcio: Named after the Besòs ('Bissocium') river, which receives its waters from a great number of tributaries, as are the Congost, Mogent, Tenes, Caldes, and Ripoll. The river is given this name from the confluence of the first two tributaries near Montmeló (Vallès Oriental), and is already mentioned in documents dating back to the X century.

carrer.name: Betània, Carrer de
carrer.descripcio: Bethany, Palestinian village where Saint John the Baptist used to baptize according to the Gospel. Street within a group of streets named after places in the Holy Land.

carrer.name: Béthencourt, Carrer de
carrer.descripcio: Jean IV de Béthencourt (Caux, Normandy, France, 1360 - Grainville-la-Teinturière, 1425). Norman knight, Chamberlain of King Charles VI. In 1402, he parted to conquer the Canaries. Henry III of Castile conferred him the title of King of the Canaries and Lord of Lanzarote (Lancelot) (1418-1425).

carrer.name: Betlem, Carrer de
carrer.descripcio: Named after Bethlehem, town in Palestine, place where Jesus Christ was born according to the Gospel (St. Mathew, St. Luke, and St. John). The street was really given this name because of the madhouse of Nova Betlem that existed in a tower at this place.

carrer.name: Biada, Carrer de
carrer.descripcio: Miquel Biada i Bunyol (Mataró 1789 -1848)
carrer.anteriors: Carrer de Viada (Salvador Viada i Vilaseca), 28/01/1918, Descubrimiento, before 1907

carrer.name: Bigai, Carrer de
carrer.descripcio: Josep Bigai i Sagués (Mataró, Maresme, 1815 - Sant Gervasi, 1880). Potter of a potter family from Mataró, who had established at Sant Gervasi. He lived in the Sant Guillem Street, and owned properties in the Sant Hermenegild Street. He was married to Joaquima Guinart i Ferrater, with whom he had twelve children. He was Mayor of Sant Gervasi. When he died, his son and heir Josep returned from Montevideo, he bought a house in Sagués Street Number 3, and continued working as a ceramist. He was married to Carolina Monpió.

carrer.name: Bigai, Passatge de
carrer.descripcio: Passageway dedicated to the same person as the street with the same name.

carrer.name: Bilbao, Carrer de
carrer.descripcio: Town in the Basque Land, capital of the province of Biscay.
carrer.anteriors: Navas de Tolosa (1st section); Núm. 52 (Cerdà plan)

carrer.name: Binèfar, Carrer de
carrer.descripcio: Villa and borough of Aragon (Huesca) located in the Litera plain, currently belonging to Aragon.

carrer.name: Biosca, Carrer de
carrer.descripcio: Borough of La Segarra. The street is in the Milans del Bosch housing estate, where streets are named after Catalan villages.

carrer.name: Bisbal, Carrer de la
carrer.descripcio: Named after La Bisbal d'Empordà, borough of Baix Empordà.

carrer.name: Bisbe, Carrer del
carrer.descripcio: Named 'Bishop Street' after the Episcopal Palace, where the prelates of Barcelona have been residing since before the XIII century, though many important changes and additions were made to the building along the centuries. In the XVIII century, the Bishop Josep Climent ordered the complete re-construction of the Episcopal Palace.
carrer.anteriors: Obispo Irurita; Bisbe; Zurbano, from 1854 to 1856; Bisbe; Diputació, from 1519 to 1617; Bisbal, before 1423; Santa Eulàlia, before 1417

carrer.name: Bisbe Caçador, Carrer del
carrer.descripcio: Guillem Caçador (Vic, Osona, 1510 - Barcelona, 1570). Councilor of Catalonia. Bishop of Barcelona (1561-1570). He participated in the Trent Council. Nephew of Jaume Caçador (Vic, Osona, 1484 - Barcelona, 1561), also Bishop of Barcelona (1546-1561).
carrer.anteriors: Obispo Cazador; Obispo Cassador, before 1900; Cassador, before 1900

carrer.name: Bisbe Català, Carrer del
carrer.descripcio: Named after the bishop Jaume Català i Albosa (Arenys de Mar, Maresme, 1835 - Barcelona, 1899). Bishop of The Canaries, of Cadiz, and of Barcelona. He became very popular as a fighter for the workers' rights.
carrer.anteriors: Cº de Cornellá to Fogás de Tordera; Salud

carrer.name: Bisbe Josep Climent, Carrer del
carrer.descripcio: Josep Climent i Avinent (Castellón de la Plana, Plana Alta, 1706 - 1781). Bishop of Barcelona (1766-1775). One of the most prestigious erudite prelates who were heading the diocese during the second half of the XVIII century.

carrer.name: Bisbe Laguarda, Carrer del
carrer.descripcio: Joan Josep Laguarda i Fonollera (Valencia, Horta, 1866 - Barcelona, 1913). Bishop of Urgell (1902-1907), of Jaén (1907-1909), and of Barcelona (1909-1913).
carrer.anteriors: Obispo Laguarda; Pg. del Doctor Laguarda

carrer.name: Bisbe Sivilla, Carrer del
carrer.descripcio: Tomàs Sivilla i Gener (Calella, Maresme, 1817 - Girona, 1906). Bishop and jurist. Rector of the Seminary of Barcelona (1850-1858) and Bishop of Girona (1877-1906). At the beginning of the XIX century, this street was dedicated to Nicolau Sivilla i Girbau (Calella, Maresme, ? - Barcelona, 1799). Owner of the lands. First married to Josepa Arimon (see Arimon street), and for the second time to Isabel Raspall. Ignoring this origin, the Town Hall thought the street was named after the bishop.
carrer.anteriors: Obispo Sivilla, 07/07/1942; Asturiana (without effectiveness), 23/12/1913; Cartagena, before 1927; Sivilla, 29/03/1874

carrer.name: Biscaia, Carrer de
carrer.descripcio: Region of the Basque Country. Street integrated in a group of streets of Poblenou named after Basque villages and regions.
carrer.anteriors: Vizcaya; Lope de Vega (2nd section), before 1900; Núm. 53 (Cerdà plan); Vizcaya

carrer.name: Bismarck, Carrer de
carrer.descripcio: Otto von Bismarck (Schönhausen, Brandenburg, Germany, 1815 - Friedrichsruh, Lauenburg, Germany, 1898). Chancellor of Germany (1862-1890), called "the Iron Chancellor".

carrer.name: Bismarck, Passatge de
carrer.descripcio: Passageway named after Otto von Bismarck (see Bismarck street).

carrer.name: Biure, Carrer de
carrer.descripcio: Borough of Alt Empordà. The street is located within Ramon Albó housing estate, where all streets are named after places in Catalonia.

carrer.name: Blada, Passatge de la
carrer.descripcio: Named after the white maple tree. Passageway located in the area of Can Caralleu, near the Oreneta castle.

carrer.name: Blai, Carrer de
carrer.descripcio: In 1915, the Town Hall received a proposal to honor the name of Pere Blai (Barcelona, XVI century - 1620). Master builder, architect of the Renaissance additions to the gothic Palace of the Generalitat, including the Sant Jordi Hall and the façade on Sant Jaume square.

carrer.name: Blanca, Riera
carrer.descripcio: Old place-name related with the "terrers blancs", with written reference dating from 986. The name of this riverside walk has its origin in the place named 'Petras Albas' (white rocks).

carrer.name: Blanca Selva i Henry, Jardins de
carrer.descripcio: Gardens named after Blanca Selva i Hery (Brives, Auvergne, France, 1884 - Saint Amand Tallende, Auvergne, 1942). Pianist, pedagogue and musicologue.

carrer.name: Blanco, Carrer d'en
carrer.descripcio: Formerly 'carretera Reial' , name appearing in documents dated 1847. Probably named after the landowner Francesc Blanch.

carrer.name: Blanes, Baixada de
carrer.descripcio: Downhill path named after Blanes, borough of La Selva, first village of the Costa Brava.

carrer.name: Blanqueria, Carrer de la
carrer.descripcio: The menders used to bleach their skins in this street.

carrer.name: Blanquerna, Plaça de
carrer.descripcio: In memory of the 'Mútua Escolar Blanquerna', a school founded in Barcelona in 1923, after the Graduate School of the Community was dissolved. At the same time, the Monturiol and Elisenda academies were created.

carrer.name: Blasco de Garay, Carrer de
carrer.descripcio: (XVI century - 1552). Nobleman from Toledo, mechanics enthusiast, presenting the Emperor Charles V with several mechanical artifacts, the most interesting being the shovel wheels to substitute the oars on ships.

carrer.name: Blesa, Carrer de
carrer.descripcio: Josep Blesa i Babiloni (Soneja, Alt Palància, 1822 - Barcelona, 1871). Bleacher. He got the property of the lands in 1865, when Josep Sabat i Carreras decided to make over to him the possessions formerly owned by Francesc Xavier de Duran i Descatllar.

carrer.name: Boada, Carrer de
carrer.descripcio: Joan Boada i Mauri (Barcelona, 1848 - 1922). Owner. He bought lands at La Magarola, at a place called "Vasal del Botxí", near the Can Vélez torrent.

carrer.name: Bòbila, Carrer de la
carrer.descripcio: Named after a textile mill located in this street some time ago.
carrer.anteriors: Teodoro Bonaplata; Bòvila, before 1900; Fontova (a section), before 1900

carrer.name: Bocabella, Passatge de
carrer.descripcio: Passageway named after Josep M. Bocabella i Verdaguer (Barcelona, 1815 - Barcelona, 1892). Bookseller. He gave great impulse to the initiation of the 'Sagrada Familia' temple. Founder of the spiritual association devoted to Saint Joseph.

carrer.name: Bofarull, Carrer dels
carrer.descripcio: In 1980, the Town Hall wished to honor this family of archivists and historians original from Reus, the most eminent members of which were: Antoni de Bofarull i de Brocà (Reus, Baix Camp, 1821 - Barcelona, 1892), historian, poet, novelist and playwright; Manuel de Bofarull i de Sartorio (Barcelona, 1816 - 1892), archivist and historian; Pròsper de Bofarull i Mascaró (Reus, Baix Camp, 1777 - Barcelona, 1859), archivist and historian.

carrer.name: Bofarull, Passatge de
carrer.descripcio: Passageway named after the street nearby.

carrer.name: Bofill, Passatge de
carrer.descripcio: Passageway named after Jaume Bofill i Garriga, carter, married to Josepa Serra i Rosés, owner of the lands, who inherited them in 1846 from her aunt Isabel Dulcet i Serra, together with her brother Manuel.

carrer.name: Bogatell, Espigó del
carrer.descripcio: Breakwater named after a former torrent, now an irrigation ditch.

carrer.name: Bogatell, Platja del
carrer.descripcio: Beach named after the ancient name of the place.

carrer.name: Bogatell, Avinguda del
carrer.descripcio: Avenue named after a former torrent near Vilapicina, mentioned in a document dating from 1210.

carrer.name: Bohemis, Carrer dels
carrer.descripcio: Street named after the zarzuela (operetta) 'Bohemios', by Amadeu Vives (1904), set in the XIX century.

carrer.name: Boix, Carrer del
carrer.descripcio: Street named after the boxwood, within a street group named after trees and bushes.

carrer.name: Bolívar, Carrer de
carrer.descripcio: Simon Bolívar Palacios, 'The Liberator' (Caracas, Venezuela, 1783 - San Pedro Alejandrino, near Santa Marta, Colombia 1830). South American military and politician, born in a family of Basque origin established in America since the end of the XVI century. His vocation was to serve in arms. He traveled to Europe, where he lived in Madrid, Paris, and Rome. Back in Venezuela, in 1810 he organized, together with other independentist patriots, the Movement for the Liberation of Venezuela and of all the other South American countries.

carrer.name: Bolívia, Carrer de
carrer.descripcio: Country in the Andes, in South America. Originally belonging to High Peru, after its liberation from Spain in 1825, the country was first named 'República Bolívar' in honor of "'The Liberator'", but finally the name was changed to Bolivia, this time definitively.
carrer.anteriors: Ausias March (2nd section), before 1900; Lletra P (Cerdà plan)

carrer.name: Boltres, Carrer d'en
carrer.descripcio: Boltres, or Voltres, was the family name of the people who owned the lands around the XIV century. There is a title deed dating from 1316, where a certain Guillem Voltres is mentioned as the landowner.

carrer.name: Bon Pastor, Carrer del
carrer.descripcio: Named after the Cloister of the Sisters of the Good Shepherd (Bon Pastor) that existed in this street.

carrer.name: Bonaire, Carrer del
carrer.descripcio: Street named after Our Lady of Bonaria, patroness of Cagliari, town in Sardinia, with which Barcelona maintained good relationship by sea.

carrer.name: Bonanova, Passeig de la
carrer.descripcio: Avenue leading to the square with the same name.
carrer.anteriors: Enrico Malatesta,1937,Conde de Llar (joined to it); Ntra. Sra. de la Bonanova, 25/10/1922 (joined to it); Ctra. de Cornellà to Fogars de Tordera (joined to it); De Sarrià to la Bonanova, 29/06/1930 (joined to it); Pedro Juan de Sarrià; Doctor Robert; Font

carrer.name: Bonanova, Plaça de la
carrer.descripcio: Square named after the primitive church dedicated to the Saint Martyrs Gervasius and Protasius, which had a lateral altar dedicated to the Virgin of Bonanova (which means Good News). As the city expanded and grew in population, it was necessary to build a new, larger church. Its construction works began in 1847. After being destroyed in 1936, the construction of the present church started in 1939.

carrer.name: Bonaplata, Carrer de
carrer.descripcio: Salvador Bonaplata i Curriol (? - 1855). Local manufacturer and landowner, followed by his son and heir Ramon Bonaplata i Nadal. The nomenclature of 1980 dedicated this street to Josep Bonaplata (Sallent, Bages ? - Barcelona, 1839). Manufacturer who installed the factory called El Vapor, the first one using steam in the Catalan Countries and on the Iberian Peninsula.
carrer.anteriors: Barcelona, before 1888; Arrieta (Town Hall of Sarrià)

carrer.name: Bonaventura Pollés, Carrer de
carrer.descripcio: Bonaventura Pollés i Vivó (Barcelona, 1857 - Seville, 1919). Architect with important works at Vilanova i la Geltrú (Garraf), the place where his family was from, as well as in Barcelona. Great traveler and eminent watercolorist, part of his works remains at the Superior School of Architecture of Barcelona.

carrer.name: Bonavista, Carrer de
carrer.descripcio: This name is due to the panoramic views over the city of Barcelona this street offered when it was opened (2nd third of the XIX century).

carrer.name: Bonavista, Passatge de
carrer.descripcio: Passageway so named for the views from Vallvidrera.

carrer.name: Boné, Passatge de
carrer.descripcio: Passageway named after Manuel Boné i Boné (Nogueroles, Teruel, 1861 - Elche, Baix Vinalopó, 1937). Sackcloth manufacturer. Owner of the lands where it was opened, near a place called Lligalbé (place-name mentioned in documents dating back to 1128). He is buried in Barcelona, in Les Corts cemetery.

carrer.name: Bonet i Muixí, Plaça de
carrer.descripcio: Square named after Manuel Bonet i Muixí (Barcelona, 1913 - Rome, 1969). Ecclesiast. Doctor in Civil and Canonical Law, Bachelor of Theology, professor at the Seminary of Barcelona and at the Pontifical University of Salamanca. Auditor of the Roman Rota. He worked for the Vatican Council II, spokesman of the council spirit in Catalonia.

carrer.name: Bonsoms, Carrer de
carrer.descripcio: Isidre Bonsoms i Sicart (Barcelona, 1849 - Valldemossa, Occidental Majorca, 1922). Bibliophile. Cervantist. He left his collection of Cervantes' works to the Institute for Catalan Studies. He lived in Berlin, Vienna, Paris, and London. Member of the Academy of Fine Letters since 1907.

carrer.name: Bonsuccés, Carrer del
carrer.descripcio: Street named the same as the the square it runs into.

carrer.name: Bonsuccés, Plaça del
carrer.descripcio: Square named after the church dedicated to Our Lady of Good Success, with the annexed convent, formerly belonging to the Servite monks, established in Barcelona in 1576, who built the convent and the church in 1635. In 1835, it became a shelter for disabled people, later a military hospital and infantry quarters.

carrer.name: Bonveí, Carrer de
carrer.descripcio: Jaume Bonvehí Marí (Sants, Barcelona, 1852 - 1930). Farmer. Owner and promoter who bought real estate along the Riera Blanca.

carrer.name: Boquer, Carrer d'en
carrer.descripcio: It is known that Pere Boquer had his house here in the XIV century, but he also owned other sites and real estate in this street.

carrer.name: Boqueria, Carrer de la
carrer.descripcio: The chronicler Pujades ('Crónica universal de Catalunya') thinks that this is the corrupt name of 'bocaria' (mouth). Opposite the old Santa Eulàlia gate, Ramon Berenguer IV installed the gates of Almeria, booty of the conquest. People stood around looking at them in admiration, with their mouths wide open, this being the meaning of the verb' bocava'.

carrer.name: Boqueria, Pla de la
carrer.descripcio: Also called Pla de l'Os. The market named Boqueria was inaugurated in 1840.

carrer.name: Borbó, Avinguda de
carrer.descripcio: Ducal family that has given sovereigns to the royal houses of France, Spain, Two Sicilies, the Dukedom of Parma and the Great Dukedom of Luxembourg.
carrer.anteriors: Borbón; Paseo del Mariscal Joffre; Borbón; Cº Antiguo de San Acisclo

carrer.name: Bordeta, Carretera de la
carrer.descripcio: Street of a quarter built around the royal path that led from Creu Coberta to Hospitalet, at a place where already in the XVI century there was an old inn between the path and the Riera Blanca, which, according to legend, was called "Hostal de la Bordeta" since one of the inn owners decided to adopt a foundling.

carrer.name: Bordeus, Carrer de
carrer.descripcio: Named after Bordeaux, Town in Gascogne, France. The street was given this name because the Congregation of the Holy Family of Bordeaux, founded by Pierre Bienvenu Noailles, born in that city, had its domicile there. The local streets named Loreto and Rita Bonnat are related with Bordeaux street, the first because of the Our Lady of Loreto school pertaining to this Congregation, the second because Rita Bonnat was a nun of this Congregation.

carrer.name: Bordils, Carrer de
carrer.descripcio: Borough of Gironès. Street within the Ramon Albó housing estate, at Turó de la Peira, where streets are named after Catalan villages and towns.

carrer.name: Borges Blanques, Carrer de les
carrer.descripcio: Street originally dedicated to Ramon Borjas Donat, who lived here and had a bar in this street in 1931.

carrer.name: Borgonya, Carrer de
carrer.descripcio: Street named after the French region of Burgundy, in a group of streets named Alsàcia (Alsace), Lorena (Lorraine) and Marne.

carrer.name: Bori, Passatge de
carrer.descripcio: Literally 'Borri'. Passageway named after Josep Borri i Viñas and Antoni Borri i Sabater, bleachers who bought the lands in 1874, selling them in 1891. The correct etymological form is 'bori'.

carrer.name: Bori i Fontestà, Carrer de
carrer.descripcio: Antoni Bori i Fontestà (Badalona, Barcelonès, 1862 - 1912). Writer and teacher. His patriotic and regional poems achieved great popularity and won many awards.

carrer.name: Bòria, Carrer de la
carrer.descripcio: Etymologically this name comes from an ancient Roman name, 'forum bovarium', the place where cattle was kept outside the city walls. Later, a tower called "de la boieria" was built at this place, name which later changed to "boeria", and finally to "bòria". So, "bòria" means the place where cattle is sheltered at the outskirts, or in this case, outside the city wall.

carrer.name: Born, Passeig del
carrer.descripcio: Avenue named after the verb 'bornar' (to celebrate tournaments), so this was the place where tournaments were celebrated. This place was specially important in the life of Barcelona from the XIII to the XVII century, because not only tournaments, but also jousts, popular feasts, processions, and other public events were celebrated here.
carrer.anteriors: Borne; Pl. del Born; Pl. Mayor

carrer.name: Borràs, Carrer de
carrer.descripcio: Pere Borràs Trinxant (1876 - 1955), landowner. He bought the lands in 1879 from Àgata de Martorell i Fivaller, Marquess of Lapilla, heiress of the Duke of Almenara Alta. The street was known as "de la casa d'en Borràs".

carrer.name: Borràs, Plaça de
carrer.descripcio: Square named after Joaquim Maria de Borràs i Rodríguez (Barcelona, 1794 - 1855). Infantry Lieutnant-Colonel, owner of the lands he inherited in 1832. Married to Clotilde Sixto i Lorente, he had a daughter, Palmira Borràs i Sixto. This streetname dates from 1857, when the land was urbanized.

carrer.name: Borrell, Passatge de
carrer.descripcio: Passageway named after Florenci Borrell i Valls, broker, married to Francesca Sensat i Olivé, owner of the lands until 1923.

carrer.name: Borrell i Soler, Carrer de
carrer.descripcio: Antoni Borrell i Soler (Barcelona, 1864 - 1956). Lawyer and jurist. Specialist in Catalan civil law, which he taught at the University. In 1907 he was elected President of the Academy of Jurisprudence, and in 1934, Magistrate of the Court of Cassation of Catalonia.

carrer.name: Borriana, Carrer de
carrer.descripcio: Street named after a borough of Plana Baixa.

carrer.name: Bosc, Carrer del
carrer.descripcio: The name refers to the woods in general, that can be seen not far from this place at the foot of Vallvidrera.

carrer.name: Boscà, Camí
carrer.descripcio: Name that refers to the geographic situation of this path within the township of Barcelona.

carrer.name: Bosch, Carrer de
carrer.descripcio: Francesc d'Assís Bosch i Termes (1760 - 1837) was the owner of this property, which his son Miquel Bosch i Pinell (1798 - 1867) inherited in 1864, and later his grandson Francesc d'Assís Bosch i Fernàndez.

carrer.name: Bosch i Alsina, Carrer de
carrer.descripcio: Ròmul Bosch i Alsina (Calella, Maresme, 1852 - Barcelona, 1923) Politician and ship-owner. Deputy, Senator, and finally Mayor of Barcelona (1905). He was one of the founders of Pinillos Navigation Company, and Crèdit i Docks. He started the enlargement works of the port of Barcelona.

carrer.name: Bosch i Alsina, Moll de
carrer.descripcio: Known as "moll de la fusta" (pier of the wood), as large amounts of imported wood were stored in the open air during many years at this place. This pier is named after Ròmul Bosch i Alsina (Calella, Maresme, 1852 - Barcelona, 1923). Politician and ship-owner. As President of the Board of Works for the Port of Barcelona (1900), he started the enlargement and modernization works. Deputy, Senator, and Mayor of Barcelona in 1905.

carrer.name: Bosch i Gimpera, Carrer de
carrer.descripcio: Pere Bosch i Gimpera (Barcelona, 1891 - 1974). Archaeologist and paleontologist of international prestige. Rector of the University of Barcelona. Specialist in classical philology, especially in Greek. He was chief of the Division of Philosophy and Humanities at the UNESCO in Paris.

carrer.name: Bosch i Labrús, Passatge de
carrer.descripcio: Passageway named after Pere Bosch i Labrús (Besalú, Garrotxa, 1827 - Barcelona, 1894). Lawyer. Merchant. Supporter of the Catalan economic protectionism.

carrer.name: Bosquet dels Encants, Jardins del
carrer.descripcio: These gardens, situated between the Meridiana avenue, Castillejos, the Gloria Catalana square, and the Gran Via de les Corts Catalanes, were named 'Bosquet dels Encants' (small fairy wood) by the jury invited to the Spring Feast celebrated on March 21, 1995.

carrer.name: Boston, Plaça de
carrer.descripcio: Square named after Boston, the capital of Massachusetts, USA.

carrer.name: Bot, Carrer d'en
carrer.descripcio: This street already appears with this name in documents dating back to 1484. Most probably named after a family owning properties at this place.

carrer.name: Botella, Carrer d'en
carrer.descripcio: Named after a Catalan family. In documents dating back to the XIV century appear a certain Bernat Botella, market gardener (1373), and a Ramon Botella (1403).

carrer.name: Boters, Carrer dels
carrer.descripcio: The coopers guild, whose first ordinances date as far back as 1441, already had its guild house here in 1448.

carrer.name: Botticelli, Plaça de
