carrer.descripcio: Square named after Alessandro de Mariano Filipepi, known as Sandro Botticelli (Florence, Italy, 1445 - 1510). Italian painter. He was part of the team who painted the Sixtine Chapel. Among his best-known paintings were 'The Spring' and 'The Birth of Venus'. Towards 1490 he started to illustrate Dante's 'Divina Comedia'.

carrer.name: Bou de Sant Pere, Carrer del
carrer.descripcio: Long time ago, there used to be two streets called Bou in the old city, both named after a distinguished aristocratic Catalan family from Ullastret (Baix Empordà), which gave glorious public celebrities to the city. In the XV century, there is notice of Joan Bou, merchant (1445); Bartomeu Bou, merchant (1411); Bonanat Bou (1405), and Guillem Bou, tailor (1431).

carrer.name: Boyeros, Plaça de
carrer.descripcio: Square named after the International Agropecuary Park of Rancho Boyeros, at La Habana, Cuba, situated about 30 minutes from the center of La Habana, and about 10 minutes from the International Airport José Martí.

carrer.name: Bràfim, Carrer de
carrer.descripcio: Borough of Alt Camp, at the right side of the Gaià. This place-name of Arab origin (until 1570 known as 'Abràfim'). Traditionally a village dedicated to agriculture, though there is written notice about the presence of cloth combers since the XV century.

carrer.name: Bragança, Carrer de
carrer.descripcio: Street named after this Portuguese town, together with other streets as Lisboa (Lisbon) and Lusitània, the latter non-existing at present.

carrer.name: Brasil, Rambla del
carrer.descripcio: Promenade named after this South American country.
carrer.anteriors: 07/03/1939 (calle); Joaquin Dicenta; Núm. 11 (map of Les Corts); Marquès del Duero; Rector

carrer.name: Breda, Carrer de
carrer.descripcio: Borough of La Selva, near the Montseny massif. Famous for its Romanesque monastery.

carrer.name: Bretón de los Herreros, Carrer de
carrer.descripcio: Manuel Bretón de los Herreros (Logroño, 1795 - Madrid, 1873). Castilian writer, poet, theater critic. Member of he Academy of Language since 1837. Director of the 'Gaceta' (1843) and of the National Library (1847).

carrer.name: Briquets, Carrer de
carrer.descripcio: Eulàlia Briquets i Ventura (Parets del Vallès, Vallès Oriental, 1886 - Barcelona, 1963). Owner of the lands, wife of Josep Llovera i Sampons, merchant of L'Hospitalet.

carrer.name: Briz, Baixada de
carrer.descripcio: Francesc Pelagi Briz i Fernàndez (Barcelona 1839 - 1889). Romantic writer, editor and folklorist. He lived in this place.

carrer.name: Brocaters, Carrer dels
carrer.descripcio: Named after the brocade makers. Originally, the street name was Broquerers, referring to shield makers (who used to make small, convex, normally leather-lined wood shields). Old brocade makers established at this place, governed by an ordinance dating from the end of the XIV century.

carrer.name: Bronze, Carrer del
carrer.descripcio: Alloy of copper and tin. Street located in an area where most streets are named after metals and metallurgical tools.

carrer.name: Brosolí, Carrer del
carrer.descripcio: Street named after the thread used to tie fishing hooks, probably an article sold in a shop in this street. Nonetheless, there is a document issued during the First Dictatorship ordering to change the name of this street into "calle de Brosoli", i.e. translate it into Spanish. Thus, 'Brósoli' or 'Brosolí' would have been the name of a neighbor who lived in this street, or of somebody related with it.

carrer.name: Brossa, Carrer de
carrer.descripcio: Marià Brossa i Arnó (Sant Andreu, 1831 - 1881). Pedagogue and journalist. Mayor of Sant Andreu in 1869.

carrer.name: Bruc, Carrer del
carrer.descripcio: Street dedicated to Bruc, borough of L'Anoia, in memory of the events occurred at the beginning of the Independence War. A battle took place on June 6, 1808 at a pass near the Bruc, and a second battle on June 14, 1808. An inscription of a monument in memory of those events: "Caminante, para aquí, que el francés aquí paró, y el que por todo pasó no pudo pasar de aquí." (Wayfarer, here the French had to stop, and those who passed everywhere could not go on from here).

carrer.name: Bruc, Costa del
carrer.descripcio: Named after the heather bush. Some kinds of heather wood are used to make artisan pipes.

carrer.name: Brugada, Plaça de
carrer.descripcio: Joan Brugada i Vaquerisses (1859 - 1908). He left all his possessions to the Town Hall of Barcelona to build schools.

carrer.name: Bruguera, Carrer de
carrer.descripcio: Village belonging to the borough of Ribes de Freser (Ripollès). Street within Ramon Albó housing estate, at Turó of the Peira, where streets are named after towns and villages of Catalonia.

carrer.name: Brull, Carrer del
carrer.descripcio: Borough of Osona. Street at Torre Baró, where many streets are named after places in Catalonia.

carrer.name: Brull, Passatge del
carrer.descripcio: Passageway belonging to the same neighborhood as the street it runs into.

carrer.name: Bruniquer, Carrer de
carrer.descripcio: Esteve Gilabert Bruniquer i Riera (Granollers, Vallès Oriental, 1561 - Barcelona, 1641). Notary Public. Syndic in Barcelona.

carrer.name: Brusi, Carrer de
carrer.descripcio: Named after a family of printers, who were publishing the newspaper 'Diario' 'de Barcelona', doyen of the Spanish press, founded by Husson de Lapezaran in 1792.Antoni Brusi i Mirabent (Barcelona, 1775 - 1821), printer and bookseller, was the first in publishing the daily in 1814; Antoni Brusi i Ferrer (Barcelona, 1815 - 1878), owner and director of the daily, First Marquis of Casa Brusi, nobility title conferred by Alfonso XII in 1875, is the person first thought when dedicating the street; Antoni Maria Brusi i Mataró (Barcelona, 1846 - Sant Gervasi de Cassoles, Barcelona, 1887), Second Marquis of Casa Brusi, owner and editor of 'Diario de Barcelona'.

carrer.name: Brussel·les, Carrer de
carrer.descripcio: Street named after Brussels, capital of Belgium and of the province of Brabant, near the Senne river and the Anvers-Charleroi channel.

carrer.name: Budapest, Carrer de
carrer.descripcio: Capital of Hungary, and of the County of Pest.

carrer.name: Buenaventura Durruti, Plaça de
carrer.descripcio: Square named after Buenaventura Durruti Dumange (León, 1896 - Madrid, 1936). Anarchist leader. A learned mechanic, he started his activities as unionist at the 'Unión de Metalúrgicos' in 1912. Member of CNT-FAI, great activist, he died heading his column at the gates of Madrid.

carrer.name: Buenaventura Muñoz, Carrer de
carrer.descripcio: Buenaventura Muñoz y Rodríguez (Toledo, 1853 - ?). Magistrate and politician. President of the High Court of Barcelona.

carrer.name: Buenos Aires, Carrer de
carrer.descripcio: Named after the Capital of Argentina. Street within the group of streets in the Eixample named after Capital Cities, such as London and Paris.

carrer.name: Buïgas, Carrer de
carrer.descripcio: Josep Buïgas i Gauran (Barcelona 1805 - 1877). Owner of the lands around the place formerly known as "Torre de Sant Sever", and later as "Torre Gironella". He bought them from Antoni de Gironella, landowner, in 1850.

carrer.name: Bunyola, Carrer de
carrer.descripcio: Borough of Occidental Majorca. Street within the group of streets at Vilapicina named after villages and places in Majorca: Felanitx, Valldemossa, Formentor, Alcúdia, etc.

carrer.name: Burgos, Carrer de
carrer.descripcio: Named after the town and province of the region of Castile-León, consisting of five natural areas: El Páramo, La Bureba, La Ribera, La Sierra and Zona Norte, further to the County of Treviño.

carrer.name: Burrull, Passatge de
carrer.descripcio: Passageway named after Tomàs Borrull i Fita (Barcelona, 1807 - 1857). Farmer, married to Maria Casamitjana, owner of the lands that were formerly the property of the Marchioness of Mojà i de Cartellà. The name of this family appears both as Borrull or Burrull, a variant of Borrell.

carrer.name: Buscarons, Carrer de
carrer.descripcio: Gervasi Buscarons i Anglada, farmer who died in 1859, owner of the lands and house at the place known as "can Tut", which had formerly belonged to the estate Manso Vendrell. Married to Josepa Duran. The old Buscarons house, which was still there at the beginning of the XX century, was one of those lonesome houses which inspired the denomination of Cassoles, which were added to Sant Gervasi (etymology uncertain).

carrer.name: Buxó, Carrer de
carrer.descripcio: Originally dedicated to Francesc Buxó i Oliana, who bought the surrounding lands, which had belonged to the estate Torre de Santa Caterina, of the former Convent of the Dominican Fathers, from the State in 1842. The nomenclature of 1980 ignores this circumstance, and considers the street named after Narcís Buxó i Prats. Republican politician. Mayor of Barcelona in 1873.

carrer.name: C, Carrer
carrer.descripcio: With few exceptions, streets within the Consortium of Barcelona's Zona Franca designated with letters run in the North-South direction, while streets designated with numbers run in the East-West direction.

carrer.name: Ca dels Seguers, Passatge de
carrer.descripcio: Passageway named after a manor house, converted into a wax bleachery in the XVIII century. This is where the name comes from, as "'seguers'" means beehives, of which the bees have swarmed out to the wild, and there were many beehives stored.

carrer.name: Ca l'Alegre, Carrer de
carrer.descripcio: Named after the manor house there had been in the XVIII century, but was demolished in 1907, when the Travessera de Dalt was urbanized.

carrer.name: Ca l'Alegre de Dalt, Carrer de
carrer.descripcio: Named after the manor house (XVIII century).

carrer.name: Ca l'Alena, Jardins de
carrer.descripcio: The gardens in the Mare de Déu de Port Street are named after the factory that had been where now the Compañía Anónima de Productos Africanos, CAPA (Anonymous Company of African Products) has its housing estate. Though this is the name written with big cement letters on the door of this company, popularly everybody knew the place as "ca l'Alena", which was its old name, made up by the last letter of each word: Compañía Nacional de Colonización Africana, ALENA (National Company for African Colonization).

carrer.name: Ca l'Aranyó, Jardins de
carrer.descripcio: Gardens named after a former textile factory called "ca l'Aranyó ", founded in 1878 by the English company Prince Smith and Son, from Keighley. It is one of the most interesting industrial buildings in town, which follows the factory building model or Manchester style.

carrer.name: Ca l'Iglésies, Carreró de
carrer.descripcio: Named after the farmers' family that used to live at this place in a farmhouse surrounded by the annexed lands.

carrer.name: Ca l'Isidret, Camí de
carrer.descripcio: Path along an irrigation channel named the same, after an old place-name of Poblenou.

carrer.name: Ca n'Altimira, Jardins de
carrer.descripcio: Gardens bearing the name of the manor house, which was named after Josep Altimira i Reniu (Barcelona, 1822-1898), owner of the estate since 1867, when he bought it from Carmen Dalmases, Pere Màrtir Fortuny, and Pau Ganduxer i Aymerich.

carrer.name: Ca n'Ensenya, Plaça de
carrer.descripcio: Square named after the house owners.

carrer.name: Ca n'Oliva, Carrer de
carrer.descripcio: Belongs to a place called "camp de la Mata", formerly "Arriassa", a field of two 'mujadas' (approx. 13,000 m2) irrigated by waters from the Comtal irrigation channel. This field, together with others, was surrendered to Joan Vicenç Cellarés by Brother Gaspar Despares, monk and Chamberlain of the Monastery of Ripoll, in a document signed in favor of Cellarés by Bernat Oliva, Canon and Administrator of the Casa de Caritat (House of Charity) of the Cathedral of Barcelona, in 1590. The heir was Josep Oliver Cellarés i Natalí. The street was named after Ramon Oliva i Bogunyà, owner of "Casa Llarga" and gardener of the Ciudadella park.

carrer.name: Ca n'Oliva, Passatge de
carrer.descripcio: Passageway named after the same person as Ca n'Oliva street.

carrer.name: Caba, Plaça de
carrer.descripcio: Square named after Antoni Caba i Casamitjana (Barcelona, 1838 - 1907). Painter. Professor and Director of the School of Fine Arts.
carrer.anteriors: Ptge. de Caba, 29/03/1922; Ptge. de Santa Eulàlia, 21/06/1862

carrer.name: Caballero, Carrer de
carrer.descripcio: Dolors Caballero i Rasco (1844 - 1886), wife of Joaquim de Mercader i de Belloch, Count of Bell-lloc, owner of the lands.

carrer.name: Cabanelles, Carrer de
carrer.descripcio: Borough of Alt Empordà. Street within Ramon Albó housing estate, where streets are named after towns and villages of Catalonia.

carrer.name: Cabanes, Carrer de
carrer.descripcio: Family of owners from Poble-sec. In 1799, Pere Cabanas i Ferreras bought some land around this place from Pere Orri i Llosellas, inherited by his only son, Pere Cabanas i Nadal, whose heir was Ramon Cabanas i Figueras, his son from his first wife. With his second wife, Anna Gruart i Queralt, he had two sons, Manuel and Pere Cabanas. Ramon Cabanas had two children and heirs, Dolors and Bonaventura Cabanas i Bressiano. The street is considered to be dedicated to the grandfather, Pere Cabanas i Ferreras.

carrer.name: Cabanyal, Carrer del
carrer.descripcio: Named after a coastal district of Valencia.

carrer.name: Cabestany, Carrer de
carrer.descripcio: Guillem de Cabestany (Roussillon, 1162 - 1212?). Catalan troubadour in Provençal language. Provençal biographies attribute to him the legend, that he was in love with Saurimonda, wife of Ramon de Castellrosselló. The furious husband killed the troubadour and gave his heart to eat to Saurimonda, who committed suicide when she knew it.

carrer.name: Cabrera, Carrer de
carrer.descripcio: Guerau de Cabrera (XII century). Noble troubadour, Viscount of Girona and of Àger. He, together with Guillem de Berguedà and Guillem de Cabestany, were the three greatest Catalan troubadours in Provençal language.

carrer.name: Cabres, Carrer de les
carrer.descripcio: A very old popular name, derived from the goat shelters there used to be in this place since the XV century.

carrer.name: Caçador, Baixada de
carrer.descripcio: Illustrious Catalan family, whose most eminent members were: Guillem Caçador (Vic, Osona, 1477 - Rome, 1527), Canon of Vic and Bishop of Algheró (Sardinia); Jaume Caçador, brother of the former (Vic, Osona, 1484 - Barcelona, 1561), Canon of Vic and Bishop of Barcelona (1546-1561); Guillem Caçador (Vic, Osona, 1510 - Barcelona, 1570), nephew of the former, also Bishop of Barcelona (1561-1570); Joan Caçador, Bishop and writer, cousin of the former.

carrer.name: Caçador, Rambla del
carrer.descripcio: Around this boulevard, all streets are named after protected animals, so the hunter (caçador) will have little to hunt.

carrer.name: Càceres, Carrer de
carrer.descripcio: Cáceres, capital and very large province of Extremadura, whose main regions are: Las Hurdes, La Vera, Las Villuercas and the Valley of Plasencia.

carrer.name: Cadaqués, Carrer de
carrer.descripcio: Street named after a borough of Alt Empordà, the same as Portbou street.

carrer.name: Cadena, Camí de la
carrer.descripcio: A path crossing the railroad to Baix Llobregat; the railroad crossing used to be protected with a chain.

carrer.name: Cadernera, Passatge de la
carrer.descripcio: Passageway named after the goldfinch, near another street and passageway also named after a bird, Passerell.

carrer.name: Cadí, Carrer del
carrer.descripcio: Mountain chain in the lower Catalan Pre-Pyrenees. In the Turó de la Peira neighborhood, where there are many streets named after mountains and peaks.

carrer.name: Cadis, Carrer de
carrer.descripcio: Capital of the Cádiz province (the town known by the Romans as 'Gades', main port of Bética), in Western Andalusia. The Parliament of Cádiz approved the first Spanish Constitution in 1812.

carrer.name: Cai Celi, Carrer de
carrer.descripcio: Duumvir of 'Barcino' in the I century b.Ch. A memorial tablet in his memory, found at Montjuïc, proves that there was a first 'Barcino' at the foot of the mountain.

carrer.name: Caire, Carrer del
carrer.descripcio: Capital of Egypt.

carrer.name: Caixa d'Estalvis, Passatge de la
carrer.descripcio: Passageway opened on land belonging to La Caixa when the first houses were built.

carrer.name: Cal Notari, Camí de
carrer.descripcio: Path leading to the country house at the beginning of the road to Horta, named after the profession of a former owner, who was a notary. In the beginning of the XX century, the property passed on to Francesc Galimany, farmer.

carrer.name: Cal Notari, Torrent de
carrer.descripcio: Torrent named the same as the country house.

carrer.name: Cal Sèbio, Jardins de
carrer.descripcio: Gardens so named in memory of the rural past of the Marina neighborhood and of the farm that was at this place, where still now a palm tree can be seen, planted by the family living in that farm. Urban area situated between Foc street and Mare de Déu de Port street.

carrer.name: Cal Totxo, Camí de
carrer.descripcio: Path named after the house owner's nickname, in the Vallvidrera area.

carrer.name: Calàbria, Carrer de
carrer.descripcio: Region of Southern Italy. Street named Calabria in memory of the historic expansion of Catalonia and Aragon over the Mediterranean.

carrer.name: Calaf, Carrer de
carrer.descripcio: Borough of La Anoia.
carrer.anteriors: Conca de Barbará (joined to it), 05/09/1907; Cortés, 19/08/1868; Fortuny, 27/09/1876

carrer.name: Calafell, Passatge de
carrer.descripcio: Passageway named after Jaume Calafell i Rovira (1861 - 1937). Mason. The property of the lands formerly belonging to the Manso Grau estate were surrendered to him by Alexandre de Bacardí i Janer.

carrer.name: Calàndries, Carrer de les
carrer.descripcio: So named in memory of a shepherd and woodcutter who lived in this street before, and who used to raise calandria larks and teach them to sing.
carrer.anteriors: Ubach y Viñeta; Calàndrias; Ubach y Viñeta (Town Hall of Sarrià); Federico Soler; Calàndrias, before 1888

carrer.name: Calatrava, Carrer de
carrer.descripcio: Named after the Military Order of Calatrava, founded in 1158 by the Abbot of Fiteró, Ramon Serrat, adopting the Cistercian Rule. The Order was integrated into the Catalan-Aragonese Crown by Alfons I 'el Cast', who had asked the monks for help when trying to conquer the Matarraña area. In compensation, a great part of the conquered territory, including the important town of Alcañíz, was surrendered to the Order in 1180.
carrer.anteriors: Bernat de Sarrià; Calatrava; Bernat de Sarrià (Town Hall of Sarrià); Comercio

carrer.name: Calderón de la Barca, Carrer de
carrer.descripcio: Pedro Calderón de la Barca (Madrid, 1600 - 1681). Priest invested with the habit of Santiago (Saint James), and a world-famous classic Castilian playwright and writer at the Court.

carrer.name: Calders, Carrer de
carrer.descripcio: Named after an old noble Catalan family, Earls of Segur and Pierola. An eminent member of this family was Lluís Joan de Calders, Chief Councilor of Barcelona in 1639.

carrer.name: Calella, Carrer de
carrer.descripcio: Borough of Maresme. The expanding overseas trade with America in the XVIII century gave rise to the textile and spinning industry. Until the first half of the XX century, Calella was one of the leading Catalan textile centers.

carrer.name: Calendau, Carrer de
carrer.descripcio: Jaume Calendau (XVIII century). Administrator of the Barons de la Barre, and owner of the lands (by means of a cession by the Barons) where the street was opened.

carrer.name: Call, Carrer del
carrer.descripcio: In this street, the Jews used to buy and sell their goods. Main street of the old Jewish Neighborhood in the city, surrounded by the streets named Baixada de Santa Eulàlia, Banys Nous, Call, and Sant Honrat.

carrer.name: Callao, Carrer del
carrer.descripcio: Named after this Peruvian town, where in 1866 took place the act of arms of the same name, starting point of the Pacific War between Spain, Chile and Peru.

carrer.name: Càller, Carrer de
carrer.descripcio: Town in Sardinia. In the Middle Ages, this port, together with Algheró and the Sicilian ports of Palermo and Trapani, was one of the end points of the islands route, and one of the bases of Barcelona's overseas trade.

carrer.name: Calvell, Passeig de
carrer.descripcio: In 1831, Manuel d'Ibarra, General Bailiff and Administrator of the Royal Patrimony of Catalonia, surrendered some land around the place called "del Canyet" in favor of Jaume Calvell i Riera, deep-sea fisherman and manufacturer of fishing tackle, after whom this promenade is named. The latter made build a factory, which he made over in good faith to his brother, Joan Calvell i Riera (1804-1866), also manufacturer of fishing tackle. The saga continued with Jaume's son, Pau Calvell i Julià, his grandson Pau Calvell i Martí, and his grand-grandson Pau Calvell i Pàmies.

carrer.name: Calvet, Carrer de
carrer.descripcio: Maria del Remei Calvet i Sagrera (Barcelona, 1848 - 1927). Owner of the lands where the street was built, which she inherited from her husband Salvador Sagués i Quintana, who had bought the estate in 1871. Ignoring this fact, the nomenclator of 1980 dedicates this street to Damàs Calvet i de Budalles (Figueres, Alt Empordà, 1836 - Barcelona, 1891). Poet and romantic playwright. Teacher at Gaya Ciencia (1878). Usually, when the origin of a street name was unknown, it was attributed to celebrities that appeared in the Encyclopaedia.

carrer.name: Calvó, Plaça de
carrer.descripcio: Square named after Francesc Calvó i Brossa, proxy, administrator, testament executor of Consol de Moragas i de Quintana, Marchioness of Moragas, and of her daughter, Consol Vidal de Moragas, wife of Joaquim Jover i Costas, Marquis of Gelida, who were the owners of the lands when they were urbanized in the beginning of the XX century, when the street was opened.

carrer.name: Camarasa, Carrer de
carrer.descripcio: Borough of La Noguera. Street within Milans del Bosch housing estate, where streets are named after towns and villages of Catalonia.

carrer.name: Cama-sec, Camí del
carrer.descripcio: Path named after a mushroom with a cream-colored hat and rosy flesh when fresh, and paler when dry.

carrer.name: Cambrils, Carrer de
carrer.descripcio: Borough of Baix Camp, street so named in memory of the fact that in 1437, this town made a petition to be integrated into the city trough a procedure known as 'carreratge'. According to the terms of the petition, the inhabitants of the borough enjoyed the same rights and privileges as the inhabitants of the city. This is a major reason above any other, for giving the name of the street.

carrer.name: Camèlies, Carrer de les
carrer.descripcio: Street at Gràcia dedicated to the camellias, the plant giving the well-known exuberant flowers. This romantic name is probably a consequence of the romanticism that was in vogue when the street was opened.

carrer.name: Camèlies, Passatge de les
carrer.descripcio: Passageway of the camellias, so named because it runs into the street named the same.

carrer.name: Camí del Mas Sauró, Passatge del
carrer.descripcio: Passageway named after the farmhouse that used to be there.

carrer.name: Camil Fabra, Carrer de
carrer.descripcio: Camil Fabra i Fontanills (Barcelona, 1833 - 1902). First Marquis of Alella. Industrial y politician. Mayor of Barcelona (1893). In 1901, he financed the construction of the Fabra Observatory at the Tibidabo.
carrer.anteriors: Camilo Fabra; Inside Fabra i Coats factory

carrer.name: Camil Oliveras, Carrer de
carrer.descripcio: Camil Oliveras i Gensana (Figueres, Alt Empordà, 1840 - Barcelona, 1898). Master builder and architect. He belonged to the first generation of Catalan modernist architects. Author of the project for the Provincial Maternity Hospital at Les Corts de Sarrià.
carrer.anteriors: Camilo Oliveras; Arco de San Martín (a section), 04/02/1931

carrer.name: Camil Oliveras, Passatge de
carrer.descripcio: Originally known as Oliveras passageway, named after Josep and Marcià Oliveras i Casellas, who were the owners of the lands until 1925.

carrer.name: Caminal, Passatge del
carrer.descripcio: Passageway named so after the old path called "Pont de les vaques".

carrer.name: Camós, Carrer de
carrer.descripcio: Borough of Gironès. Street within Ramon Albó housing estate, at Turó de la Peira, where streets are named after towns and villages of Catalonia.

carrer.name: Camp, Carrer del
carrer.descripcio: Makes reference to the fields of Our Lady of the Conception Monastery, belonging to the Order of Discalced Carmelites, bought by Nicolau Sivilla i Girbau, sailmaker, citizen of Barcelona, on June 30, 1768. Josep Garriga i Llastanós (Vic, Osona, 1800 - Barcelona, 1877) bought approximately seven hectares from the Sivilla heirs, which he urbanized in 1874.

carrer.name: Camp, Passatge del
carrer.descripcio: Passageway leading out to some fields.

carrer.name: Camp, Plaça del
carrer.descripcio: Square named after the fields around the Monastery of the Carmelite nuns. When Josep Garriga i Llastanós (Vic, Osona, 1800 - Barcelona, 1877) was the owner of these fields, he promoted their urbanization. In the urbanization plan, the names of the former owners, Sivilla and Arimon, were maintained, adding the name of the new owner, Garriga (now Muntaner street), and Camp, in memory of the aforesaid fields. Finally, to satisfy the promoter's wishes, one of the streets at the field limits was called Babilònia (Babylon); the reason for this name is not quite clear.

carrer.name: Camp Arriassa, Carrer del
carrer.descripcio: Place formerly called "Arriassa", later known as "Camp de la Mata". In 1590, this field and others were surrendered in favor of Joan Vicenç Cellarés by brother Gaspar Despares, monk and Chamberlain of the Monastery of Ripoll, in a document signed in favor of Cellarés by Bernat Oliva, Canon and Administrator of the Charity House of the Cathedral of Barcelona, as well as by Jordi Peranton, Francesc Bofill and Pere Pau Caçador, Canons of the aforesaid Holy Church, Provosties of January and March, and by Jaume Cordellas and Joan Vila, Canons Protectors of the Provosty of August. The owners were Josep Antoni Oliver i Pagès, and his heir Josep Oliver Cellarés i Natalí in 1782. In the XIX century, finally the property went to Josep Mallart i Augé (Barcelona, 1829 - 1879).

carrer.name: Camp de Sarrià, Jardins del
carrer.descripcio: In this land belonging to the Can Balasc and Can Gironella property, a sports field known as the Camp de Sarrià was opened in 1923. It was also known as Can Ràbia, the name of an inn which had stood in the road that led from Sarrià to Barcelona, and after which a suburb was named.

carrer.name: Camp del Ferro, Carrer del
carrer.descripcio: Popular name of a site at Sagrera.

carrer.name: Camp d'en Vidal, Carrer del
carrer.descripcio: In 1856, Josep Jordà i Gelabert surrendered a part of the lands in favor of Rupert Santaló i Vinyals. Also Domènec Vidal i Balaguer was owner of lands, consisting of three sites higher up, in front of the house called "De Laforge". After his death, the property went to his minor sons, Domènec and Sebastià Vidal i Soler.

carrer.name: Campana de La Maquinista, Carrer de la
carrer.descripcio: In memory of the bell that used to announce the beginning of the working shifts at the La Maquinista factory at La Barceloneta. Street belonging to the shopping center, situated between Sâo Paulo street and the Potosí promenade, in Sant Andreu district.

carrer.name: Campana de La Maquinista, Jardins de la
carrer.descripcio: Gardens between the Ferran Junoy and Sâo Paulo streets, named after the bell that used to announce the beginning of the working shifts at the La Maquinista factory at La Barceloneta.

carrer.name: Campeny, Carrer de
carrer.descripcio: Named after Damià Campeny i Estrany (Mataró, Maresme, 1771 - Sant Gervasi, 1855). Sculpturer.

carrer.name: Campins, Carrer de
carrer.descripcio: Borough of Vallès Occidental. Street within Baró de Viver housing estate, where streets are named after towns and villages of Catalonia.

carrer.name: Campions, Plaça dels
carrer.descripcio: Square so named in memory of the champions of the Olympic Games.

carrer.name: Campo Florido, Carrer de
carrer.descripcio: Rural district of Guanabacos, La Habana (Cuba). So named by some Spanish emigrants (indianos) who returned from America after having made a fortune, lived in this district, and named all streets around after Caribbean towns (Pinar del Río, Manigua, Matanzas, Puerto Príncipe, Cienfuegos).

carrer.name: Campoamor, Carrer de
carrer.descripcio: Ramon de Campoamor i Campoosorio (Navia, Asturias, 1817 - Madrid, 1901). Postromantic poet. Politician of the Moderate Party. He was Governor of Valencia (1851), Deputy of the Spanish Parliament, General Director for Welfare and Health, and member of the Spanish Academy (1862).

carrer.name: Campreciós, Carrer de
carrer.descripcio: Miquel Campreciós i Albert (Barcelona, 1878 - 1953), manufacturer of chemical products, owner of a small ground at a place called "La Muntanya" or "Pedrera de Tardà" when the street received its name. In 1928, he sold part of his estate. He died in the house Number 28 of the street named after him.

carrer.name: Camprodon, Carrer de
carrer.descripcio: Borough of Ripollès, at the confluence of the rivers Ter and Ritort.

carrer.name: Camps Elisis, Passatge dels
carrer.descripcio: Passageway so named in memory of the extensive park of the same name, which had been built at this place in 1853, which included a fairground, a small lake, a stage for gymnastics and circus shows, and a racetrack dating from 1856.

carrer.name: Camps i Fabrés, Carrer de
carrer.descripcio: Antoni Camps i Fabrés (Manresa, Bages, 1822 - Barcelona, 1882). Textile manufacturer and romantic poet. Provincial Deputy for Manresa in 1871. He won a special award at the Floral Games, and the Natural Flower in 1861.
carrer.anteriors: Camps y Fabrés; Príncipe de Asturias

carrer.name: Can Balasc, Camí de
carrer.descripcio: Path named after a farm in the mountains within the borough of Barcelona.

carrer.name: Can Baró, Avinguda de
carrer.descripcio: Josep de la Barre i de Taberner, Baron de la Barre i de Pechman (? - 1855), had bought an extension of 71 and a half 'mujadas' (about 460,000 m2) of the estate Manso Falcó iCasa de la Farigola. His heir was Agustí de la Barre de Flandes i Díaz de Manso, diplomat in Rio de Janeiro. But it is thought that this avenue is named after Josep Pasqual de Taberner Pascali i Sampere, Baron of Sant Lluís, who also had been the owner.

carrer.name: Can Baró, Plaça de
carrer.descripcio: Square named after the Baron of Sant Lluís, Josep Pasqual de Taberner Pascali i Sampere.

carrer.name: Can Basseda, Carrer de
carrer.descripcio: Named after the country house, properly called Can Beceda.

carrer.name: Can Batllori, Jardins de
carrer.descripcio: Gardens named after a farmhouse there used to be at this place. This name should be preserved, as it is also the name of important Ibero-Roman archaeological vestiges found at this place.

carrer.name: Can Berdura, Passatge de
carrer.descripcio: Passageway named after an old country house called "Can Berdura". Josep Berdura i Sitjà, farmer, who died in 1843, was the owner of the house and of the lands located at a place called "Vilatrau". On request of the heirs, on June 14, 1991, the initial' v' was changed to 'b'.
carrer.anteriors: Can Verdura; Casa Verdura; Sin nombre (Casa Verdura residential area)

carrer.name: Can Besora, Escales de
carrer.descripcio: Stairs named after the farmhouse.

carrer.name: Can Borni, Camí de
carrer.descripcio: Path named after the local manor house, already mentioned by Mosén Clapés in 1843 as an old farm house.
carrer.anteriors: Casa Borni; Antiguo de San Cugat

carrer.name: Can Brasó, Jardins de
carrer.descripcio: Gardens named after an old family, established at Horta in 1708. The Brasó family members filled several posts in the Town Hall of Horta between 1736 and 1819. Can Brasó was a small, two stories high farmhouse near Can Rossell, between the road to Sant Cebrià and the Convent of Minimal nuns. The house disappeared when the housing blocks in the Vall d'Hebron park were built.

carrer.name: Can Bruixa, Carrer de
carrer.descripcio: Named after a house built in the middle of the XVIII century by Guerau Piera and Agnès Llopart, which was known by the owners' nickname. Josep Piera i Estruch gave the lands for the streets crossing his property for nothing, under the condition that the streets were named Can Bruixa and Can Novell.

carrer.name: Can Caralleu, Carrer de
carrer.descripcio: Named after the property.

carrer.name: Can Caralleu, Rotonda de
carrer.descripcio: A road space named after the ancient property that formerly existed where there now is a small urbanised area, situated between the Castell de l'Oreneta park and the Carretera de les Aigües.

carrer.name: Can Caralleu, Torrent de
carrer.descripcio: Torrent named after the property.

carrer.name: Can Castelló, Jardins de
carrer.descripcio: Gardens named after the house with 8 'mujadas' (about 50,000 m2) of land, bought by Josep Castelló-Galvany i Quadras in 1871.

carrer.name: Can Castellví, Carrer de
carrer.descripcio: Named after the manor house.

carrer.name: Can Castellví, Camí de
carrer.descripcio: Path named after an important manor house in the mountains within the township of Barcelona, near the road to Santa Creu d'Olorda.

carrer.name: Can Clos, Camí de
carrer.descripcio: Path named after the manor house to which it led.

carrer.name: Can Clos, Carrer de
carrer.descripcio: Named after the manor there was before the housing blocks were built.

carrer.name: Can Cuiàs, Jardins de
carrer.descripcio: Gardens named after a nearby estate called Can Cuiàs or Gasparó, formerly situated on the axis of the Travessera de les Corts.

carrer.name: Can Dragó, Plaça de
carrer.descripcio: Square at the confluence of the Santa Coloma promenade and the Meridiana and Rio de Janeiro avenues, named after a former manor house called Can Dragó.

carrer.name: Can Fabra, Plaça de
carrer.descripcio: Name by which the Fabra i Coats factory facing this square was popularly known.

carrer.name: Can Falgàs, Carrer de
carrer.descripcio: Street named after a house that existed in this place. This house had been built in the middle of the 19th century on grounds that belonged to Francesc Buxó i Oliana, owner of the property of the Torre de Santa Caterina, a land that belonged to the Dominican friars before the confiscation of church lands which took place in 1835.

carrer.name: Can Felipa, Plaça de
carrer.descripcio: Square named after the creator of one of the most important waterworks of Spain, Felipe Ferrando. The name of the waterworks, called "Can Felipe" after the first owner, degenerated into "Can Felipa", as the CATEX company was popularly known.

carrer.name: Can Ferrero, Jardins de
carrer.descripcio: Gardens named after Cal Ferrero, an old factory, which disappeared except for the house with a nice clock tower where the owners used to live. This factory was popularly known as "the bucket factory", because zinc buckets and pails were manufactured here.

carrer.name: Can Feu, Jardins de
carrer.descripcio: Gardens named after a farmhouse there used to be at this place. This is a traditional name, coming from a historic country house within the township of Les Corts, already mentioned in the works of the poet J. V. Foix.

carrer.name: Can Figuerola, Carrer de
carrer.descripcio: Here were the lands located in the Sant Genís dels Agudells neighborhood, that belonged to the Can Figuerola estate in the XV century, and now lodge the head office of the Palmero Art Institute. It is named after an important family in Spanish History of the XIX century.

carrer.name: Can Galta Cremat, Plaça de
carrer.descripcio: Square named after an old textile factory owned by the brothers Mateu, popularly known as "can Galta Cremat". This factory stood a long time still, and finally disappeared between 1997 and 1998.

carrer.name: Can Garriga, Placeta de
carrer.descripcio: Small square named after the place where the country house used to be.

carrer.name: Can Llavallol, Camí de
carrer.descripcio: The origin of the Llavallol family in this region dates back to 1595, when mister Lavol, the first member of the family tree, died at Sarrià. This is when the family established in the country house at Vallvidrera. The path named after this country house goes from the confluence of the roads to Mas Sauró and Alt Mas Sauró up to the township of Sant Just Desvern.

carrer.name: Can Mantega, Torrent de
carrer.descripcio: Torrent named after an old country house.

carrer.name: Can Mantega, Jardins de
carrer.descripcio: Gardens named after a farmer's house there used to be at this place until a few years ago.

carrer.name: Can Marcet, Avinguda de
carrer.descripcio: Avenue named after the owner of this place, a property bought by Frederic Marcet i Vidal in 1872.

carrer.name: Can Mateu, Baixada de
carrer.descripcio: A descending road named after the old country house.

carrer.name: Can Móra, Camí de
carrer.descripcio: Path leading to the country house after which it is named.

carrer.name: Can Móra, Carrer de
carrer.descripcio: Named after the local property.

carrer.name: Can Pujolet, Carrer de
carrer.descripcio: Miquel Pujol i Padró Jr. (Fadrí) (1784 - 1864). The owner's son and heir of the property bought by his father, Josep Pujol i March. The country house was named after his nickname.

carrer.name: Can Ràbia, Carrer de
carrer.descripcio: Named after an inn there used to be on the road to Sarrià, in front of Anglesola street, which also gave name to a suburb.

carrer.name: Can Robacols, Plaça de
carrer.descripcio: Square named after a popular house in the Clot neighborhood.

carrer.name: Ignasi de Ros, Carrer d'
carrer.descripcio: Street named after Ignasi de Ros i Puig (Barcelona 1876 - 1947). Councilman of Barcelona during the dictatorship of Primo de Rivera, he was the main promoter, since the Proposal of the Nomenclature, of the discovery of the history of the town and of Catalonia, changing lots of street names in the index of streets and squares into others that could remind of brave deeds in the Spanish History explained according to the view of the regimen established in those days. The Ros family was the owner of the lands where the street is now located.

carrer.name: Can Segalar, Carrer de
carrer.descripcio: Can Segalar, Torre Parladé or Torre Víctor. Old country house, property of the Vinyals family, known as Vinyals del Torrent. Between 1694 and 1714, the owner was Jaume Sagalà i Vinyals, honest citizen and notary of Barcelona. In the middle of the XIX century, the owner was Salvador Llongueras i Sagalà i de Portolés, who sold the house and the estate to Josep Parladé i Llucià, whose heir was his nephew, Josep Sanroman i Parladé. Finally, the property went to Maria Antònia Martínez i Sanroman and her husband, Federico Víctor i Iñigo, after whom it was named.

carrer.name: Can Senillosa, Jardins de
carrer.descripcio: Can Senillosa is one of the farmhouses of Sarrià, now included in the Catalogue of Historical and Artistic Heritage elaborated by Barcelona Town Council. A street named Senillosa came out from this farmhouse. The street has since been extended and has become the Carrer del Capità Arenas. From among the illustrious people who owned this property, we could single out Manuel Pujol de Senillosa i de Vedruna (Barcelona 1834 - 1872), Fidel Pujol de Senillosa, Josep Pujol de Senillosa i Gispert, Manuel Pujol de Senillosa i Hernández Pons de Bofarull (Tarragona ? - Barcelona 1857).

carrer.name: Can Sentmenat, Jardins de
carrer.descripcio: Gardens around a palace built in 1779, which was properly called "Country house of the Marquis of Sentmenat". In an evaluation of the marquis' properties made in 1899 on request of their heirs, this property is referred to as Torre de Sarrià, to distinguish it from the others. Since then, it is always called the Palace of the Marquis of Sentmenat. In 1940, the area around the palace was landscaped in a style emphasizing the sumptuous presence of the palace.

carrer.name: Can Toda, Riera de
carrer.descripcio: Brook named after the house and property.
carrer.anteriors: Casa Toda; T. de la Font de Xirot

carrer.name: Can Travi, Carrer de
carrer.descripcio: Named after a local country house dating back to the XVI century. The name comes from a landowners family from Cerdanya, Xavier Trabi and his wife Isabel Llanés.
carrer.anteriors: Berruguete; Berruguete (a section); C. Vila Olímpica 13, Vall d'Hebron (not official)

carrer.name: Can Valero, Carrer de
carrer.descripcio: Old local place-name.

carrer.name: Can Xirot, Carrer de
carrer.descripcio: Popular name. Located near the Carmelite Sanctuary.

carrer.name: Canaan, Carrer de
carrer.descripcio: This is how the Palestine of our days is called in the Old Testament. Street in the Vall d'Hebron neighborhood, where streets are named after villages and places of that country.

carrer.name: Canadell, Passatge de
carrer.descripcio: Jaume Canadell i Pujol, who died in 1845, owner of the lands belonging to the estate called Torre Regàs. His successors were Joan B. Canadell Tort, and later the Canadell Prats brothers. The remark "Just Trials by Ordeal, Saint Bartholomew" in his testament means that any testament not containing this remark would be nil and void.

carrer.name: Canalejas, Carrer de
carrer.descripcio: José Canalejas Méndez (Ferrol, Galicia, 1854 - Madrid, 1912). Lawyer and liberal politician. President of the Spanish Government (1910-1912).

carrer.name: Canàries, Carrer de les
carrer.descripcio: The Spanish archipelago in the Atlantic Ocean, near the coasts of Africa, consisting of seven big islands: Lanzarote and Fuerteventura in the East, Gran Canaria and Tenerife in the center, and Gomera, Hierro, and La Palma in the West.
carrer.anteriors: Canarias; Arquitecto Martorell; Canàrias; Arquitecto Martorell (Town Hall of Sarrià); Santa Ana

carrer.name: Cançó, Carrer de la
carrer.descripcio: Street name honoring the Song, a musical composition with text, for one or more voices, and often accompanied by an instrument. Street within a group of local streets dedicated to musical arts.

carrer.name: Candeles, Carrer de les
carrer.descripcio: A very old popular name, in memory of the tallow and wax candlestickmaker guilds, whose first ordinances date back to 1372.

carrer.name: Cànem, Carrer del
carrer.descripcio: Named after the hemp, a plant which used to "pay tithe and first fruits, as this crop was cultivated in large extensions until a few years ago..." within the township area of Sant Andreu de Palomar.

carrer.name: Canet, Passatge de
carrer.descripcio: Passageway named after an important family, owner of the country house of this name.

carrer.name: Canet, Carrer de
carrer.descripcio: Part of land which belonged to Manso Canet. The last owner was Josep Bosch i Canet (1795 - 1871), who married Joaquima Margenat i Cuyàs in 1812. Their heir, Francesc Bosch Margenat, was the first in not perpetuating the old family name. Members of the Canet family participated in the government of the small town of Sarrià in the XVII century.

carrer.name: Canfranc, Carrer de
carrer.descripcio: Named after Canfranc, the small town and valley in the Huesca province, in the Pyrenees.

carrer.name: Canigó, Carrer del
carrer.descripcio: Massif in the Pyrenees. Street within Turó de la Peira, where all streets are named after mountains.

carrer.name: Canó, Carrer del
carrer.descripcio: Named so in memory of a charcoal burner society at Gràcia.

carrer.name: Canonge Almera, Carrer del
carrer.descripcio: Jaume Almera i Comas (Vilassar de Mar, Maresme, 1845 - Barcelona, 1919). Geologue and ecclesiastic. Professor of Geology and Natural History at the Barcelona Seminary, and founder of the Museum of Geognosy and Paleontology. President of the Academy of Sciences and Arts of Barcelona (1907).
carrer.anteriors: Canónigo Almera; Doctor Almera; Andrés Molins; Collagats

carrer.name: Canonge Colom, Plaça del
carrer.descripcio: Square named after Joan Colom (? - 1229). Medieval ecclesiastic, In 1219, he founded the Colom Hospital, which in 1401 merged with other welfare establishments, constituting the General Holy Cross Hospital (Hospital de la Santa Creu). He was canon of the Cathedral of Barcelona.

carrer.name: Canonge Cuffí, Passatge del
carrer.descripcio: Passageway named after canon Cuffí (born at Mataró, Maresme). Canon of the Cathedral of Girona, he organized the militia forces when war was declared on France in 1794.

carrer.name: Canonge Pibernat, Carrer del
carrer.descripcio: Esteve Pibernat i Girbau (Granollers, Vallès Oriental, 1834 - Barcelona, 1907). Theologue and lecturer. Administrator of the parish of Sants. Professor at the Seminary.

carrer.name: Canonge Rodó, Plaça del
carrer.descripcio: Square named after Francesc Rodó i Sala (Terrassa, Vallès Occidental, 1816 - Barcelona, 1902). Rector of the church at Clot during more than thirty years.

carrer.name: Canonja, Baixada de la
carrer.descripcio: Downhill path named after the 'canonja' or 'calonja', that is how the canons' residence is called in Catalan.

carrer.name: Canovelles, Carrer de
carrer.descripcio: Borough of Vallès Oriental, and street of Barcelona so named in memory of the fact that in 1385, this town made a petition to be integrated into Barcelona through a procedure known as 'carreratge', by which the borough is considered as a street of Barcelona. According to the terms of the petition, the inhabitants of the borough enjoyed the same rights and privileges as the inhabitants of the capital city.

carrer.name: Cànoves, Carrer de
carrer.descripcio: Borough of Vallès Oriental. Street within the neighborhood of Sant Genís dels Agudells.

carrer.name: Cantàbria, Carrer de
carrer.descripcio: Territory in Northern Spain, the capital of which is Santander. Belongs to a group of streets within the same neighborhood named after regions and provinces of the Iberian Peninsula.

carrer.name: Cantera, Carrer de la
carrer.descripcio: Makes reference to the Tardà quarry that existed at this place. The street was called 'cantera' (big rock) to avoid duplicity with the street named "de les Pedreres".

carrer.name: Cantí, Passatge de
carrer.descripcio: Passageway named after Joan Cantí i Sanvicens (1817 - 1890), who bought the property from Mariano d'Aguirre i de Venero in 1856. His son and heir Domènec Cantí i Joan became the owner of the factory for tanning and priming products.

carrer.name: Cantunis, Passeig de
carrer.descripcio: Promenade named after a neighborhood of Barcelona; here used to be the property of shipwright Manuel Antunis (or Antúnez), died in 1763.

carrer.name: Canuda, Carrer de la
carrer.descripcio: There is evidence that this street was so named already in 1446, after the nickname of Canut's (a celebrity so called because of his gray hair) wife, who must have been famous for reasons which are not known.

carrer.name: Canvis Nous, Carrer dels
carrer.descripcio: So named after the money changers (XIII century), who used to put up their tables at this place.

carrer.name: Canvis Vells, Carrer dels
carrer.descripcio: So called because of the money changers. The government tried to prevent abuse in exchange rates by establishing a change table or deposit in 1401.

carrer.name: Canyameres, Carrer de
carrer.descripcio: The name means hemp collectors, because hemp was planted in lands belonging to the estate Dragó de Dalt and around the place called Pla de Canyelles. The Planas family owned more than 11 'mujadas' (about 71,000 m2) of soil in the XIX century, and Baltasar Molins before them, the most important neighboring owners being, among others, Joan Diumenjó, Pacià Masadas, Joan Batllori, and Gabriel Campanyà.

carrer.name: Canyelles, Carrer de
carrer.descripcio: Actually Josep Cañellas, owner of the place developed when this street was built in the XIX century.

carrer.name: Cap de Guaita, Carrer del
carrer.descripcio: Refers to the Chief of Guard of the Montjuïc, a public officer at the service of the Council of the Hundred.

carrer.name: Cap del Món, Carrer del
carrer.descripcio: Corrupted name of 'capdemunt', street which led to one of the corn exchange markets of old Barcelona.

carrer.name: Capçanes, Carrer de
carrer.descripcio: Borough of the Priorat. Street belonging to the Torre Baró neighborhood, where most streets are named after Catalan villages.

carrer.name: Capcir, Carrer del
carrer.descripcio: Valley of Alta Cerdanya.

carrer.name: Capdevila, Passatge de
carrer.descripcio: Maria Lacasa i Roig (Roses, Alt Empordà, 1846 - Barcelona, 1919), and her sons Artur Capdevila Lacasa (Roses, Alt Empordà, 1873 - Barcelona, 1912) and Joan Capdevila Lacasa (Barcelona, 1871 - 1931) were the owners of this place, later inherited by Maria and Anna Capdevila Marcenario. The passageway is deemed to be dedicated to Artur Capdevila, who died before the passageway was named after him.

carrer.name: Capella, Carrer de
carrer.descripcio: Francesc de P. Capella i Sabadell (Barcelona, 1823 - 1901). Writer.

carrer.name: Capella de Can Caralleu, Carrer de la
carrer.descripcio: Named after a chapel existing in this street.

carrer.name: Capellades, Carrer de
carrer.descripcio: Named after a borough of La Anoia. Within a street group furthermore integrated by the following streets: Cardedeu, Montornès, Palou, and Castellterçol, all of them in the Coll neighborhood.

carrer.name: Capellans, Carrer dels
carrer.descripcio: It seems that this name dates back to 1666, when regular Theatinian priests of Sant Gaietà erected their convent here, thus giving place to a huge concentration of priests in this street.

carrer.name: Capità Arenas, Carrer del
carrer.descripcio: Félix Arenas y Gaspar (San Juan, Puerto Rico, 1891 - Mont Arruït, 1921). Captain of Engineers, died in the African War, in the battle of Mont-Arruït (July 29, 1921). Son of Artillery Captain Félix Arenas i Escolano and Enriqueta Gaspar i Gómez, both from Molina de Aragón, Guadalajara. This street was named after him in 1928, on request of the Engineer Commander's Heardquarter.
carrer.anteriors: Capitán Arenas, 26/07/1928; Núm. 17 (Plan of Les Corts)

carrer.name: Caponata, Carrer dels
carrer.descripcio: Andreu Caponata i Greco was the name of an owner of Italian origin, who bought some property and a country house here in 1826. People used to call them "Caponata's fields".

carrer.name: Capsec, Carrer de
carrer.descripcio: Village belonging to Vall de Bianya (Garrotxa) borough. The street is among those in the Ramon Albó housing estate Ramon Albó housing estate, where streets are dedicated to towns and villages of Catalonia.

carrer.name: Caputxes, Carrer de les
carrer.descripcio: So named because of the hoodmaker shops there used to be long time ago.

carrer.name: Caputxins, Passatge dels
carrer.descripcio: Passageway named after the old Convent of Capuchins, dedicated to Saint Madrona, established here on November 14, 1578, which later moved to Rambla del Centre.

carrer.name: Carabassa, Torrent de la
carrer.descripcio: Torrent named after the country house of Can Carabassa.

carrer.name: Carabassa, Carrer d'en
carrer.descripcio: One of the first streets crossing the "pebble place" where the potters had their shops and furnaces. Carabassa probably was a professional potter.

carrer.name: Caracas, Carrer de
carrer.descripcio: Capital city of Venezuela. The street belongs to the Bon Pastor neighborhood, an industrial area where streets are named after American towns and villages.

carrer.name: Caramelles, Plaça de les
carrer.descripcio: Easter Feasts are of rural origin, as they pretended to celebrate the arrival of Spring with all the flowers, promising a rich harvest. Celebrations usually included a trip to the fields to sing the return of flowers, as do the 'caramellaires,' i.e. the singers of typical Easter songs. This is where the name of this square has its origin.

carrer.name: Carassa, Carrer de la
carrer.descripcio: So named because of the mask engraved on the lintel of the house on the corner of Mirallers street. According to R.i C, there are good reasons to believe that this is the name of an old Catalan family.

carrer.name: Caravel·la La Niña, Carrer de la
carrer.descripcio: Named after one of the three caravels that took part in Columbus' expedition.
carrer.anteriors: Carabela Niña; Doctor Zamenhof; Núm. 19 (Plan of Les Corts)

carrer.name: Caravel·la La Pinta, Carrer de la
carrer.descripcio: Named after one of the three caravels that took part in Columbus' expedition.
carrer.anteriors: Carabela Pinta; Lletra D (Plan of Les Corts)

carrer.name: Carbonell, Passatge de
carrer.descripcio: Passageway named after the First Marquis de la Quadra.

carrer.name: Carbonell, Carrer de
carrer.descripcio: Lluís Carbonell i Ferràs, Marquis de la Quadra, title bestowed upon him by King Fernando VI on March 31, 1757. His successors were owners of the lands of Barceloneta, who gave up the orchards of Gurri, Botet, and Torrents, among others, to build the Barceloneta housings. An eminent member of this family was Joan Maria d'Oliveras de Carbonell i de l'Estanyol (Vic, Osona, 1797 - Barcelona, 1879).

carrer.name: Carcassona, Carrer de
carrer.descripcio: Town in the Languedoc, capital of the French department of Aude, Occitaine. Its County was acquired by Ramon Berenguer I in 1067, and reinforced by Ramon Berenguer III, who linked it to the Provence.

carrer.name: Cardedeu, Carrer de
carrer.descripcio: Borough of Vallès Oriental. Street named so in memory of the fact that in 1384, this town made a petition to be integrated into Barcelona through a procedure known as 'carreratge', by which the borough is considered as a street of Barcelona. According to the terms of the petition, the inhabitants of the borough enjoyed the same rights and privileges as the inhabitants of the city.

carrer.name: Cardedeu, Passatge de
carrer.descripcio: Borough of Vallès Oriental.

carrer.name: Cardenal Casañas, Carrer del
carrer.descripcio: Salvador Casañas i Pagès (Barcelona, 1834 - 1908). Bishop of La Seu d'Urgell (1879-1901) and of Barcelona between 1901 and 1908, the year he died. He had been Professor of the Seminary, Canon, Rector of the parish Santa Maria del Pi. He was designated Cardinal in 1895.
carrer.anteriors: Riera del Pino; Enrique Fontbernat; Cardenal Casañas, before 1900; Ra. del Pino, before 1865

carrer.name: Cardenal Cicognani, Plaça del
carrer.descripcio: Square named after Caetano Cicognani e Ceccioni (Brigighella, Ravenna, Italy, 1881 - Rome, 1962). Related with the Eucharistic Congress celebrated in Barcelona in 1952. Papal Nuncio for Spain. Designated Cardinal by Pope Pius XII in 1953.

carrer.name: Cardenal Cisneros, Carrer del
carrer.descripcio: Gonzalo Jiménez de Cisneros (Torrelaguna, 1436 - Roa, 1517). Castilian ecclesiastic y politician. When he took his vows, he changed his name for Francesc.

carrer.name: Cardenal Reig, Carrer del
carrer.descripcio: Enric Reig i Casanova (Valencia, Horta 1859 - Toledo, 1927). Bishop of Barcelona (1914-1920). He created a Diocesan Archaeological Museum, and reorganized the Acción Católica (Catholic Action). He was designated Archbishop of Valencia in 1920, and Cardinal in 1922.

carrer.name: Cardenal Sentmenat, Carrer del
carrer.descripcio: Antoni de Sentmenat i de Cartellà (Barcelona, 1734 - Aranjuez, 1806), son of Joan Manuel de Sentmenat-Oms de Santapau i d'Olmos, Marquis of Castelldosrius. This street was named after him in 1927 "because he was an illustrious member of a family whose branch has its manor house at Sarrià, and whose head is the Councilor of this Town Council, mister Sentmenat". He was Canon and Archdeacon of Barcelona, Bishop of Avila, Cardinal and Patriarch of the Indies.
carrer.anteriors: Capitán Mirambell; Cardenal Sentmenat; Estació, before 1900; Orri (Town Hall of Sarrià); Tirol

carrer.name: Cardenal Tedeschini, Carrer del
carrer.descripcio: Federico Tedeschini (Antrodoco, Lazio, 1873 - Rome, 1959). Italian Prelate. Papal Nuncio in Madrid (1921-1939). Archpriest of Saint Peter of the Vatican, and the Pope's Datary. Collaborator of Pope Pius XII, he was legate in the Eucharistic Congress of Barcelona in 1952.

carrer.name: Cardenal Vidal i Barraquer, Avinguda del
carrer.descripcio: Francesc Vidal i Barraquer (Cambrils de Mar, Baix Camp, 1868 - Fribourg, Switzerland, 1943). Cardinal and Archbishop of Tarragona (1919-1943). Exiled to Lucca during the Spanish Civil War, and finally to Switzerland. His remains were transferred to the Cathedral of Tarragona in 1978.

carrer.name: Cardenal Vives i Tutó, Carrer del
carrer.descripcio: Josep de Calassanç Vives i Tutó (Sant Andreu de Llavaneres, Maresme, 1854 - Monte Porzio, Italy, 1913). He was Director of the Seraphic Seminary of Perpignan, France. Designated Cardinal by Pope Leo XIII in 1899. Founder of the Collegio Pío-Latino-Americano of Rome, and co-founder of the Spanish Pontifical College. Capuchin, he used to stay for long periods at Sarrià.
carrer.anteriors: Cardenal Vives i Tutó, 05/05/1927; Núm. 15; Santa Rosa

carrer.name: Cardener, Carrer del
carrer.descripcio: Named after this pre-pyrenaic river, main tributary of the Llobregat.

carrer.name: Carders, Carrer dels
carrer.descripcio: Initially a Roman track, then an access road to the city, near which a church dedicated to Sant Cugat was built in 1023. Later it became a street, which was named after the woolcomber cord manufacturers here installed.

carrer.name: Cardó, Carrer de
carrer.descripcio: Convent and hermitage, now a health spa, within the township of Benifallet, Baix Ebre, in the upper Cardó Valley.

carrer.name: Cardona, Carrer de
carrer.descripcio: Borough of Bages, with an old monastery and castle. The origin of the lineage lies in the viscounts who owned the castle which, around 1062, was named after the viscounts of Cardona.

carrer.name: Cardona, Plaça de
carrer.descripcio: Street originally named after Margarita Cardona i Prats (1812 ? 1849 ?), wife of the local owner Pau Rosés i Calvet. Ignoring this fact, it was thought that it was dedicated to Cardona, borough of Bages, with its old monastery and castle. Square opened in 1852 in the lands of Camp d'en Vidal, formerly belonging to Josep Jordà i Gilabert, son of Josep Jordà i Santandreu, then property of Domènec Vidal i Balaguer. Cardona is one of the oldest and most important families in the Catalan Territory.

carrer.name: Caresmar, Carrer de
carrer.descripcio: Jaume Caresmar i Alemany (Igualada, Anoia, 1717 - Barcelona, 1791). Ecclesiastic and erudite. Advocate of historical investigation. At 25, he took the white habit of Saint Norbert in the Convent of Bellpuig de les Avellanes, where he was archivist and teacher. He worked in several archives, and since 1770, in the Archive of the Cathedral of Barcelona and in the Diocesan Archive. He was member of the Academy of Fine Letters.

carrer.name: Cariteo, Carrer de
carrer.descripcio: Benet Garret (Barcelona, 1450 - Naples, Italy 1514). Poet and humanist. He lived at the Court of Alfons 'el magnànim' in Naples, where he was known as 'Il Cariteo'.

carrer.name: Carles Barral, Jardins de
carrer.descripcio: Gardens named after Carles Barral i Agesta (Barcelona, 1928 - 1989). Poet and editor. Bachelor of Law. He participated in the Seix i Barral Company and in Barral Editores, publishing, among others, the works entitled 'Metropolitano', 'Usuras', 'Catalunya a vol d'ocell', and 'Cuando las horas' 'veloces'. Since 1982, Senator for the PSC-PSOE (Socialist Party) for Tarragona. These gardens are inside the block on the waterfront, limited by the Bac de Roda street, the Taulat promenade, the Josep Ferrater i Mora street, and the Garcia Fària promenade.

carrer.name: Carles Buïgas, Plaça de
carrer.descripcio: Square named after Carles Buïgas i Sans (Barcelona, 1898 - 1980). Illuminating Engineer. He took part in the preparatory work commission for the Universal Exhibition (World Fair) of Barcelona in 1929. His projects included the fountains of the Pedralbes Palace and the primitive illuminated fountain of Montjuïc, the illumination and the monumental fountains of changing shape and colors within the fair.

carrer.name: Carles Cardó i Sanjoan, Plaça de
carrer.descripcio: (Valls, Alt Camp, 1884 - Barcelona, 1958). Ecclesiastic and writer. Doctor in Theology and Canon Law. Canon in Barcelona (1918). Militant of the Catalanist Movement.

carrer.name: Carles Collet, Carrer de
carrer.descripcio: Charles Collet Colomb (Onex, Geneva, Switzerland, 1902 - Barcelona, 1983). Sculpturer and goldsmith. In 1923, he worked in Barcelona, in the workshop of the Corberó family, and with the goldsmith Ramon Sunyer. In 1929 he became professor at the Massana School. His wife, Eugénie Millioud, known as Ninon Collet, ceramist and goldsmith, often exhibited her works together with those of her husband.

carrer.name: Carles I, Parc de
carrer.descripcio: Park named after Charles I (Ghent, Flanders, 1500 - Yuste, Extremadura, 1558). Emperor of the Germanic-Roman Empire, King of Castile, and of Catalonia and Aragon.

carrer.name: Carles III, Gran Via de
carrer.descripcio: Named after Charles III (Madrid, 1716 - 1788). King of Spain. Duke of Parma and of Plasencia (1731-1735). King of Naples (1734-1759) and of Spain (1759-1788).

carrer.name: Carles Pi i Sunyer, Plaça de
carrer.descripcio: Square named after this eminent Catalan politician, economist, and writer (Barcelona, 1888 - Caracas, Venezuela, 1971). He was Director of the Municipal School for Craftsmanship of Sants, and of the Superior School of Agriculture of the Community. He was member of the Parliament of Catalonia and of the Parliament of Spain. He also was Councilor for Finance of the Generalitat (1932). Mayor of Barcelona (1934). After his exile, he established in Caracas, Venezuela, in 1952.

carrer.name: Carles Pirozzini, Carrer de
carrer.descripcio: Carles Pirozzini i Martí (Barcelona, 1852 - 1938). Art critic. General Secretary of the World Fair of 1888. Supporter of art exhibitions. Member of the Sant Jordi Academy (1907).

carrer.name: Carles Riba, Carrer de
carrer.descripcio: Carles Riba i Bracons (Barcelona, 1893 - 1959). Writer and humanist. He studied Law and Humanities, achieving the Doctor's degree in 1938. Lecturer of Greek at the Bernat Metge Foundation, of which he was Director after his return from exile in 1943.

carrer.name: Carles Soldevila, Carrer de
carrer.descripcio: Carles Soldevila i Zubiburu (Barcelona, 1892 - 1967). Writer. Bachelor of Law and journalist.

carrer.name: Carlet, Camí del
carrer.descripcio: Path named after this mushroom having a fleshy, compact flesh or red colored hat, convex while young, and later extended or with a depression.

carrer.name: Carlit, Jardins del
carrer.descripcio: Gardens named after Carlit, an axially running massif in the Eastern Pyrenees, within the Alta Cerdanya, between the Perxa Plain and the Pimorent Pass. Bordering the Capcir and the País de Foix in the North, and closing the Cerdanya in the South. Carlit is also the name of the highest peak (2.921 m) in the Eastern Pyrenees. Public park between the following streets: Roger de Flor, Consell de Cent, Nàpols, and Diputació.

carrer.name: Carlos Ibáñez, Plaça de
carrer.descripcio: Square named after Carlos Ibáñez e Ibáñez de Ibero (Barcelona, 1825 - near Nice 1890). Mathematician, geodesist, and military. He was an important expert in cartography, geodesy, and cadaster in the XIX century. Director of the Geographical and Statistical Institute of Madrid, where he started publishing the topographic map of the Spanish State. He was promoted to General of Division, and conferred the title of Marquis of Mulhacén (1889), as proposed by the jury of the International Fair of Barcelona of 1888.

carrer.name: Carlota de Mena, Passatge de
carrer.descripcio: Passageway named after Carlota de Mena i Zamora (Tortosa, Baix Ebre, 1845 - Manresa, Bages, 1902). Catalan dramatic actress.

carrer.name: Carme, Plaça del
carrer.descripcio: Square dedicated to Our Lady of Mount Carmel, passionately worshipped by many people.

carrer.name: Carme, Carrer del
carrer.descripcio: Named after the Carmel Convent, where the nuns of the Order of Our Lady of Mount Carmel (Calced Carmelites) were established since before 1294. After their secularization, the Literary University was installed in this building.

carrer.name: Carme Karr, Carrer de
carrer.descripcio: Carme Karr i Alfonsetti (Barcelona, 1865 - 1943). Writer. In 1913, she founded and directed the first residence for professors and students, named La Llar. She was a fierce defender of improvement and modernization of education for women.

carrer.name: Carmel, Rambla del
carrer.descripcio: This boulevard, as well as the hill and the neighborhood, are named after the sanctuary of Our Lady of Mount Carmel.

carrer.name: Carmel, Torrent del
carrer.descripcio: Torrent named after the sanctuary of Our Lady of Mount Carmel.

carrer.name: Carmel, Carretera del
carrer.descripcio: The sanctuary of Our Lady of Mount Carmel gave name to a hill formerly called "colina d'en Mora", as well as to this road and to the whole neighborhood.

carrer.name: Carmel, Parc del
carrer.descripcio: Park so named because of its proximity to the sanctuary of Our Lady of Mount Carmel.

carrer.name: Carmen Amaya, Carrer de
carrer.descripcio: Carmen Amaya i Amaya (Barcelona, 1913 - Begur, Baix Empordà, 1963). Dancer born in a Gypsy family, in a slum at Somorrostro, Barcelona.
carrer.anteriors: Camí rere el Cementiri Vell; Cº de detrás del Cementerio Viejo

carrer.name: Carmen Tórtola Valencia, Plaça de
carrer.descripcio: A dancer born in Seville on 18th June 1882. She was the daughter of Florença Tórtola, who came from Catalonia, and Georgina Valencia. At the age of three she started her dancing classes in a London suburb, where her parents had emigrated. She received an orthodox Victorian education. She made her début in London in 1902. She performed in Vienna, Berlin and Paris. In 1910 she made her first appearance at the Romea theatre in Madrid, and in 1912 at the Novedades in Barcelona. She taught at Munich's Art Theatre until 1914. Her figure appeared on canvasses, drawings and posters done by painters of the time. She died in Barcelona on 13th February 1955 in Carrer Major de Sarrià, 232.

carrer.name: Carolines, Carreró de les
carrer.descripcio: Alley having the same name as the street it runs into.

carrer.name: Carolines, Carrer de les
carrer.descripcio: Named after this Micronesian archipelago, discovered in 1526 by a Spanish expedition commanded by Toribio Alonso de Salazar. Annexed to the Spanish Crown in 1686. Sold to Germany for 25 millions Pesetas in 1899.
carrer.anteriors: Las Carolinas; Juan Vinyas; San Gervasio

carrer.name: Carrasco i Formiguera, Carrer de
carrer.descripcio: Manuel Carrasco i Formiguera (Barcelona, 1890 - Burgos, 1938). Politician and lawyer. Militant of the Catalanist Movement and one of the founders of 'Acció Catalana' in 1922. He took part in the Government under Francesc Macià, continuing as Councilor in the First Government of the Generalitat. He was one of the main leaders of the Unió Democràtica de Catalunya (Democratic Party of Catalonia).
carrer.anteriors: Doctor Amigant, 07/03/1939; Campmany, 25/09/1931; Pedro de Amigant, 04/02/1931; Doctor Amigant, 18/05/1927; Colegio Máximo

carrer.name: Carrencà, Carrer de
carrer.descripcio: Josepa Carrencà, wife of Pau Ganduxer i Aymerich, owner of the lands. Her heir was Josepa Ganduxer i Carrencà (Corró de Vall, Vallès Oriental, 1855 - Barcelona, 1941).

carrer.name: Carrera, Carrer de
carrer.descripcio: Antoni Carrera i Draper, lawyer. Owner of the lands where the street was opened, at a place known as "d'Hortes de Sant Bertran". In the nomenclature of 1980, this street is dedicated to Joaquim Carrera i Sayrol (Barcelona, 1824 - 1890). Engineer, builder of the first railroad of Spain, between Barcelona and Mataró (1848). He also built the rack rail from Monistrol to Montserrat, and the Tibidabo cable railway.

carrer.name: Carreras, Carrer de
carrer.descripcio: Joaquim Carreras i de Compte (1853 - 1931). Manufacturer, owner of the lands.

carrer.name: Carreras, Passatge de
carrer.descripcio: Passageway named after Mercè Carreras i Blasi (Barcelona, 1900 - 1965). She and her sister Dolors bought the lands from Maurici de Sivatte i de Bobadilla in 1941.

carrer.name: Carreras i Candi, Carrer de
carrer.descripcio: Francesc Carreras i Candi (Barcelona, 1862 - 1937). Geographer, historian, and politician. Lawyer and prolific writer. He was Consul of the Dominican Republic. Owner of the lands around the place called "la Vall", where this street was opened.

carrer.name: Carretes, Carrer de les
carrer.descripcio: This street is already mentioned in a public document dating from 1383, where it is referred to as a path going from the Monastery of Saint Paul to the street named "del Pedró". An ordinance dating from 1583 establishes the excise taxes chariots, carts, and carriages had to pay to go around the city "because they spoil the pavement". This street name is obviously of popular origin, and very old.

carrer.name: Carril, Plaça del
carrer.descripcio: Square named after the popular name of the train to Sarrià.

carrer.name: Carrilet, Avinguda del
carrer.descripcio: Carrilet is the popular name which used to be given to the train of the Ferrocarrils Catalans which goes to Sant Boi and which was taken underground here in the nineteen-eighties.

carrer.name: Carroç, Carrer de
carrer.descripcio: Properly Carròs. Important Catalan family, of which there is records in documents dating as far back as the XI century, associated with the Llança family, who urbanized this place. Joaquím de Llança i de Belloch was the owner of these lands until 1859.
carrer.anteriors: Carroz; Maria López de Sagredo; Ignacio Llanza residential area (a section); Casa Soca

carrer.name: Carsi, Passatge de
carrer.descripcio: Passageway named after Ricard Carsi i Lacasa (Valencia, Horta, 1883 - Barcelona, 1968). Engineer, well builder. As the owner of a nearby estate, he built a well to grant the water supply to neighbors, who dedicated this passageway to him in gratitude.

carrer.name: Cartagena, Carrer de
carrer.descripcio: Town in Murcia. In ancient times, it received the name 'Cartago Nova' or 'Cartago' 'Spartaria'. It was the capital of the Roman province 'Carthaginiensis'.

carrer.name: Cartago, Carrer de
carrer.descripcio: Named after the ancient Carthage, 17 km North-West of modern Tunis, founded by the Phoenicians in 814 b.Ch. Capital city of the Carthaginian State until 146 b.Ch., when it was conquered by the ancient Romans. This street was so named in memory of Saint Augustin, who had spent his youth in this town.
carrer.anteriors: San Agustín (a section); Lletra F (Casa Falcó)

carrer.name: Cartellà, Carrer de
carrer.descripcio: Family name of the Barons of Albi, owners of large extensions of land at this place. Descendants of Jordi Galceran de Cartellà i Sabastida, Baron of Albi and of Falgons (Falgons, Pla de l'Estany, 1651 - Albi, Garrigues, 1725). Supporter of King Archduke Charles III, who conferred him the Barony of Cartellà (1707).

carrer.name: Cartoixa, Carrer de la
carrer.descripcio: Cloister of the Order founded by Saint Bruno in 1086.

carrer.name: Casa Blanca, Passatge de la
carrer.descripcio: Passageway named after the property at Paseo de la Mare de Déu del Coll Number 89, known by this name (White House).

carrer.name: Casa Bloc, Jardins de
carrer.descripcio: Gardens named after the housing block comprising 207 flats, built between 1933 and 1937 at Sant Andreu de Palomar, a neighborhood of Barcelona, according to a project made by the GATCPAC (Grupo de Arquitectos y Técnicos Catalanes para el Progreso de la Arquitectura Contemporánea =Group of Catalan Architects and Technicians for the Progress of Contemporaneous Architecture).

carrer.name: Casa Llarga, Passatge de
carrer.descripcio: Passageway so named after a longish house of undefined style there used to be in the area around the Arriassa field.

carrer.name: Casafranca, Carrer de
carrer.descripcio: So named in memory of a house free of any charges and duties, mentioned in the home tax registers of the XVII century. Also a local patronymic.

carrer.name: Casals, Carrer de
carrer.descripcio: Salvador Casals i Solé (Borges del Camp, Baix Camp, 1870 - Barcelona, 1940). Landowner.

carrer.name: Casals i Cuberó, Carrer de
carrer.descripcio: Salvador Casals i Solé (1870 - 1940) and Miquel Coberó i Bernadas (Torà, Segarra, 1864 - Barcelona, 1928) were the owners since 1918.

carrer.name: Casamitjana, Passatge de
carrer.descripcio: Passageway named after Antoni Casamitjana i Agustí (Enveig, Cerdanya, 1822 - Barcelona, 1885). Owner of 19 3/4 'mujadas' (about 127,100 m2) of land at the place called "Taulat", later inherited by his daughters Carme Casamitjana i Dalmau and Antònia Casamitjana i Gadilla.

carrer.name: Casanova, Carrer de
carrer.descripcio: Rafael Casanova i Comes (Moià, Bages, 1660 ? - Sant Boi de Llobregat, Baix Llobregat, 1743). Chief Councilor of the City of Barcelona, heroic defender of the city during the siege in 1714.

carrer.name: Casanovas, Passatge de
carrer.descripcio: Passageway named after Baltasar de Casanovas i Bacardí, owner of the lands at the place called "Lligalbé". The 6 pieces ('mujadas') (38,613 m2) of property where this passageway is were sold to the Ventalló Llobatera brothers in 1862.

carrer.name: Casas i Amigó, Carrer de
carrer.descripcio: Francesc Casas i Amigó (Sant Antoni de Vilamajor, Vallès Oriental, 1859 - Barcelona 1887). Poet. His works are influenced by Verdaguer's mysticism and by popular poetry.

carrer.name: Cascades, Parc de les
carrer.descripcio: Avenue within the Vila Olímpica.

carrer.name: Cascades, Plaça de les
carrer.descripcio: Square so named because of the cascades installed at this place.

carrer.name: Cases Boada, Carrer de les
carrer.descripcio: Refers to a hamlet within the township of Sant Martí de Provençals, which already in 1860 constituted an urban area with forty-eight neighbors called "the Boada houses", as they were built on a site in the "'camp del penjat'" ("hangman's field") owned by Josep Boada (XVIII century), whose successor was his son, Joan Boada i Llimona (? - 1854).

carrer.name: Casetes, Carrer de les
carrer.descripcio: Refers to the small houses lining the street.

carrer.name: Casp, Carrer de
carrer.descripcio: In memory of the Agreement of Caspe (June 24, 1412) the Judges elected by the Parliaments of the Principality of Catalonia and of the Kingdoms of Aragon and of Valencia came to after King Martin died on May 31, 1410, without leaving a direct successor. According to this Agreement, the Trastamara house was to occupy the Throne of Catalonia and Aragon.

carrer.name: Castanyer, Carrer de
carrer.descripcio: Joaquim Castanyer i Molet (Barcelona 1804 -1858), married to Maria de la Consolació de Moragas i de Quintana, was the last owner of the new Torre Castanyer, built on the same place as the old Castanyer house.

carrer.name: Castanyers, Passeig dels
carrer.descripcio: So named because of the many chestnut trees lining this promenade.

carrer.name: Castanys, Carrer de
carrer.descripcio: Francesc Castanys i Solà (Olot, Garrotxa, 1810 - Salamanca, 1859). Jurist and politician. Lecturer of Law in Barcelona. He lived at Poblenou. This street was dedicated to him by an agreement of the Town Hall of Sant Martí (then independent) of January 2, 1879. Owner of 2 1/4 'mujadas' (about 14,480 m2) at this place.

carrer.name: Castelao, Plaça de
carrer.descripcio: Square named after Alfonso Daniel Rodríguez Castelao (Rianxo, Galicia, 1886 - Buenos Aires, Argentina, 1950). Galician politician, writer, and sketcher. In 1946, when he lived in Paris, he was designated Minister of the Government of the Spanish Republic in Exile.

carrer.name: Castell, Avinguda del
carrer.descripcio: Avenue leading to the Montjuïc castle.

carrer.name: Castell d'Argençola, Carrer del
carrer.descripcio: Old feudal castle on top of a promontory overlooking the Villa of Argençola (Anoia).

carrer.name: Castell de l'Oreneta, Parc del
carrer.descripcio: Park named after the local castle.

carrer.name: Castell d'Olorda, Carrer del
carrer.descripcio: The Castle of Olorda is mentioned in a document dating from 1335, when the King Pere 'el' 'Cerimoniós' sold it to Pere Desllor. In 1377 it was acquired by Berenguer de Relat, citizen of Barcelona and treasurer of Queen Elionor of Sicily.

carrer.name: Castella, Carrer de
carrer.descripcio: Castile, the region and former kingdom filling the center of the Iberian Peninsula. Constituted as a State when King Ferran III definitively united the kingdoms of Leon and Castile, plus the territories conquered from the Muslims, under the same Crown in 1230.

carrer.name: Castella, Plaça de
carrer.descripcio: In the XIX century, here used to be the Military Hospital of Catalonia, with a capacity of 680 beds, in a four storey high building with a chapel in the middle, the latter being the only thing that still exists.

carrer.name: Castelladral, Carrer de
carrer.descripcio: Village and former capital of the borough of Navars (Bages).

carrer.name: Castellar, Carrer de
carrer.descripcio: Castellar de n'Hug, borough of Berguedà. Street around Can Papanaps.

carrer.name: Castellbell, Carrer de
carrer.descripcio: Barony conferred to Josep d'Amat de Planella i Despalau (Barcelona, 1670 - 1715) in 1702. The Castellbell became owners of large estates at Sant Andreu.

carrer.name: Castellbisbal, Carrer de
carrer.descripcio: Borough of Vallès Occidental. Street within a group of local streets named after Catalan villages.

carrer.name: Castelldefels, Carrer de
carrer.descripcio: Borough of Baix Llobregat, so named because of its castle. The fortress must have been built in times of Count Guifré 'el Pelós' (878-897). The original name of Castelldefels was Fèlix, probably after the officer or follower at the Count's service personally in charge of the fortifying works.

carrer.name: Castellers, Jardins dels
carrer.descripcio: Gardens dedicated to the people practicing the ancient Catalan tradition of rising human towers, the famous 'castells'. Generally, human towers are risen by a group of trained people ('colles),' with an experienced leader ('cap de colla', 'casteller)' directing the process step by step.

carrer.name: Castellet, Carrer de
carrer.descripcio: Village of Alt Penedès, capital of the borough of Castellet i la Gornal.

carrer.name: Castellfollit, Carrer de
carrer.descripcio: Castellfollit de la Roca. Borough of La Garrotxa. Street in the Torre Baró neighborhood, where most streets are named after villages and places of Catalonia.

carrer.name: Castellfollit, Travessia de
carrer.descripcio: Cross-street named the same as the main street.

carrer.name: Castellnou, Carrer de
carrer.descripcio: Pau Vicenç Castellnou Sabater i Serra (1760 - 1823). Doctor of Law. Successor of his grandfather, Pau Vicenç Sabater i Serra, owner of the estate Ca la Nena Casas (178,715 m2).

carrer.name: Castelló, Carrer de
carrer.descripcio: Josep Castelló-Galvany i Quadras (1829 - 1880) bought a several stories high house with 8 'mujadas' (51.484 m2) of land here in 1871.
