The Company was formed by over 100 women with ages between 18 and 22 and it was subdivided into four squadrons: Sant Narcís, headed by Llúcia Jonama i Bellsolà de Fitzgerald (la Bisbal d'Empordà, Baix Empordà 1785 - Girona 1858); the square of Sant Pere was assigned to this squadron. The squadron of Santa Eulalia, headed by Maria Custí, was assigned to the Mercadal square. The squadron of Santa Dorotea, headed by Maria Àngela Vivern was posted to the Plaza del Vi square. The fourth, the squadron of Concepció, headed by Ramona de Nouvilas was posted to the Plaza de l'Hospici square. The Company of Santa Barbara helped to defend Girona against Napoleon in 1809.

carrer.name: Herois del Bruc, Carrer dels
carrer.descripcio: The Bruc battle was fought on the 6th and the 14th of June 1808. The first battle was fought between 3.800 solders and the resistance troops which included a Swiss detachment from the Wimpffen regiment, a group of Walloon guards and about 2.000 members of the Catalan militia. The second battle was fought between a French division and the resistance troops, which included 1.550 voluntaries from Lleida, headed by Joan Baget, the militia from Manresa and Igualada, the 'Tercios' from Cervera and about one hundred solders of the same Swiss regiment in plain clothes as well as several solders from Barcelona. The battle of Bruc was an important victory against Napoleon in the Independence War.

carrer.name: Heures, Carrer de les
carrer.descripcio: Street named after the ivy that used to grow along its gardens until the middle of the 19th century.

carrer.name: Hilari Salvadó, Plaça d'
carrer.descripcio: Named after the politician Hilari Salvadó i Castell (Barcelona 1899 - 1966), fishermen's son from the Barceloneta. He was a militant of Esquerra Republicana and Councilor in Barcelona. He was appointed mayor of Barcelona in 1937 to replace Carles Pi i Sunyer. He was exiled in 1939 and only returned many years later. The square that bares his name is located between the streets Sant Carles de Salamanca and Santa Lluïsa de Marillac, in the Barceloneta neighborhood.

carrer.name: Hipòlit Lázaro, Carrer d'
carrer.descripcio: Named after Hipòlit Lázaro i Higueras (Barcelona 1887 - 1974), tenor born here. He made his début at the Liceo de Barcelona in 1914.

carrer.name: Hiroshima, Jardins d'
carrer.descripcio: Named after Hiroshima, Japanese city located in the south-east of the Honshu island, capital of the borough with the same name. In 1945 it was the first city in the world to suffer an atomic attack from the USA. The bomb caused great damage and 150.000 people were killed.

carrer.name: Hispanitat, Plaça de la
carrer.descripcio: Named after all the nations grouped under this denomination.

carrer.name: Historiador Maians, Carrer de l'
carrer.descripcio: Named after Gregori Maians i Siscar (Oliva, Safor 1699 - Valencia, Horta 1781), erudite writer. Law Professor at the University of Valencia and Royal librarian in Madrid. His works introduced in Spain many of the European intellectual tendencies of the time.

carrer.name: Homer, Carrer d'
carrer.descripcio: Named after the Greek author of 'The Iliad' and 'The' 'Odyssey'.

carrer.name: Hondures, Carrer d'
carrer.descripcio: Named after the Central American country.
carrer.anteriors: Honduras, 25/04/1945; Juan de Austria, 07/03/1939; Fluviá (2nd section), 04/02/1931; Juan de Austria, 1927; Ampurdán, 17/03/1908; Balmes, before 1900; Fluviá (2nd section), 05/09/1907; Núm. 56 (Cerdà plan)

carrer.name: Horaci, Carrer d'
carrer.descripcio: Named after Quintus Horatius Flaccus (Venusia, Apulia 65 a.C. - Rome 8 a.C.), Latin poet.
carrer.anteriors: Horacio, 05/09/1907; Nuestra Señora del Carmen, before 1864

carrer.name: Horitzontal, Carrer
carrer.descripcio: The city planners named this street "horizontal" on a whim - the street is in fact "horizontal", it is completely leveled.

carrer.name: Hort de la Bomba, Carrer de l'
carrer.descripcio: At the beginning of the 19th century the area where this street is now located was divided in little orchards, part of the last division of the lower Sant Pau del Camp orchard. The workers used to carry the water taken from the wells on their back until a water pump ("bomba") was installed near this street. The street was inaugurated in 1806.

carrer.name: Hort de la Vila, Carrer de l'
carrer.descripcio: This street runs next to what used to be the communal orchard of the town of Sarrià, the fruits of which were distributed to beggars by the local authorities.

carrer.name: Hort de Sant Pau, Carrer de l'
carrer.descripcio: Named after the orchard of the convent of Sant Pau del Camp.

carrer.name: Hort dels Velluters, Passatge de l'
carrer.descripcio: During the 16th and the 17th centuries, the Barcelona velvet makers had their stores and ateliers on this passageway.

carrer.name: Horta, Carrer d'
carrer.descripcio: The Horta village was annexed to Barcelona in 1904. The first reference to this village goes back to the year 965, when "la Vall d'Horta" is mentioned in a document related to a donation of land to the church of Sant Miquel, in Barcelona. According to the legend, at the beginning of the 12th century, Guillem d'Horta, "lord of the house of Horta", founded the Sant Joan chapel. There are signs of the existence, during the 13th century, of a small neighborhood around the church's square and of another one in the area "plana de Tarrida". The first proper urban settlement, near can Gras, dates back to 1550. The Horta family gave it the same name as the square - Santes Creus - and later was built there the town hall.

carrer.name: Horta a Cerdanyola, Carretera d'
carrer.descripcio: It indicates the way and goes through the ravine of "Forat del Vent".

carrer.name: Hortal, Carrer de l'
carrer.descripcio: Miquel Hortal i Martí, bought this property together with Antoni Vinyals, in 1856. He was succeeded by his son Miquel Hortal i Arisó (1847 - 1903), who was a piano tuner, and whom this street is named after. He married Amàlia Batet i Gil who also has a street named after her (carrer de Batet).
carrer.anteriors: Pje. de Viñals (extension of l'Hortal street)

carrer.name: Hortènsia, Carrer de l'
carrer.descripcio: Named after the flower hortensia. This street is located in the neighborhood Font de la Guatlla, where many streets have been named after flowers or plants.

carrer.name: Hortes, Carrer de les
carrer.descripcio: This name is reminiscent of the old neighborhood "les Hortes de Sant Bertran" which was delimited by the chapel of San Bertrán, the sea and the gates of Santa Madrona, San Pablo and San Antonio. At the beginning of the 15th century the orchards after which this street is named were looked after by the "workers from outside the gate of San Antonio".
carrer.anteriors: Huertas; Huertas de San Beltrán; Pje. de la Huerta

carrer.name: Hortes de Sant Bertran, Jardins de les
carrer.descripcio: The same as the street de les Hortes.

carrer.name: Horts de Sant Pau, Jardins dels
carrer.descripcio: Named after the church of Sant Pau del Camp.

carrer.name: Hospital, Passatge de l'
carrer.descripcio: Same as the street.

carrer.name: Hospital, Carrer de l'
carrer.descripcio: Named after the Holy Cross Hospital (Hospital de la Santa Creu, Barcelona's general hospital, built between 1401 and 1406) the front door of which is on this street.
carrer.anteriors: Pica de Colom; Cadenas; Ra. de Valldoncella

carrer.name: Hostafrancs de Sió, Carrer d'
carrer.descripcio: Village belonging to the borough of Aranyó (Segarra), on the right bank of the river Sió. In this area there was a guesthouse for traders which belonged to Joan Corrades i Bosch, who was born in Segarra. The new neighborhood owes its name to this fact.

carrer.name: Hostal de Sant Antoni, Carrer de l'
carrer.descripcio: Old street where a guesthouse of the same name opened mid 18th century.

carrer.name: Hostal d'en Sol, Carrer de l'
carrer.descripcio: Famous 18th century guesthouse owned by a Mr Sol.

carrer.name: Hostalric, Carrer d'
carrer.descripcio: Borough of Selva.

carrer.name: Huelva, Carrer de
carrer.descripcio: Named after the town of Huelva, in Andalucía

carrer.name: Hug de Rocabertí, Carrer d'
carrer.descripcio: Named after Bernat Hug de Rocabertí i d'Erill (1415 - 1479), a poet and officer of the army. He professed in the San Juan order and was 'comendador' of Alfambra, Monzón and Castellà d'Amposta. He fought at the side of Joan II.

carrer.name: Hurtado, Carrer d'
carrer.descripcio: Named after Antonio Hurtado (Cáceres 1825 - Madrid 1872) who was governor of Barcelona shortly before the street was opened (1879). He was also a playwright and a novelist. He was "adopted" by the city for his actions during the cholera epidemic in 1865. During the outbreak of scarlet fever in 1870, the Capitanía General was installed at his official residence. Originally, it is possible that the street was dedicated to Maria del Sagrario Hurtado i Palomeque, wife of Joaquim de Craywinckel i Craywinckel, landowner.

carrer.name: Ibèria, Plaça d'
carrer.descripcio: This square forms a group with the street with the same name dedication. The land was property of Ferran de les Llanas i Vallparda before passing to the properties of Manuel Hortal i Diumenjó in the XIX century.

carrer.name: Ibèria, Carrer d'
carrer.descripcio: This name was given by the Greeks to the eastern part of the Peninsula, starting from the Straits of Gibraltar until the Pyrenees, maybe in memory of the ancient region located near the Black Sea that existed with this name, in the Greek world. The same name is also synonym for the Iberian Peninsula.

carrer.name: Icària, Avinguda d'
carrer.descripcio: Idyllic island where the plot of 'Voyage en Icarie' takes place, Étienne Cabet's philosophical novel, a description of a country where communism was widespread. In 1846-1847 some followers of Cabet settled down to live together as a community in the Poblenou neighborhood, that is why this neighborhood has been known for a while with the name of Icària.

carrer.name: Ictíneo, Plaça de l'
carrer.descripcio: Narcís Monturiol gave this name to each one of the two submarines he invented. The first one, in 1859, was an experimental work and was hand propelled. The second one, in 1864, was the first engine that sailed submerged and provided with an artificial atmosphere regenerating itself in an indefinite way.

carrer.name: Idumea, Carrer d'
carrer.descripcio: Street referring to an old Palestinian region, south of Judea, the present Negueb. Within the neighborhood all streets are named after biblical lands of Middle East.

carrer.name: Iecla, Carrer de
carrer.descripcio: Named after Yecla, a Murcia's city. The avenue comes out onto the Segura street (name of a Murcia's river), within the Polvorí neighborhood.

carrer.name: Ifni, Carrer d'
carrer.descripcio: South-western territory of Morocco, littoral region of the Atlantic Ocean. It was partly Spanish territory from 1476 and then province between 1958 and 1969, when it was given back to Morocco.

carrer.name: Iglésias, Passatge d'
carrer.descripcio: Passageway named after Iglésias, market gardener of Barcelona, who owned lands in Poblenou at the beginning of the XIX century.

carrer.name: Ignasi Agustí, Carrer d'
carrer.descripcio: Ignasi Agustí i Peypoc (Lliçà de Vall, Vallès Oriental 1913 - Barcelona 1974). Novelist, journalist and poet.

carrer.name: Ignasi Iglésias, Carrer d'
carrer.descripcio: Ignasi Iglésias i Pujades (Sant Andreu de Palomar 1871 - Barcelona 1928). Dramatist. The street name was proposed by Joan Esteva Gili in 1929 but was officially approved later.
carrer.anteriors: Ignacio Iglesias, 14/06/1976; Orden, 07/03/1939; Ignacio Iglesias, 26/03/1930; Orden, before 1900

carrer.name: Ignasi Juliol, Plaça d'
carrer.descripcio: Street named after the owner of the property, with his ancestral house located near the square. He was councilor of the city council of Barcelona in 1809 and related to the general Manso.

carrer.name: Igualada, Carrer d'
carrer.descripcio: Borough in Anoia. The street name was proposed in memory of the fact that in 1381 this city made a petition to be integrated into Barcelona through a procedure known as 'carreratge', by which the city is considered as a street of Barcelona. According to the terms of the petition, the inhabitants of the borough enjoyed the same rights and privileges as the inhabitants of the capital. In this case, this led to a change of 'veguería' (jurisdiction of the 'veguer'), from Vilafranca to Barcelona. The privilege of 'carreratge' was granted in 1385 and was the first solicited by the city.

carrer.name: Igualtat, Passatge de la
carrer.descripcio: In honor of one of the three principles of the French Revolution: equality.

carrer.name: Ildefons Cerdà, Plaça d'
carrer.descripcio: Ildefons Cerdà i Sunyer (Centelles, Osona 1815 - Santander 1876). Engineer, town planner and politician.

carrer.name: Illas i Vidal, Carrer d'
carrer.descripcio: Joan Illas i Vidal (Barcelona 1819 - 1876). Lawyer and economist.
carrer.anteriors: Yllas y Vidal, 05/09/1907; San Salvador, before 1868

carrer.name: Immaculada, Carrer de la
carrer.descripcio: Street named after the Immaculate Conception of the Virgin Mary. The name can be related to a religious settlement in those surroundings.
carrer.anteriors: Hermenegildo Goula, 29/03/1922; Nueva de Santa Eulàlia, 18/05/1927 (2n section); Santa Eulàlia, before 1922

carrer.name: Inca, Carrer d'
carrer.descripcio: The name refers to the borough of Inca, situated in the northern part of Majorca. The street is located next to the neighborhood of Porta, where most of the streets and squares are named after towns of the Balearic Islands.

carrer.name: Independència, Carrer de la
carrer.descripcio: The dedication derives from its position, since it runs parallel to the street of Dos de Maig, and wants to evidence the fight against the Napoleonic invasion.

carrer.name: Independència, Passatge de la
carrer.descripcio: Passageway with the same dedication as the street.

carrer.name: Indians, Plaça dels
carrer.descripcio: There was an urbanization in the north-eastern part of the Maragall square, considered to be the residential center of the Spaniards of Barcelona who returned to Spain having made their fortune in Latin America, after the loss of those colonies. The name is given in memory of this episode.

carrer.name: Indíbil, Carrer d'
carrer.descripcio: (II century B.C.). Street named after the leader or king of the 'ilergetas', Iberian tribe, who rose up together with Mandoni against the Romans.

carrer.name: Índic, Carrer de l'
carrer.descripcio: Street named after the Ocean. The dedication derives from its position, near the harbor.

carrer.name: Indústria, Jardins de la
carrer.descripcio: Public space recovered after the demolition of an old factory, next to the Indústria street.

carrer.name: Indústria, Carrer de la
carrer.descripcio: Name given by the city hall, with the group of streets within the Eixample district, by proposal of Víctor Balaguer (1863), "to remember the industrial activity of Barcelona starting before the XIII century".
carrer.districtes: EIXAMPLE (02) GRÀCIA (06) SANT ANDREU (09) SANT MARTÍ (10)

carrer.name: Indústria lletra C, Passatge de la
carrer.descripcio: Passageway referring to the old property of Josep Xifré known as "Park or Tower of entertainment". His son Josep Xifré i Hamel sold it to the 'Sociedad Coll Hermanos', represented by Pasqual Coll Portabella.

carrer.name: Infància, Plaça de la
carrer.descripcio: In 1959, the Urban Development Committee of Barcelona expropriated 31 estates and one more for barter to carry out the fulfillment of the important partial plan of the East Area of 1958. During that plan this square was built.

carrer.name: Infanta Isabel, Carrer de la
carrer.descripcio: Street named after Elisabet Francisca de Asís (Madrid 1851 - 1931), daughter of Isabel II and Francisco de Asís. Street located within the housing group belonging to the marquise of Moragas in 1911, whose named was changed in 1939.

carrer.name: Infantes, Jardins de les
carrer.descripcio: Gardens belonging to the house with garden known as "Can Gasparó", in honor of Gaspar Cuyàs i Cors, later redesigned and used for public pastime. The grandson Vicenç Cuyàs Barbarà i Diumenjó was one of the most famous owners of the building. In 1932 the city hall seized the fortified house that became later the public school Duran i Bas. Dedicated to the infantes of Spain in general, since there is no name specification in the dedication, which was not made official until 1939. The name consolidation corresponded to the date of birth of the princess Margareth of Bourbon and Bourbon. During the Second Republic they were named after Magalí. According to Dr. Moran, the chant of Magalí in the poem 'Mireia', of Frederic Mistral, was the real reason for the name of the gardens of Can Cuiàs.

carrer.name: Inflamables, Moll d'
carrer.descripcio: The pier was named after the loading and unloading area for gas products and inflammable liquids.

carrer.name: Institut Escola, Pas de l'
carrer.descripcio: Model of the 'Instituto Escuela' of Madrid, to organize the teaching for the secondary school. It was supervised by Josep Estalella and was installed in the Park of the Ciudadella. The Instituto Escuela played a decisive role in the formation of the teacher training and the teaching - in Catalan - was above all formative, in contrast to the previous educative tradition. The year 1939 meant the end of the 'Instituto Escuela', but the pedagogical line of this institution and of other schools of the time continued thanks to professors and students who still worked and created school during the dictatorship. He published the 'Butlletí de l'Institut-Escola'. Name dedication proposed by 'Amics de l'Institut'-'Escola'.

carrer.name: Institut Frenopàtic, Carrer de l'
carrer.descripcio: Street that runs adjacent to the Psychiatric Institute, founded in 1862 by the doctors Tomàs Dolsa and Pau Llorach, first established in Gràcia and then transferred to the present location in 1867.

carrer.name: Institut Químic de Sarrià, Carrer de l'
carrer.descripcio: Center of the Catholic Church founded in 1916 by the Jesuit Eduardo Vitoria, recognized in 1965 by the State as Superior School of Chemical Engineering.

carrer.name: Iradier, Carrer d'
carrer.descripcio: Street named after Manuel Iradier y Buffly (Vitoria 1854 - Madrid 1911). Basque explorer.
carrer.anteriors: Joan Sardà, 1931; Iradier, 1927; Joan Sardà, 1922; Anselm Clavé, before 1922

carrer.name: Iriarte, Carrer d'
carrer.descripcio: Referring to Tomás de Iriarte (Tenerife 1750 - Madrid 1791). Writer and fabulist.

carrer.name: Irlanda, Carrer d'
carrer.descripcio: Referring to the Island of the British Archipelago.

carrer.name: Irlanda, Passatge d'
carrer.descripcio: The passageway name derives from the one of the street it comes out onto.

carrer.name: Isaac Albèniz, Carrer d'
carrer.descripcio: Street named after Isaac Manuel Francisco Alveníz i Pascual (Camprodon, Ripollès 1860 - Kanbo, Lapurdi, Basque country 1909). Catalan pianist and composer internationally known. Son of Ángel Alveníz Gauna, illegitimate son of Gasteiz, customs administration manager. Although in all ecclesiastical documents (baptism, marriage, etc.) he appears as Alveníz, its correct etymology is the one of Albéniz, name that corresponds to a small village of Vizcaya.

carrer.name: Isabel, Passatge d'
carrer.descripcio: Passageway situated in the old territory known as "camp dels Albes", where there was a landed property whose house was the guesthouse or inn of the Farigola. This passageway was dedicated to Isabel II. After the aggregation of Horta to Barcelona, a duplicity with the name of the street took place, and the passageway kept the name of Isabel.

carrer.name: Isabel de Villena, Plaça d'
carrer.descripcio: (Valencia, Horta 1430 - 1490). Religious name under which the writer and abbess Elionor Manuel de Villena was known, illegitimate daughter of Enric de Villena.

carrer.name: Isabel II, Passeig d'
carrer.descripcio: (Madrid 1830 - Paris1904). Queen of Spain (1833-1868). Daughter of Fernando VII and of Maria Cristina of the Two Sicilies. They began to open the passageway in 1834, by demolishing the stretch of walls included between Pla del Palau and the bastion of San Ramon.

carrer.name: Isabel Ribó, Passatge d'
carrer.descripcio: In 1923 Rosa Guardiola i Sitjàs, married to Josep Ribó i Batllori, acquired some lands belonging to the estate Manso Llobet, known at that time as "les Carasses". Ribó's man and wife dedicated the passageway to their only child Isabel, wife of Jaume Queraltó, who died in 1918, when she was 38 years old. After Josep Ribó's death in 1923, the property was sold in 1924.

carrer.name: Isadora Duncan, Pas d'
carrer.descripcio: (San Francisco 1878 - Nice 1927). American dancer. After a classical education, her style turned to free dance. She founded several schools to educate the most helpless children, among these the Grunewald school, in Germany, in 1904. She left several writings and it is worth mentioning 'Mi vida', which was the plot of the film 'Isadora' (1969).

carrer.name: Isard, Carrer de l'
carrer.descripcio: Integrated in a group of streets named after animals related to the Rambla del Caçador, where which they meet.

carrer.name: Isidre Nonell, Plaça d'
carrer.descripcio: Square dedicated to Isidre Nonell i Monturiol (Barcelona 1873 - 1911). Painter and draftswoman.

carrer.name: Islàndia, Plaça d'
carrer.descripcio: Square named after Iceland, an island in the North Atlantic, near the Arctic Circle that forms a country with the same name. The dedication derives from a jet of water similar to a geyser projected for this place. Therefore, they looked for sponsorship through the collaboration with Icelandic factories.

carrer.name: Isona, Carrer d'
carrer.descripcio: Borough of Pallars Jussà, in the Conca de Tremp. Group of streets named after Catalan villages within the Bon Pastor neighborhood.

carrer.name: Isop, Plaça d'
carrer.descripcio: Square named after a Greek (VI century B.C.). Greek fabulist.

carrer.name: Ítaca, Passeig d'
carrer.descripcio: Greek island of the Ionian Sea that was identified as Ulysses' fatherland. That is the reason why it has been subject matter of an archaeological research to check the information of the 'Odyssey. '

carrer.name: Ivorra, Carrer d'
carrer.descripcio: Street named after an important family of Sarrià. In the history of Sarrià's town appears a certain Joan Ivorra. Someone called Ivorra took part, on behalf of Joan II, in the capitulation of Barcelona in 1472. The street was dedicated to Ivorra in 1927, together with other Catalans who took part in the capitulation, the so-called "de Pedralbes" capitulation.
carrer.anteriors: Iborra, 1939; Jaume Piquet (continuation); Iborra; Sant Vicenç, 1922; Empresaris, before 1900

carrer.name: J. V. Foix, Avinguda de
carrer.descripcio: Josep Vicenç Foix i Mas (Sarrià 1893 - 1987). Poet, journalist and essayist. Member of the Institute for Catalan Studies. Catalan Letters Award of Honor. Gold Medals from the City of Barcelona and the Generalitat. He used the pseudonym Fòcius.

carrer.name: Jacint Guardiola, Passatge de
carrer.descripcio: Jacint Guardiola was the father of Rosa Guardiola i Sitjàs (Barcelona 1854 - 1933), who bought the land where the passageway was built, in 1923. She dedicated this passageway to her father and another to her daughter Isabel Ribó, who died in 1918.

carrer.name: Jacint Reventós, Plaça de
carrer.descripcio: Jacint Reventós i Bordoy (Barcelona 1883 - 1968). Doctor, patron of the arts. He taught tisiology at the Autonomous University of Barcelona in 1933. He was the director and co-founder of the Association of Respiratory Pathology for the Academy of Medical Sciences. He worked at Barcelona's Clinical Hospital and Saint Paul Hospital, where he was chief consultant from 1939 onwards.

carrer.name: Jacinto Benavente, Carrer de
carrer.descripcio: Jacinto Benavente y Martínez (Madrid 1866 - 1954). Spanish dramatist. He won the Nobel Prize for Literature in 1922.

carrer.name: Jacquard, Carrer de
carrer.descripcio: Joseph Marie Jacquard (Lyons 1752 - Oullins, Roine, Alps 1834). French mechanical engineer, inventor of the spinning machine, which was named after him.

carrer.name: Jadraque, Carrer de
carrer.descripcio: Owes it name to Jadraque, a borough in the Guadalajara region.

carrer.name: Jaén, Carrer de
carrer.descripcio: A city in Andalusia, formerly 'Aurgi' (Roman 'Auringis', 'Oringis') and called 'Chien' by the Moors, from where the present name is derived. Fernando III of Castile conquered it in 1246. It was reconquered and plundered in 1368 by invaders from Granada. Reclaimed by Castile, it was attacked nine times by the Moors in 1407 and 1449.

carrer.name: Ja-hi-som, Carrer de
carrer.descripcio: Access to this road is gained by climbing up the Vallvidrera hill on foot via a shortcut. When people get there they shout "ja-hi-som!" (We're there!). It leads from the Vallvidrera shortcut to the funicular. It has always been called like this.

carrer.name: Jaime Gil de Biedma, Jardins de
carrer.descripcio: (Barcelona 1929 - 1990). Spanish poet. He was a member of the Barcelona School. His work was full of colloquial language and irony, which he used as a way to comment on social and existential matters. His most well-known works are: 'Según sentencia del tiempo' (1953); 'Colección particular' (1969); 'Las' 'personas del verbo' (1975), amongst others.

carrer.name: Jambrina, Carrer de
carrer.descripcio: Rigobert Jambrina i Fernàndez, owner of land which formed part of a piece of property belonging to Joan Antoni de Peguera i Bayllet until 1836. In 1922 he was elected president of the sports group 'Avenç', which, after a merger with 'Andreuenc', became the Sant Andreu Sports Union.

carrer.name: Jane Addams, Carrer de
carrer.descripcio: Laura Jane Addams, sociologist and North American social reformer, was born in Cedarville, Illinois, on September 6th 1860. She was the daughter of John Huy Addams and Sarah Weber Addams. In 1889, together with her friend Ellen G. Starr, she founded a social establishment in Chicago called Hull House (a building constructed by Charles Hull), which became a model for other establishments and a centre of great social reform activity. Jane Addams was a pacifist and a suffragette, and a militant in favour of blacks and immigrants. A defender of women's vote, she was the president of the Women's International League for Peace and Freedom until 1929. In 1910, she was the first woman who occupied the presidency of the National Conference of Social Work in the United States. On December 10th 1931, she was awarded the Nobel Peace prize, but she was unable to attend the ceremony as she had recently been admitted to a Baltimore hospital. She died on May 21st 1935, three days after a complicated operation. The funeral took place in the courtyard of Hull House. The name of this street, together with those of other thoroughfares in the area, refers to the struggle for peace and human rights.

carrer.name: Japó, Carrer del
carrer.descripcio: Owes its name to Japan, the archipelago and country in Asia.

carrer.name: Jardins d'Alfàbia, Plaça dels
carrer.descripcio: It recalls the gardens found on a property in the borough of Bunyola (West Majorca).

carrer.name: Tòquio, Jardins de
carrer.descripcio: Named for the same reason as is the street.

carrer.name: Jardins d'Elx, Plaça dels
carrer.descripcio: The original gardens bearing this name, found in the town of Elx, Baix Vinalopó, were added to Unesco's World Heritage List in 2000.

carrer.name: Jaume Brossa, Carrer de
carrer.descripcio: Jaume Brossa i Roger (Barcelona 1869 - 1919). Writer who laid the foundations of the Modernist movement's ideology, and who formed part of the anarchic literary movement in Catalonia which contributed to the downfall of the 1896 repression. He wrote for the publications 'Catalonia', 'L'Avenç' and 'Revista Blanca'. He edited 'Iberia' and 'El Diluvio'. He died as a result of a flu epidemic.

carrer.name: Jaume Cabrera, Carrer de
carrer.descripcio: (? - after 1412). He painted in Barcelona and was possibly trained at the Serra brothers' studio. He started working independently from 1394 until 1432, during which time his paintings evolved from the style of the Serra brothers, to the Italogothic, showed influences from Borrassà and the International Gothic style. He is an extremely popular artist.
carrer.anteriors: Jaime Cabrera; Lletra F (Casa Móra residential area)

carrer.name: Jaume Càncer, Carrer de
carrer.descripcio: (Barbastro, Aragon 1549 - 1631). Jurist and lawyer. Doctor in Civil and Canon Law, he was one of the best lawyers in Catalonia of his time.

carrer.name: Jaume Cascalls, Carrer de
carrer.descripcio: (Berga, Berguedà ? - 1378). Sculptor. He lived in Barcelona where he worked on commission for Pere III of Catalonia and Aragon.
carrer.anteriors: Jaime Cascall; Lletra C (Casa Móra residential area)

carrer.name: Jaume Fabra, Carrer de
carrer.descripcio: A family of landowners in the area who records show to be heirs to Camil Fabra.

carrer.name: Jaume Fabre, Carrer de
carrer.descripcio: (Majorca 13th-14th centuries). Master builder from Majorca. It would seem that he drew the final plans for the cathedral of Barcelona (1317).

carrer.name: Jaume Giralt, Carrer de
carrer.descripcio: Popular pronunciation of Jaume Gerart or Girart, a man of distinction in Barcelona during the Middle Ages. The reference could either be to one of the first ministers in the 'Council of the Hundred' - the regional parliament- (1249) who later became the city's chief councilor (1258). Or to Jaume Girart, the chief councilor in 1300. Or, finally, to the Bishop of Barcelona from 1445 to 1456, who also had the same name.

carrer.name: Jaume Huguet, Carrer de
carrer.descripcio: (Valls, Alt Camp 1415 - Barcelona 1492). Painter. One of the best representatives of Medieval Catalan art.

carrer.name: Jaume Huguet, Plaça de
carrer.descripcio: For the same reason as the street.

carrer.name: Jaume I, Carrer de
carrer.descripcio: (Montpellier, Languedoc 1208 - Valencia, Horta 1276). Count of Barcelona and King of Aragon (1213-1276), King of Valencia (1239-1276) and of Majorca (1229-1276) and Lord of Montpellier. Known as 'el Conqueridor' (the Conquerer). Son of Pere I the Catholic and María Montpellier.

carrer.name: Jaume II, Plaça de
carrer.descripcio: Jaume II of Catalonia and Aragon, (Valencia, Horta 1267 - Barcelona 1327), he was known as 'el Just' (the Just). Count of Barcelona, King of Aragon, Valencia, Majorca and Sicily. Son of Pere 'el Gran' and Constança of Sicily. He instigated policies to unite Spain. The square is named after him due to his relationship to the Monastery of Pedrables through his wife, Queen Elisenda of Montcada, who founded the monastery.
carrer.anteriors: Jaime II; Central (Casa Móra residential area)

carrer.name: Jaume Martí, Carrer de
carrer.descripcio: Originally dedicated to Jaume Martí i Batista, father to the owner of the land, Pere Martí i Vilaplana. Unaware of this fact, the 1980 nomenclature named the street after Jaume Martí i Miquel (Villajoyosa, Marina Baja 1840 - Madrid 1910). Journalist and poet.

carrer.name: Jaume Pinent, Carrer de
carrer.descripcio: Jaume Pinent i Pedrol (Barcelona 1869 - 1922). Married for the third time to Rosa Valls i Graells, daughter of the owner of the land where the road was built, Joaquim Valls i Martí.

carrer.name: Jaume Piquet, Carrer de
carrer.descripcio: Jaume Piquet i Piera (Les Corts de Sarrià 1839 - Sarrià 1896). Writer and theatre manager, carpenter and engraver. Philanthropist. He lived and died in a house in this street.
carrer.anteriors: Jaime Piquet, 18/05/1927 (ratified on 04/02/1931); Iborra (joined to it), 18/05/1927 (on 42/07/07 it is named again Iborra); Libertad (joined to it), before 1900 (ratified on 09/10/1928); Montesa (joined to it), 18/05/1927 (on 42/07/07 it is named Montero

carrer.name: Jaume Planas i Alemany, Jardins de
carrer.descripcio: (Barcelona 1910 - 1993). Woodcarver and wordsmith, he used a plane by day and pencils by night and on holidays. He was a voluntary fighter in support of the Republicans in 1936. He was a founder member of the Carmel Neighborhood Association.

carrer.name: Jaume Puigvert, Carrer de
carrer.descripcio: (17th century). Commander of the Generalitat's regiment. He died in combat in the 1639 Siege of Salses.

carrer.name: Jaume Roig, Carrer de
carrer.descripcio: (Valencia, Horta ? - Benimámet, Horta 1478). Doctor and poet. Author of 'Llibre' 'dels Consellers' o 'Llibre de les Dones', published in 1531. Physician to María of Castile, wife to Alfons 'el magnànim'.
carrer.anteriors: Jaime Roig, 29/03/1922; Castilla, 05/09/1907; San Rafael, before 1900

carrer.name: Jaume Roig, Passatge de
carrer.descripcio: Jaume Roig is one of the signatories of a manifesto, dating from April 1883, in which the inhabitants of the Sants neighborhood claimed that the area should form part of Barcelona. Of the three inhabitants living in the neighborhood at the time with the same name and surname, the most likely person to have signed the document is a certain Jaume Roig i Reventós (L'Hospitalet, Barcelonès 1855 - Sants, 31st July 1883). No other connection has been able to be made between Jaume Roig i Reventós and the street. Nevertheless, the dedication has been accepted.

carrer.name: Jaume Sabartés, Plaça de
carrer.descripcio: Jaume Sabartés i Gual (Barcelona 1881 - Paris 1968). Sculptor and writer. He settled in Paris in 1935 and was Picasso's private secretary. He published 'Picasso en su obra' (1935), in Madrid; 'Picasso' (1937), in Milan y the biography' portraits et souvenirs' (1946), in Paris. He successfully served as a link between Picasso and Catalonia by securing the agreement on 27th July 1960 with the city authorities to create the Picasso Museum. After working for Picasso for twenty-five years, he had amassed a large collection of the artist's works, which he donated, to the city of Barcelona.

carrer.name: Jaume Vicens i Vives, Carrer de
carrer.descripcio: Jaume Vicens i Vives (Girona 1910 - Lyons 1960). Historian. He studied philosophy and arts in Barcelona (1926-30), where he was taught by Antonio de la Torre y Pere Bosch i Gimpera.

carrer.name: Jaume Vicens i Vives, Jardins de
carrer.descripcio: (Girona 1910 - Lyons 1960). Historian. He studied philosophy and arts in Barcelona (1926-30). Prolific writer. Professor of geography and history at Figueres College, and of modern history at the universities of Zaragoza and Barcelona.

carrer.name: Jean Genet, Plaça de
carrer.descripcio: (Paris 1910 - 1986). French writer. Abandoned at the age of ten, he spent most of his youth in institutions for juvenile delinquents and later in prison. He was a male prostitute and delinquent in Barcelona and other European cities. These experiences marked all of his literary output, from his autobiographical works such as 'Our Lady of the Flowers' (1944) and 'The Thief's Journal' (1949), to his plays 'The Maids' (1947), through to his novels such as 'Querelle'. 'The Maids' made him one of the most important dramatists of the Vanguard Movement. He dealt basically with problems of identity, estrangement and political, social and religious prejudices. Name proposed by the organization 'la Ponència' and by Lluís Permanyer.

carrer.name: Jerez, Carrer de
carrer.descripcio: Jerez de la Frontera, an Andalusian town. The road starts in 'calle de Porto' (Port) and is connected to the latter because of the reputation for good wines that both cities have.

carrer.name: Jericó, Carrer de
carrer.descripcio: Palestinian city. The street is located in the Vall d'Hebron neighborhood, where most of the streets are named after places and towns in the Holy Land.

carrer.name: Jerusalem, Carrer de
carrer.descripcio: Named after the convent Santa Maria de Jerusalem established in this street.

carrer.name: Jesús, Carrer de
carrer.descripcio: The road owes its name to the nearby church 'iglesia de Jesús', belonging to the Franciscan friary, which was established in 1823 and made the parish church in 1836.

carrer.name: Jesús i Maria, Carrer de
carrer.descripcio: The name is taken from the boarding school, established in the street in 1893, run by the nuns of the order 'Jesús i María'.

carrer.name: Jiménez i Iglesias, Carrer de
carrer.descripcio: Ignacio Jiménez Martín and Francisco Iglesias Brage. Aviators who made the first transatlantic flight in the plane 'Jesús del Gran Poder'.
carrer.anteriors: Aviadors Jiménez i Iglesias, 12/06/1980; Aviadores Jiménez e Iglesias, 10/12/1929

carrer.name: Joan Alcover, Carrer de
carrer.descripcio: Joan Alcover i Maspons (Ciudad de Mallorca 1854 - 1926). Poet, essayist, lawyer and politician. Corresponding member of the Royal Spanish Academy, the Fine Arts Academy of Barcelona and the Institute for Catalan Studies (1916).

carrer.name: Joan Altisent, Jardins de
carrer.descripcio: Joan Altisent i Ceardi (Barcelona 1891 - 1971). Composer of instrumental and chorus music. His opera 'Amunt!' and his ballet 'Gavines '(1962) were premiered at the 'Liceo de Barcelona' theatre.

carrer.name: Joan Amades, Plaça de
carrer.descripcio: Joan Amades i Gelat (Barcelona 1890 - 1959). Specialist in folklore, famous for his work 'Costumari català'. Curator at Barcelona's 'Museo de Industrias y Arte Popular' in the Spanish Village (Poble Espanyol). He was responsible for the section of popular engravings at the AHCB.

carrer.name: Joan Blanques, Carrer de
carrer.descripcio: Chief consul of Perpignan (1473). He defended the union of Roussillon with Catalonia in the 1462-1472 civil war.

carrer.name: Joan Carles I, Plaça de
carrer.descripcio: Juan Carlos I de Borbón y Borbón (Rome 1938). Constitutional king of Spain. Proclaimed king on 22nd November, 1975.

carrer.name: Joan Casanelles, Plaça de
carrer.descripcio: Joan Casanelles i Ibars (Barcelona 1904 - 1986). Politician and lawyer. Deputy mayor of Barcelona and member of the Catalan parliament (1933) and later of the national parliament representing the party 'Esquerra Republicana de Catalunya'.

carrer.name: Joan Casas, Passatge de
carrer.descripcio: Joan Casas i Villarubias (Barcelona 1774 - 1853). Landowner. Cotton manufacturer. He bought land in the Grossot neighborhood.

carrer.name: Joan Comorera, Carrer de
carrer.descripcio: Joan Comorera i Soler (Cervera, Segarra 1895 - Burgos 1958). Politician. He became a member of the USC in 1931. In 1934 and 1936 he was minister for agriculture and economy, and in 1937 for labor, public works and justice in the local autonomous government. In 1936 he was appointed general secretary of the Catalan Socialist Party (PSUC). In 1939 he went into exile to France, Moscow and Mexico. In 1951 he returned under an assumed name, Josep Planes I Valls, and settled in Ripoll. He was arrested in Barcelona in 1954, put on trial and sent Burgos prison, where he died.

carrer.name: Joan Cornudella, Plaça de
carrer.descripcio: Joan Cornudella i Barberà (Les Borges Blanques, Garrigues 1904 - Barcelona 1985). Politician. Read economics at university. Member of Catalonias's autonomous parliament.

carrer.name: Joan Coromines, Plaça de
carrer.descripcio: Joan Coromines i Vigneaux (Barcelona 1905 - Pineda de Mar, Maresme 1997). Linguist. He began his studies in Barcelona and finished them in Montpellier, Madrid, Zurich and Paris. He taught Romance languages at the University of Barcelona until 1939, when he went into exile. He was a professor at Argentina's University of Cuyo until 1948. From there he went on to the University of Chicago, where he worked until he retired. A member of the Institute for Catalan Studies, he was also a scholar of Catalan, Spanish and Occitan, as well as being an expert in Indo-European and Arabic linguistics. In 1989 he was awarded the Spanish Arts National Prize. His most noteworthy works include 'Diccionario crítico' 'etimológico de la lengua castellana' (1957), 'Estudis de toponímia' 'catalana' (1970), 'Diccionari Etimológic y Complementari de la Llengua' 'Catalana' (1988) and 'Onomasticon Cataloniae', an exhaustive compilation of place names in Catalonia which he began in 1931 and which he was still working on at the time of his death. He was married to Bárbara de Haro y Rodríguez, from Bédar, Almeria. The official ceremony to name this square took place on 30th April 1997.

carrer.name: Joan Corrades, Plaça de
carrer.descripcio: Joan Corrades i Bosch (Hostafrancs de Sió, Segarra 1814 - Barcelona 1875). In 1840 he built the Hostal in the Hostafrancs neighborhood. In doing so his place of birth became the name of one of the city's boroughs.

carrer.name: Joan Cortada, Carrer de
carrer.descripcio: Joan Cortada i Sala (Sant Gervasi de Cassoles, Barcelona 1805 - 1868). Writer and philosopher.

carrer.name: Joan d'Alòs, Carrer de
carrer.descripcio: Joan d'Alòs i de Rius (? - 1746). Lifelong city councillor. He owned the Torre Ponsic property and other land in the Sarrià neighborhood. He was married to Maria Francesca Fontanet. His brother Francesc was the regent of the Royal Audience in Catalonia.
carrer.anteriors: Juan de Alós, 25/09/1931; Juan de Alós, 19/11/1929; Finestrelles

carrer.name: Joan d'Àustria, Carrer de
carrer.descripcio: (Regensburg 1545 - Bruges 1578). King Carlos I and Bárbara Blomberg's illegitimate child. Chief of naval operations in the Mediterranean. He commanded operations at the battle of Lepanto.
carrer.anteriors: Juan de Austria, 07/07/1942; Lepanto (1st section), 01/08/1929; Polonia, 17/03/1908; Lepanto; Núm. 41 (Cerdà plan)

carrer.name: Joan de Borbó Comte de Barcelona, Passeig de
carrer.descripcio: Juan de Borbón y Battenberg (La Granja de San Ildefonso 1913 - Pamplona, Navarre 1993). Infante of Spain (1919-33) Prince of Girona, Asturias and Viana (1941-1993): Count of Barcelona and head of the Spanish royal household. Son of King Alfonso XIII, he was forced into exile when the Second Republic was proclaimed. He abdicated in favor of his son Juan Carlos.

carrer.name: Joan de Palomar, Carrer de
carrer.descripcio: (15th century). Archdeacon at the cathedral of Barcelona.

carrer.name: Joan de Peguera, Carrer de
carrer.descripcio: Joan Antoni de Peguera i de Bayllet (1755 - 1837). Landowner. The last in a line of knights and noblemen from Barcelona. He died without descendants in 1837. He was buried at Sants cemetery. His first marriage was to Maria Eulàlia de Fluvià i de Berart, daughter to the Baron of Esponelà, in 1785. Widowed, he married Maria Miquela de Borràs i de Valls in 1829. On 13th March 1862, the Sant Martí de Provençals town authorities agreed to change the name from 'carrer Montserrat' to 'carrer Don Juan de Peguera' at the behest of his widow, who by then had married Maties Ramon de Casanovas.
carrer.anteriors: Juan de Peguera, before 1900; Don Juan de Peguera, 1862; Montserrat

carrer.name: Joan Fuster i Ortells, Jardins de
carrer.descripcio: (Sueca, Ribera Baixa 1922 - 1992). Writer and graduate of law. He was a noted Carlist in the county where he was born. Among many other works he published: 'Sobre Narcís' (1949); 'Escrit per el silenci' (1954); 'Joan Serrallonga' (1961); 'Raimon' (1964); 'Babels i babilònies' (1972). He is without a doubt the most outstanding Catalan essayist to have emerged from the post-Civil War generation.

carrer.name: Joan Gamper, Carrer de
carrer.descripcio: Joan (Hans) Gamper i Hässig (Winterthur, Zurich, Switzerland 1877 - Barcelona 1930). Sportsman, he founded the F.C Barcelona football club in 1899. He was married to Emma Pilloud i Robin, who was from Girona.
carrer.anteriors: Juan Gamper, 04/03/1947; Crisantemos, 07/03/1939; Juan Gamper, 06/06/1934; Crisantemos, 23/11/1911; Exportación, 25/11/1909; San José, 08/09/1848

carrer.name: Joan Goula, Passatge de
carrer.descripcio: Joan Goula i Soley (Sant Feliu de Guíxols, Baix Empordà 1843 - Buenos Aires 1917). Composer and conductor.

carrer.name: Joan Güell, Carrer de
carrer.descripcio: Joan Güell i Ferrer (Torredembarra, Tarragonès 1800 - Barcelona 1872). Manufacturer and economist. Together with Ramis and other associates he founded the textile factory 'El Vapor Vell de Sants'. City councilor, member of the national parliament and senator (1862).
carrer.anteriors: Juan Güell; Lletra M (map of Les Corts)

carrer.name: Joan I, Carrer de
carrer.descripcio: King Joan I of Catalonia and Aragon (Perpignan, Roussillon 1350 - Foixà, Alt Empordà 1396), known as 'el Descurat' (the Careless) or 'el Caçador' (the Hunter) or 'l'Aimador de la Gentilesa' (Lover of Courtesy). King of Catalonia and Aragon (1387-1396), son of Pere III, 'el Cerimoniós 'and Elionor of Sicily.

carrer.name: Joan Llarch, Jardí de
carrer.descripcio: Joan Llarch i Roig (Barcelona 1920 - 1987). Writer from Sarrià. He published novels, biographies, tales, historical works, etc. As a journalist he made contributions to 'Tele Expres', 'El Noticiero', 'Destino', 'La Vanguardia', amongst others. He was a man of great human kindness which is reflected in his work.

carrer.name: Joan Llongueras, Plaça de
carrer.descripcio: Joan Llongueras i Badia (Barcelona 1880 - 1953). Musician. Founder and director of the dance school 'l'Institut Català de Rítmica i Plàstica', 'Joan Llongueras Institute'.

carrer.name: Joan Manén, Carrer de
carrer.descripcio: Joan Manén i Planas (Barcelona 1883 - 1971). Violin player and composer. His career began with a public performance when he was aged seven. He is considered to be one of the masters of violin playing. He wrote many works, his autobiography, a treatise on the violin and librettos for opera.

carrer.name: Joan Maragall, Jardins de
carrer.descripcio: Joan Marital i Groin (Barcelona 1860 - 1911). Writer and poet. Founder member of the department of philology at the Institute for Catalan Studies. Master in the art of poetry and president of the Athenaeum of Barcelona.

carrer.name: Joan Massana, Carrer de
carrer.descripcio: Joan Massana i Badia, officer in the royal corps the 'Vales Reales'. A hero in the War of Independence. He was executed in 1809.

carrer.name: Joan Mirambell i Bertran, Passatge de
carrer.descripcio: (El Masnou, Maresme 1796 - 1863). Mariner. In 1834 he was the commander of the pollaca the 'Constancia', of which he was the owner. Risking his own life, he opened trade routes with the new countries in the Americas who were still at war with Spain. This gave rise to great growth in trade and industry in Barcelona and in the rest of the country.

carrer.name: Joan Miró, Parc de
carrer.descripcio: Joan Miró i Ferrà (Barcelona 1893 - Palma de Mallorca 1983). Universally acclaimed painter and sculptor. The park was built over the land where Barcelona's slaughter house once stood. Its area is equivalent to four blocks of the 'Eixample' district.

carrer.name: Joan Miró, Carrer de
carrer.descripcio: Joan Miró i Ferrà (Barcelona 1893 - Palma de Mallorca 1983). Universally acclaimed painter and sculptor. He created the Study Center for Contemporary Arts, the 'Fundació Miró. '
carrer.anteriors: Joan d'Àustria (a section); Vila Olímpica 3 (not official)

carrer.name: Joan Obiols, Carrer de
carrer.descripcio: Joan Obiols i Vié (Granollers, Vallès Oriental 1919 - Barcelona 1980). Psychiatrist.

carrer.name: Joan Oliver, Carrer de
carrer.descripcio: Joan Oliver i Sallarès (Sabadell, Vallès Occidental 1899 - Barcelona 1986). Writer. Awarded the Catalan Theatre Prize (1938). The Ausiàs March and Golden Letter prizes. Catalan Letters Award of Honor (1970).

carrer.name: Joan Orpí, Carrer de
carrer.descripcio: Joan Orpí (Piera, Anoia 1593 - Nueva Barcelona, Venezuela 1645). Conquistador and coloniser of Venezuela. In 1638 he founded the city which he named Nova Barcelona. A graduate in Canon Law and doctor in Civil Law, he belonged to the farming family, the Orpí del Pou. On setting sail he used the pseudonym Gregorio Izquierdo.
carrer.anteriors: Juan de Urpí, 18/05/1927; Ferrer Bassa; Roca

carrer.name: Joan Peiró, Plaça de
carrer.descripcio: Joan Peiró i Belis (Barcelona 1887 - Paterna, Horta 1942). Anarcho-syndicalist who started his life as a militant in Badalona, in the glass makers' union 'the Federación Española de Vidrieros y Cristaleros'. He was the minister for industry in Largo Caballero's government.

carrer.name: Joan Riera, Carrer de
carrer.descripcio: The street was originally dedicated to Joan Riera i Saladrigas, the father of the owner of the land, Francesca Riera Molins, who was married to Pere Martí Vilaplana. Unaware of this fact the 1980 nomenclature attributed the origin of the name to the sculptor Joan Riera (Arenys de Mar, Maresme 1578 - 1638).

carrer.name: Joan Sales, Carrer de
carrer.descripcio: Joan Sales i Vallès (Barcelona 1912 - 1983). Writer and publisher. Law graduate. He went into exile in 1939, living mainly in Mexico, where he published together with Ferran Pol and others 'Quaderns de l'Exili'. He returned to Barcelona in 1948, where he went into publishing. He was the technical advisor for the book 'Historia dels Catalans' which was edited by Ferran Soldevila. His greatest novel is 'Incerta gloria'.

carrer.name: Joan Torras, Carrer de
carrer.descripcio: Joan Torras i Guardiola (Sant Andreu de Palomar 1827 - Barcelona 1910). Architect and professor.
carrer.anteriors: Juan Torras, 10/05/1917; T. de Paixalet (a section), before 1900

carrer.name: Joan Vinyoli, Jardins de
carrer.descripcio: Joan Vinyoli i Pladevall (Barcelona 1914 - 1984). Poet. He received numerous prizes: from the City of Barcelona, the Generalitat of Catalonia and the National Literature Prize.

carrer.name: Joan XXIII, Avinguda de
carrer.descripcio: Angelo Giuseppe Roncalli Mazola (Sotto il Monte, Bergamo 1881 - Rome 1963). Pope from 1958 to 1963. He convoked the Second Vatican Council (1962).
carrer.anteriors: Papa Joan XXIII; Papa Juan XXIII

carrer.name: Joana Tomàs, Jardins de
carrer.descripcio: Joana Tomàs i Sabaté (Barcelona 1933 - 1982). Backed by the neighbourhood association of the Clot-Camp de l'Arpa area, he managed to have company 'Alcohols Mompet' relocated due to the dangerous nature of such an industry.

carrer.name: Joanic, Plaça d'en
carrer.descripcio: Esteve Juanich i March (Granollers, Vallès Oriental 1793 - Barcelona 1869). Landowner of 12 'mujades' in the Gràcia district where the square bearing his name and the street 'carrer de l'Escorial' were built.

carrer.name: Joanot Martorell, Carrer de
carrer.descripcio: (Gandía, Safor 1413 - 1468). Knight and writer. Author of 'Tirant lo Blanc'.

carrer.name: Joaquim Blume, Carrer de
carrer.descripcio: Joaquim Blume i Carreras (Barcelona 1933 - Sierra de Valdemecas, Castile, in a flying accident 1959). Gymnast. European champion in 1957.

carrer.name: Joaquim Domingo i Sánchez, Jardins de
carrer.descripcio: (Barcelona 1917 - 1981). He was born and lived in the Sants neighborhood. He was an excellent billiards player. He was a member of the 'Billar Sants' billiard club from an early age. He was second in the world amateur championship when he was 18. He won a total of 150 titles. He was awarded the City of Barcelona Gold Medal for Sportsmanship.

carrer.name: Joaquim Folguera, Plaça de
carrer.descripcio: Joaquim Folguera i Poal (Santa Coloma de Cervelló, Baix Llobregat 1893 - Barcelona 1919). Literary critic and poet.

carrer.name: Joaquim Molins, Carrer de
carrer.descripcio: Joaquim Molins i Galí (Barcelona 1844 - 1902). Landowner. Unmarried bother of the owner of the Torre Rodona property, in the Les Corts district. It seems that the street was originally dedicated to Ignàsia Molins i Milà, daughter of Miquel and Madrona, who had inherited the land where the road was built from her husband Bonaventura Piera i Prats, who died in 1857. The name 'Molins' was maintained as the street name until the middle of the 20th century, when it was modified by adding the Christian name 'Joaquim' to the surname 'Molins.'

carrer.name: Joaquim Pena, Plaça de
carrer.descripcio: Joaquim Pena i Costa (Barcelona 1873 - 1944). Musicologist and music critic. A leading spirit of Barcelona's Wagnerian movement. He lived and died in a house in the square, formerly called 'plaça de Llevant'.

carrer.name: Joaquim Puig i Pidemunt, Carrer de
carrer.descripcio: Joaquim Puig i Pidemunt (Osor, Selva 1907 - executed before a firing squad in Barcelona, Camp de la Bota 1949). Spokesman for food on the Generalitat's Board of Finances between 1936 and 1938. He founded the publication 'Catalunya' in France during the German occupation. During the same period he founded 'Lluita', the mouthpiece for the Catalan Socialist Party (PSUC). Member of the PSUC's executive committee in Catalonia, from 1945 to 1949, a post which he continued to hold until his execution.

carrer.name: Joaquim Pujol, Passatge de
carrer.descripcio: Joaquim Pujol i Marcé, landowner and industrialist who set up an important leather works in the passageway.

carrer.name: Joaquim Renart, Passeig de
carrer.descripcio: Joaquim Renart i Garcia (Barcelona 1879 - 1961). Sketcher, guilder, decorator, collector and bookplate maker. He founded the arts' organization FAD (1903).

carrer.name: Joaquim Rita, Passatge de
carrer.descripcio: Joaquim Rita i León (Mahon, Menorca 1859 - Barcelona 1922). Owner of the land from 1915.

carrer.name: Joaquim Ruyra, Carrer de
carrer.descripcio: Joaquim Ruyra i Oms (Girona 1858 - Barcelona 1939). Writer and poet. Landowner.
carrer.anteriors: Joaquín Ruyra, 13/04/1949; Poeta Balart, 07/07/1942; Joaquín Ruyra, 13/03/1936

carrer.name: Joaquim Ruyra, Jardins de
carrer.descripcio: Named for the same reason as the street.

carrer.name: Joaquim Sunyer, Carrer de
carrer.descripcio: Joaquim Sunyer i de Miró (Sitges, Garraf 1874 - 1956). Painter and engraver. Légion d'Honneur (1949). First prize at the Hispano-American Biennial, Havana (1954).

carrer.name: Joaquim Valls, Carrer de
carrer.descripcio: Joaquim Valls i Martí (La Sénia, Montsià 1870 - Barcelona 1948). From 1916 he owned the land on a piece of property called 'Can Dragó', where the street was built. He was married to Josepa Graells i Jobal.

carrer.name: Joaquim Xirau i Palau, Plaça de
carrer.descripcio: Joaquim Xirau i Palau (Figueres, Alt Empordà 1895 - Mexico 1946). Philosopher and pedagogue. He studied philosophy in Barcelona and did his doctorate in Madrid. He completed his studies in Madrid. He was a grammar school teacher in Vigo and lecturer at the University of Zaragoza. He came to Barcelona in 1927, where he taught until his exile to Mexico in 1939. He was a member of the Socialist Union of Catalonia. He wrote many books on philosophy.

carrer.name: Joaquima Raspall, Jardí de
carrer.descripcio: Joaquima Raspall i Juanicó, teacher. She was born in Poblenou, on 9th February 1877, where she was popularly known as Donya Quimeta. She worked there as a teacher for more than seventy years, and taught four generations of girls in the district. She died in Barcelona, on the 2nd March 1968, in the Carrer de Wad-ras, 236 (nowadays, Carrer Doctor Trueta).

carrer.name: Joaquín Costa, Carrer de
carrer.descripcio: Joaquín Costa i Martínez (Monzón 1846 - Graus 1911). Writer, lawyer and politician.

carrer.name: Joaquín Maurín, Plaça de
carrer.descripcio: Joaquín Maurín i Julià (Bonansa, Alta Ribagorça 1896 - New York 1973). Writer and politician. He was a militant member of the CNT and, as such, a delegate at the International Trades Union Congress in Moscow. He confronted the anarchists to defend the right of the CNT to stay in the ISR. He was a member of the Spanish communist party's (PCE) central committee. Despite differences with the party he created the worker's organisation the 'Bloque Obrero y Campesino'. He was expelled from the PCE in 1931. He was the driving force behind Catalonia's Workers' Alliance. In 1935 he was elected secretary general of POUM. Member of parliament in 1936. He wrote 'La Revolución española' (1932) and 'Hacia la Segunda Revolución' (1935). Proposal made by Manuel Alberich.

carrer.name: Jocs del 92, Carrer dels
carrer.descripcio: To commemorate the 1992 Barcelona Olympic Games.

carrer.name: Jocs Florals, Carrer dels
carrer.descripcio: Pays homage to the annual poetry competition the 'Jocs Florals'. King Joan I established the event in 1393. After circumstantial interruptions over the centuries, the event was reinstated in 1859.

carrer.name: Johann Sebastian Bach, Carrer de
carrer.descripcio: Johann Sebastian Bach Lämmerhirt (Eisenach, Thuringia 1685 - Leipzig, Saxony 1750). World famous German composer.
carrer.anteriors: Juan Sebastián Bach, 29/04/1959; Compositor Bach, 07/07/1942; Lletra F (Turó Park residential area)

carrer.name: John F. Kennedy, Plaça de
carrer.descripcio: John Fitzgerald Kennedy (Brooklyn 1917 - Dallas 1963). President of the United States of America (1961-1963).

carrer.name: John Lennon, Plaça de
carrer.descripcio: John Winston Lennon (Liverpool, Lancashire 1940 - New York 1980). Musician and song writer. He met up with Paul McCartney and George Harrison in 1956, and with Ringo Starr later on. Together they formed the group The Beatles.

carrer.name: Joncar, Carrer del
carrer.descripcio: Former name of the Poblenou neighborhood. An area with sandbanks and marshes full of rushes. Used by the army, it was an area reserved for hunting for Catalonia's top officials. King Carlos IV was there on occasion in 1802.

carrer.name: Jonquera, Carrer de la
carrer.descripcio: Borough in the Alt Empordà region. A possible etymological explanation for the name is that it comes from 'Iounkarion Pedion', in Greek; 'Iuncarius Campus', in Latin; 'juncars' (marshland), because of the marshes along the coast. The road separates the railway track from the Mar Bella beach.

carrer.name: Jonqueres, Carrer de
carrer.descripcio: The name is taken from the old Jonqueres monastery, founded in 1214, whose name is adopted from the convent in Sant Vicenç de les Jonqueres (in the borough of Castell d'Arraona, in Sabadell). The nuns moved to the outskirts of Barcelona in 1293. The name established itself and lasted: the Merdançer stream which flowed there soon became known as the Jonqueres stream; a street with the name appeared near the monastery. In the 15th century it was accepted as a place name 'el forn de Jonqueres' (the Jonqueres bakery).

carrer.name: Jorba, Carrer de
carrer.descripcio: Dionís Jeroni Jorba (Barcelona 16th century). Humanist. Professor of law and humanities in Barcelona.

carrer.name: Jorba, Passatge de
carrer.descripcio: The brothers Josep and Isidre Jorba i Raventós (Castellolí, Anoia 1893 - Barcelona 1972) bought the land where the passageway was built in 1924.

carrer.name: Jordà, Avinguda del
carrer.descripcio: River in Palestine. The street is located in the Vall d'Hebron neighborhood, where most of the streets are named after places and towns in the Holy Land.

carrer.name: Jordà, Carrer de
carrer.descripcio: Josep Jordà i Cirera (1801 - 1866). Owner of the property where the street was built in 1842.

carrer.name: Jordi de Sant Jordi, Carrer de
carrer.descripcio: (Valencia ? - 1424). Poet and knight. Royal chamberlain under the protection of Alfons 'el magnànim'.
carrer.anteriors: Jordi de San Jordi; Sales y Ferrer; La Habana; Font Catalana ?

carrer.name: Jordi Ferran, Passatge de
carrer.descripcio: Jordi Ferran i Sol (Lleida, Segrià 1929). His grandfather was Salvador Ferran i Curcoll (1865 - 1951), son to Pere and Maria. Builder. He was married to Eulàlia Piera i Martí (1866 - 1953). They owned the land where the passageway was built. It was the grandmother's wish that the passageway be named after her first grandchild.

carrer.name: Jordi Girona, Carrer de
carrer.descripcio: Jordi Girona i Salgado (Barcelona 1903 - 1936). A reserve officer, he took an active part in the military uprising on 18th July 1936. It is thought that he was assassinated in the same year. The street is located on land that his family owned.

carrer.name: Jordi Rubió i Balaguer, Carrer de
carrer.descripcio: (Barcelona 1887 - 1982). Professor, lecturer, librarian and researcher. His achievements and merits include: President of the Institute for Catalan Studies (1968-1970) and Catalan Letters Award of Honor (1969).

carrer.name: Jorge Manrique, Carrer de
carrer.descripcio: Jorge Manrique y de Figueroa (Paredes de Nava 1440 - Castillo de Garci-Muñoz, Castile 1479). Spanish poet and nobleman. Lord of Belmonte. Commander of the Order of Santiago. He died defending Isabella the Catholic against Beltraneja partisans.

carrer.name: José Millán González, Carrer de
carrer.descripcio: (Barcelona 1893 - Sant Miquel de Campmajor, Pla de l'Estany 1939). Journalist. Publicist. He taught physical education at the school 'Escuela de Trabajo', and at the city's municipal cultural institutions. He was officially posted as teacher of physical education by the city authorities in 1925. He organised popular sports events especially for children and teenagers, and he instituted campaigns to promote physical education in schools.
carrer.anteriors: Pompeyo Gener; Cº Coll del Portell (a section)

carrer.name: José Sánchez Ríos, Plaça de
carrer.descripcio: (Alcalá de los Gazules, Cádiz 1941 - Barcelona 1990). Metal worker at SEAT.

carrer.name: Josep Amat, Jardins de
carrer.descripcio: Josep Amat i Pagès (Barcelona 1901 - 1991). Painter and sketcher. He lived in Barcelona, Sant Feliu de Guíxols and in Paris. He came from a family of artists and was a neighbor and disciple of Joaquim Sunyer. He later met Josep Mir and together they went on trips to study art around Catalonia. He was a teacher at the Sant Jordi School of Fine Arts. He developed an impressionist style and his catalogue of works is made up of rural and urban landscapes. They are marked by an interest in atmospheric effects which are the focal point of his painting and which show the influence he received from Mir and Dufy. His works hang in the National Museum of Art of Catalonia, the Reina Sofia Museum, the Museum of Fine Arts of Bilbao and in Sant Feliu de Guíxols. Proposal made by Pasqual Maragall. The official opening of the gardens took place on 14th June 1997.

carrer.name: Josep Andreu i Abelló, Plaça de
carrer.descripcio: (Montblanc, Conca de Barberà 1906 - Madrid 1993). Lawyer and politician. He was one of the founders of the ERC. In 1936 he was the president of the High Court of Barcelona and later of the Supreme Court of Appeal in Catalonia. In 1939 he went into exile to France, Mexico and Tangiers. He became a member of the Congress of Catalonia's Socialist party (PSC). He helped to draw up the statute 'el' 'Estatuto de Sau'. He was the president of Barcelona's Athenaeum.

carrer.name: Josep Anselm Clavé, Carrer de
carrer.descripcio: Josep Anselm Clavé i Camps (Barcelona 1824 - 1874). Musician, poet and politician. He founded the choir the 'Cors d'Euterpe', now known as the 'Cors d'en Clavé'. His motto was: Progress, virtue and love.
carrer.anteriors: José A. Clavé; Dormitorio de San Francisco

carrer.name: Josep Balari, Carrer de
carrer.descripcio: Josep Balari i Jovany (Barcelona 1844 - 1904). Philologist, historian, lawyer and stenographer. Professor of Greek. Amongst other achievements and merits, he was the President of the Fine Arts Academy (1893-1901).

carrer.name: Josep Bertrand, Carrer de
carrer.descripcio: Josep Bertrand i Salsas (Molins de Rei, Baix Llobregat 1856 - Barcelona 1922). Industrialist. He made a conditional donation of the land where the Turó Park stands. He was married to Manuela Girona i Clavé.

carrer.name: Josep Canaleta, Carrer de
carrer.descripcio: Josep Canaleta i Coch (Barcelona 1714 - 1768). Master silk weaver and manufacturer. He set up spinning machines for cotton, supposedly the first in Catalonia. He imported raw cotton.

carrer.name: Josep Carner, Passeig de
carrer.descripcio: Josep Carner i Puig-Oriol (Barcelona 1884 - Brussels 1970). Writer. Graduate in Law and in Philosophy and Arts. He was a member of the department of philology in the Institute for Catalan Studies (1911). He was a member of the Generalitat's government in exile (1945-1947).

carrer.name: Josep Ciurana, Carrer de
carrer.descripcio: It was originally dedicated to Josep Ciurana i Cabré, husband of the property's owner, Maria Costa España. They owned the land known as Torre Vèlez. Unaware of this fact, the 1980 nomenclature dedicated the street to Josep Ciurana i Majó (Torroja, Priorat 1878 - ?). Writer and Journalist.

carrer.name: Josep d'Agulló, Carrer de
carrer.descripcio: Josep d'Agulló-Pinós i de Pinós, first Marquis of Gironella (17th - 18th centuries). General whom Philip V made commander of the troops in Africa. He defended Ceuta against Moorish attacks and, later, against the English. He was bestowed his title by Philip V in 1702.
carrer.anteriors: Romaní y Puigdengolas; José de Agulló; Romaní y Puigdengolas (Town Hall of Sarrià); Gironella Baja

carrer.name: Josep Estalella, Carrer de
carrer.descripcio: Josep Estalella i Graells (1879 - 1938). Physicist and chemist. Professor at the University of Barcelona and lecturer at colleges in Girona, Tarragona and Barcelona. He was the president of the Catalan Society for Physics, Chemistry and Mathematics. A noteworthy educator, author of text books and translator.

carrer.name: Josep Estivill, Carrer de
carrer.descripcio: Officer in one of Barcelona's battalions who fought against the French in the 1793-1795 campaign, called the War of the First Coalition.
carrer.anteriors: Jose Estivill; Lletra G (Cerdà plan); Còrsega (3rd section)

carrer.name: Josep Ferrater i Móra, Carrer de
carrer.descripcio: (Barcelona 1912 - 1991). Philosopher and essayist. Exiled in 1939, he lectured in Havana, Santiago de Chile and Pennsylvania. He was taught by Joaquim Xirau, and influenced by Ortega, Zubiri and Sartre. His 'Diccionario de filosofía' (Mexico, 1941) is fundamental. His work reflects a wide range of interests from existentialism, 'El ser y la muerte' (1962); to logic and the philosophy of language, 'Las palabras y los hombres' (1972); to the idiosyncrasies in Catalonia, 'Las formas de vida catalana' (Santiago de Chile, 1948); and Spanish thinkers in his books on Ortega and Unamuno. In his integrational approach he tried to distinguish between subject-focused thought and object-focused thought. Made honorary doctor by the University of Barcelona (1988).

carrer.name: Josep Finestres, Carrer de
carrer.descripcio: Josep Finestres i de Monsalvo (Barcelona 1688 - Cervera, Segarra 1777). An eminent jurist, he was also the spiritual leader of the University of Cervera which had a golden age in the mid 18th century.

carrer.name: Josep Garí, Carrer de
carrer.descripcio: Josep Garí i Cañas (Mataró, Maresme 1854 - Barcelona 1925). Banker. Together with Manuel Arnús i Fortuny he set up the Arnús-Garí bank.
carrer.anteriors: José Garí, 20/07/1943; Núm. 6 (S.A. El Tibidabo residential area)

carrer.name: Josep Goday i Casals, Jardins de
carrer.descripcio: (Mataró, Maresme 1881 - Barcelona 1936). Architect. He was the architect in charge of city council's Cultural Committee. He built the school complexes in the boroughs of Baixeras, Lluís Vives, Pere Vila, etc. These works defined the end-of-century architectural style in Barcelona. Together with his teacher Josep Puig i Cadafalch and Antoni de Falguera he published 'L'Arquitectura romànica a Catalunya'.

carrer.name: Josep Irla i Bosch, Carrer de
carrer.descripcio: (Sant Feliu de Guíxols, Baix Empordà 1876 - Saint Rafael, Provence 1958). Politician. He was the President of the Generalitat in exile (1940-1955).

carrer.name: Josep Jover, Carrer de
carrer.descripcio: Josep Jover i Casas (1884 - 1954). Banker. Landowner who donated part of the 'Manso Fregatell' property to build the 'Hospital Militar'.

carrer.name: Josep Llovera, Passatge de
carrer.descripcio: Josep Llovera i Bofill (Reus, Baix Camp 1846 - 1896). Painter and sketcher. Doctor of Pharmacy. He used the pseudonym Sr. Petrequín (1865).
carrer.anteriors: José Llovera, 07/03/1939; Catorce de Abril, 13/01/1933; José llovera, 21/12/1921; Maria Eugenia, before 1921

carrer.name: Josep M. de Sagarra, Carrer de
carrer.descripcio: Josep Maria de Sagarra i de Castellarnau (Barcelona 1894 - 1961). A writer from Barcelona who belonged a line of Catalan aristocrats. His plays were very popular. He was a distinguished member of the Institute for Catalan Studies and the Academy of Fine Arts. He won a great number of literary awards.

carrer.name: Josep M. Florensa, Carrer de
carrer.descripcio: Josep Maria Florensa de Jaumar (Barcelona 1848 - 1926). Lawyer. Legal secretary. As a landowner he worked jointly with Doctor Andreu in the development of land in the Tibidabo area.
carrer.anteriors: José Mª Florensa, 20/07/1943; Núm. 2 (S.A. El Tibidabo residential area)

carrer.name: Josep M. Folch i Torres, Plaça de
carrer.descripcio: (Barcelona 1880 - 1950). Novelist, narrator and playwright. A prolific writer, his books were mainly for children and adolescents.

carrer.name: Josep M. Jujol, Carrer de
carrer.descripcio: Josep M. Jujol i Gilbert (Tarragona 1879 - Barcelona 1949). Architect. He assisted Gaudí. He maintained the superrealistic tradition.

carrer.name: Josep Maria Lladó, Carrer de
carrer.descripcio: Josep Maria Lladó i Figueres, a journalist and lawyer, was born in Barcelona, on July 30th 1910, in the Carrer del Carme 44. He was the Secretary of the Barcelona Journalists Association. He collaborated with "La Publicitat", "L'Opinió" and "La Humanitat" and was the Editor of "Última Hora". He took part in the Spanish Civil War as an officer of the column named Macià-Companys. He exiled himself in 1939 and in 1945 he published the magazine "Per Catalunya" in Nice. He wrote the Journal d'un expatrié catalan in 1946. In 1950 he returned to Catalonia. He wrote for the newspaper "Tele/eXprés" and "Tele estel". He is the author of several books. He lived in Carrer Balmes 366 and died on May 9th 1996.

carrer.name: Josep Maria Poblet, Plaça de
carrer.descripcio: Josep Maria Poblet i Guarro (Montblanc, Conca de Barberà 1897 - Barcelona 1980). Self-taught writer.

carrer.name: Josep Maria Serra Martí, Parc de
carrer.descripcio: (Barcelona 1927 - 1991). He earned his doctorate of Industrial Engineering at the University of Barcelona. Deputy mayor of Barcelona for Environment and Municipal Services from 1987. Co-founder and teacher at the school 'Escuela EMI,' chairman of the Sant Gervasi Neighborhood Association (1975-1979) and city councillor for Municipal Services and Enterprises (1981). After a period of political independence he became a militant member of the Socialist Party of Catalonia. He took an active part in the milestone of the urban renewal in preparation for the Olympic Games.

carrer.name: Josep M. Sert, Carrer de
carrer.descripcio: Josep M. Sert i Badia (Barcelona 1874 - 1945). Painter and decorator of world-wide repute.

carrer.name: Josep Maria Sostres, Jardins de
carrer.descripcio: Josep Maria Sostres i Maluquer (La Seu d'Urgell, Alt Urgell 1915 - Barcelona 1984). Architect. His work is decisive in establishing links with contemporary trends. He was responsible for the controversial building 'El Noticiero Universal' (1963-1965). It is worth mentioning his role as co-founder and theoretician of the group 'Grupo R' (1952).

carrer.name: Josep Miret, Carrer de
carrer.descripcio: Josep Miret i Musté (Barcelona 1907 - Florisdorf, Mauthausen, Austria 1944). He was the counsellor for the Generalitat of Catalonia in 1937. Leader of the Spanish Socialist Party (PSUC) in exile.

carrer.name: Josep Munté, Jardins de
carrer.descripcio: Josep Munté i Rodríguez was born in Barcelona on 29th October 1913. He began militating in the Estat Català political party from a very early age. He took part in the creation of the Front Nacional de Catalunya, and was detained and imprisoned. During the last years of Franco's dictatorship, he joined the Partit Socialista de Catalunya. He founded the Neighbors' Association of the Sant Ramon Nonat district, was appointed member of the District Council, and was chosen the Most Valued Citizen of the Les Corts District of Barcelona (Corsenc de l'Any) for 1996. He died in Barcelona, on 27th December 1996, in the Carrer d'Arístides Maillol, 17.

carrer.name: Josep Obiols, Plaça de
carrer.descripcio: Josep Obiols i Palau (Sarrià 1894 - Barcelona 1967). Painter. Born in the Sarrià neighborhood (according to parish records, dating from 1833, the Obiols household was close to the parish church). He studied at the school for decorative arts founded by Torres-Garcia in Sarrià. He nurtured the art of mural painting, concentrating on children's themes. A noted member of the 1917 generation who, given his age, was able to carry on the end-of-century style until the post Civil War period, thus adding his own personal touch in the realm of Catalan art. In 1919, together with ten other artists, the Town Council of Sarrià refused him a grant to carry out a project to promote culture. It sees appropriate, therefore, that a square in Sarrià is dedicated to him.

carrer.name: Josep Pallach, Plaça de
carrer.descripcio: Josep Pallach i Carolà (Figueres, Alt Empordà 1920 - L'Hospitalet de Llobregat, Barcelonès 1977). Politician and pedagogue. Graduated in Philosophy and in Montpellier. Doctor of Education. Secretary of the Socialist party 'PSC-Reagrupament' (1977).

carrer.name: Josep Pijoan, Carrer de
carrer.descripcio: Josep Pijoan i Soteras (Barcelona 1879 - Lausanne 1963). Historian, poet, essayist and art writer. His poetry was well liked by Joan Maragall, to whom he dedicated the work 'El meu amic Don Joan Maragall' (1927). He also dedicated 'Mi Don Francisco Giner' (1927) to Giner de los Ríos. He was a figure of prime importance in the world of Catalan culture. He was one of the driving forces behind the reappraisal and retrieval of Romanesque painting. He took part in restoring and moving various pieces of Romanesque art to the Museum of Art of Catalonia. He lived in different countries in America and Europe and organised the Spanish School for Archaeology and History in Rome. He published 'Historia del' 'Arte' (1914), 'Historia del Mundo' (1926-1941) and 'Summa artis' (1931, with other authors). Pasqual Maragall made the proposal for the dedication.

carrer.name: Josep Pla, Carrer de
carrer.descripcio: Josep Pla i Casadevall (Palafrugell, Baix Empordà 1897 - 1981). Writer and journalist. Awarded the Generalitat's Gold Medal (1980).

carrer.name: Josep Puig i Esteve, Plaça de
carrer.descripcio: (Agramunt, Urgell 1876 - 1931). Shop assistant. He was one of the founder members of the CADCI (Autonomous Centre for Shop Assistants in Trade and Industry). He was its secretary from 1903 to 1910 and chairman from 1910 to 1917, year in which he was made a city councillor. He built and set up a housing co-operative in the streets 'calle Manuel de Falla' 'and pasaje Roserar'. It is for this reason that until 1942 one of the streets in the area, 'calle Riu d'Or' , was called 'pasaje del Cadci'.

carrer.name: Josep Ricart i Giralt, Passatge de
carrer.descripcio: (Barcelona 1847 - 1930). Seaman, scientist, writer and publicist. Director of the Nautical School (1900). In 1876 he founded an observatory in Barcelona for naval chronometers. He was a chief executive officer for the 1888 Barcelona Universal Exhibition. From 1889 he was a technical advisor for the Board of Museums and the Zoo. He was awarded many prizes and medals and held posts in the most prestigious scientific associations of his time. He belonged to the Catalan Association for Scientific Expeditions and the Catalan Ramblers Association. He contributed to the Ramblers Association's newspaper 'La Renaixença', in which he wrote a daily column giving information on meteorology and astronomy.

carrer.name: Josep Rovira, Plaça de
carrer.descripcio: Josep Rovira i Canals (Rubí, Vallès Occidental 1902 - Boulogne-sur-Seine, France 1968). Politician. A carpenter by trade, from an early age he was a militant in the pro-Catalan movement and became a member of the organization 'Estat Català'. He founded the Proletarian Catalan Party and later joined the workers' party the 'Bloque Obrero y Campesino'. In 1944 he co-founded the Socialist Movement of Catalonia. He was an outstanding military strategist and leader of popular militias.

carrer.name: Josep Samitier, Carrer de
carrer.descripcio: Josep Samitier i Vilalta (Barcelona 1902 - 1972). Football player. He made his debut for the youth team 'el Internacional' and went on to play for Barcelona Football Club when he was sixteen. He became one of the team's mythical players and, along with Ricard Zamora, is the most famous of Catalonia's football players.

carrer.name: Josep Sangenís, Carrer de
carrer.descripcio: (Balaguer, Noguera ? - ?). Colonel of engineers. Under the orders of General Palafox he defended Zaragoza against the French (War of Independence).

carrer.name: Josep Serrano, Carrer de
carrer.descripcio: Josep Serrano i Simeón (Sueca, Ribera Baja 1873 - Madrid 1941). Composer. He composed Valencia's anthem.

carrer.name: Josep Soldevila, Carrer de
carrer.descripcio: Josep Soldevila i Soler. Mayor of Sant Andreu de Palomar (1886 - 1888).

carrer.name: Josep Solé i Barberà, Carrer de
carrer.descripcio: Josep Solé i Barberà (Llívia, Baixa Cerdanya 1913 - Barcelona 1988). Politician and lawyer. Member of parliament for the Spanish Socialist Party (PSUC). He formed part of the committee that drew up the Sau Statutes (1978).

carrer.name: Josep Sunyol i Garriga, Carrer de
carrer.descripcio: (Barcelona 1898 - Sierra de Guadarrama, Castile 1936). Politician and industrialist. He founded the weekly newspaper 'La Rambla' (1930). He was a board member of Barcelona Football Club and the Catalan Football Federation. He was a member of the national parliament for the ERC party (1931, 1933, 1936). He was arrested while on a trip to Madrid and, together with his two travelling companions, shot without a trial.

carrer.name: Josep Tarradellas, Avinguda de
carrer.descripcio: Josep Tarradellas i Joan (Cervelló, Baix Llobregat 1899 - Barcelona 10th June 1988). President of the Generalitat of Catalonia. He was a member of Francesc Macià's Nationalist Democratic Federation from its beginnings (1919). He was also a member of the nationalist youth party 'La Falç '(1920). When the party 'Esquerra Republicana de Catalunya' was formed in 1931, he became its secretary general. Commandeur de la Légion d'Honneur (1985). Marquis of Tarradellas (1986).
carrer.anteriors: C. de Josep Tarradellas, 27/12/1988; C. de la Infanta Carlota, 27/07/1944; C. Infanta Carlota Joaquina, 07/03/1939; C. Bernat Metge, 26/08/1931; C. Infanta Carlota Joaquina, 19/11/1929; Gran Vía P (map of Les Corts), 1917

carrer.name: Josep Trueta, Jardins de
carrer.descripcio: Josep Trueta i Raspall (Barcelona 1897 - 1977). Surgeon of international repute. Awarded the City of Barcelona and Sant Jordi Gold Medals, as well as the Jaume I Prize (1977).
carrer.anteriors: Pl. de Josep Trueta; Lope de Vega

carrer.name: Josep Yxart, Carrer de
carrer.descripcio: Josep Yxart i de Moragas (Tarragona 1852 - 1895). Writer and critic. Considered to be the best critic of Catalan Renaissance literature

carrer.name: Josepa Massanés, Carrer de
carrer.descripcio: Maria Josepa Massanés i Dalmau (Tarragona 1811 - Barcelona 1887). Teacher and poetess. She won the 'Jocs Florals' literary prize in 1864.

carrer.name: Jota, Carrer de la
carrer.descripcio: In the urban development plan the street was called 'calle J'. As the letter is pronounced in the same way as the Aragonese dance the 'jota', the name was changed.
