carrer.name: Jovellanos, Carrer de
carrer.descripcio: Gaspar Melchor María de Jovellanos y Ramírez (Gijón 1744 - Vega 1811). Writer, historian, teacher and Asturian politician.

carrer.name: Juan Bravo, Carrer de
carrer.descripcio: (Segovia ? - Villalar, Castile 1521). Councilor for Segovia. He was one of the leaders of the 'Comuneros', an army made up of townspeople, farmers and minor noblemen who rebelled against the policies of King Carlos I.
carrer.anteriors: Bravo y Maldonado; Copérnico; Negrevernís (joined to it)

carrer.name: Juan de Ávila, Carrer de
carrer.descripcio: (Almodóvar del Campo, Cuenca 1500 - Mantilla, Cordoba 1569). Clergyman, Spanish writer.

carrer.name: Juan de Garay, Carrer de
carrer.descripcio: (Orduña, Basque Country 1528 - 1583 ?). Basque conquistador and navigator. He founded Santa Fe. Chief of naval operations in Rio de la Pata (1574) and governor of Asuncion (1576). He rebuilt Buenos Aires in 1580. The former name of the street was 'carrer de Buenos Aires'. As another street already existed with this name it was changed. The intention of the new name was to reflect a connection with its original name so the man who had rebuilt it replaced the city's name.

carrer.name: Juan de Mena, Carrer de
carrer.descripcio: (Cordoba 1411 - Torrelaguna 1456). Andalusian poet.

carrer.name: Juan de Sada, Carrer de
carrer.descripcio: Nobleman from Aragon. He owned Sada Castle, in the borough of Sos (Zaragoza) where the king Fernando the Catholic was born.

carrer.name: General Almirante, Carrer del
carrer.descripcio: It is possible that this name, given to this street in July 1942, refers to the general of the same name who led Franco's army in the battle of the Ebro (1938). However, it is more likely that the street was named after José Almirante y Torroella (Valladolid 1823 - Madrid 1894), lieutenant in 1842, he rose to division general.

carrer.name: Juan Ponce, Jardins de
carrer.descripcio: Juan Ponce Perujo (Cuevas del Becerro, Málaga 1905 - 1989). On retiring, he became very active in the Carmel Neighborhood Association.

carrer.name: Juan Ramón Jiménez, Carrer de
carrer.descripcio: Juan Ramón Jiménez (Moguer, Huelva 1881 - Santurce, Puerto Rico 1958). Andalusian poet. Nobel Prize for Literature in 1956.

carrer.name: Juan Valera, Carrer de
carrer.descripcio: Juan Valera y Alcalá Galiano (Cabra, Cordoba 1824 - Madrid 1905). Writer, politician and diplomat.

carrer.name: Jubany, Carrer de
carrer.descripcio: Gustau Jubany i Bergnes (Barcelona 1883 - 1971). Property developer. He was Sebastià Auger i Massanet's partner in the company 'Auger i Jubany', founded in 1919. They developed an area with two roads naming on 'Auger' and the other 'Jubany'.

carrer.name: Judea, Carrer de
carrer.descripcio: A historic region in southern Palestine. One of the streets in the Vall d'Hebron neighborhood.

carrer.name: Judici, Carrer del
carrer.descripcio: A popular street in the Barceloneta neighborhood.

carrer.name: Jules Verne, Carrer de
carrer.descripcio: Jules Gabriel Verne Allotte(Nantes 1828 - Amiens 1905). French writer. His science-fiction novels are a reflection of the morality of science and progress.

carrer.name: Juli González, Plaça de
carrer.descripcio: Juli González i Pellicer (Barcelona 1876 - Arcueil, Paris 1942). Sculptor. He learnt forging and silversmithery in his father's workshop. In 1918 he went to work in Paris as a welder for Renault. In 1927 he started working on metal sculptures using sheet iron. He was a prolific artist. Influenced by Pau Gargallo, Brancusi, Magnelli and Picasso, his sculptures are found in the world's most important museums.

carrer.name: Julià, Carrer de
carrer.descripcio: The road was originally dedicated to the owner of the land, Francesc Julià i Farell (1841 - 1914). At the beginning of the 20th century it was suggested to the city authorities that the street should honour Benet Julià i Julià (Torroella de Montgrí, Baix Empordà 1726 - Montserrat, Bages 1787). Musician, composer and organ player in Montserrat.

carrer.name: Julià, Passatge de
carrer.descripcio: Francesc Julià i Farell (Barcelona 1841 - 1914). Landowner. Married for the second time to Dolors Serrahima i Folch, who owned the property. She inherited the land from Joan Serrahima i Vilà, who bought it in 1857.

carrer.name: Júlia, Via
carrer.descripcio: Barcelona was a Roman colony known as 'Colonia Iulia Augusta Paterna' 'Faventia Barcino'.
carrer.anteriors: Cuarenta Metros; Carlos Marx; Cuarenta Metros; Lletra M (connection map)

carrer.name: Julià Portet, Carrer de
carrer.descripcio: Julià Portet, a young craftsman who was a mat-maker by trade. He became a militiaman. One of the Cuitadella martyrs. A hero in the War of Independence. Executed in 1809.

carrer.name: Julián Besteiro, Carrer de
carrer.descripcio: Julián Besteiro Fernández (Madrid 1870 - Carmona, Seville 1940). Politician. Professor of logic at the University of Madrid (1912). President of the Constituent Assembly which passed the Statute of Catalonia in 1932.

carrer.name: Julián Romea, Carrer de
carrer.descripcio: Julián Romea y Yanguas (Aldea de San Juan, Murcia 1813 - Madrid 1863). Theatre actor. Married to the actress Matilde Díez, they ran Madrid's 'Teatro Príncipe'. When the Romea Theatre was built in 1863, it was named after him.

carrer.name: Juliol, Carrer del
carrer.descripcio: This area was developed at the end of the 19th century by Llorenç Julià i Roca, together with Messrs Florit and Iglésias. The latter had streets named after them but they disappeared when the 'ronda de Guinardó' ring road was rebuilt. There also used to be a 'calle de Julià', dedicated to the former, but it was probably changed to its present name as another street had the same name.
carrer.anteriors: Julio; Pje. de Elna; Pje. de Julio

carrer.name: Junta de Comerç, Carrer de la
carrer.descripcio: Named after the institution created in Barcelona in 1758 to govern commercial and industrial activity. It helped to set up various cultural institutions such as the Nautical School (1769), the School of Noble Arts (1775), the School of Chemistry (1805), the School of Stenography (1805) and the School of Botany (1807).

carrer.name: Jupí, Carrer de
carrer.descripcio: A popular corrupted form of an old Catalan surname of a family of traders. It probably comes from 'Gelpí', of which mention is made in the 13th century. In documents from the 15th century the name 'Jeupí' is found. With the passing of time other forms have been 'Jenpí, Jaupí' and 'Jupí'.

carrer.name: Júpiter, Carrer de
carrer.descripcio: Owes its name to Jupiter, the planet. Several streets in the Rectoret area are related to astronomy.

carrer.name: K, Carrer
carrer.descripcio: In the industrial estate of the Consortium of Barcelona's Zona Franca, the streets, with few exceptions, are streets designated with letters in the North-South direction, while streets designated with numbers run in the East-West direction.

carrer.name: Karl Marx, Plaça de
carrer.descripcio: (Trier 1818 - London 1883). German philosopher , politician and economist. Author of voluminous works focused on discovering the 'modern' society's development and transformation laws. He was an outstanding politician of the First International.

carrer.name: Klein, Passatge de
carrer.descripcio: The commercial company Klein y Cia., headquartered in Segovia and represented by its president Ernest Marcel Klein Ducrocq, bought in 1917 a real estate and established a gum factory specialized in tyre production. This passage way is dedicated to a Georges Klein Daeffler (1856 - 1914).

carrer.name: Köbe, Plaça de
carrer.descripcio: The name is due to the Japanese city of Kobe, situated on Honshu Island near the Osaka Bay. Most important seaport of Japan. City twinned with Barcelona since April 6th, 1993.

carrer.name: L, Carrer
carrer.descripcio: With few exceptions, streets within the Consortium's Zona Franca of Barcelona designated with letters run in the North-South direction, while streets designated with numbers run in the East-West direction.

carrer.name: La Barcelonesa, Carrer de
carrer.descripcio: Company established in 1838, one of the predecessors of what later would be La Maquinista Terrestre y Marítima.

carrer.name: La Canadenca, Passatge de
carrer.descripcio: The Barcelona Traction, Light and Power Company Limited, founded by Frederick Stark Pearson, was known with this name.

carrer.name: La Maquinista, Carrer de
carrer.descripcio: This street allowed for access to the factories of La Maquinista Terrestre y Marítima, S.A., built in 1855.

carrer.name: La Maquinista, Plaça de
carrer.descripcio: The space situated between the Ginebra street and Pompeu Gener square receives this name in memory of La Maquinista Terrestre y Marítima, an important joint stock company, established on September 14th 1855, that had got factories in this place long time before it established the great factories in Sant Andreu de Palomar.

carrer.name: La Maquinista de Sant Andreu, Parc de
carrer.descripcio: Refers to the iron machinery and construction company located in this place of Sant Andreu between 1917 and 1991.

carrer.name: La Pegaso, Parc de la
carrer.descripcio: It takes its name from the Pegaso factory, which used to be in this place and was demolished, except for the architectural features in its entrance portico.

carrer.name: La Puntual, Plaça de
carrer.descripcio: The shop of 'L'auca del senyor Esteve', from Rusiñol, is named La Puntual. Therefore, the Ribera neigbhorhood dedicates this square to the shop.

carrer.name: La Tamarita, Jardins de
carrer.descripcio: The heirs of Francesc Solernou i Vallès, married to María Guadalupe Fernández, bought in 1835 from the Government the Gomis or Frare Blanc property, one of the state possessions proceeding from the removed P. P. Dominicos School. In 1847, a vineyard of two "'mujadas'" (approximately one hectare) was granted to Feliu Palmerola. This area, proceeding from the mentioned property, was known as "La Tamarita". In February of 1848, Feliu Palmerola transferred "La Tamarita" property to Antoni Camps i Ramon, married to Bernarda Weyler i Lavigne, who built in 1849 a country residence that adopted the name of the place. In 1852, he asked the Sant Gervasi town hall for permission to urbanize part of his property. This petition was opposed by the Craywinckel family alleging that the access had been projected inside their property. Gone into debts, he had to buy the property for 4,576 pounds and 10 salaries in 1853. The current garden was projected before 1937 by the architect Nicolau Rubió i Tudurí.

carrer.name: La Traviata, Carrer de
carrer.descripcio: The work by Verdi. A street in the Rectoret neighborhood, where the residents gave the names to many of the thoroughfares.

carrer.name: Laberint, Carrer del
carrer.descripcio: It belongs to a group of interlaced and small streets, situated around the Prim square in Poblenou.

carrer.name: Laberint, Parc del
carrer.descripcio: The name is due to the homonymous property proceeding from the garden designed there with intricated lanes so that it is difficult to find the exit.

carrer.name: Labèrnia, Carrer de
carrer.descripcio: Pere Labèrnia i Carreras (1865 - 1895). Owner of the land that would belong to Casa Baró property, because it was granted to him by Lluïsa de Llanas i Lòpez. He was married to Montserrat Solà i Vilavella.

carrer.name: Lafont, Carrer de
carrer.descripcio: Rafael Lafont i Thomàs (1797 - 1885). Lawyer. Owner of a three 'mujada'-sized property (approximately 1.5 hectare) with a timber house, two kitchen gardens and four pools that belongs to the Sant Pau field, part of the Sant Beltran gardens since 1831. It was inherited by Antoni Lafont i Palaudàries.

carrer.name: Laforja, Carrer de
carrer.descripcio: Pere Delaforge i Grau (? - 1787). Haberdasher, shopkeeper in linen, drapes and silk. Owner. In 1776 he bought from Jaume Rosés a property of two 'mujadas', one 'quarta' and 3.5 'mundinas' (approximately 1.2 hectares). Married to Agnés Carrera. The land was inherited by his only daughter Antònia Delaforge i Carrera, married to Francesc Comaduran Rovira. A country residence was built there (probably with the name scratched on the main façade) that due to its situation in between the fields became soon a reference point and gave its name to the Laforja neighborhood. With regard to the correct use of the surname, Pere Delaforge himself wrote: "..... mes declara que si bé es veritat que molts temps la mia firma que he practicat des de los primers anys he començat a firmar tot lo any mil set-sents setanta tres he firmat per lo apellido de Pera Laforge. Però des del primer dia del any mil set-sents setanta quatre per aver averiguat que la firma o nom de mon pare i avi es escrita Delaforge per això totas mas firmas del dia expresat en avan van firmades per Pera Delaforge". (.... although it is true that for a long time this was the signature I used to affix from the first years on, I started to undersign with the name Pera Laforge in 1774. Indeed, from the first day of the year 1774 on, all my signatures will be Pera Delaforge as I have found out that my father and grandfather undersigned with Delaforge).

carrer.name: Laguna de Lanao, Plaça de la
carrer.descripcio: Lagoon situated in Mindanao, island of the Philippines archipelago.

carrer.name: Laietana, Via
carrer.descripcio: The name remembers the "Layetanos", a pre-Roman Iberian tribe established in the area currently occupied by the districts of Maresme, Barcelonès, Baix Llobregat y Vallès, whose capital was the mythical city of Laie situated near the Roman quarry of Montjuïc and the graveyard. The Via was projected in 1879 in order to provide a fast communication between the Eixample and the harbor, crossing the city's historical center.
carrer.anteriors: Claris (joined to it); Layetana; Buenaventura Durruti; Bilbao (a section, joined to it); Núm. 30 (Cerdà plan, joined to it); Gran Vía Layetana; Lletra A (Cerdà plan)

carrer.name: Lamote de Grignon, Carrer dels
carrer.descripcio: Joan Lamote de Grignon i Bocquet (Barcelona 1872 - 1949). Musician. Founder and director of Barcelona's Symphonic Orchestra. Leader of the Barcelona Municipal Band since 1914. Director of the Conservatorium of the Liceo. Ricard Lamote de Grignon i Ribas (Barcelona 1899 - 1962). Musician and son of the personage described before.

carrer.name: Lancaster, Carrer de
carrer.descripcio: Agustín de Lancaster y Araciel (18th century). General Captain of Catalonia between 1797 and 1799. The street was opened in 1797.

carrer.name: Lanzarote, Carrer de
carrer.descripcio: Island of the Canary archipelago.

carrer.name: Laribal, Jardins de
carrer.descripcio: Public space situated next to the Miró foundation between the Estadi avenue and the Santa Madrona esplanade, on the Montjuïc mountain.

carrer.name: Larrard, Carrer de
carrer.descripcio: Antoni Alexandre de Larrard i Juez-Sarmiento (Barcelona 1818 - 1887). Landowner. Owner of the Pelada mountain. Son of Pere Alexandre de Larrad i de Llauder (? - 1823) who bought the lands in 1822 from Josep Maria de Càrcer i de Peguera.

carrer.name: Las Navas, Plaça de
carrer.descripcio: Popularly and as the neighbors always thought, the square name is due to the battle of Las Navas de Tolosa (July 16th 1212).

carrer.name: Las Navas de Tolosa, Carrer de
carrer.descripcio: Battle that took place on July 16th 1212 and in which the allied peninsular kings Alfonso VIII of Castile, Pere I of Catalonia and Aragon and Sancho VII of Navarra with numerous Hispano Christian knights and crusaders from beyond the Pyrenees defeated the Almohad caliph Muhammad al-Nasir.

carrer.name: L'Avançada, Carrer de
carrer.descripcio: Amateur company founded by Ignasi Iglésias i Pujades that performed most of his works. Theater company acting in Sant Andreu de Palomar and various Catalan towns.

carrer.name: Lázaro Cárdenas, Carrer de
carrer.descripcio: This street honors the former president of the Mexican Republic (Jiquilpán, Michoacán 1895 - Mexico City 1970). Mexican politician. In 1913 he joined the revolutionary movement and participated in several war campaigns, rising to the rank of general. In 1929 he was elected Chairman of the National Revolutionary Party. He was in charge of various ministries (1931-1933) and elected to be President of the Republic for the term 1934-1940. He promoted the agricultural reform and gave shelter to refugees of the Spanish republic. Lenin Peace Prize (1955).
carrer.anteriors: Herraiz; Mas y Cuadras; Herraiz; Gòsol (by error)

carrer.name: Legalitat, Carrer de la
carrer.descripcio: This street complements the three principles of the French Revolution that form the groundwork of the liberal state, together with the streets named Llibertat and Fraternitat, as well as the passageway Igualtat.

carrer.name: Legazpi, Carrer de
carrer.descripcio: Mikel López de Legazpi (Zumárraga 1510 - Manila 1572). Basque navigator and conqueror who founded the city of Manila. Governor and general captain of the Philippine Islands (1569).

carrer.name: Leiva, Carrer de
carrer.descripcio: Antonio de Leiva (Navarra 1480 - Aix en Provenza 1536). One of the most important Spanish military men during the kingdom of Charles I. He distinguished himself in the battle of Ravenna (Italy) and defending Pavia (1525). He was recompensed for this defense by the government of the Duchy of Milan and the title of Prince of Ascoli.

carrer.name: León, Passatge de
carrer.descripcio: Faustino León y Arroyo, owner. Resident of Cintruénigo (Navarra). He bought the land where the passageway was opened in 1929.

carrer.name: Leopoldo Alas, Carrer de
carrer.descripcio: Leopoldo Alas y Ureña (Zamora 1852 - Oviedo 1901). Novelist, journalist and essayist whose pseudonym was Clarín. He was considered Asturian because of his family origin.

carrer.name: Lepant, Carrer de
carrer.descripcio: Naval battle that was fought by the Holy League (Pontifical States, Venice and Spain) on October 7th 1571 in the Gulf of Lepanto (also called the Gulf of Corinth) against the Turks, with the participation of Catalan ships and seamen from the Catalan Countries.

carrer.name: Lepant, Moll de
carrer.descripcio: Between the piers of Álvarez de la Campa and Evaristo Fernández.

carrer.name: Lesseps, Plaça de
carrer.descripcio: Ferdinand-Marie de Lesseps (Versalles 1805 - Castillo de la Chênaie 1894). Diplomat. French consul in Barcelona, who had his residence in the square near the torrent. He intervened in favor of the city during the bombing by Van-Halen (1842). He was granted the concession of the company that was to open the Suez Canal. Place popularly known as "Josepets", because of the Carmelite monastery of Santa Maria de Gracià, founded in 1626 and called "de los Josepets".
carrer.anteriors: Lesseps; Fernando de Lesseps, 21/01/1905; Josepets, before 1895

carrer.name: Lilà, Carrer del
carrer.descripcio: Shrub with purple flowers. Situated in the Rectoret neighborhood and integrated in a group of streets named after plants and flowers.

carrer.name: Lima, Carrer de
carrer.descripcio: Named after Lima, city of Peru and capital of the Republic. Integrated in a group of streets of the Bon Pastor industrial estate that are dedicated to villages and places in Latin America.

carrer.name: Lincoln, Carrer de
carrer.descripcio: Abraham Hanks Lincoln (Hodgenville, Kentucky 1809 - Washington 1865). US-American politician. 16th President of the United States of America, from 1860 to 1865. He proclaimed the emancipation of all slaves (1862). Murdered during a theater performance.

carrer.name: Lírica, Carrer de la
carrer.descripcio: Musical genre based upon a songlike poetry outpouring. Street situated in the Montbau neighborhood where a group of streets is dedicated to similar themes: dance, song, music, etc.

carrer.name: Lisboa, Carrer de
carrer.descripcio: Named after Lisbon, city of Portugal and capital of the Republic. Its foundation is uncertain. Roman village: 'Olisipo'.
carrer.anteriors: Olmatell (without effectiveness); Gaig; Ra. Alta; Ra. de Horta (a section)

carrer.name: Litoral, Avinguda del
carrer.descripcio: Avenue that lines the seaside promenade of Mar Bella, created as a result of the urban development of Vila Olímpica del Poblenou.

carrer.name: Litoral, Ronda del
carrer.descripcio: Important urban traffic road carried out on the occasion of the Olympic Games although projected long time before. Together with the "ronda de Dalt", it forms a ring road around the city.

carrer.name: Liuva, Carrer de
carrer.descripcio: Liuva I. King of Visigoths. 6th century.

carrer.name: Llacuna, Carrer de la
carrer.descripcio: Marshland. Place name documented as 'Llacuna' in 1057 that gave name to the neighborhood of Sant Martí de Provençals established in the 19th century. The sector was floooded in the 15th century by marshlands. In the 18th century (1716), the Llacuna irrigation ditch was built. It is also called "Verboom" in memory of its architect, the engineer Pròsper de Verboom. The lake that gave name to the lagoon was drained in the early 19th century and the channel in the early 20th century.

carrer.name: Llacuna, Passatge de la
carrer.descripcio: The passageway leads to the street with the same name.

carrer.name: Llafranc, Carrer de
carrer.descripcio: Village belonging to the borough of Palafrugell (Baix Empordà). Street located in the Ramon Albó housing estate, where the streets are named after Catalan villages and places.

carrer.name: Llagostera, Carrer de
carrer.descripcio: Village of Gironès.

carrer.name: Llagut, Plaça del
carrer.descripcio: Small boat with variable tonnage and equipped with latin sail for fishing and coastal trading. Generally used by the fishermen from Barceloneta in the 19th century. Dedication originally proposed by Jesús Portavella, in memory of the famous catboat San Antonio, commanded by Gaietà Portavella (1771 - 1844), fisherboat captain.

carrer.name: Llana, Plaça de la
carrer.descripcio: We know for sure that the place had this name already in 1513. Formerly, there was a public wool market.

carrer.name: Llança, Carrer de
carrer.descripcio: Corrado Lancia - Conrad Llança - (? - Capo d'Orlando, Sicily 1299). Sicilian admiral and chancellor serving to Pere II 'el Gran'. Name proposed by Víctor Balaguer (1863), together with those of Roger de Llúria and Bernat Vilamarí, "to remember the glorious Catalan marine history".

carrer.name: Llàstics, Carrer d'en
carrer.descripcio: Surname of a Catalan family to whom, in the middle of the 15th century, a grand master of the order Saint John of Jerusalem belonged. According to documentary evidence, this street already existed with the same name in 1492.

carrer.name: Llatzeret, Carrer del
carrer.descripcio: Formerly, there was a lazaret near the street. It depended on the town hall. In virtue of the disentailment law of 1835, the State took over and divided the property in parts that were transferred to private persons. The bishop Climent promoted the construction of the old graveyard (blessed in 1775), taking into account the proximity of the lazaret.

carrer.name: Llauder, Carrer de
carrer.descripcio: Manuel de Llauder i de Camín. Marquis of Vall de Ribes (Argentona, Maresme 1789 - Madrid 1851). Military man and politician. General captain of Catalonia from 1832 to 1835. He distinguished himself in the Independence War.

carrer.name: Llavallol, Passatge de
carrer.descripcio: Important Catalan lineage (documented a person named Jaume Llavallol serving to Ramon Berenguer I). Owners in Vallvidrera. Teodor Llavallol i Pons (Barcelona 1841 - 1897), lawyer. Interim secretary of the Deputation between 1873 and 1887.

carrer.name: Llebre, Carrer de la
carrer.descripcio: It is said that the people assigned this name to the street because it is so short that a rabbit could cross it.

carrer.name: Llebrencs, Carrer dels
carrer.descripcio: Popular name given to the natives of Vallvidrera, for their rabbit-like way they walk.

carrer.name: Lledó, Carrer de
carrer.descripcio: Old-established family of the place who gave celebrities to the city since the 15th century such as Cristòfor Lledó i Carreres (Barcelona 17th - 18th century). Military man and politician. Second counselor of Barcelona during the War of the Spanish Succession.

carrer.name: Lledoner, Carrer del
carrer.descripcio: In memory of an old tree of Can Figuerola.

carrer.name: Lleialtat, Carrer de la
carrer.descripcio: This street was originated in 1832 by the construction of the monastery dedicated to Saint Severinus and Saint Charles Borromeu, commonly known as the seminar for lay preachers. After interrupting the construction in 1835, the building was converted into prison which was inaugurated in 1838.

carrer.name: Lleida, Carrer de
carrer.descripcio: Street named after Lleida, city of Segrià, in the middle of the plain with the same name, capital of the region.

carrer.name: Llenega, Camí de la
carrer.descripcio: Excellent mushroom (hygrophorus dichrous) that grows in forests, especially pinewoods.

carrer.name: Llenguadoc, Carrer del
carrer.descripcio: Street named after Languedoc, the south eastern region of Occitania. The main cities are Narbonne, Tolouse and Montpellier. In the Middle Ages known as the Cathar country.
carrer.anteriors: Languedoc; Llengüadoc; Llengua d'Oc; San Miguel

carrer.name: Lleó, Carrer del
carrer.descripcio: There is documentary evidence that this street already existed in 1858 together with other streets named after animals such as tiger and dove. The tree names ('lleó', 'tigre' and 'paloma') belonged to two male dogs and one female dog owned by a gardener of this place.

carrer.name: Lleó XIII, Carrer de
carrer.descripcio: Name (Leo) adopted by Vicenzo Gioacchino Pecci (Carpineto Romano, Emilia-Romana 1810 - Roma 1903), when becoming Pope (1878-1903).

carrer.name: Lleona, Carrer de la
carrer.descripcio: The person responsible for feeding the lions of the zoo of the former "Hort de la Reina" (garden of the little royal palace), one of the world's first botanical gardens and zoos, is supposed to have lived in this street. It is known that there were lions, above all since the kingdom of Alfons III.

carrer.name: Llerona, Carrer de
carrer.descripcio: Village belonging to the borough of Franqueses del Vallès (Vallès Oriental) and street of Barcelona. In memory of the fact that this village made a petition in 1416 to be integrated into Barcelona through the so-called 'carreratge' procedure, by which the borough is considered as a street of Barcelona. Thus, its inhabitants could enjoy the same rights and privileges as the residents of the capital.

carrer.name: Lletres, Carrer de les
carrer.descripcio: The name was given to this street for being the prolongation of the street named Ciències.

carrer.name: Llevant, Carrer de
carrer.descripcio: Named after the bastion of Levante. According to documentary evidence, its first stone was laid on April 14th 1535 by the Infante Frederick of Portugal. The construction works began in 1538.

carrer.name: Llevant, Plaça de
carrer.descripcio: Public space situated in the confluence of the Rambla de Prim and the Diagonal avenue. The name is due to the geographical situation of Poblenou, in East Barcelona.

carrer.name: Llevant, Moll de
carrer.descripcio: Between the Eastern and the floating pier.

carrer.name: Llibertat, Plaça de la
carrer.descripcio: Popular market of the old town of Gràcia that makes up the square.

carrer.name: Llibertat, Carrer de la
carrer.descripcio: Homage to one of the three principles of the French Revolution.

carrer.name: Llibreteria, Baixada de la
carrer.descripcio: Formerly, it was called Baixada de la Presó: replaced by the current name upon request of some neighbors who did not like the previous name. Prolongation of the street named Llibreteria.
carrer.anteriors: Libreteria; Devallada de la Cort; Portal de Santa Eulàlia; Portal del Mar; Cárcel, before 1865

carrer.name: Llibreteria, Carrer de la
carrer.descripcio: In the early 16th century, the sales of books, a latest novelty at that time, were concentrated in this street.
carrer.anteriors: Libreteria; Calzeteria o Calzeters; Espasers; Espeners; Apotecaris

carrer.name: Lliça, Camí de la
carrer.descripcio: This path led to the lists of Sarrià.

carrer.name: Lliçà, Carrer de
carrer.descripcio: Reference to the boroughs (Lliça d'Amunt and Lliça de Vall) of Vallès Oriental. Street belonging to the neighborhood of Torre Baró where most streets are dedicated to Catalan villages and places. This village made a petition in 1384 to be integrated into Barcelona through a procedure called 'carreratge', by which the borough is cons considered as a street of Barcelona. Thus, its inhabitants could enjoy the same rights and privileges as the inhabitants of the capital.

carrer.name: Llicorella, Carrer de la
carrer.descripcio: Schistose rock with foliated form abundant in the Collserola mountains.

carrer.name: Lligalbé, Torrent de
carrer.descripcio: Place-name documented in 1128. A country house with this name appears in documents of 1298, 1301 and 1386.

carrer.name: Llimona, Pati d'en
carrer.descripcio: Named after Tomàs Llimona who received this place from the community of the Saints Justo and Pastor in 1779. Former owner of the house adjoining the patio that gave access to a group of buildings bearing the name of Gualbes, a famous family of Barcelona before the 14th century.

carrer.name: Llinars del Vallès, Carrer de
carrer.descripcio: Village of Vallès Oriental.

carrer.name: Lliri, Carrer del
carrer.descripcio: Named after the lily flower. Name given to the street when urbanizing the place together with the street names Camèlies and Llessamí (the last one was replaced some time ago).

carrer.name: Llívia, Passatge de
carrer.descripcio: Village of Baixa Cerdanya.

carrer.name: Llobera, Carrer de
carrer.descripcio: Josep Llobera i Sampons (Tàrrega, Urgell 1868 - Barcelona 1938). Trader from L'Hospitalet, husband in second marriage of Eulàlia Briquets i Ventura, owner of the areas where the street was opened.

carrer.name: Llobera, Escales de
carrer.descripcio: The same dedication as the street.

carrer.name: Llobet, Carrer de
carrer.descripcio: Place-name that dates back before 1038. Name of an old property belonging to the parish of Santa Maria de Sants, situated in the place. The street adopted the name of the owner of the Port castle, the archdeacon Sinifred Llobet, in the 11th century. Nevertheless, a municipal document refers to the possibility that the name honored the author Julià Llobet, who died in 1460.

carrer.name: Llobet i Vall-llosera, Carrer de
carrer.descripcio: Josep Antoni Llobet i Vall-llosera. (Barcelona 1799 - Alicante 1861). Scientist and historian. President of the Science Academy. He collaborated in the creation of the Archeological Museum of Barcelona.

carrer.name: Llobregat, Passatge del
carrer.descripcio: Mediterranean river of the Iberian Peninsula. It is part of a group of streets in the Polvorí quarter that bear names of rivers: Segura, Jalón, Nerbion, Guadalquivir and Túria.

carrer.name: Llobregós, Carrer del
carrer.descripcio: Left tributary of the Segre river.

carrer.name: Llopis, Carrer de
carrer.descripcio: Encarnació Llopis, mother of Ramon Llorens i Llopis (Navarrés, Canal de Navarrés 1885 - Barcelona 1955). One of the three owners who bought in the early 20th century the ground in the place called "la Montanya" o "Pedrera de Tardà". The index of streets of 1980 referred to the possibility that the name honored the painter Josep M. Llopis i de Casades (Sitges, Garraf 1886 - Barcelona 1915).

carrer.name: Llorca, Plaça de
carrer.descripcio: Named after Lorca, city of the province of Murcia. Street belonging to the neighborhood of Polvorí where the streets are dedicated to places and rivers of Murcia such as Iecla, Fortuna and Segura.

carrer.name: Llorens i Artigas, Carrer de
carrer.descripcio: Josep Llorens i Artigas (Barcelona 1892 - 1980). Potter and art critic. Teacher in ceramics in the Massana School of Barcelona. He was awarded various prices all over the world.

carrer.name: Llorens i Barba, Carrer de
carrer.descripcio: Francesc Xavier Llorens i Barba (Vilafranca del Penedès, Alt Penedès 1820 - Barcelona 1872). Philosopher and professor for metaphysics of the University of Barcelona.

carrer.name: Llorer, Carrer del
carrer.descripcio: There was a big laurel in this place before its urbanization.

carrer.name: Lloret de Mar, Carrer de
carrer.descripcio: Village of La Selva borough in the Costa Brava.
carrer.anteriors: Lloret, 05/09/1907; San Joaquín; Priorato; Monjas; Hermanas

carrer.name: Llosa, Carrer de la
carrer.descripcio: Old village belonging to the borough of Lles (Baixa Cerdanya).

carrer.name: Lluc, Carrer de
carrer.descripcio: Sanctuary situated in the village of Escorca (Northern Mallorca). Street located in the neighborhood of Porta where various streets are dedicated to places and villages of the Balearic Islands.

carrer.name: Lluçà, Carrer de
carrer.descripcio: Village of Osona.

carrer.name: Lluçanès, Carrer del
carrer.descripcio: Subregion of the central Catalan high plateau, situated northwestward from Osona and bordering with Berguedà and Bages.

carrer.name: Llucena, Carrer de
carrer.descripcio: Village of Alcalatén, situated in the borough of Alcora, Castellón de la Plana.
carrer.anteriors: Lucena; Lletra E, grup V (b. Verdún)

carrer.name: Llucmajor, Plaça de
carrer.descripcio: Village of Eastern Mallorca. Square located in the utmost northern part of the Porta neighborhood.

carrer.name: Lluís Bonifaç, Carrer de
carrer.descripcio: Lluís Bonifaç, called "Lluís Bonifaç el Vell" (Marsella ? - Riudoms, Baix Camp 1696). Founder of a lineage of sculptors. Father of Lluís Bonifaç i Sastre (Barcelona 1683 - Valls, Alt Camp 1765) and Grandfather of Lluís Bonifaç i Massó (Valls, Alt Camp 1730 - 1786) who was one of the most prolific sculptors. Considered as the most important artist of the Catalan baroque.
carrer.anteriors: Luis Bonifas; Lletra E (Casa Móra residential area)

carrer.name: Lluís Borrassà, Carrer de
carrer.descripcio: (Girona ? - Barcelona 1424/1426). Catalan painter belonging to a large family of painters from Girona. He was one of the most important representatives of the medieval Catalan painting (altarpiece of Sant Pere d'Egara).

carrer.name: Lluís Casassas, Plaça de
carrer.descripcio: Lluís Casassas i Simó (Sabadell, Vallès Occidental 1922 - Barcelona 1992). Geographer. Doctor's degree in 1976 with the dissertation on the role of Barcelona in the creation and arrangement of the territory of Catalonia ('El paper de Barcelona en la creació i l'ordenament del territori de Catalunya'). Professor in the University of Barcelona and secretary of the Catalan geographic society (Sociedad Catalana de Geografía). He published, among other works, 'Barcelona i la seva rodalia al llarg del temps' (1974); 'El Barcelonès i Barcelona ciutat' '1974.' 'L'organització territorial i administrativa de Barcelona'; 'Funcions i àmbits de descentralització: els nous' 'districtes', in cooperation with J. Clusa and others (1980).

carrer.name: Lluís Companys, Passeig de
carrer.descripcio: Lluís Companys i Jover (El Tarròs, Urgell 1882 - Castle of Montjuïc, Barcelona 1940). President of the Generalitat (1934 and from 1936 to 1940). Proclaimed the Catalan State within the Federal Spanish Republic (1934).
carrer.anteriors: Salón de Víctor Pradera; Fermín Galán; Salón de San Juan; Núm. 35 (Cerdà plan)

carrer.name: Lluís Cutchet, Passatge de
carrer.descripcio: Lluís Cutchet i Font (Llivia, Baixa Cerdanya 1815 - Barcelona 1892). Writer on a variety of subjects and journalist. Promoter of the Renaixença (rebirth). Member of the Academy of Literature (1873).

carrer.name: Lluís Dalmau, Carrer de
carrer.descripcio: (Valencia, Horta ? - Barcelona before 1460). Painter. One of the most important artists of the Catalan gothic (altarpiece of the Virgin of the Councilors, 1443-1445).

carrer.name: Lluís el Piadós, Carrer de
carrer.descripcio: (Chasseneuil, Poitou 778 - Rhine island near Ingelheim 840). King of Aquitaine and emperor of the Franks. Son of Charlemagne. In 801 he conquered Barcelona which was incorporated into the Carolingian Empire. Berà was appointed as count of Barcelona. According to tradition, he founded the monastery of Sant Pere de les Puel·les.
carrer.anteriors: Ludovico Pío; Lluís el Piadós, before 1900

carrer.name: Lluís Marià Vidal, Carrer de
carrer.descripcio: Lluís Marià Vidal i Carreras (Barcelona 1842 - 1922). Mine engineer and geologist. He carried out geological studies of the Catalan Countries. President of the 'Centre Excursionista de Catalunya' (1896-1900).
carrer.anteriors: Luis Mariano Vidal; Lluís Marià Vidal; Pje. de San Hermenegildo

carrer.name: Lluís Millet, Plaça de
carrer.descripcio: Lluís Millet i Pagès (el Masnou, Maresme 1867 - Barcelona 1941). Musician, co-founder of the Orfeón Catalán. Teacher and director of the Municipal Music School and founder of the Sant Felip Neri chapel of Barcelona (1897).

carrer.name: Lluís Muntadas, Carrer de
carrer.descripcio: Lluís Muntadas i Rovira (1865 - 1911). Pioneer of factories related to electricity (such as Lámparas Z). He designed the Tibidabo blue tram.
carrer.anteriors: Luis Muntadas, 20/07/1943; Marquès de Lamadrid; Muntadas; Núm. 11 (S.A. El Tibidabo residential area)

carrer.name: Lluís Nicolau i d'Olwer, Carrer de
carrer.descripcio: (Barcelona 1888 - Mexico 1961). Historian, hellenist, journalist and politician. He participated in various republican organizations and publications.

carrer.name: Lluís Pellicer, Passatge de
carrer.descripcio: Josep Lluís Pellicer i Fenyè (Barcelona 1842 - 1901). Painter, draughtsman and federalist republican politician. Councilor of Barcelona.

carrer.name: Lluís Pericot, Carrer de
carrer.descripcio: Lluís Pericot i Garcia (Girona 1899 - Barcelona 1978). Paleontologist. Professor of the University of Santiago de Compostela and Valencia. Dean of the faculty of letters. Vice president of the Senior Council of Scientific Research, besides other functions and merits.

carrer.name: Lluís Sagnier, Carrer de
carrer.descripcio: Lluís Sagnier i Nadal (1831 - ?). Lawyer, son of Lluís Sagnier i Vidal, landowner, married to Rosa Nadal i Dodero. The ground where the street was opened belonged in part to property called Can Basté de les Parets that at the end of the 18th century was owned by Antoni Nadal, print cloth manufacturer.
carrer.anteriors: Luis Sagnier; Bartra o Casa Bartra

carrer.name: Lluís Solé i Sabarís, Carrer de
carrer.descripcio: (Gavà, Baix Llobregat 1908 - Capellades, Anoia 1985). Geologist and geographer. Professor for Natural History and Geography in Figueres, Tarragona and Barcelona.

carrer.name: Lluís Vives, Carrer de
carrer.descripcio: Joan Lluís Vives i Marc (Valencia, Horta 1492 - Brujas 1540). Humanist philosopher. Writer on a variety of subjects. Tutor of Prince Guillaume de Croÿ. Professor for Latin of the University of Lovaina.

carrer.name: Lluïsa Vidal, Passatge de
carrer.descripcio: Lluïsa Vidal i Puig (Barcelona 1876 - 1918). Paintress. She was the second-eldest among nine sisters and three brothers. Her father was a famous cabinet maker who expected all his sons to be artists. Therefore, Lluïsa Vidal completed her studies with Eugène Carrière in París and was the only paintress who joined the modernist movement in Catalonia. She sold a lot of her works and received very positive criticism. Authoress of bright and optimistic daily scenes, numerous portraits, above all of women and children. She worked hard as illustrator, especially for the 'Feminal' journal. Moreover, she was dedicated to teaching. Part of her works can be seen in Barcelona's Museum of Modern Art. Dedication proposed by the Female Group of the Municipal Council for Social Welfare (Grupo Mujer del Consejo Municipal de Bienestar Social).

carrer.name: Llull, Carrer de
carrer.descripcio: Ramon Llull i d'Eril (City of Mallorca 1233 - 1316). Patriarch of Catalan poetry and prose: writer, philosopher, mystic and missionary. Great traveler. One of the most important writers of the medieval Catalan culture. His nickname was the "enlightened doctor" (doctor iluminado).

carrer.name: Lluna, Carrer de la
carrer.descripcio: The natural satellite o the Earth. Name capriciously given by those who opened the street between Peu de la Creu and Ferlandina.

carrer.name: Logronyo, Carrer de
carrer.descripcio: Street named after Logroño, city and capital of the Autonomous Community of La Rioja.

carrer.name: Lohengrin, Carrer de
carrer.descripcio: Wagner's opera. Name given by the neighbors of the Rectoret neighborhood.

carrer.name: Lola Anglada, Plaça de
carrer.descripcio: Lola Anglada i Sarriera, draughtswoman, illustrator and writer. She was born in Barcelona on 28th October 1892 in the Carrer Mercader, 1. She created a world of her own populated with children's myths deeply rooted in the Barcelona of the eighteen-hundreds. She also collaborated in graphic chronicles which constitute a valuable document on the customs, dress and furniture of the time. She died in Tiana, in the Maresme region of Catalonia, on 12th September 1984. She is buried in the Poblenou cemetery in Barcelona.

carrer.name: Londres, Carrer de
carrer.descripcio: Street named after London, capital of the United Kingdom of Great Britain.

carrer.name: Lope de Vega, Carrer de
carrer.descripcio: Félix Lope de Vega y Carpio (Madrid 1562 - 1635). Spanish poet and playwright.

carrer.name: López Catalán, Carrer de
carrer.descripcio: Julián López Catalán (San Martín del Río, Teruel 1834 - Barcelona 1890). Teacher and pedagogue. Founder of the infant schools of Barcelona.

carrer.name: Lorda, Carrer de
carrer.descripcio: Street named after Lourdes, city of Gascony, in Occitania, center of Virgin Mary pilgrimage from all over the world.
carrer.anteriors: Cº de Lourdes and pje. de Lourdes

carrer.name: Lorena, Carrer de
carrer.descripcio: Northeastern region of France. Its departments Moselle and Meurthe were integrated into Germany from 1871 to 1919 when being recovered by France, history that was repeated during the Second World War. This street complements the neighbor streets Alsàcia and Marne, as well as Verdun promenade which remember battles of the First World War.

carrer.name: Lorenzale, Carrer de
carrer.descripcio: Claudi Lorenzale i Sugrañes (Barcelona 1815 - 1899). Painter. Director of "La Lonja" School of Fine Arts from 1858 to 1885.

carrer.name: Loreto, Carrer de
carrer.descripcio: Once, there was in this street a school for girls conducted by the sisters of Loreto of the Congregation of the Holy Family of Bordeaux, established in 1863. Loreto is an Italian city in the region of Marches (Ancona) and a Virgin Mary pilgrimage center.

carrer.name: Los Angeles, Carrer de
carrer.descripcio: Named after Los Angeles, city on the West coast of the USA in the State of California. Host of the Olympic Games of 1932 and 1984.

carrer.name: Los Castillejos, Carrer de
carrer.descripcio: Valley of Los Castillejos, near Ceuta. Here the Spanish General Prim fought against the Moroccan Army on January 1, 1860, during the African War.

carrer.name: Lotus, Carrer del
carrer.descripcio: Named after the herbaceous aquatic plant of Lotus. Street situated in the neighborhood of Font de la Guatlla where various streets are dedicated to flowers and plants.

carrer.name: Louis Braille, Carrer de
carrer.descripcio: (Coupvray, Seine-et-Marne 1809 - Paris 1852). French educator. At the age of 3 years he got blind. He invented the Braille method of reading and writing for blinds. In this street, there was the seat of ONCE, the National Organization for Spanish Blinds.
carrer.anteriors: Luis Braile; Oriente, before 1865; Tomàs Canes (very old)

carrer.name: Lucà, Carrer de
carrer.descripcio: Lucan (Cordoba 39 - Rome 65). Latin poet. Marcus Annaeus Lucanus was Seneca's nephew.

carrer.name: Lucà, Passatge de
carrer.descripcio: The same dedication as the street.

carrer.name: Lugo, Passatge de
carrer.descripcio: The same dedication as the street.

carrer.name: Lugo, Carrer de
carrer.descripcio: Named after Lugo, city of Galicia.

carrer.name: Luis Antúnez, Carrer de
carrer.descripcio: (Las Palmas ? - Barcelona 1916). Governor of Barcelona (1886). Adoptive son of Gràcia. He left all his fortune to the city for the purpose of educational institutions. He promoted the construction of the Clinical Hospital.

carrer.name: Luz Casanova, Carrer de
carrer.descripcio: Maria de la Concepción, Luz, Agustina Rodríguez Casanova y García San Miguel (Avilar, Asturias 1873 - Madrid 1949). Always known as Luz Casanova. Spanish woman who founded the Institute of Apostolic Ladies of the Sacred Heart of Jesus, an organization dedicated to social assistance of any kind. In 1958, her beatification process was started. This institute has a building in Barcelona, located in the place where the street was dedicated.

carrer.name: M, Carrer
carrer.descripcio: Street within the industrial area of the Consortium of Barcelona's Zona Franca, where most streets designated with letters run in the North-South direction, while streets designated with numbers run in the East-West direction.

carrer.name: Madame Butterfly, Carrer de
carrer.descripcio: Street named after Puccini's opera, located within the Rectoret neighborhood, where street names were chosen by the neighbors.

carrer.name: Madoz, Passatge de
carrer.descripcio: Passage named after Pascual Madoz Ibáñez de Iriarte (Pamplona, 1806 - Genoa 1870). Lawyer and liberal politician. Civil Governor of Barcelona. The city owes him the authorization to demolish the city wall (1854). President of the constituting Parliament and Minister of Finance. Author of the 'Diccionario geográfico-estadístico histórico de España y sus posesiones de ultramar'.

carrer.name: Madrazo, Carrer dels
carrer.descripcio: Family of Castilian painters of the XIX century: José de Madrazo y Agudo (Santander, 1781 - Madrid, 1859), designated Court painter by King Charles IV in 1916; Federico de Madrazo y Kuntz (Rome, Italy, 1815 - Madrid, 1894), son of the former, author of over six hundred remarkable portraits, director of the Prado Museum; Luis de Madrazo y Kuntz (Madrid, 1825 - 1897), Federico's brother; as well as Federico's sons Raimundo de Madrazo y Garreta (Rome, Italy, 1841 - Versailles, France, 1920) and Ricardo de Madrazo y Garreta (Madrid, 1851 - 1917).
carrer.anteriors: Madrazo, 05/09/1907; Molins de Rey (extension from Madrazo), 05/09/1907; 21/04/1954 (extension); Progreso (a section), 09/12/1874; Nuestra Señora del Carmen, before 1864

carrer.name: Madres de la Plaza de Mayo, Pla de las
carrer.descripcio: Square named after this movement organized by the mothers of people missing as a consequence of the terror regime governing Argentina after the military coup d'état of 1976.

carrer.name: Madrid, Avinguda de
carrer.descripcio: Avenue named after Madrid, capital city of the Spanish State since the reign of Felipe II, and of the Autonomic Community of the same name.

carrer.name: Madriguera, Carrer de la
carrer.descripcio: Named after the Madriguera irrigation channel next to this street.

carrer.name: Madrona Piera, Passatge de
carrer.descripcio: Passage named after Madrona Piera i Martí (1887 - 1913), in memory of the unmarried sister of Eulàlia Piera i Martí, owner of the lands. Daughter of Joan Piera i Carbonell and Vicenta Martí i Torné.

carrer.name: Madrona Prat, Plaça de
carrer.descripcio: Square named after Madrona Prat i Palmer (Barcelona, 1903 - 1987), daughter of Salvador Prat Sumell, from Piera (Anoia), and of Empar Palmer i Alemany. She lived in several manors of Sant Genís dels Agudells, such as Can Figuerola (Torre Figuerola), Can Gresca (Casa Groga), Can Safont, and finally Can Pagès, where the person giving name to the Elies Pagès avenue used to live. Madrona became famous after the Spanish Civil War, when she lovingly took care of the many immigrants who started moving to Barcelona in search of a job, leaving all their possessions behind.

carrer.name: Maduixer, Carrer del
carrer.descripcio: Old name of this place.

carrer.name: Maestrat, Carrer del
carrer.descripcio: Region in the North-East of the Valencia Land.

carrer.name: Magalhäes, Carrer de
carrer.descripcio: Fernäo Magalhäes (Saborosa, Porto, Tras Os Montes, Portugal, 1480 - Mactán, Philippines, 1521). Portuguese seafarer. Captain-in-Chief of the Castilian Fleet at the service of King Charles I.

carrer.name: Magarola, Passatge de
carrer.descripcio: Passage opened to traffic in the lands where formerly a chapel dedicated to Our Lady of Montserrat had been, intermittently in service between the XVII and the XIX century, until the Magarola built their palace, repairing and improving the house where the chapel had been. The passage gate had been formerly the door of the old manor, showing the family coat of arms on its lintel. The house had been the procuration of Montserrat in Barcelona.

carrer.name: Magatzems, Carrer dels
carrer.descripcio: So named in memory of the old Port warehouses or depositories where the goods were temporarily stored, when their entry could not be authorized as long as the customs requirements were not fulfilled.

carrer.name: Magdalenes, Carrer de les
carrer.descripcio: So named after the Magdalenes convent established in this street in the XIV century (1372), under Bishop Pere de Planella. It was expropriated in 1835 (de-amortization), and later recovered, and the nuns stayed until they were expelled from the convent in 1868 (September Revolution) for giving refuge to "freedom volunteers". The convent was demolished in 1880.
carrer.anteriors: Magdalenas; Las Penedidas; La Murtra; Ermita; Borradonà

carrer.name: Magraner, Passatge del
carrer.descripcio: Passageway named after the pomegranate tree, within a group of streets named after trees and bushes.

carrer.name: Maignon, Carrer de
carrer.descripcio: Josep Maignon i Sargelet (Cignac, Languedoc, France, 1762 - Barcelona, 1847). Owner of the lands. But as there exists a Sargelet street, so named after Gabrielle Sargelet, mother of the owner, it is quite probable that this street is dedicated to her father, Esteve Maignon.

carrer.name: Mainada, Plaça de la
carrer.descripcio: This is how this square is popularly called among the neighbors of this quarter.

carrer.name: Maiol, Passatge de
carrer.descripcio: Passage so named after Pere Mayol i Babot (Barcelona, 1775 - 1845). Owner of 63 areas plus 46 hundred areas he had bought from Jaume Llavallol in 1818. His successor was Pere Mayol i Pujolà (Barcelona, 1819 - 1888), his son.

carrer.name: Major de Can Caralleu, Carrer
carrer.descripcio: Street leading to the sports center, and to the Can Caralleu neighborhood.

carrer.name: Major de Sarrià, Carrer
carrer.descripcio: Mainstreet of the old township of Sarrià.
carrer.anteriors: Sarrià; Capuchinos; Cataluña; Mayor (junction of); Prim (junction of); Serrano; Capuchinos del Desierto

carrer.name: Major del Rectoret, Carrer
carrer.descripcio: So named because of the tenant farmer of Can Planes, who used to help out in the Vallvidrera parish, and was therefore called "el rectoret" (the sacristan).

carrer.name: Major del Rectoret, Plaça
carrer.descripcio: Square at the entrance of the Rectoret neighborhood when coming from Les Planes station.

carrer.name: Malacca, Passatge de
carrer.descripcio: Passageway within a group of streets near the Barcelona harbor dedicated to or related with seas and oceans, which is named after the Strait of Malaya separating the Malayan Peninsula from the Sumatra Island,.

carrer.name: Maladeta, Carrer de la
carrer.descripcio: Massif in the Aragones Pyrenees.
carrer.anteriors: Piqué, before 1900; T. de Piqué (a section)

carrer.name: Màlaga, Jardins de
carrer.descripcio: Gardens named after Malaga, the Andalusian town. The dedication is a result of a location change in naming the urban space.

carrer.name: Malats, Carrer de
carrer.descripcio: Joaquim Malats i Miarons (Sant Andreu de Palomar, 1872 - Barcelona, 1912). Musician. Pianist and composer. Winner of the first award of the Conservatoire for Music of Paris and of the Diémes Prize (1903).
carrer.anteriors: Vasconia (a section joined to); Hostal, before 1900

carrer.name: Malcuinat, Carrer del
carrer.descripcio: Street covered by the underpass leading from the Royal Palace to Santa Maria del Mar church. Protected by this roofing, soon selling stands were installed in this street, some serving a typical dish of cooked giblets called 'malcuinat'.

carrer.name: Malet, Passatge de
carrer.descripcio: Passageway named after Francesc de Paula Malet i Casas (Barcelona, 1817 - 1876). Lawyer. Married to Maria Concepció Galí i Boscà, owner of the estate she had inherited from her father, Jacint Galí i Vilar.

carrer.name: Malgrat, Carrer de
carrer.descripcio: Malgrat de Mar. Borough of Maresme.

carrer.name: Mallofré, Passatge de
carrer.descripcio: Passageway named after Josep Mallofré, stockbroker, from Sant Quintí de Mediona (Alt Penedès), who bought the lands around a building formerly belonging to military quarters, where the cars of a transport company used to be sheltered. He demolished the building and opened this passageway between 1866 and 1870.

carrer.name: Mallorca, Carrer de
carrer.descripcio: Named after Majorca, the Balearic Island, in memory of its re-conquest by Jaume I, in 1229. The decision to re-conquer Majorca was taken by the Parliament on December 24, 1228.
carrer.anteriors: Màlaga (a section); Núria (from Rogent up to Sibèlius); Lletra J (Cerdà plan)
carrer.districtes: EIXAMPLE (02) SANTS-MONTJUÏC (03) SANT ANDREU (09) SANT MARTÍ (10)

carrer.name: Malnom, Carrer del
carrer.descripcio: This street was so renamed, because its old name, "Tifella", was considered rude and offensive. (RiC; FiH). According to Joan Amades, "its old name was 'd'en Titella', as shown in a document dating back to 1624".

carrer.name: Maluquer, Passatge de
carrer.descripcio: Passageway named after Josep Maluquer i Salvador (Granollers, Vallès Oriental, 1863 - Madrid 1931). Legal adviser. Doctor of Law. Founder of the National Institute for Social Security.

carrer.name: Malva, Carrer de la
carrer.descripcio: Within a group of streets named after trees and plants.

carrer.name: Manacor, Carrer de
carrer.descripcio: Borough of Eastern Majorca.

carrer.name: Mandoni, Carrer de
carrer.descripcio: Mandoni (? - 205 b.Ch.) was the chief of the Ilergetes. He fought the Romans side by side with his brother Indibil. Finally he was defeated and died.

carrer.name: Mandri, Carrer de
carrer.descripcio: Josepa Mandri i Rifós, daughter of Andreu Mandri, Doctor of Law at Sant Andreu de Llavaneres (Maresme). She was the last "pubilla" of the Can Mandri estate, instituted the universal heir of all properties by marriage capitulations bestowed upon her in 1801, when she married Antoni Dionís Ferret i Torrents, Doctor of Law at Vilanova i la Geltrú. Her successors were her children Joaquim and Josepa Ferret i Mandri, who inherited the estate in 1850. In the General Street Map of Sant Gervasi dating back to 1895, this street does not exist yet. So when it was opened later, it was named after the dower.

carrer.name: Manelic, Carrer d'en
carrer.descripcio: Named after the main character of 'Terra Baixa', by Ángel Guimerà.

carrer.name: Manigua, Carrer de la
carrer.descripcio: Manigua means a compact tropical forest with plenty of lianas, and hard to cross, typical of Cuba and of the American tropics in general.

carrer.name: Manila, Carrer de
carrer.descripcio: Named after Manila, capital of the Philippines. The street, formerly called Tòquio, was so named in 1945, when the facts of Japanese occupation in the Philippines during World War II started to be known. Later (1955), a street of Pedralbes was named Tòquio.
carrer.anteriors: Tokio; Lletra A (Plan of Les Corts)

carrer.name: Manlleu, Passatge de
carrer.descripcio: Passageway named after this borough of Osona.

carrer.name: Manlleu, Carrer de
carrer.descripcio: Borough of Osona. Street within the Coll neighborhood, where many streets were named after Catalan villages.

carrer.name: Manresa, Carrer de
carrer.descripcio: Name of an important Catalan family living in the city since the XIII century, among whose descendants were many remarkable citizens and Councilors. The street was so named in the second half of the XVIII century, after a "Hostal d'en Manresa" (hostel) there had been according to documents dating back to 1767. The hostel was demolished in 1909, when the city was remodeled to open the Via Laietana.
carrer.anteriors: Màrtir Battisti; D'en Jordi Ras y d'en Tripó

carrer.name: Manrique de Lara, Carrer de
carrer.descripcio: Lluís Carreras i Lastortras (Mataró, Maresme, 1840 - Barcelona, 1888). Journalist and republican politician. He wrote under the pseudonym Manuel Manrique de Lara, the name of an important Spanish aristocratic family.

carrer.name: Manso, Carrer de
carrer.descripcio: Josep Manso i Solà (Borredà, Berguedà, 1785 - Madrid, 1863). Count of Llobregat (1844). Commander-in-Chief of Aragon (1845), Valencia (1846-1847), and Castile La Nueva (1847). Specially known for his actions during the Independence War. The "carrer del General Manso" is also dedicated to him.

carrer.name: Manuel Ainaud, Plaça de
carrer.descripcio: Square named after Manuel Ainaud i Sànchez (Barcelona, 1885 - 1931). Artist, sketcher, pedagogue. Sketching teacher at the Horacian School. Director of the Colegio Mont d'Or. President of the Popular Encyclopedical Athenaeum. Technical consultant of the Culture Committee of the Barcelona City Council. Founder of several schools of international prestige. He instigated the creation of the City Council's School Patronage.

carrer.name: Manuel Angelon, Carrer de
carrer.descripcio: Manuel Angelon i Broquetas (Lleida, Segrià, 1831 - Barcelona 1889). Poet, novelist, playwright, and historian.

carrer.name: Manuel Arnús, Carrer de
carrer.descripcio: Manuel Arnús i Fortuny (Barcelona, 1852 - 1916). Doctor of medicine. Together with Josep Garí, he founded the Arnús-Garí Bank.

carrer.name: Manuel Azaña, Avinguda de
carrer.descripcio: Avenue named after Manuel Azaña i Díaz (Alcalá de Henares, 1880 - Montauban, Occitaine, France, 1940). Spanish politician and writer. Acting Head of the Government between October, 1931 and September, 1933. President of the Spanish Republic from May, 1936 to February, 1939, when he exiled to France.

carrer.name: Manuel Ballbé, Carrer de
carrer.descripcio: Manuel Ballbé i Prunés (Barcelona, 1920 - 1961). Lawyer and jurist. Lecturer of Administrative Law at the University of Murcia (1945) and of Zaragoza (1953). Lecturer of Administrative Law and Economy at the University of Barcelona. He was related with many institutions in Catalonia, and with the Fundación March (March Foundation).

carrer.name: Manuel Blancafort, Jardins de
carrer.descripcio: Gardens named after Manuel Blancafort de Rosselló (La Garriga, Vallès Oriental, 1897 - Barcelona, 1987). Composer. Disciple of Joan Lamote de Grignon. Influenced by French impressionism, he became world-wide known after his debut in Paris with his oeuvre 'Parc d'atraccions'. Later he developed a solid classical deepness, writing symphonies, remarkable concerts for piano, and excellent quartets, his most important works being: 'Sonata antigua' (1929), 'Concerto omaggio' (1944), 'Concierto Ibérico' (1946), 'Cuarteto de Pedralbes' (1949), 'Sinfonía en' 'mi mayor' (1950), 'Rapsodia catalana' (1953), 'Evocaciones' (1969), and 'Cantata a la Virgen María' (1965), the latter awarded by the Catalan Choral Society. This street was dedicated to him on proposal of Helena Calsamiglia i Blancafort.

carrer.name: Manuel Corachan, Plaça de
carrer.descripcio: Square named after Manuel Corachan i Garcia (Xiva, Foia de Bunyol, 1881 - Barcelona, 1942). Surgeon. Director of the Surgical Service at the Holy Cross Hospital (Hospital de la Santa Creu) (1921). Founder of the Clínica Corachan, now Corachan Institute. President (1932-1934) of the Academy and Laboratory of Medical Sciences. Councilor for Health of the Generalitat in 1936. Exiled to Venezuela, he was director of the Institute for Experimental Surgery and lecturer of Anatomic Techniques at the University of Caracas. Among others, he published the 'Diccionari de medicina' (Dictionary of Medicine), a glossary of medical terms in Catalan language.

carrer.name: Manuel de Falla, Carrer de
carrer.descripcio: Manuel de Falla Matheu (Cadiz, 1876 - Alta Gracia, Cordoba, Argentina, 1946). Andalusian composer of universal renown.

carrer.name: Manuel de Pedrolo, Jardins de
carrer.descripcio: Gardens named after Manuel de Pedrolo i Molina (L'Aranyó, Segarra, 1918 - Barcelona, 1990). Writer. After moving to Barcelona in 1943, he cultivated all kinds of literature: poetry, theater plays -within the theater of the absurd-, novels, and short stories, the narrative being his forte. He also translated from English and French. His best known work is 'Mecanoscrit del segon origen'. He lived in the Fort Pius neighborhood.

carrer.name: Manuel Girona, Passeig de
carrer.descripcio: Boulevard named after Manuel Girona i Agrafel (Barcelona, 1817 - 1905). Financier. Mayor of Barcelona (1876). Life-time Senator. He was married to Catalina Vidal from Maracaibo, Venezuela.

carrer.name: Manuel J. Arnalot, Jardins de
carrer.descripcio: Manuel Jiménez Arnalot (Barcelona 1927 - 1993). Sketcher, bill painter, abstract painter using all kinds of debris materials (iron, clips, paper, yarn, marble powder, oil and acrylic paint, etc.) in his famous 'collages'. Tragic iconography of opposition and contradiction.

carrer.name: Manuel Ramon, Carrer de
carrer.descripcio: In 1902, Manuel Ramon i Miravent (Barcelona 1859 - 1921) was the owner of this part of the Torre Gomis or Frare Blanc estate.

carrer.name: Manuel Ribé, Placeta de
carrer.descripcio: Small square named after Manuel Ribé i Labarta (Barcelona, 1878 - 1961). Master of Ceremonies of the Barcelona City Council, and of the Urban Guard.

carrer.name: Manuel Sacristán, Jardins de
carrer.descripcio: Gardens named after Manuel Sacristán Luzón (Madrid, 1925 - Barcelona, 1985). Philosopher and writer. Due to his political activities, he became the leader of the clandestine PSUC party, and played a relevant part in the Catalan university movement.

carrer.name: Manuel Sanchis Guarner, Carrer de
carrer.descripcio: Manuel Sanchis Guarner (Valencia, Horta, 1911 - 1981). Philologue, historian, folklorist. Ordinary member of the Institute for Catalan Studies, and of the Valencian Culture Center. Member of the Spanish Academy. Teacher at the Escuela Lulística of Majorca. Catalan Letters Award of Honor in 1974 (Premi d'Honor de les Lletres Catalanes).

carrer.name: Manuel Sancho, Carrer de
carrer.descripcio: Manuel Sancho i Bou, married to Concepció Roca i Pitarch, was the owner of the place in 1922.

carrer.name: Manuel Sancho, Passatge de
carrer.descripcio: Passageway named after the same person as the street.

carrer.name: Manuel Torrente, Plaça de
carrer.descripcio: Square named after Juan Manuel Torrente de Flores (Ferrol, A Coruña, 1829 - 1916). In 1844, when he was 15 year old, he emigrated to Cuba, where he lived at San Carlos de Matanzas until the Spring of 1857, when he returned to Spain. Already living in Barcelona, he married Gaspar Preciado's widow, Mrs. Mercè Frigola i Poch, in 1857. Soon he became the proxy of Massens and Rabassa, all three owners of part of the Alegre de Dalt estate, formerly belonging to the Holy Cross Hospital of Barcelona (Hospital de la Santa Creu) (1861). As shown in documents, the city owes him the invention of the Torrent de les Flors street.

carrer.name: Manufactures, Passatge de les
carrer.descripcio: Passageway within a group of factory buildings, opened in 1873.

carrer.name: Manxa, Carrer de la
carrer.descripcio: Region of the Iberian Peninsula, in the eastern section of the Central Massive.

carrer.name: Manzanares, Carrer de
carrer.descripcio: District capital within the Ciudad Real province, so named in memory of the Manzanares Manifest, written by Cánovas del Castillo, and signed by General O'Donnell on July 7, 1854 (after the Vicálvaro insurrection), consolidating the victory of the Liberal Progressist Movement all over Spain. The Barcelona Insurrection, under the leadership of General Dulce, took place on July 14, 1854.

carrer.name: Mañé i Flaquer, Plaça de
carrer.descripcio: Square named after the same person as the street.

carrer.name: Mañé i Flaquer, Carrer de
carrer.descripcio: Joan Mañé i Flaquer (Torredembarra, Tarragonès, 1823 - Barcelona, 1901). Journalist and writer. Director of the journal 'Diario de Barcelona' (1865), called "el Brusi" after the founder's name.

carrer.name: Maó, Carrer de
carrer.descripcio: Borough of Menorca.

carrer.name: Mar, Rambla de
carrer.descripcio: A footbridge connecting the Portal de la Pau with the Moll d'Espanya. It is considered the natural extension of the Rambla.

carrer.name: Mar, Plaça del
carrer.descripcio: Square at the southern end of the Barceloneta neighborhood, with the sea at both sides.

carrer.name: Mar, Carrer del
carrer.descripcio: Street at the Barceloneta neighborhood, reminding us that the sea is not far from here. This was the former main street of Barceloneta.
carrer.anteriors: Josep Pous o Pons; Mayor, before 1865

carrer.name: Mar Bella, Espigó de la
carrer.descripcio: Breakwater called the same as the adjoining beach.

carrer.name: Mar Bella, Platja de la
carrer.descripcio: Beach so named in memory of the old sandy grounds on which the Barceloneta neighborhood was erected. According to the great geographer Carreras Candi, 'marbell' or 'marbella' means "ebb tide", but also sands freed by the ebb tide. Therefore, the property now occupied by the Barceloneta neighborhood were formerly referred to as "la marbella", because they were recovered from the sea as the waters went down. As time went by, there was a confusion about the original meaning, so the place was called "Mar Bella". There also had been a bathing establishment of this name on this beach during the first half of the XX century.

carrer.name: Mar Groga, Carrer de la
carrer.descripcio: All streets around the Port of Barcelona are named after seas and oceans, this street being dedicated to the Yellow Sea.

carrer.name: Mar Roja, Carrer de la
carrer.descripcio: This street near the Port of Barcelona is named after the Red Sea.

carrer.name: Maracaibo, Carrer de
carrer.descripcio: Named after Maracaibo, the city of Venezuela. This street is within the Bon Pastor industrial area, where streets are named after Latin American places and towns.

carrer.name: Maragall, Plaça de
carrer.descripcio: Square named after the same person as the boulevard.

carrer.name: Maragall, Passeig de
carrer.descripcio: Boulevard named after Joan Maragall i Gorina (Barcelona, 1860 - 1911). Writer and poet. Founding member of the Philological Section of the Institute for Catalan Studies, master in the art of poetry "Gaya Ciencia", and president of the Athenaeum of Barcelona.
carrer.anteriors: General Martínez Anido (joined to it); Ctra. Nueva de Horta, before 1900
carrer.districtes: HORTA-GUINARDÓ (07) NOU BARRIS (08) SANT ANDREU (09) SANT MARTÍ (10)

carrer.name: Marbre, Carrer del
carrer.descripcio: So named because of the nearby Montjuïc marble quarries.

carrer.name: Marc Aureli, Carrer de
carrer.descripcio: Marcus Aelius Aurelius Verus (Rome, 121 - Sirmium, 180). Roman Emperor and philosopher.

carrer.name: Marçà, Carrer de
carrer.descripcio: Named after this borough of the Priorat. The cross street is Cornudella street, also named after a borough of the Priorat, as all streets within the Ramon Albó housing estate are named after Catalan places and villages.

carrer.name: Marcel·lí, Carrer de
carrer.descripcio: This street is the extension of the Marcel·lí riverside walk.

carrer.name: Marcel·lí, Riera de
carrer.descripcio: Old place-name at Horta.
carrer.anteriors: Marcelino; Ra. o t. de Casa Iglesias

carrer.name: Marco Polo, Carrer de
carrer.descripcio: Marco Polo (Venice, Italy, 1254 - 1324). Medieval Venetian traveler and adventurer. This street belongs to the Rectoret neighborhood, where many street names were chosen by the neighbors.

carrer.name: Marcos Redondo, Jardins de
carrer.descripcio: Gardens named after Marcos Redondo Valencia (Pozoblanco, Cordoba, 1893 - Barcelona, 1976). Baritone. His career started in 1919 in Madrid, where he sang 'La Traviata' at the Gran Teatro. His debut in Barcelona was in 1923, at the Liceu Opera House with 'Manon Lescaut'. After establishing in Barcelona, in 1924 he left the opera for the zarzuela (Spanish operetta), genre he had his debut in at the Novetats theater, becoming very popular and successful all over Spain and Latin America as the excellent singer he was. He retired in 1957, leaving behind a large number of records of his best performances.

carrer.name: Marcús, Placeta d'en
carrer.descripcio: Small square named after Bernat Marcús (Barcelona, XII century). Bourgeois from Barcelona, who played his part in the country's high politics. In 1166, he gave lands and money for a hospital and a chapel dedicated to Our Lady of the Guide (Virgen de la Guía), which were built where this square is now.

carrer.name: Mare de Déu de Gràcia, Carrer de la
carrer.descripcio: In the beginning, at the site where the Josepets church is now, there was a chapel dedicated to Our Lady of Grace (Virgen de Gràcia). Since the end of the XIV century, this was the name given to the population building up around this chapel.

carrer.name: Mare de Déu de la Pau, Plaça de la
carrer.descripcio: Square so named in memory of the Peace reached in April, 1939, thus ending the Spanish Civil War.

carrer.name: Mare de Déu de la Salut, Carrer de la
carrer.descripcio: So named for the chapel, or sanctuary, installed in a manor nearby, which was opened to public worship in 1864, and also gave name to the housing neighborhood erected around this place between 1866 and 1870. In May, 1904, the forty-years celebrations of the sanctuary took place. But until 1949, the street was simply called "de la Salut" (Health Street).

carrer.name: Mare de Déu de les Neus, Carrer de la
carrer.descripcio: So named on proposal of the neighbors.
carrer.anteriors: Covadonga, 07/03/1939; Mare de Déu de Núria, 04/02/1931; Covadonga, 18/05/1927; Virgen de Núria (Ajuntament de Sarrià), abans 1922; Buenos Aires, abans de 1888

carrer.name: Mare de Déu de l'Estrella, Passatge
carrer.descripcio: According to the 'Dietario de l'Antich Consell Barceloní 'and 'Dietari de Barcelona' manuscripts, when the pest raged in Barcelona in 1651, the Local Government asked the monastery of Santa Maria de Jerusalem, formerly on Gardunya square, to open their garden for burying the dead, as there was little place left in Barcelona for burying them all. Seven nuns fell ill, but it seems that Our Lady of the Star (Virgen de la Estrella), to whom the monastery was dedicated, helped the monastery and the city to overcome the worst. At present, this Virgin is worshipped at the Royal Monastery of Santa Maria de Jerusalem at Sarrià. The order was established in Barcelona more than 500 years ago. This passageway was dedicated to Our Lady of the Star on proposal of the Abbess of the Monastery.

carrer.name: Mare de Déu de Lorda, Avinguda de la
carrer.descripcio: Avenue named after Lourdes, the town in Gascogne, Occitaine, France, known by pilgrims of the whole world since Bernadette Soubirous asserted to have seen the Virgin in the Massabielle cave in 1858.
carrer.anteriors: Nuestra Señora de Lourdes; Cº de Lourdes; Cº de Fons

carrer.name: Mare de Déu de Lorda, Camí de la
carrer.descripcio: Walk dedicated to Our Lady of Lourdes, who appeared before Bernadette Soubirous in 1858, under the aspect of the Immaculate Conception.

carrer.name: Mare de Déu de Montserrat, Carrer de la
Mare de Déu de Montserrat, Avinguda de la
carrer.descripcio: Avenue dedicated to the patron Holy Virgin of Catalonia.
carrer.anteriors: Virgen de Montserrat; Castellana (without effectiveness); Dos Rius; Fuente Castellana

carrer.name: Mare de Déu de Núria, Carrer de la
carrer.descripcio: Street dedicated to Our Lady of the Pyrenees. In the 1939 Nomenclator, the name was changed to "Virgen de Covadonga", until it recovered its original name in 1979.
carrer.anteriors: Virgen de Nuria, 1979; Covadonga, 1939; Virgen de Nuria (Town Hall of Sarrià); Buenos Aires, before 1888

carrer.name: Mare de Déu de Port, Carrer de la
carrer.descripcio: So named because of an old hermitage, which also gave name to the whole neighborhood. Nonetheless, the place-name Port dates back farther than the X century, referring to a natural port there was West of the Montjuïc hill prior to the arrival of ancient Romans.
carrer.anteriors: Nuestra Señora de Port; Ctra. de Port, before 1900; Ra. de Magòria

carrer.name: Mare de Déu del Carmel, Carrer de la
carrer.descripcio: Dedicated to the sanctuary of the same name.

carrer.name: Mare de Déu del Coll, Carrer de la
carrer.descripcio: Dedicated to the sanctuary of the same name.
carrer.anteriors: Nuestra Señora del Coll; Pje. Nuestra Señora del Coll (joined to it)

carrer.name: Mare de Déu del Coll, Passeig de la
carrer.descripcio: A hermitage built in the XI century by priest Guerau Mir, later converted into a Benedictine Priory affiliated to Sant Cugat del Vallès in 1098, gave name to the street, to this boulevard, and to the whole neighborhood.

carrer.name: Mare de Déu del Pilar (Ciutat Vella), Carrer de la
carrer.descripcio: This street, formerly called "d'en Cuc", was renamed after a chapel dedicated to Virgen del Pilar there had been in the neighborhood. This chapel was closed to the public in 1909.
carrer.anteriors: Virgen del Pilar, before 1900; Llibertat; Cuch, before 1865

carrer.name: Mare de Déu del Remei, Carrer de la
carrer.descripcio: Remei was the name of the daughter of the urbanizer and land owner Jaume Grases i Hernández, and of his wife Joaquima Fabrés i Coll. There also had been a hermitage dedicated to this Virgin (Our Lady of the Remedies) in the old Raval, on the boundary of the San Bertran orchards.

carrer.name: Mare de Déu dels Àngels, Carrer de la
carrer.descripcio: So named after Àngela Rosell i Inglés, wife of Joaquim Taxonera i Cassà, owner of the place.

carrer.name: Mare de Déu dels Desemparats, Carrer de la
carrer.descripcio: Street dedicated to the patron saint of Valencia.
carrer.anteriors: Virgen del Amparo, before 1900; Faust Castells

carrer.name: Mare de Déu dels Reis, Carrer de la
carrer.descripcio: So named in honor of the first name of Maria de los Reyes de la Barre i Díaz de Manso (Barcelona, 1836 - 1909), sister of Pilar and Agustí, owners of the lands where this street was opened.

carrer.name: Mare Eterna, Carrer de la
carrer.descripcio: Title of a work in honor of Mother Nature, written by Ignasi Iglésias in 1900.

carrer.name: Mare Nazaria March, Plaça de la
carrer.descripcio: Square named after Nazaria Ignacia March Mesa (Madrid, 1889 - Rivadavia, Argentina, 1943). Founder of the order of Crusader Missionaries of the Church. This institution, dedicated to help and teach the poor, and to give social assistance to women, opened establishments in Spain, Bolivia, Argentina, and Uruguay. On this square, there is a school belonging to the Institute founded by mother Nazaria.

carrer.name: Maresme, Carrer del
carrer.descripcio: Principat district within the Barcelona region, later renamed to Maresme, where this street is. The geographical name 'maresme' means "coastal region".

carrer.name: Maresme, Plaça del
carrer.descripcio: Square named after the Principat neighborhood within the Barcelona region.

carrer.name: Margalló, Carrer del
carrer.descripcio: Street named after the palmetto tree, within a group of streets of the Rectoret neighborhood named after trees and bushes.
carrer.anteriors: Victòria dels Àngels; Ctra. del Atajo

carrer.name: Margarida Xirgu, Plaça de
carrer.descripcio: Square named after Margarita Xirgu i Subirà (Molins de Rei, Baix Llobregat, 1888 - Montevideo, Uruguay, 1969). Actress. She worked for the Josep Santpere Company. In Madrid, she was first lady of the Spanish theater.

carrer.name: Margarit, Carrer de
carrer.descripcio: Josep Margarit i de Biure (Castell d'Empordà, Baix Empordà, 1602 - Perpignan, Roussillon, France, 1685). Military and politician. Grand Field Master of Vilafranca. He was Governor of Catalonia in opposition to Philip IV of Castile, and ambassador of the Generalitat in Paris. He fought against the troops of the Marquis of Los Vélez in the defense of Barcelona (1641). This street, as well as those of Cabanyes, Radas, and Tapioles (all of them at Poble-sec), were given their names after Catalan heroes of the Rippers' War, together with Pau Claris, Fontanella, and Tamarit.

carrer.name: Margenat, Carrer de
carrer.descripcio: Joan Margenat i Salvany (XIX century) bought the lands formerly belonging to the Mas Anglí estate, previously owned by Francesc Anglí i Brichfeus (XVIII century). He had been three times Mayor of Sarrià in the XIX century (1854, 1858, 1865). His father was Francesc Margenat i Cuyàs, who died in 1824, and his mother Antònia Salvany i Casas.

carrer.name: Marí, Passatge de
carrer.descripcio: Passageway named after Llorenç Marí i Vilallonga, owner between 1901 and 1923 of a piece of property within the 28 'mujadas' (approx. 180,200 m2) of land around the Carabassa house.

carrer.name: Marí, Carrer de
carrer.descripcio: Jeroni Marí i Molins (Barcelona, 1841 - 1913). Farmer, owner of the lands around the places called "Camp del Coll" and "Camp de les Tres Puntes", formerly "dels Pins". He was married to Narcisa Bernet i Molins. Supposedly, this street is dedicated to his father, Antoni Marí i Bota, mason.

carrer.name: Maria, Carrer de
carrer.descripcio: Street between Gran de Gràcia and Sant Pere Mártir, near Jesús street, dedicated to Maria, the God Mother.

carrer.name: Marià Aguiló, Carrer de
carrer.descripcio: Marià Aguiló i Fuster (Ciudad de Mallorca, now Palma de Majorca, 1825 - Barcelona, 1897). Poet, philologue, and bibliographer. Master in the art of poetry, president of the Floral Games (1867-1888). Member of the Academy of Fine Letters of Barcelona. He was a leading person of the Renaixença movement in the Catalan-speaking countries.
carrer.anteriors: Mariano Aguiló; San Pedro del Taulat

carrer.name: Maria Aurèlia Capmany, Carrer de
carrer.descripcio: Maria Aurèlia Capmany i Farnés (Barcelona, 1918 - 1991). Writer, playwright, theater director, and essayist. Sant Jordi Prize in 1968 for 'Un lloc entre els morts'. In 1948, Joanot Martorell Prize for 'El cel no és transparent'. President of the Catalan Pen Club (1979-1983). Councilor for Culture of the Barcelona City Council since 1983. Since 1987, he was responsible for municipal issues. President of the Nomenclature Commission for public roads, streets, and squares in Barcelona.

carrer.name: Maria Auxiliadora, Carrer de
carrer.descripcio: Dedicated to the Salesian Order, which has its Institute here.

carrer.name: Maria Barrientos, Carrer de
carrer.descripcio: Maria Barrientos i Llopis (Barcelona, 1884 - Ziburu, Lapurdi, 1946). Soprano. She created an annual scholarship for music students to complete their studies abroad.

carrer.name: Marià Brossa, Plaça de
carrer.descripcio: Square named after Marià Brossa i Arnó (Sant Andreu de Palomar, Barcelona, 1831 - 1881). Pedagogue and journalist. Mayor of Sant Andreu in 1869.
carrer.anteriors: Mariano Brossa; Duque de la Victoria, before 1900
