carrer.name: Marià Cañardo i Lacasta, Jardins de
carrer.descripcio: Gardens named after María Cañardo i Lacasta (Olite, Navarra, 1906 - Barcelona, 1987). Cycle racer.

carrer.name: Marià Cubí, Carrer de
carrer.descripcio: Marià Cubí i Soler (Malgrat, Maresme, 1801 - Barcelona, 1875). Scientist specialized in phrenology and linguist. He founded the 'Colegio Buenavista' in Havana, Cuba, and the magazine 'Revista Bimestre Cubana' (1831), published until 1959. Back in Barcelona, he founded the magazine 'La Antorcha'.

carrer.name: Maria Espinalt i Font, Plaça de
carrer.descripcio: Soprano. She was born in Barcelona on 29th July 1910. The daughter of Teodor Espinalt i Prat and Mercè Font i Danti, she made her début at the Barcelona Opera House (Gran Teatre del Liceu) in 1931, where she performed for over 10 seasons. She was the widow of Josep Maria Coll i Rovira, and on 10th December 1938 she married a second time, on this occasion to Manuel Ulloa Robles. She was considered the foremost figure of the Spanish stage at the time. The government of the Spanish Republic awarded her the "Lazo de la Orden de Isabel la Católica". She retired in 1956. She died in Barcelona on 25th June 1981, in the Carrer d'Espaseria, 15.

carrer.name: Marià Labèrnia, Carrer de
carrer.descripcio: Marià Labèrnia i Solà (Barcelona, 1885 - 1916), heir after his father, Pere Labèrnia i Carreras, owner of the lands where the Labèrnia housing project was built.

carrer.name: Marià Manent, Jardins de
carrer.descripcio: Gardens named after Marià Manent i Cisa (Barcelona 1898 - 1988). Writer. Literature Director of Editorial Juventut, editors in Barcelona. Most of his prolific works, both as an author and as a translator and critic, are related with poetry. He was awarded with the Josep Pla Prize in 1974, and with the Catalan Letters Award of Honor in 1985.

carrer.name: Maria Montesori, Carrer de
carrer.descripcio: Maria Montessori (Chiaravalle, Ancona, Italy, 1870 - Noordwijk, Holland, 1952). Italian pedagogue. She started her experiments at the Psychiatric Ward at the University of Rome, and used the results for working out a method named after her (1907). Her purpose was to enhance expressiveness and initiative in children by using new didactical material. Her method was a world-wide success.

carrer.name: Maria Paretas, Carrer de
carrer.descripcio: Maria Paretas i Riera (1901 - 1965), wife of Raimond Vila Furró, owner of real estate around the place since 1942, when she bought the property from Miquel Vila i Boix.

carrer.name: Maria Reina, Carrer de
carrer.descripcio: Heavenly Queen Maria, Mother of Jesus. Street within the Can Caralleu housing estate.

carrer.name: Maria Victòria, Carrer de
carrer.descripcio: Maria Victoria del Pozzo della Cisterna i de Ghislaine (Paris, France, 1847 - San Remo, Italy, 1876). Queen of Spain (1871-1873). Daughter of Carlos Manuel del Pozzo della Cisterna and of Luisa Carolina Ghislaine, Countess of Merode. She married Amadeo, Duke of Aosta (1867). During the reign of her husband, King Amadeo I, she lived in Spain.

carrer.name: Maria Vila, Passatge de
carrer.descripcio: Passageway named after Maria Vila i Panadès (Barcelona 1897 - 1963). Actress. Daughter of actors, she began acting very young, and very soon she became the first actress in the Enric Borràs Company, performing at the Novedades Theater. In 1920, she created her own company together with her husband, the also actor Pius Daví. They used to perform preferably at the Romea Theater, specializing in Catalan theater. After the Spanish Civil War, they contributed to the recovery of scenic arts. One of her admirers, Josep M. de Sagarra, wrote for her 'L'hostal de la Glòria' (1931). She was considered in justice one of the most important actresses of the Catalan scene. This passageway was dedicated to her on proposal of the Women's Group of the Municipal Council for Social Welfare.

carrer.name: Maria Zambrano, Carrer de
carrer.descripcio: María Zambrano Alarcón, writer, lecturer in Philosophy, and journalist. She was born in Vélez-Málaga on 22nd April 1904. She had to go into exile in 1936, and traveled first to Chile. She became a lecturer at the Mexican Universidad de Morelia in 1939. She later took up teaching posts in Havana from 1940 till 1943, and in Puerto Rico. She next moved to France and Switzerland, until her final return to Spain in 1984. She published several books in which she expresses a form of thought structured around hope and the connections between philosophy and poetry. She was awarded the Cervantes Spanish Literary Prize in 1988. She died in Madrid on 6th February 1991.

carrer.name: Maria-Antònia Salvà, Plaça de
carrer.descripcio: Square named after Maria-Antònia Salvà i Ripoll (Ciudad de Mallorca, now Palma, Majorca, 1869 - Llucmajor, Eastern Majorca, 1958). Poet and translator. She lived almost all her quiet, sedentary life at Llucmajor, except for 1907, when she traveled with Costa i Llobera to the Greek Islands and to the Middle East. Her most notable friends were Miquel Ferrà and Josep Carner, who became her literary mentors. In 1903, she received an award at the Literature Contest of Majorcan Fairs and Feasts for her poem 'Joc de nins'. Her poems were published in two volumes: 'Poesies' (1910), 'Espigues en flor' (1926), 'El retorn' (1934), etc. She was a collaborator of the magazines 'Catalunya' and 'Feminal'. But she also did an excellent job as a translator, translating important authors, such as Frederic Mistral, Francis James, Manzoni, Petrarca, and Saint Therese of Lisieux. This street was dedicated to her on proposal of the Women's Group of the Municipal Council for Social Welfare.

carrer.name: Mariana Pineda, Carrer de
carrer.descripcio: Mariana Pineda Muñoz (Granada, 1804 - 1831). She actively contributed to the liberal cause, loyal to the 1812 Constitution, making embroider a constitutional flag with the inscription "Law, Freedom, Equality", that should have been used during an insurrection planned in Granada. She was sentenced to death.
carrer.anteriors: Palet de Rubi; Mariana Pineda, before 1900; Numància

carrer.name: Marianao, Carrer de
carrer.descripcio: Village on the Cuban North coast, East from Havana, origin of the Marquis title bestowed upon a Catalan family, whose most illustrious member was Salvador de Samà i de Torrents, Marquis of Marianao (Barcelona, 1861 - 1933). Mayor of Barcelona (1905-1906 and 1910-1911). Together with Ramon d'Abadal and Giner de los Ríos, he presided the Assembly of Catalan Members of the Parliament in 1917, stating the will of Catalonia to achieve the autonomic status.

carrer.name: Marie Curie, Carrer de
carrer.descripcio: Marya Sklodowska Boguska (Varsaw, Poland, 1867 - Sancellemoz, Haute Savoie, France, 1934). French physician of Polish origin. She went to Paris in 1891 to continue her studies at the Sorbonne. Later she married Pierre Curie, with whom she investigated radioactivity. The couple received the Nobel Prize in Physics in 1903, together with Becquerel. In addition to the investigations carried on with her husband, Marie Curie discovered the thorium radioactivity at the same time as the German scientist Schmidt. After Pierre Curie's death, she became the first woman lecturer at the Sorbonne. She founded 'the Institut du Radium', the director of which she was until her death. In 1911, she won the Nobel Prize in Chemistry for isolating pure radium.

carrer.name: Marimon, Passatge de
carrer.descripcio: Passageway named after Josep Marimon i Guardiola (? - 1885), son of Vicenç and Isabel). Owner of the lands according to documents dating from 1875. In 1927, the origin of this name was defined as being that of "an old family from Barcelona, owner of one of the houses at the village of Sarrià".

carrer.name: Marín, Carrer de
carrer.descripcio: Rafael Soriano Marín, mechanic, neighbor of Manresa, was one of the three owners of the place from the beginning of the XX century until 1929.

carrer.name: Marina, Carrer de la
carrer.descripcio: So named in honor of the Catalan merchant and military navy.
carrer.data: 15/05/1992 ((from Diagonal avenue to the Olympic Port))
carrer.anteriors: Pg. de Carles I, 07/03/1939; Pg. del Doctor Robert; Marina (a section), before 1900; Núm. 40 (Cerdà plan)
carrer.districtes: CIUTAT VELLA (01) EIXAMPLE (02) HORTA-GUINARDÓ (07) SANT MARTÍ (10)

carrer.name: Marina, Moll de
carrer.descripcio: Peer of the Olympic Port of Barcelona.

carrer.name: Marina, Pas de la
carrer.descripcio: Small passage accessible from Alcalde de Móstoles street.

carrer.name: Marina, Passatge de la
carrer.descripcio: Passageway running along the former Via Marina, which already appears in documents dating back to the XI century. Most probably named so after Rita Marina, owner of the lands in 1920.

carrer.name: Marina de Sants, Plaça de la
carrer.descripcio: Square named so because here used to be the old coastal area of Sants. During many years, this area covered a large extension of land from the Can Tunis beach to the Gran Via, and from the Montjuïc hill up to the Llobregat river. This was a very fertile farming area, giving three harvests per year.

carrer.name: Marinada, Carrer de la
carrer.descripcio: Named so after the wind coming from the sea and blowing towards the land, also called 'embat' or 'garbí', preferably from April to September.

carrer.name: Mariné, Passatge de
carrer.descripcio: Passageway named after Agustí Mariné i Iglésias (1800 - 1871). Owner of the lands since 1851, after a property transfer by Francesc Mariné i Calvet and others, who inherited them from Pau Mariné in 1801.

carrer.name: Mariner, Passatge de
carrer.descripcio: Passageway named after the owner family who opened and urbanized the public street. The family saga starts in the XVIII century with Pau Mariné, married to Maria Mariné, followed by his children: Francesc, married to Calvet; Pau, married to Cantí; Anton, married to Iglésias; and Mariàngela, married to Cuxart.

carrer.name: Mariners, Carrer dels
carrer.descripcio: Named so in honor of the seamen. In this street there existed a hostel for sailors in transit.

carrer.name: Marítim de la Barceloneta, Passeig
carrer.descripcio: Promenade flanking the seashore from the Barceloneta neighborhood up to Marina street.

carrer.name: Marítim de la Mar Bella, Passeig
carrer.descripcio: This new promenade was created when the city was remodeled for the Olympic Games.

carrer.name: Marítim de Nova Icària, Passeig
carrer.descripcio: Promenade within the Olympic Village, at Poblenou.

carrer.name: Marítim del Bogatell, Passeig
carrer.descripcio: Promenade running along the former seaside walk named the same.

carrer.name: Marítim del Port Olímpic, Passeig
carrer.descripcio: Promenade separating the Olympic Port from the Olympic Village.

carrer.name: Marlet, Carrer de
carrer.descripcio: Named after an old Catalan Christian family, probably living in this street since the XV century, when this formerly exclusively Jewish neighborhood started to be inhabited by Christians. In this street, the following Hebrew inscription can be found: "The Holy Rabbi Samuel Hasareri. His life will never end. Year 692".

carrer.name: Marmellà, Carrer de
carrer.descripcio: The true name of this old village and castle within the township of Montmell (Baix Penedès) is' Marmellar', as shown in a document dating as far back as 1023, where it is called "'terminum de Marmellare'". Etymologically, this name comes from 'Marmaya' or 'Marmay', meaning "bush or thicket", probably making reference to the original situation the place was in when this street was opened.

carrer.name: Marne, Carrer del
carrer.descripcio: River in France, famous for the battles there were fought during World War I (from August 24, to September 13, 1914, and from July 18, to August 6, 1918). Together with the streets named Lorena (Lorraine), Alsàcia (Alsace), and Verdun, this street group reminds of important facts and places related with World War I.

carrer.name: Marquès de Barberà, Carrer del
carrer.descripcio: The Marquis of Barberà ordered this street to be opened when he was Governor of Barcelona at the beginning of the XIX century. The Marquis title was bestowed upon Josep de Galceran de Pinós i de Rocabertí, Lord of Santa Maria de Barberà, in 1702.
carrer.anteriors: Marqués de Barbará; Barbará, before 1900; Marqués de Barbará, before 1865; Fontseca

carrer.name: Marquès de Campo Sagrado, Carrer del
carrer.descripcio: Francisco de Asís Bernaldo de Quirós Mariño (Oviedo, Asturias, 1763 - Madrid, 1836). Commander-in-Chief of Catalonia in 1814, 1824, and 1826-1827. Among other interesting urbanistic works, he brought the waters from Montcada to Barcelona. The "Pla de Palau" monument, designed by architect Daniel Batanear, was dedicated to him, "because he ordered the new urbanization of the Plan".

carrer.name: Marquès de Castellbell, Avinguda del
carrer.descripcio: Avenue named after the Marquis of Castellbell, owner of extensive real estate at this place. The first Marquis of Castellbell was Josep d'Amat de Planella i Despalau (Barcelona, 1670 - 1715), defender of the city in 1697.

carrer.name: Marquès de Castellbell, Passatge del
carrer.descripcio: Passageway named after the same person as the avenue.

carrer.name: Francesc Ferrer i Guàrdia, Avinguda de
Marquès de Foronda, Plaça del
carrer.descripcio: Square named after the same person as the homonymous street, because "as the royal commissar he contributed to the splendor of Barcelona's International Fair of 1929".

carrer.name: Marquès de Foronda, Carrer del
carrer.descripcio: Mariano de Foronda González-Bravo (El Escorial, 1887 - Vitoria, 1961). Director of the Barcelona Tramway Company from 1902 to 1931. He surrendered the property where this street is to the City Council. He sponsored the Cooperative of Journalists.

carrer.name: Marquès de la Mina, Carrer del
carrer.descripcio: Jaime Miguel de Guzmán-Dávalos Spínola (Sevillana, 1690 - Barcelona, 1767). Commander-in-Chief of Catalonia, temporarily from 1742 to 1746, and properly from 1755 to 1767. He charged Cermeño with the urbanization of Marbella, presently Barceloneta. On February 3, 1753, the parish church was inaugurated, where the Marquis is buried.

carrer.name: Marquès de la Quadra, Carrer del
carrer.descripcio: Joan Maria Oliveras de Carbonell i de l'Estanyol (Vic, Osona, 1797 - Barcelona, 1879), Marquis de la Quadra. Owner of real estate at Barceloneta. Promoter of the Caixa d'Estalvis savings bank, and philantropist. Successor of Lluís de Carbonell i Ferràs, Senior Councilor of Barcelona, and Captain of the Military Port. Lord de la Quadra de Sant Agustí de Lluçanès.

carrer.name: Marquès de Lamadrid, Carrer del
carrer.descripcio: Eusebio López y Díaz de Quijano (Comillas, Santander, Cantabria, 1873 - Seville, 1937). Financier.
carrer.anteriors: Luis Muntadas; Núm. 14 (S.A. El Tibidabo residential area), 23/03/1906

carrer.name: Marquès de l'Argentera, Avinguda del
carrer.descripcio: Avenue named after Eduard Maristany i Gibert (Barcelona 1855 - 1941). Railroad engineer of the MZA. He made build the France Railroad Station (Estación de Francia).
carrer.anteriors: Eduardo Maristany; Marqués de la Argentera; Pº de la Aduana; Frente Aduana

carrer.name: Marquès de Mulhacén, Carrer del
carrer.descripcio: Carlos Ibáñez e Ibáñez de Ibero (Barcelona, 1825 - near Nice, 1890). Mathematician, geodesist, and military. First president of the Geographic and Statistic Institute. He was bestowed with the title of Marquis of Mulhacén because of the vertex on top of this mountain, allowing to link the Spanish triangulation with the French triangulation in Algeria.

carrer.name: Marquès de Santa Ana, Carrer del
carrer.descripcio: Ferran Puig i Mauri, a politician and the owner of the estate (Barcelona 1871 ' Madrid 1921), knight of the Gran Cruz de Isabel la Católica, senator of the realm, deputy in the parliament, alderman and Deputy Mayor of the Madrid Town Council and General Inspector of primary education. He became the Marquis of Santa Ana through his marriage with the granddaughter and heiress of Manuel María de Santana.

carrer.name: Marquès de Santillana, Carrer del
carrer.descripcio: Iñigo López de Mendoza y de la Vega (Carrión de los Condes, 1398 - Guadalajara, 1458). Spanish poet.
carrer.anteriors: Ruiz Zorrilla; Umbert; Santa Lucía, before 1900

carrer.name: Marquès de Sentmenat, Carrer del
carrer.descripcio: Francesc III de Sentmenat-Torrelles i d'Agulló (Barcelona, 1697 - 1762). Poet. Founder of the Academy of Fine Letters of Barcelona. Baron de la Roca y Montbui, vassal of Toralla, Lord of Pera, Miralles, Vallparadís de Terrassa, Erinyà, Torrelles, and Pallejà. Married to Maria Teresa de Boixadors.
carrer.anteriors: Conde de España, 07/07/1942; Trav. Baixa de las Corts; Salvador Vallverdú; Trav. de las Corts; Trav. Vieja de las Corts; Trav. de la Trinidad; Trav. de Baix

carrer.name: Marquesa, Carrer de la
carrer.descripcio: Maria Jacoba Valdés Inclán (Gijón, Asturias, 1784 - Madrid ?), second wife of the Marquis of Campo Sagrado, Commander-in-Chief of Catalonia, married in 1803. His first wife was Maria Escolàstica, sister of the former.

carrer.name: Marquesa de Caldes de Montbui, Placeta de la
carrer.descripcio: Marquis title bestowed upon Anna Girona i Vidal on August 16, 1929, by King Alfonso XIII.
carrer.anteriors: Marquesa de Caldas de Montbuy; Sin nombre

carrer.name: Marquesa de Caldes de Montbui, Carrer de la
carrer.descripcio: Anna Girona i Vidal, daughter of Manuel Girona i Agrafel, Mayor and banker. Widow after Domènech Sanllehy i Alrich, Mayor of Barcelona.
carrer.anteriors: Marquesa de Caldas de Montbuy, 07/03/1939; Prats y Roqué; Marquesa de Caldas de Montbuy, 16/08/1929; Prats y Roqué

carrer.name: Marquesa de Vilallonga, Carrer de la
carrer.descripcio: Carme de Dalmases i d'Olivart, Ferrer, Corbera, Terré, Cordelles i Gomar (Barcelona, 1842 - 1920). Owner of the estate called Torre Vilana, crossed by the street separating Sarrià from Sant Gervasi. She was married to Trinitat de Fontcuberta i de Perramon.

carrer.name: Marquet, Carrer de
carrer.descripcio: A noble family of politicians and seafarers, who gave the city many important descendants since the XIII century, the most illustrious of all being Ramon Marquet (1235 - 1302). Vice-Admiral of Catalonia. Together with Roger de Llúria and Berenguer Mallol, he achieved the dominion over the Mediterranean. Galceran Marquet, who has a statue in the fountain on Duque de Medinaceli square, commanded the galleys of the city when he was Councilor of Barcelona in 1336, taking part in the royal expedition against Genoa.

carrer.name: Marquilles, Plaça de
carrer.descripcio: Square named after a distinguished Catalan family, whose most illustrious descendants were: Jaume Marquilles (Barcelona, 1368 - 1451), Jurist who enhanced the 'Usatges' (1448;. Pere Marquilles, Councilor in 1473; Bernat Marquilles, Councilor in 1475.

carrer.name: Marroc, Carrer del
carrer.descripcio: Named after Morocco, the country in North-West Africa.
carrer.anteriors: Marruecos; Ali-bey (3rd section), before 1900; Lletra G (Cerdà plan)

carrer.name: Marsala, Carrer de
carrer.descripcio: This street, named after the Sicilian town Marsala, is integrated in a group of streets named after Italian towns, within the neighborhood South-West of the Besòs river.

carrer.name: Marsans i Rof, Carrer de
carrer.descripcio: Josep Marsans i Rof (1844 - 1927). Financier. Founder of the Banca Marsans and of the Travel Agency Marsans.

carrer.name: Martí, Carrer de
carrer.descripcio: Ramon Martí i d'Eixalà (Cardona, Bages 1807 - Madrid 1857). Legal adviser and philosopher. Director of the 'Instituto Barcelonés'. Member of the Parliament representing the Liberal Party. Lecturer of Civil and Mercantile Law at the University of Barcelona. Son of Ramon Martí i Balius, owner of the lands where this street was opened.

carrer.name: Martí i Alsina, Carrer de
carrer.descripcio: Ramon Martí i Alsina (Barcelona, 1826 - 1894). Painter. Teacher of arithmetic and geometry at the Lonja School (1852), and of figure drawing (1854).

carrer.name: Martí i Franquès, Carrer de
carrer.descripcio: Antoni de Martí i Franquès (Altafulla, Tarragonès, 1750 - Tarragona, 1832). Scientist. Noble of Ardenya Manor, at Altafulla. Member of the Academy for Natural Sciences and Arts of Barcelona (1786). The Institute for Catalan Studies created a prize bearing his name.

carrer.name: Martí i Julià, Carrer de
carrer.descripcio: Domènec Martí i Julià (Barcelona, 1861 - 1917). Doctor of medicine and politician. Specialist in psychiatry, he was Director of the Phrenopatic Institute of Les Corts (1909-1915) in Barcelona, and President of the Society for Psychiatry and Neurology. The Institute for Catalan Studies created a prize bearing his name.

carrer.name: Martí Llauradó, Plaça de
carrer.descripcio: Square named after Martí Llauradó i Mariscot (Barcelona 1903 - 1957). Sculptor, winner of a First Medal at the National Exposition of Madrid (1934). He was an important representative of the young generation of the "postnoucentisme". Teacher at the 'Institut Escola' of the Generalitat.

carrer.name: Martí Molins, Carrer de
carrer.descripcio: Martí Molins i Botey (Gràcia, 1842 - Barcelona, 1905). He lived at Sagrera 128, and was a worker at the Sert factory. Being an enthusiastic promoter of popular culture, he founded a Museum of Archaeology, Natural History and Catalan Curiosities at Sagrera. He was married to Antònia Rafel, with whom he had a daughter.

carrer.name: Martí-Codolar, Avinguda de
carrer.descripcio: Avenue named after Lluís Martí-Codolar i Gelabert (Barcelona 1843 - 1915). Banker. Owner of Granja Vella (old farm), formerly belonging to the Monastery of San Jerónimo de la Vall d'Hebron, which already appears with this name in documents dating back to 1722. In 1886, the Regent Queen María Cristina gracefully allowed him to join both family names.
carrer.anteriors: C. Vila Olímpica 1, Vall d'Hebron (not official)

carrer.name: Martin Luther King, Carrer de
carrer.descripcio: (Atlanta, Georgia, 1929 - Memphis, Tennessee, 1968). Protestant minister influenced by Gandhi, leader of the pacific movement for liberation of the black population in the USA. After several failed attempts, he was finally killed in Memphis, Tennessee.

carrer.name: Martínez de la Rosa, Carrer de
carrer.descripcio: Francisco Martínez de la Rosa (Granada, 1787 - Madrid, 1862). Andalusian playwright,, poet, philosopher and politician. Member of the Parliament of Cadiz (1812).

carrer.name: Martinica, Passatge de la
carrer.descripcio: Martinique, an island in the Caribbean Sea. An overseas department of France with a statute of territorial collectivity from 1982. Its capital is Fort-de-France. This lane is located in the Area of Logistic Activities (Zona d'Activitats Logístiques, ZAL) in Barcelona harbor.

carrer.name: Martorell i Peña, Carrer de
carrer.descripcio: Francesc Martorell i Peña (Barcelona, 1822 - 1878). Archaeologist and naturalist. He founded the museum named after him, bequeathing the city with valuable collections and the necessary funds to maintain this institution.

carrer.name: Martorelles, Carrer de
carrer.descripcio: Martorelles de Baix and Martorelles de Dalt, boroughs of Vallès Oriental. This street is within the Torre Baró neighborhood, where most streets are named after places and villages of Catalonia.

carrer.name: Martras, Passatge de
carrer.descripcio: Passageway named after Joaquim de Martras i de Ballester (1820 - 1889). Notary Public and owner of the lands. In 1890, the property went to his sister Francesca.

carrer.name: Mas Casanovas, Carrer del
carrer.descripcio: Named after this farmhouse.

carrer.name: Mas de Roda, Passatge de
carrer.descripcio: Passageway formerly called "pasaje de Mas", after an owner's family name. To avoid duplicate names, "de Roda" was added in honor of Josep Mas i Torre, nicknamed "Mas de Roda" (Roda de Ter, XVII-XVIII century). Politician and guerrillero, Honest Citizen of Barcelona.

carrer.name: Mas Duran, Carrer del
carrer.descripcio: Rosa Duran i Pasarell, wife of Joan Campañà i Feliu, local landowner until 1898.

carrer.name: Mas Pujol, Carrer del
carrer.descripcio: Named after a local farmhouse, in the Font d'en Fargas neighborhood.

carrer.name: Mas Sauró, Camí del
carrer.descripcio: Road leading to the homonymous farmhouse at Vallvidrera.

carrer.name: Mas Yebra, Carrer de
carrer.descripcio: Juan Adolfo Mas Yebra (Alhabía, Almería, 1850 - Barcelona, 1943), lawyer, owner of lands at the Tibidabo, and stockholder of the company S.A. El Tibidabo, founded to urbanize the Tibidabo hill.

carrer.name: Masadas, Plaça de
carrer.descripcio: Square named after Pacià Masadas i Teixidó (Barcelona ? - 1873). Lawyer. Owner of nine and a half mujadas (61,137 m2) of land inherited from his father, Josep Francesc Masadas i Santmartí, silversmith. Widower after Elionor Roquer, in 1856 he married Amàlia Baradat i Vera from Kingstown, Jamaica.

carrer.name: Mascaró, Carrer de
carrer.descripcio: Francesc Mascaró i Gauran (1844 - ?), royal shipbroker and interpreter. He bought the land where this street was opened in 1897. Around 1910, this street name was proposed to honor Josep Mascaró i Capella (Barcelona, 1838 - 1905)., doctor of medicine.

carrer.name: Masnou, Carrer del
carrer.descripcio: Street named after a borough of the Maresme, together with the streets named Sants, Premià, and Salou.

carrer.name: Masoliver, Passatge de
carrer.descripcio: Passageway named after Salvi Masoliver i Freixas (1829 - 1886). Owner. In 1873, Joan Conti i Soler, together with the brothers Salvi and Bartomeu Masoliver i Freixas, bought a piece of land at the place called "Pont de les Vaques". After Salvi's dead, his nephews inherited the property, his brother Bartomeu (Olot, Garrotxa, 1824 - Barcelona, 1900) being the usufructuary.

carrer.name: Maspons, Carrer de
carrer.descripcio: Marià Maspons i Labrós (Granollers, Vallès Oriental, 1840 - Barcelona, 1885). Bachelor of Law. Politician, who presented King Alfonso XII, during the Memorial of Greuges, in 1885. Supporter of the Floral Games (1885).
carrer.anteriors: Escuder (joined to it); Santa Madrona (a section), before 1900

carrer.name: Maspons i Labrós, Carrer de
carrer.descripcio: Francesc Maspons i Labrós (Granollers, Vallès Oriental, 1840 - Bigues, Vallès Oriental, 1901). Legal adviser and folklorist writer. One of the founders of the Excursionist Center of Catalonia. Dean of the Notary Bar Association of Barcelona (1897).

carrer.name: Masquefa, Carrer de
carrer.descripcio: Borough of L'Anoia. Street within the Torre Baró neighborhood, where streets are preferably named after villages and places of Catalonia.

carrer.name: Masriera, Carrer dels
carrer.descripcio: Named after the brothers Josep Masriera i Manovens (Barcelona, 1841 - 1912) and Francesc Masriera i Manovens (Barcelona, 1842 - 1902), artist jewelers and painters. Originally, the street was dedicated to Francesc, when his brother Josep still lived.

carrer.name: Massaguer, Passatge de
carrer.descripcio: Passageway named after Caterina Massaguer i Janer, owner, until 1882, of the lands she had bought in 1875 from Tomàs Carreras i Massanet, master builder.

carrer.name: Massana, Jardins de
carrer.descripcio: Gardens within the Massana Group, located between the following streets: Felip II, Cardenal Tedeschini, Sant Pasqual Bailón, and l'Espiga.

carrer.name: Massanet, Carrer de
carrer.descripcio: After the September Revolution of 1868 succeeded, this street was originally dedicated to Josep Massanet, a revolutionary lawyer, who was one of the leaders of the revolt originating the "night of Saint James" in 1835, during which convents were set on fire, and monks killed. He was sentenced to death and shot with another nine accused, but he saved his life, escaping from the charriot transporting the corpses to the cemetery. Later, the City Council, ashamed of this dedication, changed the name to "Maçanet", on proposal of the historians Roca and Comas, who wished to honor the borough of Maçanet de Cabrenys.
carrer.anteriors: Maçanet; Palma de Santa Catalina, before 1865

carrer.name: Massens, Carrer de
carrer.descripcio: Miquel Masens (this is how he used to sign) i Soler (Malgrat de Mar, Maresme, 1827 - ?). Owner and urbanizer of the lands where this street was opened. He was married to Teresa Rabassa i Puig

carrer.name: Mata, Carrer de
carrer.descripcio: Originally, this street was dedicated to Magí Mata, owner of the lands at the beginning of the XIX century. He was married to Maria Mas. The 1980 Nomenclator dedicates this street to Pere Mata i Fontanet (Reus, Baix Camp, 1811 - 1877), doctor of medicine and liberal writer.

carrer.name: Matadepera, Carrer de
carrer.descripcio: Borough of Vallès Occidental. This street belongs to a group of streets within a small urban center North-East of Llars Mundet, where streets are named after Catalan villages.

carrer.name: Matagalls, Carrer del
carrer.descripcio: Montseny Peak on the North-West side of the massif.

carrer.name: Matamala, Carrer de
carrer.descripcio: Village within the borough of Les Llosses (Ripollès). Count Guifré 'el Pelós' (el Velloso) made the Santa Maria parish church over to the Monastery of Ripoll. Street within the Ramon Albó housing estate, where streets are named after Catalan places and villages, preferably of the Girona province.

carrer.name: Matanzas, Carrer de
carrer.descripcio: Cuban town. As for many other streets named after Cuban towns and places in this district, this name was chosen by neighbors returned from the former Spanish colonies.

carrer.name: Mataró, Carretera de
carrer.descripcio: Road leading to the borough of this name. In 1419, Mataró made a petition to be integrated into Barcelona by means of the 'carreratge' formula, by which the town is considered as a street of Barcelona.

carrer.name: Matemàtiques, Plaça de les
carrer.descripcio: The year 2000 was declared World Mathematics Year by the UNESCO. The name of the square is related to other street names nearby Carrer de la Física and Carrer de la Química.

carrer.name: Maternitat, Carrer de la
carrer.descripcio: The Maternity Hospital is in this street.

carrer.name: Mateu, Carrer de
carrer.descripcio: According to the available version, this street is named after Pere Benet Mateu, author of a famous pharmacopoeia published in 1521, the first known to ever have been printed in Europe. Some records in the Registry of Property make reference to a Sant Mateu street, but they don't seem to be significant enough to think of a change in the street name when Gràcia was annexed to Barcelona; or at least, there is no evidence of any such name-change in other documents of that time.

carrer.name: Mateu Ferran, Carrer de
carrer.descripcio: Mateu Ferran Arrú (Castelldans, Garrigues, 1842 - Barcelona, 1920). Teacher at Sant Andreu School, established in this street from 1871 to 1912. When he died, he left his possessions for charity and cultural purposes.

carrer.name: Matilde, Carrer de
carrer.descripcio: Matilde de Triola i Castellana, one of the owners of 107 rentals and of a piece of land belonging to the 10 mujadas (64,355 m2) dowry of Eulàlia Jordà, which was subject to an ordinary lawsuit in 1861.

carrer.name: Matilde Díez, Carrer de
carrer.descripcio: Matilde Díez Hermida (Madrid 1818 - 1883). Spanish theater actress, wife of Julián Romea. This street was named after her because she used to spend her summer holidays at Sant Gervasi.

carrer.name: Maurici Serrahima, Carrer de
carrer.descripcio: Maurici Serrahima i Palà (Manresa, Bages, 1834 - Barcelona, 1904). Legal adviser. During thirty years, he was consultant of the Barcelona City Council.

carrer.name: Maurici Vilomara, Carrer de
carrer.descripcio: Maurici Vilomara i Virgili (Barcelona, 1847 - 1930). Scenographer of the Liceu Opera House.
carrer.anteriors: Mauricio Vilumara, 1939; Doctor Robert, 1931; Mauricio Vilumara; Doctor Robert

carrer.name: Mecànica, Carrer de la
carrer.descripcio: Street so called for the mechanics, within the Zona Franca neighborhood, where streets are named after industrial topics.

carrer.name: Medes, Carrer de les
carrer.descripcio: Archipelago of Baix Empordà.

carrer.name: Mediona, Carrer de
carrer.descripcio: Borough of Alt Penedès. Street in the same neighborhood as the adjacent streets named Veciana, Cardedeu, and Manlleu.
carrer.anteriors: Ctra. de San Ginés a Nuestra Sra. del Coll; Núm. 7

carrer.name: Mediterrània, Jardins de la
carrer.descripcio: Gardens inside a block between the streets named Foneria, dels Alts Horns, de la Mare de Déu de Port, and the promenade around the Zona Franca, in the Sants-Montjuïc district.

carrer.name: Mediterrània, Carrer de la
carrer.descripcio: Named after the Mediterranean, the continental sea between Europe, Africa, and Asia. Very appropriate for a street in the Barceloneta neighborhood, practically on the waterfront.

carrer.name: Meer, Carrer de
carrer.descripcio: Ramón de Meer y Kindelán (Barcelona, XVIII-XIX century). Military of Flemish origin. Baron of Meer and first Count of Gra. Commander-in-Chief of Catalonia during 1837-1839 and 1843-1845. He defeated the Charlists in 1837, and dominated the progressist movement in Barcelona. He was designated Deputy and Senator by Queen Elizabeth (Isabel) II.

carrer.name: Meguidó, Plaça de
carrer.descripcio: Square named after Megiddo, town of ancient Palestine, of which there are archaeological remains dating back to the Neolithic Age. Two thousand years before Christ, it belonged to the area under Egyptian influence. Though in 1482 b.Ch. it was destroyed by Tuthmosis III, it was later rebuilt, fortified by Salomon (961-932 b.Ch.), and re-conquered by the Egyptians (930 b.Ch.). During the Roman era, it was known as 'Legio'. Due to its strategic situation, it had control over the most important business and military routes in the area.

carrer.name: Mejía Lequerica, Carrer de
carrer.descripcio: José Mejía Lequerica (Quito, Ecuador, 1776 - Cádiz, 1813). Politician. Ecuadorian patriot. For the first time in Spanish history, all nations then constituting the Spanish Empire had their representatives in an assembly at the Parliament of Cadiz of 1810. Mejía Lequerica, Deputy of the constituting Parliament of 1812, was the spokesman and leader of the fifty-six American Deputies. For his ease of speech, he was called "the American Mirabeau".

carrer.name: Melbourne, Carrer de
carrer.descripcio: Named after Melbourne, Australian city, capital of the Victoria State. The Olympic Games of 1956 were celebrated here.

carrer.name: Melcior de Palau, Carrer de
carrer.descripcio: Melcior de Palau i Català (Mataró, Maresme, 1843 - Madrid, 1910). Engineer, poet, publicist.
carrer.anteriors: Melchor de Palau; Padre Gallifa; Fivaller, before 1900

carrer.name: Melilla, Carrer de
carrer.descripcio: Named after Melilla, Spanish town in North Africa, on the Moroccan coast.
carrer.anteriors: Cartaginesa, 23/12/1913 (without effectiveness); San Carlos, 19/02/1900 (proposal without approval)

carrer.name: Melis, Torrent de
carrer.descripcio: Torrent descending from the Guinardó Park to the Holy Cross (Santa Creu) and Saint Paul Hospital. Now disappeared under the new urbanizations.

carrer.name: Mendel, Carrer de
carrer.descripcio: Johann Gregor Mendel (Heinzendorf, Austria, 1822 - Brno, Czech Republic, 1884). Botanic and biologist. Known as father Gregor after he was ordained Augustinian canon.

carrer.name: Méndez Núñez, Carrer de
carrer.descripcio: Casto Méndez Núñez (Vigo, 1824 - 1869). Seaman. Commander of the Spanish Fleet when Peru declared war on Spain (1866).

carrer.name: Méndez Vigo, Passatge de
carrer.descripcio: Passageway named after Santiago Méndez Vigo (Oviedo, 1790 - Madrid, 1860). Liberal General. Minister of War in 1836. Governor of Puerto Rico from 1841 to 1844.

carrer.name: Menéndez y Pelayo, Carrer de
carrer.descripcio: Marcelino Menéndez y Pelayo (Santander, 1856 - 1912). Culture historian. He was considered catalanophile, specially after his speech in Catalan language at the Floral Games of 1888.

carrer.name: Menéndez y Pelayo, Jardins de
carrer.descripcio: Gardens named after Marcelino Menéndez y Pelayo (Santander, 1856 - 1912). Culture historian and Spanish erudite. Member of the Royal Academy for Spanish and of the Academy of History. Conservative Member of the Parliament and Senator.

carrer.name: Menor de Sarrià, Carrer
carrer.descripcio: This short street runs into Sarrià square, the same as Calle Mayor.

carrer.name: Menorca, Carrer de
carrer.descripcio: Balearic Island, conquered in 1287 by Alfons II of Catalonia-Aragon, constituting the independent Kingdom of Majorca together with Majorca and Roussillon until 1343, when it became part of Catalonia-Aragon. Between 1713 and 1756 it was British, between 1756 and 1763 French, and then British again until 1782, when it became definitively Spanish.

carrer.name: Menta, Carrer de la
carrer.descripcio: Street in the Rectoret neighborhood, where the names of many streets were chosen by the neighbors, though this street is newer.

carrer.name: Mercadal, Plaça del
carrer.descripcio: Square named so because of the Sant Andreu Market, a project of architect Josep Mas i Vila. The first stone was set on March 16, 1851.

carrer.name: Mercader, Passatge de
carrer.descripcio: Passageway named after the noble Mercader family, whose members had successively been the owners of the surrounding lands: Magí de Mercader i de Moragas, Ramon de Mercader i de Novell i de Sadurní, and finally his son Joaquim de Mercader (Mataró, Maresme, 1824 - Cornellà de Llobregat, Baix Llobregat, 1904), historian and archaeologist,. Count of Bell-lloc, who sold them to Pau Bori i Riu, under the condition that a 50 spans wide passageway named "de Mercader" were opened there.

carrer.name: Mercaders, Carrer de
carrer.descripcio: In the XIII century, the most important merchants of Barcelona had established their residence in this street. Queen Elionor of Cyprus, Infante of Aragon, grand-daughter of King Jaume II died in one of these houses on December 26, 1417.

carrer.name: Mercantil, Passatge
carrer.descripcio: Passageway named so because of the highly active old central market of 'El Born'.

carrer.name: Mercat, Passatge del
carrer.descripcio: Passageway leading to the Concepció market.

carrer.name: Mercat, Carrer del
carrer.descripcio: Goes to the Sant Andreu market.

carrer.name: Mercat, Baixada del
carrer.descripcio: Path descending to the Horta market.

carrer.name: Mercat, Plaça del
carrer.descripcio: Square named so for the Clot market.

carrer.name: Mercè, Plaça de la
carrer.descripcio: Square in front of the Mercè church, restored by Josep Mas, opened in 1775. In 1888, the present dome was completed, with an image of the Virgin of Mercy (Mercè) on top, which was repaired in 1959 by Miquel Oslé. In 1981, the housing blocks between Ample street and Louis Braille, Mercè, and d'en Boltres street were demolished, thus allowing to enlarge the formerly small square to its present dimensions.

carrer.name: Mercè, Carrer de la
carrer.descripcio: Named so after the church and convent of "la Mercè". The Mercè Order was instituted in 1218 by Saint Pedro Nolasc, Saint Raimundo de Peñafort, and King Jaume I. According to tradition, the Virgin appeared here in the night of August 2, 1218.

carrer.name: Mercè Capsir, Plaça de
carrer.descripcio: Square named after Mercè Capsir i Vidal (Barcelona, 1899 - Suzzara, Lombardy, Italy, 1969), one of the best sopranos there ever had been in this country. She began studying in Barcelona at the Conservatoire of the Liceu Opera House, where she made her debut in 1914 with Verdi's 'Rigoletto.' In 1934, she sang Richard Strauss' 'Rosenkavalier 'in Catalan. She sang with great success at the most famous opera houses of Europe, America, and North Africa, being specially appreciated at the Scala of Milan. She retired from scene in 1946 to teach singing at the Superior Municipal Conservatoire of Music of Barcelona. She composed a few pieces and wrote a transcription for voices of variations of a Mozart theme ('Transcripció per a cant d'unes variacions'). This square was dedicated to her on proposal of the Women Group of the Municipal Council for Social Welfare.

carrer.name: Mercè Plantada, Jardins de
carrer.descripcio: Gardens named after Mercè Plantada i Vicente (Barcelona, 1892 - Vilafranca del Penedès, Alt Penedès, 1976). Soprano. She studied with Antoni Colomer at the Center for Musical Culture, making her debut with the Association for Chamber Music of Barcelona at the "Palau de la Música". She specialized in 'lied', participating in remarkable vocal symphonic concerts. She participated in the première of Falla's 'El amor brujo' in Barcelona, conducted by the composer. In her numerous concerts she was accompanied on the piano by Igor Stravinsky, Richard Strauss, Nin, Manen, Frederic Mompou, Turina, and Pau Casals, among others. She sang in several cities abroad, and was conducted by the most eminent conductors of her time. She taught singing at the Conservatoire of the Liceu Opera House. In 1967, she was awarded with the Medal for Artistic Merit by the City Council of Barcelona. Dedication proposed by Antoni Colomer Plantada.

carrer.name: Mercè Rodoreda, Carrer de
carrer.descripcio: Mercè Rodoreda i Gurgui (Barcelona, 1908 - Girona, 1983). Writer. Teacher of Gaya Ciencia in 1949. Víctor Català Prize in 1957. Sant Jordi Prize in 1966. Serra d'Or Critic Prize in 1981. City of Barcelona Prize and Catalan Letters Award of Honor in 1980.

carrer.name: Mercedes, Rambla de
carrer.descripcio: Boulevard named after the same person as the homonymous street.

carrer.name: Mercedes, Passatge de
carrer.descripcio: Passageway named after the same person as the street.

carrer.name: Mercedes, Carrer de
carrer.descripcio: In memory of Mercedes Güell i López, daughter of Eusebi Güell, local landowner.

carrer.name: Mérida, Carrer de
carrer.descripcio: Dedicated to Merida (Yucatan State, Mexico), the cradle of Maya culture, designated Capital of American Culture in 2000. Founded by Francisco de Montejo in 1542. It recovered independence from Spain when Mexico became an independent country in 1821.

carrer.name: Meridiana, Avinguda
carrer.descripcio: Avenue named so because it runs in the North-South direction, approximately along the 2º 10' 20'' Meridian East of Greenwich.
carrer.districtes: EIXAMPLE (02) NOU BARRIS (08) SANT ANDREU (09) SANT MARTÍ (10)

carrer.name: Meridional, Carrer
carrer.descripcio: Street at a place called "Clot de la Mel", until 1843 the property of Francesc de Milans i de Duran, later the owner was Francesc Coll i Carbonell. Street names were frequently chosen by the urbanizers out of sheer caprice. So, here Meridional was probably chosen because of its similitude with Meridiana avenue, into which it runs.

carrer.name: Messina, Carrer de
carrer.descripcio: Dedicated to this Sicilian town, the same as other streets of this neigbhorhood South-West of the Besòs river, named after Italian towns and villages.

carrer.name: Mestral, Moll de
carrer.descripcio: Peer named so because of the Mistral, a cold wind blowing in the North-West direction in the Rhone Delta when European highs meet Mediterranean lows in the narrow river valley.

carrer.name: Mestrança, Carrer de la
carrer.descripcio: In old times, this street was inhabited by carpenters, shipwrights, caulkers, and blacksmiths, all crafts related with shipbuilding and ship repair.

carrer.name: Mestre Alfonso, Carrer del
carrer.descripcio: Painter from Cordoba, who lived in the XV century.

carrer.name: Mestre Aloi, Carrer del
carrer.descripcio: Aloi de Montbrai (XIV century). Sculptor.

carrer.name: Mestre Balcells, Jardins del
carrer.descripcio: Gardens named after Joan Balcells i Garcia (Barcelona 1882 - 1972). Composer and conductor. Music theory teacher at the Municipal Music School of Barcelona. Conductor of the Orfeó Gracienc (choral society, 1903-1936). Composer of pieces for the opera, choirs, couplets, harmonizations of popular songs, and a large number of sardanas.

carrer.name: Mestre Dalmau, Carrer del
carrer.descripcio: Joan Baptista Dalmau i Mayol (Barcelona, 1814 - 1880). Musician. Conductor of the Liceu Orchestra. Choirmaster of Santa Maria del Mar.

carrer.name: Mestre Nicolau, Carrer del
carrer.descripcio: Antoni Nicolau i Parera (Barcelona, 1858 - 1933). Composer and orchestra conductor. Creator of the modern Catalan choral school.

carrer.name: Mestre Serradesanferm, Carrer del
carrer.descripcio: Josep Serradesanferm i Soler (Castellterçol, Vallès Oriental, 1895 - Barcelona, 1949). Pedagogue who lived and taught in the Horta neighborhood.

carrer.name: Mestres Casals i Martorell, Carrer dels
carrer.descripcio: Ignasi Casals and Josep Martorell, pedagogues teaching at the Municipal Schools located at Sant Pere Més Baix, 33, in the beginning of the XX century. Authors of a book on arithmetic ('Aritmética)' currently in use during their lifetime. Street name approved on proposal of former pupils. Before, this street was called "de la Claveguera" (sewer street), for being the first street where a sewer was installed in this neighborhood.
carrer.anteriors: Maestros Casals y Martorell; Claveguera, before 1865

carrer.name: Metal·lúrgia, Carrer de la
carrer.descripcio: Street within the Zona Franca neighborhood dedicated to metallurgy, in an area where streets are named after materials, tools or procedures used in industry.

carrer.name: Metges, Carrer dels
carrer.descripcio: The community of the parish of Sant Pere de les Puelles built an infirmary under the patronage of Saint Cosmo and Saint Demian in this street, as well as a chapel dedicated to those saints, the patrons of physicians (doctors of medicine), in honor of whom splendid annual feasts are celebrated.

carrer.name: Mèxic, Carrer de
carrer.descripcio: Mexico, the southernmost North American country.

carrer.name: Mig, Ronda del
carrer.descripcio: Fast ring highway running along the following streets: Free Zone promenade, Ildefons Cerdà square, Badal street, Rambla del Brasil, Gran Vía de Carles III, Prat de la Riba square, Ronda del General Mitre, Lesseps square, Travessera de Dalt, Ronda del Guinardó, Ramon Albó street, Arnau d'Oms street, Piferrer street, Rio de Janeiro avenue.
carrer.districtes: SANTS-MONTJUÏC (03) LES CORTS (04) SARRIÀ-SANT GERVASI (05) GRÀCIA (06) HORTA-GUINARDÓ (07) NOU BARRIS (08) SANT ANDREU (09)

carrer.name: Mig de Can Balasc, Camí
carrer.descripcio: Path named after the manor house.

carrer.name: Mig de Can Clos, Plaça del
carrer.descripcio: Square so named because of a street of this name there had been in this area.

carrer.name: Mig del Turó, Passatge del
carrer.descripcio: Passageway in a hilly environment, together with the passageways named Alt del Turó and Baix del Turó, in the South-East sector of the Guinardó Park.

carrer.name: Migdia, Passeig del
carrer.descripcio: Boulevard named so because it is near the Migdia Park.
carrer.anteriors: C. del Doctor Font i Quer; Ctra. dels Mundials (not official); C. del Foc

carrer.name: Migdia, Mirador del
carrer.descripcio: View point at a place known as 'Sot del Migdia', between Foc street and Passeig del Migdia.

carrer.name: Miguel de Unamuno, Plaça de
carrer.descripcio: Square named after Miguel de Unamuno (Bilbao, 1864 - Salamanca, 1936). Bask writer and lecturer. He studied philosophy and humanities in Madrid. Lecturer of Greek in 1891, and Rector of the University of Salamanca. Non-conformist and conqueror of people, institutions, and regimes. He was sent to exile at Fuerteventura in 1924 by Primo de Rivera's dictatorial regime. Among others, he published the following works: 'Paz en la guerra' (Peace in war) (1897), 'La tía Tula' (Aunt Tula) (1921), 'El Cristo de Velázquez' (1920).

carrer.name: Miguel Hernández, Carrer de
carrer.descripcio: Miguel Hernández Gilabert (Orihuela, Baix Segura, 1910 - Alicante, 1942). Poet.

carrer.name: Mil Vuit-cents, Passatge del
carrer.descripcio: Passageway so named in memory of the XVIII century.

carrer.name: Milà i Fontanals, Carrer de
carrer.descripcio: Manuel Milà i Fontanals (Vilafranca del Penedès, Alt Penedès, 1818 - 1884). Philologist and writer. Historian of Catalan medieval literature. Lecturer at the University of Barcelona. President of the Academy of Fine Letters of Barcelona (1861-1878). Member of the Academy of Fine Arts, correspondent member of the Academy of History and of the Spanish Academy.

carrer.name: Milanesat, Carrer del
carrer.descripcio: Named so in memory of the Milanesate, old State in Northern Italy, with the capital in Milan. Between 1540 and 1706, it was under Spanish dominion during the Succession War, when Prince Eugene of Savoy conquered the Milanesate for Austria, under which dominion it fell by virtue of the Treaty of Utrecht (1713). In 1815 it was integrated into the Kingdom of Italy.
carrer.anteriors: Milanesado; Adolfo Blanch; Milanesado; Adolfo Blanch (Town Hall of Sarrià); Castells, before 1888

carrer.name: Milans, Carrer de
carrer.descripcio: Street opened towards 1850 in the lands belonging to the Milans family, from Arenys de Mar (Maresme). In 1739, King Philip V conferred to Bonaventura Milans, Honest Citizen of Barcelona, the 'Privilegiorum Audientia', which is a nobility title. Another member of this family was General Milans del Bosch, born at Sant Vicenç de Llavaneres, a distinguished fighter during the Independence War (Sabadell action, 1810), and a liberal defending progressist ideas. He died in 1829.

carrer.name: Milton, Carrer de
carrer.descripcio: John Milton (Londres 1608 - 1674). English poet.

carrer.name: Mímica, Carrer de la
carrer.descripcio: Mimics. This street is, together with a group of streets, in the Montbau neighborhood dedicated to scenic arts.

carrer.name: Mimoses, Carrer de les
carrer.descripcio: This street was so named 1927, replacing the old name of "Bon Repòs". Approved by the Town Council of Sarrià in 1922 "for the lovely mimosas, luxuriantly growing in a garden in this street".
carrer.anteriors: Mimosas; Buen Reposo (Town Hall of Sarrià); Buenavista, before 1888

carrer.name: Mina, Carrer de
carrer.descripcio: Francisco Espoz Ilundain (Idocín, Navarra, 1781 - Barcelona, 1836), called Espoz i Mina, liberal leader of the Independence War. Commander-in-Chief of Catalonia in 1823, and in 1835-1836, when this street was opened. He was Viceroy of Navarra.

carrer.name: Mina de la Ciutat, Carrer de la
carrer.descripcio: So named after the old mine from which the water was brought to Barcelona.

carrer.name: Mina Grott, Plaça de la
carrer.descripcio: Square named so because of the "Mina Grott", an attraction that worked from 1908 to 1916, consisting in the illumination of the wood and the cavern of the water reservoir (mine) there was in the Sarrià swamp, that could be visited riding an electric cart.

carrer.name: Mineria, Carrer de la
carrer.descripcio: Mining street, within the group of streets of the Zona Franca neighborhood dedicated to industrial issues.

carrer.name: Minerva, Carrer de
carrer.descripcio: Named after the goddess Minerva, the Roman equivalent of the Greek Athena, daughter of Zeus.

carrer.name: Minici Natal, Passeig de
carrer.descripcio: Boulevard named after Luci Minici Natal Quadroni Ver (Barcino, idus of February, 97 - 151/156 ?). Roman Senator. General under Trajanus and Adrianus. Proconsul of Africa under Antoninus Pius. Winner of a car race at the Olympic Games of 227 (129 of our era).

carrer.name: Ministral, Passatge de
carrer.descripcio: Passageway named after Joaquim Ministral i Lloveras (la Bisbal d'Empordá, Baix Empordà, 1852 - Barcelona, 1924). Owner of the lands since 1922.

carrer.name: Miño, Carrer del
carrer.descripcio: Named after the Miño, river in Galicia.
carrer.anteriors: Tibidabo (map of the Sant Gervasi enlargement), before 1865

carrer.name: Miquel Àngel, Carrer de
carrer.descripcio: Michelangelo Buonarroti di Neri (Caprese, Tuscany, Italy, 1475 - Rome, 1564). Italian sculptor, painter, architect, and poet.
carrer.anteriors: Amposta (joined to it); Miguel Ángel; Clavé (old name of Amposta street); San Juan, before 1900

carrer.name: Miquel Bleach, Carrer de
carrer.descripcio: Miquel Bleach i Burunat (Sants, 1849 - Barcelona, 1900). Pedagogue, teacher at Sants and Hostafrancs.

carrer.name: Miquel Boera, Carrer de
carrer.descripcio: Properly Miquel de Boera (Sant Feliu de Guíxols, Baix Empordà, XV-XVI century). Military. General in the service of the Viceroy of Naples, he participated in the Battle of Ravenna against the French (1512), and in the expeditions to Tripoli and Oran during the reign of Charles I.

carrer.name: Miquel Casablancas i Joanico, Plaça de
carrer.descripcio: Square named after Miquel Casablancas i Joanico (Sabadell, Vallès Occidental, 1913 - Barcelona, 1981). Vice-President of the Neighbor Association of Sant Andreu.

carrer.name: Miquel dels Sants Oliver, Carrer de
carrer.descripcio: Miquel dels Sants Oliver i Tolrà (Campanet, Majorca, 1864 - Barcelona, 1920). Journalist, historian, poet, narrator. Ideologue. President of the Ateneo Barcelonés (Athenaeum of Barcelona) (1917). Member of the Institute for Catalan Studies. Director of the journals 'Diario de Barcelona' , and later of 'La Vanguardia'.
carrer.anteriors: Miguel de los Santos Oliver; Santos Oliver

carrer.name: Miquel Ferrà, Carrer de
carrer.descripcio: Miquel Ramon Ferrà i Juan (Ciudad de Mallorca (now Palma de Mallorca), 1885 - 1947). Poet and essayist. Corresponding member of the Institute for Catalan Studies.

carrer.name: Miquel i Badia, Carrer de
carrer.descripcio: Francesc Miquel i Badia (Barcelona, 1840 - 1899). Writer and journalist. Art critic. Professor at the School of Fine Arts. Lawyer. Member of the Academies of Fine Letters, Sciences and Arts, and Jurisprudence of Barcelona.

carrer.name: Miquel Tarradell, Pla de
carrer.descripcio: Miquel Tarradell i Mateu, archaeologist. He was born in the Barceloneta quarter of Barcelona on 24th November 1920. He became a specialist in the archaeology of the Catalan-speaking Countries (Països Catalans) and published numerous works on excavations and digs. He obtained a Chair at the Universitat de València, which he transferred to the Universitat de Barcelona in 1970. He was awarded the Premi d'Honor de les Lletres Catalanes, and the Creu de Sant Jordi (St George's Cross). He died in Barcelona on the 2nd January 1995. He lived at Passeig de Colom, 24.

carrer.name: Mir, Carrer de
carrer.descripcio: In the X century, Count Mir ordered the Comtal irrigation channel to be built, highly beneficial for Sant Andreu.

carrer.name: Mir Geribert, Carrer de
carrer.descripcio: Mir Geribert (? - Tortosa, Baix Ebre, 1060). Prince of Olèrdola. Grandson of Count Borrell II. Head of the revolt of a part of the Catalan nobility against Ramon Berenguer I, who defeated the insurrect, thus consolidating his authority. Mir had to surrender to the latter his inherited viscountal castle at the Port.

carrer.name: Miracle, Carrer del
carrer.descripcio: Formerly named "del Carme" (Carmel street). According to the neighbors, by miracle, Our Lady of the Carmel preserved them all from the cholera epidemics there had raged in 1854 and 1865. Before this place was edified, there used to be many textile mills. It was said that once, digging a hole, an image of Our Lady of the Carmel was found, so the textile mill was later called "of the Miracle".

carrer.name: Mirador, Plaça del
carrer.descripcio: Square named so because of the viewpoint on the Montjuïc hill.

carrer.name: Mirallers, Carrer de
carrer.descripcio: There are documents proving that this street was named so already in 1492, because of the many mirror makers established there. Pi i Margall, famous politician and historian, was born in this street.

carrer.name: Miramar, Jardins de
carrer.descripcio: Gardens near the place called Miramar (seaview), on Montjuïc hill.

carrer.name: Miramar, Passeig de
carrer.descripcio: Boulevard going from "Nou de la Rambla" street up the Montjuïc.

carrer.name: Miramar, Carretera de
carrer.descripcio: Street leading to the viewpoint on Montjuïc hill.

carrer.name: Miramar, Avinguda de
carrer.descripcio: This is an important avenue running up the Montjuïc hill.

carrer.name: Mireia, Carrer de
carrer.descripcio: Familiarly, Maria in Provence. Poem by Frederic Mistral.

carrer.name: Miret i Sans, Carrer de
carrer.descripcio: Joaquim Miret i Sans (Barcelona, 1858 - 1919). Historian and legal adviser. Member of the Academy for Fine Letters, founding member of the Institute for Catalan Studies (1907).
carrer.anteriors: Miret y Sans, 04/11/1931; Barón de Eroles (a section), 18/05/1927; Miret y Sans, marzo de 1922; Amistad, 1852

carrer.name: Misser Ferrer, Carrer del
carrer.descripcio: 'Misser' is an old Catalan title given to learned people. On August 30, 1647, the sub-official receiver of the Consell de Cent (Council of the Hundred), took possession of the houses of micer Joseph Amigant and micer Joseph Ferrer in the name of the City.

carrer.name: Mistral, Avinguda de
carrer.descripcio: Avenue named after Frederic Mistral (Maiano, Provence, France, 1830 - 1914). French writer and poet. Nobel Prize of Literature in 1904.
carrer.anteriors: Milans del Bosch; Pº de la Cruz Cubierta, before 1900; Ctra. de Madrid; Ctra. Real; Ctra. Antigua de la Cruz Cubierta; Cº del Portal San Antonio Cruz Cubierta; Cº Antiguo de San Antonio

carrer.name: Mitja Lluna, Plaça de la
carrer.descripcio: Square (crescent) at the confluence of Gran Vista and Turó de la Rovira streets.

carrer.name: Moçambic, Passatge de
carrer.descripcio: A maritime passage in the Indian Ocean separating the Isle of Madagascar from the South-eastern coast of Africa, in front of the state of Mozambique, in southern Africa. The capital city is Maputo. This lane is located in the Area of Logistic Activities (Zona d'Activitats Logístiques, ZAL) in Barcelona harbor, where the thoroughfares are dedicated to the world's seas and oceans.

carrer.name: Modernitat, Plaça de la
carrer.descripcio: Square located between Santa Coloma boulevard and Via Favència. Name proposed by the Sant Andreu district. The square was inaugurated in a public act in July, 1993, by Mayor Pasqual Maragall, giving it this popular name.

carrer.name: Modest Urgell, Carrer de
carrer.descripcio: Modest Urgell i Inglada (Barcelona, 1839 - 1919). Painter, landscapist, and playwright.

carrer.name: Modolell, Carrer de
carrer.descripcio: Magí Modolell i Negrevernís (Sant Just Desvern, Baix Llobregat, 1789 - Barcelona, 1851). Landowner. Vicenç Modolell i Vallmajó (? - 1864). Joaquim Modolell-Vallmajor del Puig (1838 - 1890). Owners of the lands where this street was opened. The so-called Modolell hill is part of the range of low hills parallel to the Collserola Range. This name was also given to a piece of land located between Sarrià, the Galvany fields, Can Regàs, and Bonanova boulevard.

carrer.name: Mogent, Carrer del
carrer.descripcio: Named so after the small river, tributary of the Congost, constituting the Besòs river.

carrer.name: Moià, Carrer de
carrer.descripcio: Borough of Bages, and street in Barcelona. In memory of the fact that in 1384, Moià made a petition to be integrated into Barcelona by means of the 'carreratge' formula, by which the town is considered as a street of Barcelona, in order to give its inhabitants the same rights and privileges as the citizens of the Capital city.

carrer.name: Moianès, Carrer del
carrer.descripcio: Sub-region of the central Catalan high plateau.
carrer.anteriors: Moyanés; Gallo; Moyanés; Muntadas; Gallo (very old)

carrer.name: Moixeró, Carrer del
carrer.descripcio: Massif in the Eastern Pyrenees Orientales, on the border between Berguedà and Baixa Cerdanya.

carrer.name: Moles, Carrer de les
carrer.descripcio: Named so because, in old times, millstone makers were established here.

carrer.name: Molí, Carrer del
carrer.descripcio: There was a mill at this place when this street was opened.

carrer.name: Molí de Vallvidrera, Camí del
carrer.descripcio: Old name of this path, though appearing as non-official in the city map.

carrer.name: Molina, Plaça de
carrer.descripcio: Square named after Francesc Daniel Molina i Casamajó (Vic, Osona, 1812 - Barcelona, 1867). Architect, designer of the Session Chamber for the City Council on Sant Josep square, hidden under the iron skeleton of the Boqueria Market; further he designed the Reial square, the Medinaceli square, and the fountain dedicated to Catalan Genius.

carrer.name: Moliné, Carrer de
carrer.descripcio: Antoni Moliné i Casas (1797 - 1870). Owner. He bought lands of an extension of 13/4 mujadas, plus one mundina (11,568.155 m2), surrendered in his favor by Domènec Vidal i Balaguer, and in 1867 he applied for authorization to urbanize the street. His heir was his son, Antoni Moliné i Casas, married to Eulàlia Vilarós i Hortal.

carrer.name: Molist, Carrer de
carrer.descripcio: Pere Molist i Morral (1818 - 1890). Smelter. Owner of the place. In 1874, he proposed to urbanize the Montaña Pelada (Bare Mountain). He was married to Àngela Umbert.

carrer.name: Mollerussa, Carrer de
carrer.descripcio: Borough of Pla d'Urgell.

carrer.name: Mònec, Carrer d'en
carrer.descripcio: Old Catalan family name. This street was already named so in the XVI century, only the spelling changed as time went by, from 'Mònac' to 'Mònach', and finally to 'Mònech'.

carrer.name: Moneders, Carrer dels
carrer.descripcio: According to Agustí Duran i Sanpere, at the end of the XV century, there were several officers of the Seca (Mint of Barcelona) living at Sarrià, possibly in the hamlet built around the Monastery of Pedralbes.

carrer.name: Monegal, Carrer de
carrer.descripcio: Esteve Monegal i Soler (Sant Llorenç d'Hortons, Alt Penedès, 1822 - Barcelona, 1879). Landowner, who bought the lands of Putget in 1862. His successor was his son, Josep Monegal i Nogués (Barcelona, 1854 - 1931), Mayor of Barcelona in 1902-1903.

carrer.name: Monestir, Baixada del
carrer.descripcio: Path descending from the Monastery of Pedralbes.

carrer.name: Monestir, Carrer del
carrer.descripcio: So named because of the Monastery of Pedralbes.

carrer.name: Monestir, Plaça del
carrer.descripcio: Square named so because of the Monastery of Pedralbes, originally 'Petras Albas' (White Stones), as shown in documents dating back to 986.

carrer.name: Monges, Carrer de les
carrer.descripcio: So named because of the Jesús Maria school at Sant Andreu, created in 1850 by two nuns of the Avinyonet family (sister Sebastiana and sister Bernabé), who had studied at a Jesus Maria School in Lyon, France. Sister Sebastiana won her position as a Public Teacher at Sant Andreu in public competition.
carrer.anteriors: Monjas, 1939; Elisa García, 1938; Monjas, before 1900; Mediodía

carrer.name: Monistrol, Carrer de
carrer.descripcio: Monistrol de Montserrat, borough of Bages.

carrer.name: Monjo, Carrer de
carrer.descripcio: Joan Monjo i Pons (Mahón, Menorca, 1818 - Barcelona, 1884). Shipbuilder. Author of the first treaty on naval architecture ever published in Spain (1856).

carrer.name: Monlau, Carrer de
carrer.descripcio: Pere Felip Monlau i Roca (Barcelona, 1808 - Madrid, 1871). Scientist, doctor of medicine, publicist.

carrer.name: Mons, Plaça de
carrer.descripcio: Square named after the Belgian city of Mons (Bergen in Flemish language). Capital of Hainaut. The property where this street was opened belonged to the Falcó dowry, property of Josep de la Barre i Taberner, Baron of la Barre of Flanders and Pechmann until 1855.

carrer.name: Mont d'Orsà, Carrer de
carrer.descripcio: Incorrect spelling of 'mont d'Óssa', originally 'monte de Ursa' (Bear Peak), appearing in documents of 986 as Puig d'Óssa.
carrer.anteriors: Monte de Orsà; Puigdosa; Munt d'Orsa (Town Hall of Sarrià); San Pedro Mártir

carrer.name: Montagut, Carrer de
carrer.descripcio: Montagut de Fluvià, borough of Garrotxa. Street within the Ramon Albó housing estate, where most streets are named after villages and places of the Girona province.

carrer.name: Montalegre, Carrer de
carrer.descripcio: Named so because of the Monastery of Nuestra Señora de Montalegre, founded in 1362 by Augustinian canons, later the House of Charity of Barcelona.

carrer.name: Montanyans, Avinguda dels
carrer.descripcio: According to the 1980 Nomenclator, this avenue is named after an old family of Catalan origin, its most illustrious descendants being: Jaume Montanyans i Berard (Manacor, Eastern Majorca 1483 - Càller, Sardinia, Italy, 1556). Legal adviser. Regent of Sardinia; Nicolau Montanyans i Berard (Majorca, 1495 - 1565). Inquisitor of Majorca. Writer. Popularly called "avinguda dels Muntayencs", for being under the Montjuïc mountain.

carrer.name: Montanyans, Carrer de
carrer.descripcio: Named so in honor of the old, distinguished Montanyans family.

carrer.name: Montbau, Pla de
carrer.descripcio: This name was invented in the neighborhood, using the words 'mont' (mount) and 'bau' (German word meaning 'construction') to build a non-existing word somehow reminding of the German architectural movement called Bauhaus.
carrer.anteriors: Explanada de Montbau; Explanada de Monbau

carrer.name: Montbau, Jardins de
carrer.descripcio: Gardens named the same as the neighborhood they are in, between Joan Sales and Poesia streets.

carrer.name: Montcada, Carrer de
carrer.descripcio: Together with de Cardona family, the Montcadas were the most important barons of the Catalan Lands, both for the importance of their facts and of their members. Since their beginning in the service of the Counts of Barcelona, the Montcadas reached the highest positions in the middle of the XI century, when they became the first force in the country. They reached their peak when the Monastery of Santes Creus was founded, occupying most key positions in politics, the most eminent being Guillem Ramon de Montcada, who was designated Regent while King Alphons II was minor. Street opened by the Montcadas.

carrer.name: Montcada, Placeta de
carrer.descripcio: Small square dedicated to the same family as the street.

carrer.name: Montclar, Carrer de
carrer.descripcio: Montclar de Berguedà. Borough of Berguedà. Street extended up to the road to Vallvidrera.

carrer.name: Montclar, Escales de
carrer.descripcio: Named after the municipality of Montclar de Berguedà. These steps lead to the Carrer de Montclar and the Carrer del Bosc by way of a shortcut which helps to overcome the drop in the terrain between the two streets.

carrer.name: Montecassino, Carrer de
carrer.descripcio: Monastery near Cassino, Italy, founded around 529 by Benito de (Benedict of) Nursia.

carrer.name: Monterols, Parc de
carrer.descripcio: Park on the Monterols hill. Name shown in documents dating back to 987.
carrer.anteriors: Jardins del Turó de Monterols, 12/06/1980; Turó de Can Gil, 06/09/1917

carrer.name: Monterols, Carrer de
carrer.descripcio: Place-name dating back to 987. Name of a hill and of a rural neighborhood.
carrer.anteriors: Montesa; Monterols (Town Hall of Sarrià); Monturiol, before 1902; Delicias; Piquet, before 1888 (Town Hall of Sarrià)

carrer.name: Monterrey, Plaça de
carrer.descripcio: Square named after Monterrey, the town in Mexico.

carrer.name: Montevideo, Carrer de
carrer.descripcio: Named after Montevideo, capital city of Uruguay. Name chosen by Francesc Buxó i Oliana, when he urbanized his lands in 1842. Also, Joaquim and Lluís Vendrell of Pedralbes, landowners at Sarrià, had lived in Montevideo.

carrer.name: Montfar, Carrer de
carrer.descripcio: Dídac Montfar Sorts i Cellers (Barcelona, 1600 - Terrassa, Vallès Occidental, 1652). Historian. Honest Citizen. Archivist of the Crown of Aragon. Commander of the Catalan artillery in the Battle of Montjuïc (January 26, 1641).

carrer.name: Montjuïc, Carretera de
carrer.descripcio: Mountain hovering over the port of Barcelona, ending in the Morrot rock. Some think that the name comes from 'mons Jovis' (mountain dedicated to the Roman god Jupiter), others that it has to do with the Jewish cemetery caved in the rocks.

carrer.name: Montjuïc, Passeig de
carrer.descripcio: Boulevard on the North-East hillside of the Montjuïc, between Colom boulevard and Nou de la Rambla street.
carrer.anteriors: Montjuich; Ascendente de Montjuich; Ferrer y Guardia; Ascendente de Montjuich; Sabat (a section); Ctra. de Montjuich (a section)

carrer.name: Montjuïc, Parc de
carrer.descripcio: Park on the Montjuïc.

carrer.name: Montjuïc del Bisbe, Carrer de
carrer.descripcio: So named after a certain family called Montjuïc (after the mountain).

carrer.name: Montjuïc del Carme, Carrer de
carrer.descripcio: After a family called Montjuïc.

carrer.name: Montmajor, Carrer de
carrer.descripcio: Mountain of a Catalan pre-littoral mountain range, at the Vallès side. This is the highest peak of Sierra Llisa (789 m), known as "pic del Vent" (windy peak) or "de Sant Sebastià" (of Saint Sebastian). Street within a street group of Turó de la Peira named after mountains.

carrer.name: Montmany, Carrer de
carrer.descripcio: Antoni Montmany i Albornà (Barcelona 1797 - 1861). Lawyer. Landowner. In 1836, he became proprietor of a terrain out of the "Casa Xica de la Virreina" dowry, surrendered in his favor by Josep Carreras.

carrer.name: Montnegre, Carrer del
carrer.descripcio: Littoral mountain range between Tordera and the Sacreu port.
carrer.anteriors: Lletra J (map of Les Corts), 1925; Jordá, 30/01/1869

carrer.name: Montornès, Carrer de
carrer.descripcio: Montornès del Vallès. Borough of Vallès Oriental.

carrer.name: Montornès, Passatge de
carrer.descripcio: Passageway named after the same village as the homonymous street, within a group of streets at the Coll neighborhood named after villages of the Barcelona province.

carrer.name: Montpeller, Carrer de
carrer.descripcio: Montpellier, Languedoc, Occitaine, France, birthplace of King Jaume I, founded around 1000, it became the center of the Domain of Montpellier. Important trade center in the XIII century, strongly linked with the Crown of Catalonia-Aragon from 1204 to 1350. It became definitively part of the Crown of France in 1382. There is an important University, founded in 1289.

carrer.name: Mont-ral, Carrer de
carrer.descripcio: Borough of Alt Camp.

carrer.name: Mont-roig, Carrer de
carrer.descripcio: Mont-roig del Camp. Borough of Baix Camp.

carrer.name: Mont-ros, Carrer de
carrer.descripcio: Joaquima Montrós i Esteve, owner of the lands formerly belonging to the Magarola. Her heirs were her nephew Joaquim Montrós i Martí, first adjutant of artillery, and her niece Carolina Montrós i Martí. When Joaquim died at the age of 38 without leaving descendants, his part went to his sister Carolina, married to Josep Suárez i Garay.

carrer.name: Montsant, Carrer del
carrer.descripcio: Mountain massif at the South-West end of the pre-littoral Catalan mountain range. Street at Turó de la Peira, where many streets are named after mountains.

carrer.name: Montsec, Carrer del
carrer.descripcio: External, pre-pyrenaic mountain range, historical physiographic limit between the Pyrenees and the Ebro hollow.

carrer.name: Montseny, Carrer del
carrer.descripcio: Massif of the pre-littoral mountain range.

carrer.name: Montserrat, Carrer de
carrer.descripcio: Mountain massif of Bages. Monastery of Our Lady of Montserrat, religious and spiritual stronghold of the Catalans.

carrer.name: Montserrat, Jardins de
carrer.descripcio: Gardens dedicated to Our Lady of Montserrat, the same as the street.

carrer.name: Montserrat, Placeta de
carrer.descripcio: Small square so named after a country house called Montserrat, there had been at this place. It is placed in the lands belonging to the Casa Móra estate, the owner of which was Eugeni Duran Borrell.

carrer.name: Montserrat de Casanovas, Carrer de
carrer.descripcio: Maria Montserrat de Casanovas i Fernàndez de Landa (Barcelona, 1860 - 1948). Owner. In 1901, she inherited the Casa Pujol estate from Baltasar de Casanovas i de Bacardí. She was married to Pere Fargas i Sagristà.

carrer.name: Montserrat Garriga, Plaça de
carrer.descripcio: Square named after María de la Caridad del Cobre Montserrat Garriga Cabrero (Cienfuegos, Cuba, 1865 - Barcelona, 1956). She dedicated to botanic. Being a collaborator of doctor Pius Font i Quer, she duly botanized and prepared plants to be shown later in the Botanic Section of the Museum of Natural Sciences of Barcelona. She taught Botanic at the Culture Institute and Popular Library for Women. In 1954, she left her plant collection to the Botanic Institute of Barcelona.

carrer.name: Montserrat Roca i Baltà, Plaça de
carrer.descripcio: Square named after Montserrat Roca i Baltà (1892 - 1983). Schoolteacher. Director of the first municipal school of Sant Andreu, the Ignasi Iglésias school, and later of the "Escuela Municipal de Formación Doméstica Teresa de Jesús-Turó Blau" (municipal school for housekeeping), where she did an extraordinary pedagogical job. Awarded with the Gold Medal of the Sant Andreu district.

carrer.name: Montserrat Roig, Jardins de
carrer.descripcio: Gardens dedicated to Montserrat Roig i Fransitorra (Barcelona, 1946 - 1991). Writer. Bachelor of Philosophy and Arts, Lecturer of Catalan language at the University of Bristol. Winner of the Víctor Català Prize for 'Molta roba i poc sabó' (1971), where she describes the generation of university students after the Spanish Civil War, also subject of her novel 'Ramona, adéu '(1972). In 1976, she won the Sant Jordi Prize with 'El temps de les cireres', and in 1977, the Serra d'Or Critic Prize for her report 'Els catalans als camps nazis'. Her last works were the story book 'El cant de la joventut' (1989), the essay 'Digues que m'estimes encara que sigui mentida' (1991), 'L'autèntica història de Catalunya' (1991, together with Cesc), and in 1990 was the première of her 'Reivindicació de la senyora Clito Mestres'. These gardens were dedicated to her on proposal of the Women Group of the Municipal Council for Social Welfare. The official name-giving act took place on April 11, 1997.

carrer.name: Montsió, Carrer de
carrer.descripcio: So named after the Cloister of Santa Maria de Montsió, founded by Dominican nuns in 1351 near the Palacio Menor (Minor Palace). In 1423, they moved to their final residence between this street and Santa Anna square, formerly Santa Eulàlia del Camp.
carrer.anteriors: Montesión; Volta del Eura (between Amargós and Magdalenes); Montesión, before 1900

carrer.name: Monturiol, Carrer de
carrer.descripcio: Narcis Monturiol i Estarriol (Figueres, Alt Empordà, 1819 - Sant Martí de Provençals, Barcelona, 1885). Republican politician, Bachelor of Law, editor and journalist. Inventor of the submarine called 'Ictíneo'.

carrer.name: Monyarc, Passatge de
carrer.descripcio: Passageway named after Joan Monyarch i Busquets (Ciutadilla, Urgell, 1886 - Barcelona, 1933), married to Joaquima Pujol i Serracant. Owners of the lands where this passageway was opened.

carrer.name: Móra d'Ebre, Carrer de
carrer.descripcio: Borough of Ribera d'Ebre. Street opened in the lands belonging to the Casa Móra estate, at the Coll neighborhood.
carrer.anteriors: Latina (without effect); Mora de Ebro; San Mariano (a section), before 1900; San Ramón (a section)

carrer.name: Móra la Nova, Carrer de
carrer.descripcio: Borough of Ribera d'Ebre. Street opened in the lands belonging to the Casa Móra estate.

carrer.name: Morabos, Carrer dels
carrer.descripcio: So named after a deed of arms decisive for the surrender of Abd-el-Krim, Moorish leader in the Morocco War of 1921.

carrer.name: Moragas, Carrer de
carrer.descripcio: Maria de la Consolació de Moragas i de Quintana (Barcelona, 1828 - 1904), Marquise of Moragas. Owner of the lands where this street was opened. Her first husband was Joaquim Castanyer i Malet, and her second husband Rufino Vidal.

carrer.name: Moragas, Jardins de
carrer.descripcio: Fidel de Moragas i Tavern (Valls, Alt Camp 1835 - Sant Gervasi, Barcelona 1879)

carrer.name: Morales, Carrer de
carrer.descripcio: Manuel Morales i Cámara (Infantes, Ciudad Real, 1825 - Barcelona, 1903). Patent leather manufacturer, established at Les Corts in the XIX century, related with a factory there had been near this street. He was Mayor of Les Corts between 1868 and 1871. It is said that after his stay in Madrid, he returned to Les Corts bare of any fortune. On February 22, 1872, he was designated Secretary of the Corporation by the local Town Council.

carrer.name: Moratín, Carrer de
carrer.descripcio: Leandro Fernández de Moratín (Madrid 1760 - París 1828). Spanish playwright and poet. He had to emigrate to France for being "francophile". After returning from exile in 1820, he stayed for a long period in Barcelona. When the yellow fever broke out in Barcelona in 1821, he returned to France.

carrer.name: Morató, Carrer de
carrer.descripcio: Pere Morató i Mateu, real estate administrator, promoter of the first buildings erected at this place in 1870. He was married to Mercè Capdevila i Bohigas, owner of the property where this street was opened.

carrer.name: Morell, Carrer del
carrer.descripcio: Named after Morell, borough of Tarragonès.

carrer.name: Morenes, Passatge de
carrer.descripcio: Passageway named after Antoni Morenes i de Tord (Tarragona, 1836 - Barcelona, 1906). Military. He reached the degree of a Colonel. Owner of the lands through which this passageway goes.

carrer.name: Morera, Carrer de la
carrer.descripcio: This name, singular or plural (moreres), dates back beyond 1492, as already in old times there was an estate on this street, the gardens of which were full of mulberry trees. According to Joan Amades, this street name has nothing to do with the mulberry tree (known for being the best food for silkworms), but makes reference to a game so called because of the kind of balls used.

carrer.name: Moscou, Carrer de
carrer.descripcio: So named after Moscow, Capital of Russia, in memory of the Olympic Games of 1980.

carrer.name: Mosques, Carrer de les
carrer.descripcio: This is a very old street, already so named in 1441, probably by the neighbors, because of the many flies there used to be, due to the proximity of the market, with all its garbage.

carrer.name: Mossèn Amadeu Oller, Carrer de
carrer.descripcio: Reverend Amadeu Oller i Berenguer (Barcelona, 1901 - 1957). Rector of the Sant Medir parish.
carrer.anteriors: Reverendo Amadeo Oller; Panas; Vilasar (3rd section); Vistalegre, before 1900

carrer.name: Mossèn Batlle, Carrer de
carrer.descripcio: Antoni Batlle i Mestre (Sitges, Garraf, 1888 - Barcelona, 1955). Priest, pedagogue, and leader of the Young Excursionist Movement. Doctor of Philosophy and Theology. Disciple of Cardinal Gomà, and a good friend of Cardinal Vidal i Barraquer. He was an open minded man of action, interested in active pedagogy. Professor at the Escola del Mar (Sea School) and at the Blanquerna School, Secretary of the Pedagogical Laboratory Seminary of the Community of Catalonia (1918-1921).

carrer.name: Mossèn Cinto Verdaguer, Jardins de
carrer.descripcio: Gardens named after Reverend Jacint Verdaguer i Santaló (Folgueroles, Osona, 1845 - Vallvidrera, Barcelona, 1902). Priest, poet, and writer. Curate of Vinyoles d'Orís (Osona). He was chaplain of the Marquis of Comillas -living in the Moja Palace- and of the Transatlantic Company.

carrer.name: Mossèn Clapés, Plaça de
carrer.descripcio: Square named after Reverend Joan Clapés i Corbera (Sant Andreu de Palomar, 1872 - Barcelona, 1939). Author of a history in nine volumes of Sant Andreu de Palomar.

carrer.name: Mossèn Costa i Llobera, Jardins de
