carrer.anteriors: General Mola (Diagonal-trav. de Gràcia); García Hernández (Diagonal-Gràcia); República (Diagonal-Gràcia); Sant Joan, before 1900 (rda. Sant Pere-Diagonal); T. de los Garrofers (Diagonal-Gràcia); T. del Malecon (Diagonal-trav. de Gràcia); Núm. 35 (Cerdà pl

carrer.name: Sant Joan Bosco, Passeig de
carrer.descripcio: Giovanni Bosco Occhiena (Castellnuovo de Asti, Piedmont 1815 - Turin 1888). Founder of the Salesian Order. He visited Barcelona for the construction of the Temple del Sagrat Cor on Tibidabo, and lived in this street, in which there is the Salesian college.
carrer.anteriors: San Juan Bosco; Dom Bosco; Ctra. de Barcelona a Sarrià, before 1900

carrer.name: Sant Joan de Déu, Jardins de
carrer.descripcio: The Hospital of St John of God (Hospital de Sant Joan de Déu) was founded in 1867 by the brothers of the order of the Hospitalers, who established themselves in Les Corts on 16th April 1881 in the former estates of Prat d'en Rull and Can Barceló. This institution undertook the care of poor children suffering from tuberculosis, rickets, and certain disabilities.

carrer.name: Sant Joan de la Salle, Carrer de
carrer.descripcio: Jean-Baptiste de la Salle (Reims 1651 - Rouen 1719). Founder of the order of the brothers of Christian doctrine. The name was given to the street, known as El Raval, in 1942, in order to commemorate the fiftieth anniversary of the establishment of the college of the order in the Bonanova parish area, the first stone of which was laid in 1889.
carrer.anteriors: San Juan de la Salle, 29/09/1942; Raval o Arrabal

carrer.name: Sant Joan de les Abadesses, Plaça de
carrer.descripcio: Municipality of the Ripollès region of Catalonia in the valley of the Ter river, province of Girona. It is one of the chief attractions of the so-called Romanesque route of the Pyrenees.

carrer.name: Sant Joan de Malta, Passatge de
carrer.descripcio: Under the same dedication as is the street into which it opens.

carrer.name: Sant Joan de Malta, Carrer de
carrer.descripcio: Order of chivalry founded in the eleventh century and also known as the order of St John of Jerusalem. The name of the street comes from the former house of the knights of this order known as the Torre de Sant Joan, which was built in the fifteenth century and which is today the Casas Municipal School.
carrer.anteriors: Malta (without effectiveness); San Juan de Malta, before 1900; González Morago

carrer.name: Sant Joaquim, Plaça de
carrer.descripcio: Father of the Virgin Mary. Named after Joaquim Ferret i Mandri.
carrer.font: {{JPI: Els carrers de Barcelona: Sant Gervasi}.

carrer.name: Sant Joaquim, Carrer de
carrer.descripcio: Father of the Virgin Mary. Named after Joaquim Mas, who undertook the urban development of the Plaça del Sol and its surroundings.

carrer.name: Sant Jordi, Plaça de
carrer.descripcio: Under the same dedication as is the street.

carrer.name: Sant Jordi, Carrer de
carrer.descripcio: In Lydda (Diospoli), Palestine, his sepulchre was venerated. Christian martyr. The legend according to which he slew a terrible dragon to liberate a maiden or princess seems to have become established at the end of the first millennium. In the Catalan speaking domain, the cult of St. George exists as of the tenth and eleventh centuries. Abbot Oliba erected an altar to him in the monastery of Ripoll.

carrer.name: Sant Josep, Carrer de
carrer.descripcio: Spouse of Mary, the Mother of Jesus of Nazareth.

carrer.name: Sant Josep, Plaça de
carrer.descripcio: Under the same dedication as is the street.

carrer.name: Sant Josep Cottolengo, Carrer de
carrer.descripcio: Giuseppe Benedetto Cottolengo (Bra, Piedmont 1786 - Valdocco 1842). Italian founder of the institutions which bear his surname. Cottolengo has become a synonym for "house open to all misfortunes".

carrer.name: Sant Josep de Calassanç, Plaça de
carrer.descripcio: (Peralta de la Sal, Litera 1558 - Rome 1648). Ecclesiastic and founder of the Piarist Fathers (Pauline Congregation of Our Lady of the Pious School).

carrer.name: Sant Josep de la Muntanya, Passatge de
carrer.descripcio: It adopted the name of the Avinguda del Santuari de Sant Josep de la Muntanya, which it crosses.

carrer.name: Sant Josep Oriol, Carrer de
carrer.descripcio: Josep Oriol i Bogunyà (Barcelona 1650 - 1702). Incumbent at the church of Santa Maria del Pi in Barcelona. He was beatified in 1806, shortly after the opening of the street, which originally (1797) had the name of St Bernard. He was canonized by Pius X in 1909.

carrer.name: Sant Josep Oriol, Plaça de
carrer.descripcio: Until the beginning of the nineteenth century the square was occupied by the cemetery of the parish of Santa Maria del Pi.
carrer.anteriors: San José Oriol; Beato Oriol, before 1900

carrer.name: Sant Just, Plaça de
carrer.descripcio: Justus and Pastor, brothers and schoolboy martyrs. They died in 304 AD. The square is in front of the church of St Just, and the first information about that building comes from the ninth century. The present church was begun on in 1345: it is the last of the great Gothic churches of Barcelona. The square was constructed in the nineteenth century through the urban development of the lot which the former parish cemetery occupied. The fountain in the square dates from 1367.

carrer.name: Sant Liguori, Carrer de
carrer.descripcio: Alfonso Maria de Liguori Cavalieri (Marianella, Naples 1696 - Nocera degli Pagani 1787). Italian theologian and missionary. The name of the street comes from the house of refuge for homeless girls established there in 1891 under the patronage of the saint.

carrer.name: Sant Llàtzer, Camí de
carrer.descripcio: A personage in the Gospels. The brother of Martha and Mary, and a friend of Jesus. According to the Gospels, he was raised from the dead by the latter.

carrer.name: Sant Llàtzer, Carrer de
carrer.descripcio: The name comes from a charitable institution set up in the twelfth century under the advocation of St Lazarus (known as Hospital dels Mesells) which in 1401 was joined to the Hospital d'en Colom. The Romanesque chapel, which still exists in the Plaça del Pedró, belonged to this establishment: its façade, partially mutilated, is to be found crammed in between the buildings there.

carrer.name: Sant Lluc, Plaça de
carrer.descripcio: Apostle, disciple of Paul, credited with being the author of one of the Gospels and of the Acts of the Apostles. Patron of artists. The name was given to this zone because it was the neighborhood of El Maduixer, an area of dwellings established, fundamentally, as the residence of the artists of the Promotion of Decorative Arts organization (FAD).

carrer.name: Sant Lluís, Carrer de
carrer.descripcio: Luigi Gonzaga Tena (Castiglione delle Stiviere, Mantua 1568 - Rome 1591). Jesuit missionary. The street was opened in 1894 (the stretch between Torrijos and Torrent d'en Vidalet.

carrer.name: Sant Magí, Carrer de
carrer.descripcio: (Tarragona, third to fourth centuries AD). Hermit. Legendary martyr. Principal patron saint of Tarragona. The street was named after the judge of the Audiència de Barcelona, Magí Ferrer.

carrer.name: Sant Manuel, Carrer de
carrer.descripcio: A Persian martyr who died in 362 AD.

carrer.name: Sant Marc, Carrer de
carrer.descripcio: One of the four Evangelists. First century AD. A Jew by birth, he received the Hebrew name John, to which he later added the Greco-roman name Mark. Martyr. The street was named after Marc Olivés, the promoter of the urban development of that sector of Gràcia.

carrer.name: Sant Marià, Baixada de
carrer.descripcio: Eighth century AD. Of noble origin, he retired to a hermitage close to Bourges, Creuse, in France. Martyr.

carrer.name: Sant Marià, Carrer de
carrer.descripcio: Under the same dedication as is the other street.

carrer.name: Sant Màrius, Carrer de
carrer.descripcio: Third century AD. Persian. Martyr in Rome together with all his family. The name was given to the street at the request of the painter and stage designer Josep Planella i Coromines (1804-1880), who had a house in this place, in memory of his son Màrius, who died very young.

carrer.name: Sant Martí, Carrer de
carrer.descripcio: Fourth - fifth centuries AD. Pope. Hispanic martyr. The street was opened in 1807.

carrer.name: Sant Martí, Parc de
carrer.descripcio: Named after the old village of Sant Martí de Provençals.

carrer.name: Sant Martí, Ronda de
carrer.descripcio: It adopted the name of the old municipality of Sant Martí de Provençals.

carrer.name: Sant Martí de Porres, Carrer de
carrer.descripcio: (Lima, Peru 1579 - 1639). A lay tertiary in the Dominican monastery of Our Lady of the Rosary.
carrer.anteriors: San Martín de Porres, 11/07/1962; Beato Martín de Porres, 30/12/1959

carrer.name: Sant Mateu, Carrer de
carrer.descripcio: One of the twelve apostles and the first evangelist.

carrer.name: Sant Medir, Carrer de
carrer.descripcio: Third century AD. Peasant from the area around Barcelona. Hermit. It is said that he lived in the place where later on a hermitage with his name was built in the municipality of Sant Cugat del Vallès.

carrer.name: Sant Miquel, Placeta de
carrer.descripcio: It adopted the name of the Sant Miquel rivulet, which crosses it.

carrer.name: Sant Miquel, Plaça de
carrer.descripcio: The square occupies the space opened by the demolition of the parish church of Sant Miquel Arcàngel and a block of houses. The original church collapsed in 1147. Reconstructed, it existed until 1868. Its frontispiece was transferred to the church of la Mercè, where it is now the side portal.

carrer.name: Sant Miquel, Carrer de
carrer.descripcio: Name proceeding from the parish church in the Barceloneta neighborhood dedicated to the saint.

carrer.name: Sant Miquel, Platja de
carrer.descripcio: Named after the parish of Sant Miquel del Port.

carrer.name: Sant Miquel, Baixada de
carrer.descripcio: Archangel. The name Michael in Hebrew means "Who like God?". Above the portal at the entrance to the sloping street through the Carrer d'Avinyó, which had a cannon vault, there was an image of the saint, which gave the name to the street.

carrer.name: Sant Narcís, Carrer de
carrer.descripcio: (Girona, third century AD). Bishop of Girona. He was murdered in the persecution undertaken by Diocletian in 307 AD.

carrer.name: Sant Nicolau, Carrer de
carrer.descripcio: Bishop of Myra. Fourth century AD.
carrer.anteriors: San Nicolás; Agustina Zaragoza; San Nicolás, before 1900

carrer.name: Sant Oleguer, Carrer de
carrer.descripcio: (Barcelona 1060 - 1137). Bishop of Barcelona and Archbishop of Tarragona.

carrer.name: Sant Onofre, Carrer de
carrer.descripcio: Fourth century AD. Hermit and monk of the monastery of Thebes in Egypt.

carrer.name: Sant Pacià, Carrer de
carrer.descripcio: Bishop of Barcelona between 360 and 390 AD. He possessed great classical learning, and was one of the most important authors of the western Church in his time.

carrer.name: Sant Pasqual Bailón, Carrer de
carrer.descripcio: Pascual Baylón Jubera (Torrehermosa, Zaragoza 1540 - Villarreal, La Plana Baixa 1592). Minorite friar of the monastery of Montfort (València). Patron saint of Eucharistic Congresses.

carrer.name: Sant Pau, Ronda de
carrer.descripcio: Constructed on the city-wall of 1382, it was given this name because it was close to the exit from the Carrer de Sant Pau and in memory of a former portal of the same name that had been there and had been open on occasion.

carrer.name: Sant Pau, Passatge de
carrer.descripcio: Under the same dedication as is the street.

carrer.name: Sant Pau, Carrer de
carrer.descripcio: Saul of Tarsus (Tarsus of Cilicia 1/5 - Rome 67 AD). Apostle. Evangelising writer, missionary and preacher. Martyr. The street follows the outline of the pathway that united the gate of La Boqueria with the monastery of Sant Pau del Camp.
carrer.anteriors: San Pablo, before 1865; Lletra V (Cerdà plan, a section)

carrer.name: Sant Pau del Camp, Jardins de
carrer.descripcio: Given this name because of the church of Sant Pau del Camp. The space corresponds to the extension of the gardens of Els Horts de Sant Pau.

carrer.name: Sant Paulí de Nola, Carrer de
carrer.descripcio: (Bordeaux 353 - Nola 431) Saint Paulinus of Nola. Bishop. Consecrated by Bishop Lampi in the original Barcelona basilica, around which the Romanesque cathedral was established, and on both of which, in part, the Gothic one was built.
carrer.anteriors: San Paulino de Nola, 07/07/1942; San Pedro de Abanto (extension)

carrer.name: Sant Pere, Ronda de
carrer.descripcio: Name given in memory of the part of the city wall, and the bulwark of St Peter, situated at the end of the old pathway, and to recall the events in the defense of Barcelona in 1697, 1713, and 1714.

carrer.name: Sant Pere, Passatge de
carrer.descripcio: Under the same dedication as is the street.

carrer.name: Sant Pere, Carrer de
carrer.descripcio: Apostle. Simon, surnamed Peter (Petrus, stone) as a symbol of the foundations of the Church. Martyr (64 AD). Son of Jonah, and brother of St Andrew. His tomb was discovered in 1950 under the foundations of the Basilica of St Peter in Rome.

carrer.name: Sant Pere, Plaça de
carrer.descripcio: The name comes from the convent of Benedictine nuns of Sant Pere de les Puelles, founded in the middle of the tenth century (945 AD) by Count Sunyer and his wife Riquilda. Before this date there already existed a chapel in the same place dedicated to St Saturninus of Toulouse, which it is supposed the Franks had caused to be built when they came to Barcelona in 801 with Louis the Pious.

carrer.name: Sant Pere Claver, Carrer de
carrer.descripcio: Pere Claver i Sobocano (Verdú, Urgell 1580 - Cartagena de Nueva Granada 1654). Jesuit missionary. Canonized by Pope Leo XIII in 1888.

carrer.name: Sant Pere de Romaní, Carrer de
carrer.descripcio: A tenth-century church in the municipality of Molins de Rei in the Baix Llobregat region of Catalonia.

carrer.name: Sant Pere Màrtir, Carrer de
carrer.descripcio: A peak in the Collserola range.

carrer.name: Sant Pere Més Alt, Carrer de
carrer.descripcio: A road which according to tradition was followed by Louis the Pious on the conquest of Barcelona, at that time under the rule of the Saracens. The King went on a thanksgiving pilgrimage to the church of Santa Creu, which stood in the place subsequently occupied by the convent of Sant Pere de les Puelles.

carrer.name: Sant Pere Més Baix, Carrer de
carrer.descripcio: It also leads to Sant Pere de les Puelles.

carrer.name: Sant Pere Mitjà, Carrer de
carrer.descripcio: The titles of the three streets bearing the name of St Peter come from a sentence handed down by the Generalitat (fourteenth century?) as a result of the lawsuit between the residents of the three streets, who were disputing the right to use the name of St Peter.

carrer.name: Sant Quintí, Carrer de
carrer.descripcio: In memory of the battle of the same name which took place in 1557 between the army of Henry II of France and the imperial army of Philip of Spain.
carrer.anteriors: San Quintín; Martí Vilanova; Cataluña, before 1900; Núm. 47 (Cerdà plan)

carrer.name: Sant Quirze Safaja, Carrer de
carrer.descripcio: Municipality of the Vallès Oriental region of Catalonia.

carrer.name: Sant Rafael, Carrer de
carrer.descripcio: Archangel. The street was opened under this name in 1798, together with the streets called today de Sadurní and de Sant Josep Oriol.

carrer.name: Sant Ramon, Carrer de
carrer.descripcio: (? - Huesca 1126). Bishop of Roda de Ribagorça. The street was opened in 1791.

carrer.name: Sant Ramon de Penyafort, Carrer de
carrer.descripcio: (Castle of Penyafort, Santa Margarida i els Monjos, Alt Penedès, 1185 - Barcelona 1275). Canon and Archdean of the Cathedral of Barcelona. Canon lawyer. Confessor of kings and popes. Founder of the Mercedarian Order, with St Peter Nolasc.
carrer.anteriors: Rda. de San Raimundo de Peñafort

carrer.name: Sant Ramon Nonat, Avinguda de
carrer.descripcio: (Portell, Segarra about 1300 - Cardona, Bages 1346). Member of the Mercedarian Order. Cardinal. The surname "Nonat" ("not born") refers to the unnatural birth of the saint, as his mother was dead. The avenue takes the name of the parish.

carrer.name: Sant Ramon Nonat, Passatge de
carrer.descripcio: Under the same dedication as is the street.

carrer.name: Sant Roc, Carrer de
carrer.descripcio: (Montpellier 1295 - 1327). Pilgrim. Intercessor against plagues and epidemics. When he was ill, a dog took a loaf of bread to him every day at his refuge in the forest.

carrer.name: Sant Salvador, Carrer de
carrer.descripcio: Properly speaking, this is the Carrer de 'Sansalvador 'or 'Santsalvador', an important proprietor in Gràcia in the nineteenth century.

carrer.name: Sant Sebastià, Carrer de
carrer.descripcio: (Narbonne ? - Rome 288). Roman soldier. Martyr on the Appian Way.

carrer.name: Sant Sever, Carrer de
carrer.descripcio: Apocryphal saint. Bishop of Barcelona in the Visigothic period.

carrer.name: Sant Simplici, Carrer de
carrer.descripcio: Third Abbot of Montecassino. In 1688 it became known that this saint could have been born in Barcelona, for which reason the street was named after him.

carrer.name: Sant Tarsici, Pas de
carrer.descripcio: Roman boy martyr of the third century, under whose patronage children's eucharistic events take place.

carrer.name: Sant Tomàs, Carrer de
carrer.descripcio: One of the twelve apostles (first century AD).

carrer.name: Sant Vicenç, Carrer de
carrer.descripcio: (Zaragoza, second century AD). Martyr. The name was given by the proprietor Vicenç Genovart, who subdivided his estate in 1846, opened the street, and sold lots for them to be built on.

carrer.name: Sant Vicenç de Sarrià, Plaça de
carrer.descripcio: The name of Sant Vicenç de Sarrià is very ancient. The original church built in Sarrià under the advocation of St Vincent dates from before the eleventh century. Nonetheless, the two dictatorships changed the name to "San Vicente Español".
carrer.anteriors: San Vicente Español; San Vicente de Sarriá; San Vicente Español; San Vicente de Sarriá (Town Hall of Sarrià); San Vicente; Unión, before 1888

carrer.name: Santa Àgata, Carrer de
carrer.descripcio: Martyr in Catania in 251. The street is named in this way because of Àgata Badia i Puigrodon (Lleida, Segrià 1770 - Barcelona 1836), the widow of Antoni Trilla and proprietress of the estate Torre del Simó, in Gràcia, which she asked for permission to subdivide and build on in 1825. Authorization was given in 1826. The street was opened in 1830.

carrer.name: Santa Albina, Carrer de
carrer.descripcio: Virgin, saint, and martyr in Caesarea in Palestine. Decius ordered her to be decapitated, and her body, abandoned in a ship, reached Scouri, near Formia in Campania. The street received its name from the proprietress of the estates, Maria Rosa Albià, who owned an important part of the land on which the street was opened.

carrer.name: Santa Amàlia, Carrer de
carrer.descripcio: Saint and martyr of Tavio. She died with all her family. The street has this name because of Amàlia de Casanovas i de Bacardí, proprietress of the estate.

carrer.name: Santa Amèlia, Passatge de
carrer.descripcio: Martyr from Girona

carrer.name: Santa Amèlia, Carrer de
carrer.descripcio: Martyr from Girona.

carrer.name: Santa Anna, Carrer de
carrer.descripcio: The mother of Mary, according to the apocryphal proto-evangelium of James (second century AD). The street took the name of the collegiate church of St Anne that was built in 1141. The church was begun on in the twelfth century. In the following century the nave was extended and the entrance portal was constructed. In the fifteenth century the dome was built, though it is still incomplete.

carrer.name: Santa Carolina, Carrer de
carrer.descripcio: Caroline is the feminine form of St Charles.

carrer.name: Santa Caterina, Carrer de
carrer.descripcio: Virgin and martyr of Alexandria. She died in 307. Patroness of philosophers. The street had this name before 1884, and for this reason it could not have been dedicated to Saint Caterina Tomàs i Gallard, as is stated in a recent document, as the latter saint was canonized by Pius XI in 1930. Given the great number of saints by this name, it was decided to dedicate the street to this Catherine, one of the most popular of them apart from St Catherine of Siena, who already had a street dedicated to her.

carrer.name: Santa Caterina, Plaça de
carrer.descripcio: Opened on 15th August 1848. The street was formed in the land made available by the demolition of a Dominican monastery bearing the same name and dating from the mid-thirteenth century (1243). Its church, known as "the cathedral of the friars", was one of the most important Gothic buildings in the city.

carrer.name: Santa Caterina de Siena, Carrer de
carrer.descripcio: Caterina Benincasa, known as "Catherine of Siena" (Siena 1347 - Rome 1380). Dominican. The lands in which the street was opened were the property of the Dominicans before the seizing of Church properties from 1835 to 1837.
carrer.anteriors: Santa Catalina de Siena; Santa Catalina

carrer.name: Santa Cecília, Carrer de
carrer.descripcio: Martyr (third century AD). Patroness of musicians. The name means 'blind 'in Latin.

carrer.name: Santa Clara, Baixada de
carrer.descripcio: Clare of Assisi (Assisi 1193 - 1253). Foundress of the order of the Clares. Canonized in 1255 by Alexander IV. In the Plaça del Rei there existed from the eighteenth to the twentieth centuries the monastery or convent of St Clare. The convent was inside the Royal Palace and the church was in the Saló del Tinell.

carrer.name: Santa Clotilde, Carrer de
carrer.descripcio: (Lyon 474 - Tours 545). Wife of the Frankish king Clovis and author of his conversion to Catholicism. Daughter of Chilpéric, king of the Burgundians, and of Caratena.

carrer.name: Santa Coloma, Carrer de
carrer.descripcio: Santa Coloma de Gramenet. Municipality of the Barcelonès region of Catalonia. A town founded long ago. Its parish church was established by the Bishop of Barcelona, Ramon de Berga, in 1176. The Chapter of the Cathedral of Barcelona was the feudal overlord of the lands of Santa Coloma, and had the title of Baron. Martyr at Sens, France, in the second century AD.

carrer.name: Santa Coloma, Passeig de
carrer.descripcio: Named after the municipality of Santa Coloma de Gramenet, to which it leads.
carrer.anteriors: Ctra. de Santa Coloma; Ctra. de Cornellá a Fogas de Tordera (a section)

carrer.name: Santa Creu, Carrer de la
carrer.descripcio: Translation of the street's previous name (calle de Santa Cruz), which was an adulteration of Santacruz, a person's surname. According to a documentary source, this was Francesc de Santacruz (Barcelona 1586 - 1658), a sculptor. According to other sources, the name corresponds to that of the first Marquis of Santa Cruz, Álvaro de Bazán (Granada 1526 - Lisbon?) Admiral, captain of galleys at the battle of Lepanto, commandant of a fourth of the ships in the league of Christian forces. Conqueror of the Rock of la Gomera. He participated in the conquest of Tunisia.

carrer.name: Santa Creu d'Olorda, Plaça de
carrer.descripcio: The name was adopted to make official the one that the inhabitants of the area had made popular.

carrer.name: Santa Creu d'Olorda a Sarrià, Carretera de
carrer.descripcio: A road that passes through Santa Creu d'Olorda toward the municipality of Molins de Rei.
carrer.anteriors: Cº de Santa Cruz de Olorde a Sarriá

carrer.name: Santa Dorotea, Carrer de
carrer.descripcio: From Caesarea in Cappadocia (fourth century). Martyr. Name given to the street in 1949 "because of the name of the church that will be built there" (thanks to the patronage of Dorotea de Chopitea i de Villota), reads the proposal of agreement.

carrer.name: Santa Elena, Carrer de
carrer.descripcio: Or Helena. Flavia Julia Elena Augusta (Bithynia 255 - Nicomedia 329). Roman empress. Mother of Constantine I the Great. The name means 'light' in Greek. The street took the name of a nearby chapel.

carrer.name: Santa Elionor, Carrer de
carrer.descripcio: Eleanor of Provence (thirteenth century). Queen of England.

carrer.name: Santa Engràcia, Plaça de
carrer.descripcio: Named after the church of Santa Engràcia.

carrer.name: Santa Engràcia, Carrer de
carrer.descripcio: (Braga, Portugal 284 - Zaragoza 304). Martyr at the hands of Dacian. The street took the name because of Engràcia Batista Planas (1842 - 1891), the proprietress of the place. The parish church was opened in 1928.

carrer.name: Santa Eugènia, Carrer de
carrer.descripcio: (900 - 923). Cordoban virgin and martyr under the Caliphate of Abderraman III.

carrer.name: Santa Eulàlia, Baixada de
carrer.descripcio: (Barcelona third - fourth centuries AD). Virgin and martyr under the emperor Diocletian. The name means 'fair spoken. 'She was the patroness of Barcelona, and is today the co-patroness.

carrer.name: Santa Eulàlia, Carrer de
carrer.descripcio: Under the same dedication as is the other thoroughfare.

carrer.name: Santa Eulàlia, Passatge de
carrer.descripcio: Under the same dedication as is the other thoroughfare.

carrer.name: Santa Eulàlia, Passeig de
carrer.descripcio: Given this name because the chapel and the house of St Eulàlia used to exist at the place where it is believed the saint underwent martyrdom. The knight Joan de Terré granted the house to the Capuchin Fathers for them to establish themselves in, in the sixteenth century.

carrer.name: Santa Eulàlia, Plaça de
carrer.descripcio: (Barcelona third - fourth centuries A. D.). Virgin and martyr under the emperor Diocletian.

carrer.name: Santa Fe, Carrer de
carrer.descripcio: Roman virgin and martyr (second century AD), together with her sisters Hope and Charity, at the time of the emperor Hadrian.

carrer.name: Santa Fe de Nou Mèxic, Carrer de
carrer.descripcio: It owes its name to Santa Fe de Nuevo Mexico, a city of the United States of America, and capital of the state of New Mexico.

carrer.name: Santa Filomena, Carrer de
carrer.descripcio: Virgin and martyr (fourth century AD) under the emperor Diocletian.

carrer.name: Santa Gemma, Carrer de
carrer.descripcio: (Naples 1374 - 1429). Virgin.

carrer.name: Santa Joana d'Arc, Carrer de
carrer.descripcio: Jeanne d'Arc Romée (Domrémy, Lorraine 1412 - Rouen 1431). "The maid of Orleans". French heroine of the Hundred Years War. Patroness of France.
carrer.anteriors: Santa Juana de Arco; Juana de Arco

carrer.name: Santa Joaquima de Vedruna, Carrer de
carrer.descripcio: Joaquima de Vedruna i Vidal de Mas (Barcelona 1783 - 1854). Foundress of the order of the Carmelites of Charity.

carrer.name: Santa Laura, Carrer de
carrer.descripcio: (811 - 864). Cordoban martyr. Abbess in about 856 AD.

carrer.name: Santa Llúcia, Carrer de
carrer.descripcio: Saint Lucy was a virgin and martyr of Syracuse in about the fourth century AD. The name means 'light'. Barcelona dedicated the chapel to her which had originally been called "the chapel of the eleven thousand virgins", built in 1268 by Bishop Arnau de Gurb.

carrer.name: Santa Lluïsa de Marillac, Carrer de
carrer.descripcio: (1591 - 1660). Widow. Foundress of the order of the Congregation of the Sisters of Charity with St Vincent de Paul.
carrer.anteriors: Santa Luisa de Marillac; Tormenta, before 1865

carrer.name: Santa Madrona, Carrer de
carrer.descripcio: (Thessalonica third - fourth centuries). Christian martyr. Patroness of sailors. A medieval tradition has it that her body, brought from the East by some merchants on their way to Marseille, had to be taken to Barcelona on account of a tempest. It was venerated in the church of Sant Fruitós, at the foot of Montjuïc, a church which later became that of Santa Madrona. Some of her later biographers made her into a daughter of Barcelona. In Seva (Osona) an oral tradition depicts her as a local shepherdess.
carrer.anteriors: Laureano Novas; Pje. Oriol Dodero (a section)

carrer.name: Santa Madrona, Passeig de
carrer.descripcio: It formerly came out from the Drassanes (Shipyards), and the name was transferred to the thoroughfare by the Santa Madrona gate.

carrer.name: Santa Madrona, Plaça de
carrer.descripcio: Under the same dedication as is the street.

carrer.name: Santa Magdalena, Carrer de
carrer.descripcio: Named after Magdalena Escarabatxeras i Blanch (Barcelona ? - 1794). Mother-in-law of Àgata Badia i Puigrodon de Trilla, proprietress and urban developer of the sector of Gràcia where the street runs.

carrer.name: Santa Magdalena Sofia, Carrer de
carrer.descripcio: Madeleine Sophie Barat (Joigny, diocese of Sens 1779 - París 1865). Foundress of the Religious Institute of the Sacred Heart of Jesus, also known as the Dames of the Faith or of Christian Instruction.
carrer.anteriors: Paciano Ros; Santa Magdalena Sofía; Paciano Ros (Town Hall of Sarrià)

carrer.name: Santa Margarida, Carrer de
carrer.descripcio: In memory of a chapel which stood in the street centuries before, dedicated to the saint, who was martyred in Antioch in the third century AD. The chapel was still standing at the end of the seventeenth century.

carrer.name: Santa Maria, Carrer de
carrer.descripcio: It owes its name to Mary the mother of Jesus.

carrer.name: Santa Maria, Plaça de
carrer.descripcio: Named after the parish church of Santa Maria del Mar, which is in this square and was built between 1329 and 1390 by the faithful themselves, under the architectural supervision of Berenguer de Montagut and Ramon Despuig. The square was formerly occupied by the major cemetery of the parish.

carrer.name: Santa Maria de Vilalba, Passatge de
carrer.descripcio: It owes its name to Santa Maria de Vilalba, a village of the municipality of Abrera, in the Baix Llobregat region of Catalonia.

carrer.name: Santa Marta, Carrer de
carrer.descripcio: (Bethany, first century AD). Sister of Lazarus and of Mary of Bethany.

carrer.name: Santa Matilde, Carrer de
carrer.descripcio: (895 - Quedlinburg 968) Saint Mechtild. German queen, wife of Henry the Huntsman. Mother of the emperor Otto.

carrer.name: Santa Mònica, Carrer de
carrer.descripcio: (Tagaste 332 - Ostia 387). Mother of St Augustine.

carrer.name: Santa Olívia, Carrer de
carrer.descripcio: Olivia, a variant of Oliva. St Olivia of Palermo, whose body King Martin of Aragon requested in 1402 of the Caliph of Tunisia. Her cult had previously extended to various cities of Catalonia. Bishop Arnau de Gurb raised a chapel in her honor in Barcelona in 1268.

carrer.name: Santa Otília, Carrer de
carrer.descripcio: Seventh century AD. Benedictine. The street owes its name to Otília Lazzoli i Comas, proprietress of the land on which the street was opened. Wife of Hermenegild Mariné i Cuyàs del Bosch, proprietor, and heir of Josep Mariné i Baliarda.

carrer.name: Santa Peronella, Carrer de
carrer.descripcio: Roman martyr.

carrer.name: Santa Perpètua, Carrer de
carrer.descripcio: (? - Carthage 202). Martyr. The proprietor of the estate, Josep Peitg i Augé, Deputy Mayor of the town of Gràcia, gave the street the first name of his daughter Perpètua Peitg i Solà (who married Dr Sallent, a physician in Gràcia).

carrer.name: Santa Rosa, Carrer de
carrer.descripcio: Name given by Àgata Badia i Puigrodon de Trilla, the urban developer of the area of Gràcia where the street passes, in memory of her mother Rosa Puigrodon i Pla (Tremp, Pallars Jussà? - Barcelona 1816?). Saint Rose was Isabel Flores de Oliva (Lima, Peru 1586 - 1617). Dominican tertiary. Patroness of America, the Philippines, and the East Indies. Mystic.

carrer.name: Santa Rosalia, Carrer de
carrer.descripcio: Rosalia Sinibaldo (Palermo, Sicily ?). Hermit.
carrer.anteriors: Pje. de San Dalmiro; General Mendoza

carrer.name: Santa Tecla, Carrer de
carrer.descripcio: (Iconius, Asia Minor ? - Seleuce 65). Proselyte. Disciple of St Paul. Patroness of Tarragona, and because of her name, of typists. (The Catalan word 'tecla' means 'key'.)

carrer.name: Santa Teresa, Carrer de
carrer.descripcio: Teresa Sánchez de Cepeda y Ahumada (Avila 1515 - Alba de Tormes 1582). Carmelite. Writer. Foundress of the order of the Theresians. Daughter of Alonso Sánchez de Cepeda and Beatriz de Ahumada.

carrer.name: Santa Teresa, Passatge de
carrer.descripcio: Under the same dedication as is the street.

carrer.name: Santa Úrsula, Carrer de
carrer.descripcio: Virgin and martyr. (375 - Cologne, Germany 383). Venerated in Solsona. Patroness of orphans.

carrer.name: Santaló, Carrer de
carrer.descripcio: Rupert Santaló i Vinyals (Barcelona 1824 - 1872). Proprietor of the Camp de les Figueres, which he allowed to be built on in 1871. Son of Bartomeu Santaló i Mercader from Tortellà, and of Cristina Vinyals i Galí, from Terrassa. He was married to Joaquima Gassó i Nadal. Died of typhoid fever.

carrer.name: Santander, Carrer de
carrer.descripcio: It owes its name to Santander, a city of Cantabria, in Spain. Capital of the province of the same name.

carrer.name: Santanyí, Carrer de
carrer.descripcio: Municipality of eastern Majorca. A street in the neighborhood of Porta, where the great majority of thoroughfares are dedicated to places and villages in Majorca.

carrer.name: Santapau, Carrer de
carrer.descripcio: Name of a baronial estate of the Marquis of Castelldosrius, whose house of leisure - the Garrigó property - was near the street. The noble lineage in question comes from the County of Besalú (twelfth century). Ponç de Santapau i de Saguàrdia (fourteenth century) was a counselor of Pere III. Francesc Xavier de Sentmenat Oms de Santapau i de Vera, Marquis of Castelldosrius and Baron of Santapau, was Captain-General of Catalonia in 1822 and 1823.

carrer.name: Santcliment, Carrer d'en
carrer.descripcio: Name of a very old Catalan family whose members made important contributions to the city: in a text of as early as 1328 "the hospice of Pere de Santcliment", situated in the Raval (outskirts), is mentioned.
carrer.anteriors: San Clemente, before 1900; Nicolàs de Sant Climent, before 1865; D'en Cornet; D'en Sentmenat

carrer.name: Santes Creus, Carrer de
carrer.descripcio: Santa Maria de Santes Creus. Cistercian monastery of the municipality of Aiguamúrcia (Alt Camp), founded in 1152 by Ramon Berenguer IV "in recognition of the favor obtained from Heaven which bestowed a son on his marriage" with Queen Peronella (Prince Alfons).

carrer.name: Santes Creus, Plaça de
carrer.descripcio: Named for the same reason as is the street.

carrer.name: Santiago Rusiñol, Carrer de
carrer.descripcio: Santiago Rusiñol i Prats (Barcelona 1861 - Aranjuez 1931). Playwright, narrator, painter, and art-collector.

carrer.name: Santíssima Trinitat del Mont, Carrer de la
carrer.descripcio: Name given to the street at the request of the resident and proprietress Trinitat Salvany, the widow of Puig, who alleged that the street had no name, that people referred to it as "the mountain", and that the name could be conferred because in her home she had a chapel dedicated to the cult of the Holy Trinity.
carrer.anteriors: Santísima Trinidad del Monte; Héroes Republicanos de Sarrià

carrer.name: Santjoanistes, Carrer de les
carrer.descripcio: Hospitalers. Members of the Order of St John of Jerusalem. A convent belonging to this order existed in the street until 1970. The request for the change of the street's name came from the same Association of the Knights of the Military Order of St John of Malta. The name which they proposed - St John of Malta - was not given to the street because another one already had it; and it was substituted, with the acquiescence of the Association, by the name "dels Santjoanistes". The masculine definite article in this name was changed to the feminine one as the convent in the street belonged to a female order.

carrer.name: Santpedor, Carrer de
carrer.descripcio: It owes its name to Santpedor, a municipality of El Bages region of Catalonia.

carrer.name: Sants, Plaça de
carrer.descripcio: This is the center of the neighborhood that goes by this name and which was formerly a municipality. The name comes from the church of Santa Maria de Sants, which is perhaps previous to the fifth century AD, but which is documented as existing in 780 AD.

carrer.name: Sants, Carrer de
carrer.descripcio: The name of the neighborhood and former municipality comes from that of the church of Santa Maria de Sants (eighth century).
carrer.anteriors: Ctra. de Madrid; Ctra. Real, before 1900

carrer.name: Santuari de Sant Josep de la Muntanya, Avinguda del
carrer.descripcio: Street which leads to the sanctuary of this name.
carrer.anteriors: Santuario de San José de la Montaña, 20/07/1943; San José de la Montaña; Montaña de San José, before 1900; Mina, before 1900

carrer.name: Santuaris, Passatge dels
carrer.descripcio: Named for its proximity to the sanctuaries of El Coll and El Carmel.

carrer.name: Santuari, Carrer del
carrer.descripcio: Street which leads to the sanctuary of Nostra Senyora del Coll.
carrer.anteriors: Cristià (a section); Santuarios (a section); Juan Bellmunt; Cº Nuestra Sra. del Coll; Cº Antiguo del Coll; Cº Vell del Coll

carrer.name: São Paulo, Carrer de
carrer.descripcio: It owes its name to São Paulo, a city in Brazil, capital of the state of the state of the same name, near the Atlantic coast. In 1996 it had almost eleven million inhabitants. It was made the sister city of Barcelona on 15th April 1985.

carrer.name: Saragossa, Carrer de
carrer.descripcio: It owes its name to Zaragoza, a city in Aragon. The street was opened in 1849 under the name of St Philip.

carrer.name: Sarah Bernhardt, Plaça de
carrer.descripcio: Henriette Rosine Bernard, an actress who adopted the pseudonym of Sarah Bernhardt. She was born in Paris on 12th October 1844. She was educated in a convent until the age of fifteen, when she entered the Paris Conservatory of Scenic Arts. She made her début at the Comédie-Française in 1862 with a play by Racine. In 1867 she made her début at the Odeon theatre. She took part in 125 theatrical plays, and one of her greatest successes was La Dame aux Camélias. During the Franco-Prussian war, she retired from her theatrical pursuits for a time and devoted herself to the care of the wounded and the sick. After the war she was contracted anew by the Comédie-Française, from where she embarked on a hugely successful career. Apart from her work as an actress, she also attempted painting, sculpting and writing. She performed in London and in the most important cities of America, Australia, India and Egypt. In October 1895 she performed in Barcelona's Teatre Principal, from where she traveled to Madrid, Lisbon and Donosti/San Sebastián, in the Basque Country. In 1921 she made a tour of Italy. Between 1900 and 1923 she starred in six films. In 1907 she was appointed lecturer at the Paris Conservatory and in 1914 she was awarded the French Légion d'Honneur. She died in Paris on 27th March 1923.

carrer.name: Sarajevo, Pont de
carrer.descripcio: "PENDING"

carrer.name: Sarasate, Carrer de
carrer.descripcio: Pablo de Sarasate Nabaskués (Pamplona 1844 - Biarritz 1908). Violinist and composer. First prize for violin-playing in Paris in 1857.

carrer.name: Sardana, Plaça de la
carrer.descripcio: Popular Catalan dance. Represented by a monument which stands in this square.

carrer.name: Sardenya, Carrer de
carrer.descripcio: Island and kingdom of the Mediterranean, historically linked to Catalonia. The name was given it for having been under the rule of the Catalano-aragonese crown.
carrer.anteriors: Cerdeña, 01/01/1865; Comandante Lopez Tienda; Núm. 39 (Cerdà plan); T. Marine (a section); Cº Casa Sampere

carrer.name: Sargelet, Carrer de
carrer.descripcio: Gabrielle Sargelet, a native of Cignac, France (eighteenth century), mother of Josep Maignon i Sargelet, the proprietor of the estates in this place.

carrer.name: Sarrià, Avinguda de
carrer.descripcio: It leads to the former municipality of Sarrià, which was annexed to the city in 1921.

carrer.name: Sarrià, Plaça de
carrer.descripcio: The main square of the former municipality. Its origin could be that of a shop belonging to one Syrius, from which name comes 'Syrianus' or 'Sirriano', which latter name is documented in this connection in 986. The toponym was subsequently changed into 'Serriano',' Sirria',' Serria' and' Sarrià'.
carrer.anteriors: Duque de Gandía; Sarrià; Duque de Gandía; Prat de la Riba

carrer.name: Sarrià a Vallvidrera, Carretera de
carrer.descripcio: A road which leads to Vallvidrera from Sarrià.

carrer.name: Sas, Carrer de
carrer.descripcio: It owes its name to Sas, a village of the former municipality of Benés, annexed as of 1972 to that of Sarroca de Bellera (Pallars Jussà). The street belongs to the Milans del Bosch group of buildings, where the thoroughfares are dedicated to places and villages of Catalonia.

carrer.name: Sàsser, Carrer de
carrer.descripcio: It owes its name to Sàsser, a city of Sardinia. The street belongs to a group of thoroughfares dedicated to Italian cities, in the south-west neighborhood of the Besòs river.

carrer.name: Satèl·lits, Carrer dels
carrer.descripcio: It owes its name to the bodies which wheel around a planet. The name was given at the caprice of the residents of the Rectoret neighborhood.

carrer.name: Saturn, Passatge de
carrer.descripcio: It owes its name to the planet Saturnus. The name was given by the residents of the Rectoret neighborhood and subsequently accepted as the official name.

carrer.name: Saturnino Calleja, Carrer de
carrer.descripcio: Saturnino Calleja y Fernández (Burgos 1855 - Madrid 1915). Publisher. He founded his publishing-house in Madrid in 1876. It has published a great number of books, the greater part of which are of a pedagogical and recreational kind. He is the founder of the Association of Bookshops of Spain. Among his published works there stand out the well-known 'Calleja 'stories and the original study, 'Sobre el arte de enseñar a leer' (On the Art of Teaching to Read).

carrer.name: Saüc, Carrer del
carrer.descripcio: "Saüc" is the Catalan word for the elder (Sambucus), the shrub which can reach a maximum height of five meters. It grows in the zone between the foothills and the mountain peaks, and is very common in that area. Its flowers have certain medicinal properties.

carrer.name: Saumell, Passatge de
carrer.descripcio: Emili Saumell i Llavallol (? - 1915). Proprietor. He bought the estate from Francesc Casas.

carrer.name: Savina, Carrer de la
carrer.descripcio: It owes its name to the savin tree. The street belongs to the Rectoret neighborhood, where numerous thoroughfares are dedicated to the names of trees and plants.

carrer.name: Savina, Camí de la
carrer.descripcio: The pathway adopts the name of the savin tree. Through the Turó dels Mussols, the Camí del Totxo (Tibidabo) to the Camí del Salze (Vallvidrera).

carrer.name: Scala Dei, Carrer de
carrer.descripcio: The oldest Charterhouse in Spain, in the municipality of la Morera de Montsant (Priorat).

carrer.name: Seca, Carrer de la
carrer.descripcio: A building dedicated to the minting of coins. One of the façades of La Seca de Barcelona is on this street. It already existed in 1056, when one Marcús was contracted by the mint.

carrer.name: Secretari Coloma, Carrer del
carrer.descripcio: Joan de Coloma (Borja, Aragon 1442 - ? 1515), whose father was from the Empordà region of Catalonia. Secretary of Joan II and Proto-notary of Ferran II. He participated in the Capitulaciones de Santa Fe (1492), which he wrote and signed in the name of the joint monarchs, a fact which permitted the first voyage of Columbus. He favored the creation of the Tribunal of the Holy Office (the Inquisition) and was in favor of the expulsion of the Jews.
carrer.anteriors: Secretario Coloma; Pablo Alsina; Jordá, before 1900; Matadero

carrer.name: Sedeta, Jardins de la
carrer.descripcio: Gardens situated on the former site of the factory known as "La Sedeta", from which the name is taken.

carrer.name: Segadors, Carrer dels
carrer.descripcio: It commemorates the protest before the Viceroy Count of Santa Coloma, held because of the conduct of the troops of King Philip IV in 1640.

carrer.name: Segarra, Carrer de la
carrer.descripcio: A region of Catalonia, the capital of which is Cervera. In the Street Guide of 1980 it was proposed that it should honor Josep de Segarra i de Baldric (Valls, Alt Camp 1724 - Barcelona 1784). Historian. He was a member of the Academy of Fine Letters.

carrer.name: Segimon, Carrer de
carrer.descripcio: It owes its name to Segismundo, the principal character in the work by Calderón de la Barca, 'La vida es sueño'. It gives onto the Carrer de Calderón de la Barca and the Carrer de l'Alcalde de Zalamea.

carrer.name: Segle XX, Carrer del
carrer.descripcio: Decided on by somebody whose trust was in the century that was then beginning.

carrer.name: Segons Jocs Mediterranis, Carrer dels
carrer.descripcio: In memory of the Second Mediterranean Games, celebrated in Barcelona in 1958.
carrer.anteriors: Segundos Juegos Mediterráneos; Av. del Príncipe

carrer.name: Segòvia, Carrer de
carrer.descripcio: It owes its name to the city of Castile-Leon. The name was given to the street by the first Town Council of the Republic (30th May 1931) in order to avoid duplication, for the former name of the street, Carrer de Fivaller, had been given to the Carrer de Ferran.

carrer.name: Segre, Carrer del
carrer.descripcio: It owes its name to the Segre, a river of Catalonia, and a tributary of the Ebro.

carrer.name: Segur, Carrer de
carrer.descripcio: It owes its name to Segur, a village in the municipality of Veciana, in the Anoia region of Catalonia.

carrer.name: Segura, Carrer del
carrer.descripcio: It owes its name to the Segura, a river in the south-east of the Iberian Peninsula. The street forms a group with the others named Túria, Nerbión, Guadalete, and Guadalquivir, all of which are in the Polvorí neighborhood of Barcelona.

carrer.name: Selva, Carrer de la
carrer.descripcio: It owes its name to La Selva, one of the regions of Catalonia.

carrer.name: Selva de Mar, Carrer de la
carrer.descripcio: It owes its name to La Selva de Mar, a municipality of the Alt Empordà region of Catalonia.
carrer.anteriors: La Selva de Mar, 18/05/1943; La Selva, 19/11/1929; San Martín; Núm. 58 (Cerdà plan)

carrer.name: Selva del Camp, Carrer de la
carrer.descripcio: It owes its name to La Selva del Camp, a municipality of the Baix Camp region of Catalonia.
carrer.anteriors: La Selva del Campo, 19/11/1929; La Selva; Cº Antiguo de San Martín

carrer.name: Semoleres, Carrer de les
carrer.descripcio: The street already had this name in 1603, which is related to the Fraternity of Semolina-makers ('semolers'), established in 1611. The specifically feminine 'semoleres' must refer to the women who sold the merchandise.

carrer.name: Sena, Carrer del
carrer.descripcio: It owes its name to the Seine, the French river that flows through Paris. The street forms a group with the others named Danubi, Nalón, and Gállego, all in the same area.

carrer.name: Sèneca, Carrer de
carrer.descripcio: Lucius Annaeus Seneca, (Córdoba BC 4 - Rome 65 AD). Writer, philosopher, and Roman politician. 'Quaestor' in the year 31 AD.

carrer.name: Senillosa, Passatge de
carrer.descripcio: Manuel Pujol de Senillosa i de Vedruna (Barcelona 1834 - 1872). Proprietor. Estate proceeding from the Casa Mantega of the Canyelles neighborhood. The street was originally dedicated to the house of Senillosa. Lineage: Fidel Pujol de Senillosa, Josep Pujol de Senillosa i Gispert, Manuel Pujol de Senillosa i Hernández Pons de Rocafull (Tarragona? - Barcelona 1857).

carrer.name: Sentís, Carrer de
carrer.descripcio: It owes its name to Sentís, a village in the old municipality of Benés, annexed in 1972 to Sarroca de Bellera (Pallars Jussà). The street belongs to the Milans del Bosch group of buildings, where the thoroughfares are dedicated to places and villages in Catalonia.

carrer.name: Septimània, Carrer de
carrer.descripcio: It owes its name to the former region of present-day Languedoc. This name recalls the establishment there of veteran soldiers of the 'Septima Gemina Felix' legion. The name was recovered later to designate the seven episcopal sees: Narbonne, Nîmes, Béziers, Agde, Magalona, Lodeva, and Usès.

carrer.name: Sepúlveda, Carrer de
carrer.descripcio: Francisco Sepúlveda y Ramos (Salamanca 1819 - Madrid 1894). Civil Governor of Barcelona when the Eixample district was opened, and formerly, of Teruel, Cordoba, Zamora, Alicante, and Granada. Lawyer and writer.

carrer.name: Sèquia, Carrer de la
carrer.descripcio: The name was given to the street because of the course of the Comtal irrigation channel which led to the Sant Pere ponds, the first stream of water that was brought from the Besòs river to the city before the period of the Counts.

carrer.name: Sèquia Comtal, Carrer de la
carrer.descripcio: It has part of the former course of the Comtal irrigation channel which led the waters of Montcada to Barcelona and which were first used in the eleventh century.
carrer.districtes: NOU BARRIS (08) SANT ANDREU (09) SANT MARTÍ (10)

carrer.name: Sèquia Madriguera, Carrer de la
carrer.descripcio: It owes its name to the Madriguera channel which used to pass through this place.

carrer.name: Sèrbia, Carrer de
carrer.descripcio: It owes its name to Serbia, a nation included in the former state of Yugoslavia. Federal state.

carrer.name: Seròs, Carrer de
carrer.descripcio: It owes its name to the municipality of the Segrià region of Catalonia. The street belongs to the Milans del Bosch group of buildings in the neighborhood of el Bon Pastor, where the thoroughfares are dedicated to villages in Catalonia.

carrer.name: Serra, Carrer d'en
carrer.descripcio: Surname of a Catalan family of merchants and navigators, prior to the thirteenth century. During the thirteenth, fourteenth, and fifteenth centuries, many councilors and head councilors with this surname make their appearance.

carrer.name: Serra i Arola, Passatge de
carrer.descripcio: Joan Serra i Arola (Manresa, Bages 1853 - Barcelona 1924). Proprietor as of 1897, because of the purchase from Eusebi Güell i Bacigalupi of the land where the lane was opened.

carrer.name: Serra i Hunter, Carrer de
carrer.descripcio: Jaume Serra i Hunter (Manresa, Bages 1878 - Mexico 1943). Philosopher. He presided over the Consell de Cultura of the Generalitat at the time of the Republic.

carrer.name: Serra Xic, Carrer d'en
carrer.descripcio: The street was named after Bernat Serra, Councilor in 1346, who had properties in this place. The epithet 'xic' (little) refers to the dimensions of the street.

carrer.name: Serrahima, Passatge de
carrer.descripcio: Joan Serrahima i Vila (1804 - 1883). Proprietor. He bought four-and-a-half 'mujades' of land from Miquel Massaguer i Camps in 1857.

carrer.name: Serrallonga, Carrer de
carrer.descripcio: It owes its name to Serrallonga, a municipality of el Vallespir.

carrer.name: Serrano, Carrer de
carrer.descripcio: Francisco Serrano Domínguez (Jaén 1810 - Madrid 1883). Duke of la Torre. General. Regent of the Kingdom. He contributed to the triumph of the revolutions of 1854 and 1868.

carrer.name: Sert, Passatge de
carrer.descripcio: The name is owing to the carpet factory of the Sert family. In the same lane the painter Josep M. Sert was born.

carrer.name: Servet, Carrer de
carrer.descripcio: Miguel Serveto Conesa (Villanueva de Sigena, Aragon 1511 - Champel, Geneva 1553). Aragonese humanist, physician, and theologian. He wrote 'Christianismi Restitutio', in which, in the fifth book of the work, he offered an explanation of the circulation of the blood in the human body, as a consequence of which he was burned at the stake for heresy.

carrer.name: Setantí, Carrer de
carrer.descripcio: Lluís Setantí (1410-1490). Chief Councilor of Barcelona. Ship-owner and mariner. Family of merchants, originally from the city of Lucca and subsequently established in Barcelona, where they catalanized their original surname, which possibly was Accettanti.

carrer.name: Setge de 1714, Plaça del
carrer.descripcio: In memory of the heroic resistance of the citizens of Barcelona in the siege of the city undertaken by the forces of Philip V.

carrer.name: Seu, Pla de la
carrer.descripcio: In front of the Cathedral of Barcelona, the facade of which was constructed in the late nineteenth century, by the architect August Font. The square dates from 1421-1422, when the old house of the Dean and some others belonging to the Canons were demolished, together with a section of the city wall which supported those buildings.

carrer.name: Seül, Carrer de
carrer.descripcio: It owes its name to the Korean city of Seoul, the capital of the Republic of Korea. In memory of the 1988 Olympic Games.

carrer.name: Sevilla, Carrer de
carrer.descripcio: It owes its name to Seville, the capital of Andalusia. The former 'Julia Romulea' of the Romans, subsequently occupied by the Vandals, Swabians, and Visigoths, it became a cultural nucleus under St Leander and St Isidore. In 712 it was occupied by the Muslims, who named it 'Isbilia.' Fernando III of Castile conquered the city in 1248, and made it into the capital of the kingdom.

carrer.name: Sibelius, Carrer de
carrer.descripcio: Jan Sibelius (Hämeenlinna,Tavastehus 1865 - Jarvenpää 1957). Finnish composer. Professor of the Institute of Music of Helsinki (1892-1910).

carrer.name: Sibil·les, Plaça de les
carrer.descripcio: Sybilla, a woman who had the gift of foreseeing the future. The name came especially to be applied to various prophetesses, who were always virgins of acerbic temperament and impassioned with divine inspiration proceeding from Apollo. As a consequence they had the virtue of being able to utter oracles. These sybils entered into Christian literature and iconography as of very remote times. Some of the most famous were those at Erithrae, Ionium, Delphi, Marpessa, etc.

carrer.name: Sibiuda, Carrer de
carrer.descripcio: Ramon Sibiuda (? - 1436). Catalan philosopher, master artist, physician, theologian, and canon lawyer.

carrer.name: Sicília, Carrer de
carrer.descripcio: It owes its name to Sicily, the Mediterranean island historically linked to Catalonia. Pere II conquered it (1282) by organising a force of 150 ships which carried 20,000 mercenary raiders employed in the Aragonese army, 100 crossbowmen, and 2,000 horses. The domination of the island by the Spanish kingdoms continued until the Peace of Utrecht (1713).

carrer.name: Sidé, Carrer de
carrer.descripcio: Properly speaking, "Carrer d'en Sidé", according to very old documents, this being the name of a Barcelona family with properties in the area.

carrer.name: Sidó, Carrer de
carrer.descripcio: It owes its name to Sidon, the ancient Phoenician city. The street is one of a group formed with two others named Tir and Sinaí in the same neighborhood.

carrer.name: Sigüenza, Passatge de
carrer.descripcio: Named for the same reason as is the street.

carrer.name: Sigüenza, Carrer de
carrer.descripcio: It owes its name to Sigüenza, a town in Castile-La Mancha.

carrer.name: Sils, Carrer de
carrer.descripcio: It owes its name to Sils, a municipality of La Selva Catalan region.
carrer.anteriors: San Francisco, before 1900; San Antonio de la Nueva; San Antonio de Padua

carrer.name: Quarter de Simancas, Carrer del
carrer.descripcio: This is a reference to the fortress or castle of the town of Simancas (Valladolid, Spain), in which the Royal Archive was founded in 1548. Though confiscated and taken to Paris by Napoleon, it was returned in 1816. Its holdings are in excess of 5,000 volumes, and 62,000 manuscripts. The General Military Archive is in the city of Segovia, in Spain.

carrer.name: Simó, Passatge de
carrer.descripcio: Francesca Simon i Ferrer (Barcelona 1798 - 1876). Proprietress, from 1867, of lands in the Torre Vermella estate. Agustí Comellas and Francesca Simon were the proprietors of nine 'mujades' and ten 'mundines' of land, eight tenths of the estate, at the beginning of the nineteenth century.

carrer.name: Simó Oller, Carrer de
carrer.descripcio: Jaume Simó Oller is named in a text of 1326. He acquired lands and built houses. The street is already mentioned, under the same name, in 1367 and 1390.
carrer.anteriors: Simón Oller, before 1865; Carniceria d'en Sorts

carrer.name: Sinaí, Carrer del
carrer.descripcio: It owes its name to Sinai, the peninsula which unites Asia and Africa. The street forms a group with those named Tir and Sidó, in the same neighborhood.

carrer.name: Siracusa, Carrer de
carrer.descripcio: It owes its name to Syracuse, the city in Sicily in which St Lucy was born in 283. This name is given to the street in order to recall that it was previously known as Carrer de Santa Llúcia, which name had to be changed because there were various streets in Barcelona dedicated to this saint.
carrer.anteriors: Voltaire; Siracusa; Voltaire; Wagner; Santa Lucía, before 1900

carrer.name: Sitges, Carrer de les
carrer.descripcio: In the pavement of the street one could still discern, last century, the openings of the silos ('sitges') which had been there and which were in use as late as the beginning of the nineteenth century.

carrer.name: Siurana, Carrer de
carrer.descripcio: It owes its name to Siurana d'Empordà, a municipality of the Alt Empordà region of Catalonia.

carrer.name: Sivatte, Avinguda de
carrer.descripcio: Manuel Maria de Sivatte i Llopart (Barcelona 1866 - 1931). Lawyer. Proprietor of the lands in the area, an old property named "Quadra de Vallbona", under the direct overlordship of the Marquis of la Manresana.

carrer.name: Socors, Carrer del
carrer.descripcio: A street opened in the property of Francesc Catarineu i Guardiola, in accordance with an urban development plan of 1879. He was the successor of Francesc Catarineu i Quintana (1805 - 1878), a brickmaker. The lands were under the direct ownership of Pere Josep d'Avellà and Francesca de Martí i Feu. The name, given at the caprice of the proprietor, could refer to one of the advocations of the Virgin Mary.

carrer.name: Sòcrates, Passatge de
carrer.descripcio: Named for the same reason as is the street.

carrer.name: Sòcrates, Carrer de
carrer.descripcio: (Athens about BC 470 - 399). Greek philosopher. Son of the sculptor Sophroniscos and of a midwife, Phenarete. After his death there was a proliferation of literature based on his 'Dialogues'.

carrer.name: Sofia Barat, Jardins de
carrer.descripcio: Saint Madeleine-Sophie Barat et Foufé was born in Joigny, Burgundy, France, on 12th December 1779. She founded the Congregation of the Society of the Sacred Heart. She took her vows as a nun in Paris on 13th November 1801. She formed a first community known as the Dames de l'Instruction Chrétienne. The restoration of the monarchy in France made it possible for the name of the Sacred Heart to be made official. The Holy See gave its approval in 1826. The community enjoyed a great expansion throughout the world. Sophie Barat died in Paris on 24th May 1865. She was canonized in Rome on 25th May 1925.

carrer.name: Sol, Carrer del
carrer.descripcio: Near the square of the same name, in the Gràcia district.

carrer.name: Sol, Plaça del
carrer.descripcio: It owes its name to the star we call the sun. Next to the Carrer del Planeta, in the Gràcia district.

carrer.name: Sol de Baix, Plaça del
carrer.descripcio: Properly speaking, 'sòl' (from Latin 'solum', meaning land), an habitual name in Catalan toponymy: "the lowest part of a plot of land". The name corresponds to the old Can Planes del Pla farmhouse, which was the property of Maria Dolors Masferrer i Bosch, wife of Josep Comas i Masferrer. The gateway to the property was decorated with a sun.

carrer.name: Sol i Padrís, Carrer de
carrer.descripcio: Josep Sol i Padrís, or Pedrís (Barcelona 1816 - 1855). Lawyer, industrialist, and politician. Manager of the Güell factory in the Sants neighborhood, known as "el Vapor Vell". He died as a consequence of events in the Barcelona general strike on 2nd July 1855.

carrer.name: Solà, Carrer de
carrer.descripcio: Felícia Solà i Puig (Vilanova i la Geltrú, Garraf 1844 - Barcelona 1899). Wife of Josep Gelabert i Cuyàs, in 1863, and of Joaquim Gelabert i Cuyàs, in 1868. These proprietors granted the land for the opening of the street.

carrer.name: Solanell, Baixada de
carrer.descripcio: The name recalls a country house which the Solanell family had in this place. This long-standing Barcelona family gave important personages to the city, among whom was Antoni Solanell i de Montellà (seventeenth and eighteenth centuries), an ecclesiastic who became Abbot of Sant Pere de Galligants and of Sant Cugat.
carrer.anteriors: C. Scala Dei; San Miguel; Durán

carrer.name: Solanes, Carrer de
carrer.descripcio: Martí Solanes i Mas (Sant Boi de Llobregat, Baix Llobregat 1828 - Barcelona 1891). Catholic Priest. A proprietor in this area from 1879. He lived in the Carrer de Bertran.

carrer.name: Solé i Pla, Passeig de
carrer.descripcio: Joan Solé i Pla (Barcelona 1874 - Colombia 1950). Physician and botanist.

carrer.name: Soledad Gustavo, Plaça de
carrer.descripcio: Teresa Mañé i Miravent, "Soledad Gustavo", teacher and writer, was born on 29th November 1865 and was christened in Cubelles, in the Garraf region of Catalonia. She and her husband Joan Montseny, "Federico Urales", were the most active anarchist intellectuals in Spain at the time. She edited the Revista Blanca and collaborated with Tierra y Libertad. She died in Perpignan on 1st February 1939.

carrer.name: Soler i Rovirosa, Carrer de
carrer.descripcio: Francesc Soler i Rovirosa (Barcelona 1836 - 1900). Theater decorator. One of the main founders of the Catalan school of realistic scenography.

carrer.name: Sóller, Plaça de
carrer.descripcio: It owes its name to Sóller, a municipality of western Majorca. Urban area of the Porta neighborhood, where the thoroughfares are dedicated to cities of the island of Majorca.

carrer.name: Solsona, Passatge de
carrer.descripcio: Joan Solsona i Roda (Puigverd, Segrià 1800 - Sants 1881), who lived in the Carrer del Duc de la Victòria (today Gavà), number 55, next to the whitewash factory of which he was the proprietor. He was succeeded by his son Francesc Solsona i Nogués (Puigverd, Segrià 1821 - Sants 1896), an industrialist. Married to, and separated from, Francesca Payerols, he died without heirs.

carrer.name: Solsonès, Carrer del
carrer.descripcio: A county of central Catalonia.

carrer.name: Solsticis, Carrer dels
carrer.descripcio: The two points of the Sun's path for which the value of the decline of the Sun attains its maximum or minimum value.

carrer.name: Sombrerers, Carrer dels
carrer.descripcio: In the eighteenth century the receivers of the Hatters' Guild, the ordinances of which date from 1545, established themselves here. In 1658 the Guild was called 'dels barreters', as is stated in the appointment of the city Hatters' Guild receivers. The name 'sombrerers' must have been adopted at the end of the seventeenth century.

carrer.name: Sor Eulàlia d'Anzizu, Carrer de
carrer.descripcio: Mercè Anzizu i Vila (Barcelona 1868 - 1916). She was professed in the Monastery of Pedralbes in 1899, in which she exercised all the offices except that of Abbess. She contributed her fortune, as she came from a very rich family, to the restoration of the Monastery and of the sepulchre of its foundress, Queen Elisenda.
carrer.anteriors: Marimón, 07/03/1939; Sor Eulàlia Anzizu, 04/02/1931; Marimón, 18/05/1927; Sor Eulàlia Anzizu (Town Hall of Sarrià); Albareda, 10/05/1904; Pº de los Algarrobos

carrer.name: Sòria, Carrer de
carrer.descripcio: It owes its name to Soria, a city in Castile-Leon.

carrer.name: Sorolla, Carrer de
carrer.descripcio: Joaquim Sorolla i Bastida (Valencia, Horta 1863 - Cercedilla, Madrid 1922). Painter. He received more than fifteen prizes from all around the world. He exhibited in the principal cities of Europe and North America.

carrer.name: Sors, Carrer de
carrer.descripcio: Josep Ferran Sors i Muntades (Barcelona 1778 - Paris 1839). Guitarist and composer. Some people know the street as "Carrer de les Sors", because of the presence of the Germanes de la Nativitat de Nostra Senyora, whose convent is in the same street.
carrer.anteriors: Jazmín (between Trav. de Dalt and Salud); Palma, before 1900

carrer.name: Sortidor, Plaça del
carrer.descripcio: Fountain at the crossroads formed by Carrer de Blasco de Garay and Carrer de Magalhaes in the Poble Sec neighborhood.

carrer.name: Sospir, Carrer del
carrer.descripcio: As the historians Roca and Comas pointed out in reference to the Carrer de l'Amargor ('bitterness'), a street next to this one and in accordance with the same criterion, the dedication refers to the last sigh ('sospir') of Jesus Christ on the cross. The name was given at the caprice of the urban developers.

carrer.name: Sostres, Carrer de
carrer.descripcio: Victorià Sostres i Malzac (Sort, Pallars Sobirà 1864 - Barcelona 1907). Lawyer. Married to Maria Assumpció Maignon i Martí, known as Emília, proprietress of the lands where the street was opened.
carrer.anteriors: Cantera (between bda. de la Glòria and the Turull property)

carrer.name: Sot dels Paletes, Plaça del
carrer.descripcio: This name corresponded to a very deep point of the Rec Comtal near the present-day Carrer del Cinca, where all the young people in Sant Andreu used to go swimming in hot weather. The present-day square is some 200 metres from where the "sot dels paletes" used to be.

carrer.name: Sota Muralla, Pas de
carrer.descripcio: Named for occupying a site near the old sea wall constructed in 1530 to defend the city from the attacks of pirates and demolished in 1878.

carrer.name: Sotstinent Navarro, Carrer del
carrer.descripcio: Josep Navarro (Novelda, Valls del Vinalopó about 1770 - 1809). Hero of the War of Independence. Executed in 1809. He belonged to a regiment of infantry from Sarrià and previously to one from Soria. He was given the rank of second lieutenant on account of the wound received when he was engaged in battle in the area of Molins de Rei.
carrer.anteriors: Subteniente Navarro; Murallas Romanas; Subteniente Navarro; Murallas Romanas; Basea (a section)

carrer.name: Sovelles, Carrer de
carrer.descripcio: It owes its name to Sovelles, a village of the municipality of Les Llosses, in the Ripollès Catalonia region. The street belongs to the Eduard Aunós group of buildings, where the thoroughfares are dedicated to places and villages in Catalonia.

carrer.name: Soweto, Carrer de
carrer.descripcio: On 16th June 1976 the youth of the streets and the schools in Soweto (Johannesburg, Republic of South Africa), revolted against racial discrimination. During the protest march, the police fired into the crowd. Despite the fact that the official sources reported 23 dead, they were probably more than 200. The response of the police caused an authentic bloodbath. The first person to die was a teenager, Hector Petersen, who was 13 years of age. Ever since, the revolt of the schoolchildren of Soweto against apartheid is commemorated every year. The name of this street, together with those of other thoroughfares in the area, refers to the struggle for peace and human rights.

carrer.name: Subirats, Carrer de
carrer.descripcio: It owes its name to Subirats, a municipality of the Alt Penedès Catalonia region.

carrer.name: Suez, Passatge de
carrer.descripcio: Suez Canal. An artificial canal which, through the isthmus of Suez, connects the Mediterranean Sea with the Red Sea. The dedication is on account of its proximity to the port of Barcelona.

carrer.name: Sugranyes, Carrer de
carrer.descripcio: Victorià Sugrañes i Fernàndez (Reus, Baix Camp 1807 - Tetuan 1860). A soldier in the body of Catalan volunteers under the orders of Baron de Meer, who granted him the Cross of San Fernando (1839), and of General van Halen (1840). He graduated in 1844 with the rank of commandant. Under the orders of General Prim, he was killed in the Battle of Tetuan on 4th February 1860.

carrer.name: Suïssa, Carrer de
carrer.descripcio: It owes its name to Switzerland, a state in Central Europe, also known as the Helvetian Confederation. It would seem that a Swiss firm was established in this vicinity, though at the time of this present edition this supposed fact has not been able reliably to be confirmed.

carrer.name: Suñol i Gros, Carrer de
carrer.descripcio: Josep Suñol i Gros (Barcelona 1845 - 1922). Proprietor and agent for the purchase and sale of estates in that area. The street is situated in the place known formerly as 'les forques del coll de la Trinitat" between Carrer del Pare Pérez del Pulgar and Carrer del Torrent de Perera.

carrer.name: Súria, Carrer de
carrer.descripcio: It owes its name to the municipality of Súria, in the valley of the Cardener river, in the Bages Catalonia region.

carrer.name: Tagamanent, Carrer de
carrer.descripcio: A municipality in the Vallès Oriental region of Catalonia and a street in Barcelona. In 1417 this municipality requested unity with Barcelona under the formula of 'carreratge', in accordance with which the town was considered a street of Barcelona, and its inhabitants could therefore enjoy the same privileges and rights as those of the capital.

carrer.name: Tajo, Carrer del
carrer.descripcio: It owes its name to the Tagus, a river of the Iberian Peninsula. The street forms a group with the Carrer del Duero, situated in the same area.
carrer.anteriors: Ginesta (without effectiveness); Ra. d'Horta (a section); Ra. Baja

carrer.name: Talaia, Passatge de la
carrer.descripcio: From this lane one can discern the watch-tower of the mountain called El Tibidabo

carrer.name: Tallada, Carrer de la
carrer.descripcio: It owes its name to Tallada, a village in the municipality of Sant Guim de Freixenet in the Segarra region of Catalonia, within the former boundaries of Freixenet de Segarra. The street belongs to the Milans del Bosch group of buildings, where the thoroughfares are dedicated to places and villages in Catalonia.

carrer.name: Tallers, Carrer dels
carrer.descripcio: The 'tallers 'were a city gate and a street. When the Rambla city wall was constructed in 1363, the "barri dels tallers" already existed there in the inner area known as 'Vico dels T'a'yers'. The name of the street comes from the meat-cutters who exercised their profession in the vicinity. (In Catalan the verb "to cut" is "tallar".)

carrer.name: Tamarit, Carrer de
carrer.descripcio: Francesc de Tamarit i de Rifà (Barcelona 1600 - 1653). Soldier and politician. Lord of the castle of Montclar. Deputy of the military arm, defender of Barcelona in 1641 when Fontanella was Chief Councilor and Pau Claris the President of the Generalitat (Rippers' War against Felip IV). Proposal of Victor Balaguer.

carrer.name: Tamariu, Carrer de
carrer.descripcio: It owes its name to Tamariu, a village in the municipality of Palafrugell, in the Baix Empordà region of Catalonia.

carrer.name: Tànger, Carrer de
carrer.descripcio: It owes its name to Tangiers, a city in Morocco. Free port from 1906 to 1956, in which year it was annexed by Morocco. It regained the status of free port in 1962.

carrer.name: Tantarantana, Carrer d'en
carrer.descripcio: It is known that this street already had this name in 1716: the town crier lived there, and he used to announce himself with a drum-roll or a trumpet-blast. For this reason people came to refer to him under the onomatopoeic nickname of 'En Tantarantana'.

carrer.name: Tàpies, Carrer de les
carrer.descripcio: The street, under the same name, dates - at least in part - to before 1745. The name comes from the presence there, on one side, of the Sant Pau orchard wall, and on the other, of a group of walls belonging to other properties. Initially it was known as the "Carrer de rere l'hort de Sant Pau".

carrer.name: Tapineria, Carrer de la
carrer.descripcio: In this street there used to be makers of 'tapins', a kind of cork sandal lined with leather and having a cloth covering. These were previously worn by women. According to RiC the original name of the street was 'xapins 'or 'xapiners', which was the name of the artisans who made this footwear.

carrer.name: Tapioles, Torrent de
carrer.descripcio: Named because of the walls of the orchards which it crossed.

carrer.name: Tapioles, Carrer de
carrer.descripcio: The name of a member of the Montjuïc garrison that was victorious over the Castilian forces in 1641. Simultaneously with Tapioles (1871), streets were named after Radas, Cabanyes, and Margarit, military men who distinguished themselves in the Rippers' War, and especially at the Battle of Montjuïc (26th January 1641). A street of the Sants neighborhood of Barcelona has had the name since 1911, when Montfar, who was in command of the Catalan artillery at the said battle, was also honored.

carrer.name: Taquígraf Garriga, Carrer del
carrer.descripcio: Pere Garriga i Marill (Esparreguera, Baix Llobregat 1842 - Les Corts 1890). Ecclesiastic, Doctor of Laws and Philosophy and Letters, and stenographer. "When he was co-adjutor of the church of Sant Miquel del Port in 1870, he attended the sick in the epidemic of yellow fever which was affecting the parish. His conduct some few months later, when he was assigned to the parish of Sant Josep de Gràcia, was heroic, as he carried the viaticum to the sick and the wounded in the siege of that town, and did so during the hours of intense bombardment. Proposal of the Corporació Taquigràfica del Sistema Garriga.
carrer.anteriors: Taquígrafo Garriga, 21/03/1929; Carmelo, 23/11/1911; Gelabert del Coscoll, 23/09/1911; Noya (joined to it), 05/09/1907; Castellbisbal, 05/09/1907; Carmen, 07/09/1878; San Carlos, 08/09/1848

carrer.name: Taquígraf Martí, Carrer del
carrer.descripcio: Francesc de Paula Martí i Móra (Xàtiva, La Costera 1761 - Lisbon 1827). The person who introduced stenography. He founded and directed a shorthand school in Madrid. He also wrote a number of theatrical works.
carrer.anteriors: Taquígrafo Martí, 22/03/1929; Lletra R (Plan of Les Corts), 29/01/1925; Bosch y Busquets (joined to it), 12/05/1883

carrer.name: Taquígraf Serra, Carrer del
carrer.descripcio: Francesc (Serra) Ginesta i Alenyà (Olot, La Garrotxa 1765 - Barcelona 1836). Stenograper and lawyer. Director of the Shorthand School in 1805. Proposal of the Corporació Taquigràfica del Sistema Garriga. Serra was the nickname of the family.
carrer.anteriors: Taquígrafo Serra, 21/03/1929; Lletra A (Plan of Les Corts), 29/01/1925

carrer.name: Taradell, Carrer de
carrer.descripcio: It owes its name to Taradell, a municipality of the Osona region of Catalonia. It forms a group with the Carrer de Manlleu and the Carrer de Cardedeu in the same neighborhood.

carrer.name: Tarba, Carrer de
carrer.descripcio: It owes its name to Tarbes, a city of Gascony in Occitania in southern France. The street is situated in the south-west of the Besòs neighborhood, where there is a group of thoroughfares dedicated to villages in the Languedoc and North Catalonia.

carrer.name: Tàrent, Carrer de
carrer.descripcio: Taranto, a city in the Puglia region in Italy. The street forms part of the south-west of the Besòs neighborhood, where there is a group of thoroughfares dedicated to villages and cities of Italy.

carrer.name: Tarongers, Carrer dels
carrer.descripcio: The name comes from the former Torrent dels Tarongers which existed in the present-day park on the mountain of Montjuïc.

carrer.name: Tarongeta, Carrer de la
carrer.descripcio: A popular children's game (especially in the sixteenth century) which could be played in the street without any complications, as at that time there was little traffic.

carrer.name: Tarragona, Carrer de
carrer.descripcio: It owes its name to Tarragona, a municipality in the Tarragonès region of Catalonia, and formerly the Tarraco of the Romans.

carrer.name: Tàrrega, Carrer de
carrer.descripcio: It owes its name to Tàrrega, a municipality of the Urgell region of Catalonia. The street is situated in the Milans del Bosch group of buildings, where the thoroughfares are dedicated to places and villages in Catalonia.

carrer.name: Tàrrega, Passatge de
carrer.descripcio: It owes its name to Tàrrega, a municipality in the Urgell region of Catalonia.

carrer.name: Tarròs, Carrer d'en
carrer.descripcio: Catalan family name from the Conflent region of Catalonia, and dating to before the fifteenth century. The street of the same name existed prior to 1579.

carrer.name: Tasso, Passatge de
carrer.descripcio: The lane was opened in the estate of Lluís Tasso i Gonyalons (Maó, Minorca 1817 - Barcelona 1880). Typographer and publisher. Matilde de Gayolà i de Delàs leased the land where the lane was opened in 1871.

carrer.name: Taulat, Carrer del
carrer.descripcio: Name of one of the four neighborhoods into which the municipality of Sant Martí de Provençals is divided: la Muntanya, la Sagrera, el Clot and el Taulat. A 'taulat' is a block of land divided into cultivable terraces prepared for the sowing of vegetables and cereals. "El Taulat d'en Llimona", prior to the seventeenth century, was one of the most important in the sector.
carrer.anteriors: Cementerio (joined to it); Mayor del Taulat

carrer.name: Taulat, Passatge del
carrer.descripcio: See Carrer del Taulat.

carrer.name: Taulat, Passeig del
carrer.descripcio: Named for the same reason as is the street of which it originally formed part.

carrer.name: Tavern, Carrer de
carrer.descripcio: Nicolasa Tavern i Nuñez-Pastor (Oviedo 1800 - Sant Gervasi, Barcelona?) proprietress of the estate. Wife of Joan de Batlle i Ruira.

carrer.name: Taxdirt, Carrer de
carrer.descripcio: An event in the Morocco campaign of1909.
carrer.anteriors: Taxdir; San Luis (2nd section); Martí Matons; Sant Luis

carrer.name: Taxi, Plaça del
carrer.descripcio: In honor of all those supplying taxi services.

carrer.name: Taxonera, Plaça de
carrer.descripcio: Joaquim Taxonera i Cassà (Arenys de Mar, Maresme 1858 - Barcelona 1934). Producer of shoes. Proprietor of the Can Grau lands in this place. He requested permission to have them built on in accordance with a project approved on 31st December 1902. The surname, evidently, is an adulteration of the correct spelling, 'teixonera' (lair of badgers). His first marriage was to Francesca Fontrodona, and his second to Àngela Rosell i Inglés. With the normalization of the nomenclature in 1980, the name of the square was approved as Plaça de la Teixonera. This was subsequently modified at the request of district authorities, residents, and family members.

carrer.name: Teatre, Plaça del
carrer.descripcio: It is in front of the Teatre Principal, the oldest one in Barcelona. The original one, which was wooden and the project for which was promoted by the administrators of the Hospital de la Santa Creu, was opened in 1598 in "una horta de Trencaclaus" under the name of Casa de les Comèdies. Destroyed in a fire in 1787, it was rebuilt and then re-opened on 4th November 1788 under the name Teatro de Santa Cruz.

carrer.name: Teatre Grec, Jardins del
carrer.descripcio: Public area situated in front of the Teatre Grec, next to the Passeig de Santa Madrona and the Passeig de L'Exposició, in Montjuïc.

carrer.name: Teide, Carrer del
carrer.descripcio: It owes its name to the Teide, a volcanic crater at the center of the island of Tenerife in the Canary Islands.

carrer.name: Teix, Plaça del
carrer.descripcio: It owes its name to the Catalan word for the yew tree. The street forms part of a group of thoroughfares in the Rectoret neighborhood with names of trees and shrubs.

carrer.name: Telègraf, Carrer del
