carrer.descripcio: Name proposed by a teacher by the name of Mateu Romero in honor of the means of transmission then only just introduced. It formed a group with the Carrer del Telèfon (today, Carrer de Varsòvia) and Carrer del Fonògraf (today, Carrer de Gènova).

carrer.name: Televisió, Plaça de la
carrer.descripcio: A square in the Rectoret neighborhood. The name was proposed by the residents.

carrer.name: Tell, Carrer de
carrer.descripcio: It owes its name to Tell, a hamlet in the municipality of Canejan, in the Vall d'Aran. The street belongs to the Milans del Bosch group of buildings, where the thoroughfares are dedicated to places and villages in Catalonia.

carrer.name: Templers, Carrer dels
carrer.descripcio: The order of the Temple, founded in 1118, had a house in Barcelona near this street. The records state, in fact, that on 23rd April 1133 a certain Ramon Bernat de Maçanet granted lands for the building of quarters for the order. These quarters later became the secondary royal palace. In fact, however, the Templars did not have a home in Barcelona until 1225, and their presence there lasted until the order was definitively dissolved as a consequence of the battle of Pope Clement V of 22nd March 1312.

carrer.name: Tenerife, Carrer de
carrer.descripcio: It owes its name to Tenerife, the largest island in the archipelago of the Canaries.
carrer.anteriors: José María Serrano; José Serrano; Núm. 2 (Casa Baró residential area)

carrer.name: Tenor Masini, Carrer del
carrer.descripcio: Angelo Masini (Terra del Sole, Forli 1844 - Forli 1926). Rival tenor to Gayarre. He performed in the Liceu Opera House of Barcelona from 1882 to 1887. He retired in 1905.
carrer.anteriors: Massini, 03/07/1942; Tenor Massini, 07/03/1939; Massini, 05/09/1907; Santa Maria

carrer.name: Tenor Viñas, Carrer del
carrer.descripcio: Francesc Viñas i Dordal (Moià, Bages 1863 - 1933). He made his debut in the Barcelona Liceu Opera House in 1888. He was the correspondent in Rome of the 'El Noticiero Universal' newspaper. In 1905 he founded, in Moià, the Fruit Tree Festival.

carrer.name: Teodor Bonaplata, Carrer de
carrer.descripcio: (Barcelona 1841 - 1903). Actor. Protagonist in some of the best plays by Àngel Guimerà.

carrer.name: Teodor Llorente, Carrer de
carrer.descripcio: Teodor Llorente i Olivares (Valencia, Horta 1836 - 1911). Poet, journalist, and politician. Lawyer, deputy in the Cortes of Madrid and Senator-elect (1896). President and sustainer of the Floral Games poetical contest of Barcelona. President of 'Lo Rat Penat'.

carrer.name: Teodor Roviralta, Carrer de
carrer.descripcio: Teodor Roviralta i Figueres (Molins de Rei, Baix Llobregat 1854 - Lloret de Mar, la Selva, 1920). He bought the property from the El Tibidabo society in 1905.
carrer.anteriors: Teodoro Roviralta; Núm. 8 (a section); Av. Central (a section); Núm. 4 (S.A. El Tibidabo)

carrer.name: Teodora Lamadrid, Carrer de
carrer.descripcio: Teodora Herbella (Zaragoza 1821 - Madrid 1896). Actress. She occupied the professorship of Recitation at the Madrid Conservatory. At the behest of her father, she adopted the artistic name of Lamadrid, as did her sister Bàrbara.

carrer.name: Ter, Carrer del
carrer.descripcio: It owes its name to the Ter, a river of the Principality. It rises in Ulldeter in the Eastern Pyrenees, and empties into the sea at the beaches of Pals.

carrer.name: Teresa Claramunt, Plaça de
carrer.descripcio: Teresa Claramunt i Creus (Sabadell, Vallès Occidental 1862 - Barcelona 1931). Anarcho-syndicalist leader. A textile worker, she organized an anarchist group in Sabadell. She was imprisoned on a number of occasions. She founded the magazine 'El productor', and vindicated the right of women to participate in political, social, and economic life and the need for them also to participate in the struggle of the trade-union movement.

carrer.name: Teresa de Cofrents, Carrer de
carrer.descripcio: It owes its name to Teresa de Cofrentes, a municipality in the Vall de Cofrentes, in Valencia.

carrer.name: Terol, Carrer de
carrer.descripcio: It owes its name to Teruel, a city and province in Aragon.

carrer.name: Terrassa, Carrer de
carrer.descripcio: It owes its name to Terrassa, a municipality in the Vallès Occidental region of Catalonia. It was the ancient Roman city of 'Egara'.

carrer.name: Terré, Carrer de
carrer.descripcio: Barcelona notable who was involved in the capitulation of the city in 1472 to King Joan II, which was signed at Pedralbes.

carrer.name: Tessàlia, Carrer de
carrer.descripcio: It owes its name to Thessaly, a region of Greece. The street is situated in the south-west of the Besòs neighborhood, where a group of thoroughfares are dedicated to cities and places in Italy and Greece.

carrer.name: Tetuan, Plaça de
carrer.descripcio: Armed clash (4th February 1860). Occupation of the Moroccan city of that name by General Joan Prim at the head of the Catalan volunteers.
carrer.anteriors: Hermenegildo Giner de los Ríos; Tetuan

carrer.name: Teulada, Carrer de
carrer.descripcio: It owes its name to Teulada, a municipality of the Marina Baixa region in the Valencia province.

carrer.name: Tèxtil, Passatge del
carrer.descripcio: In memory of the large number of factories for the dyeing of cloth and the making of accoutrements for garments that used to be in this place.

carrer.name: Theolongo Bacchio, Plaça de
carrer.descripcio: A legendary character, presented as the overlord of the 'Lacetani 'and supposedly the victor in the battle of Baetulus in the third century BC in the countryside of Provence, which is in fact an historical falsehood.

carrer.name: Tiana, Carrer de
carrer.descripcio: It owes its name to Tiana, a municipality of the Maresme region of Catalonia.

carrer.name: Tibidabo, Avinguda del
carrer.descripcio: The highest peak in the Collserola range. The avenue leads to the bottom stage of the funicular which travels up the mountain by this name.
carrer.anteriors: Doctor Andreu, 1931; Av. Tibidabo; Pg. del Funicular, 23/03/1906

carrer.name: Tibidabo, Plaça del
carrer.descripcio: At the peak of the mountain by this name. The name comes from the sentence uttered by the Devil to Jesus: "Haec omnia tibi dabo si cadens adoraveris me" (All these things will I give thee, if thou wilt fall down and worship me). Matthew, 4,9.

carrer.name: Ticià, Carrer de
carrer.descripcio: Tiziano Vecellio (Pieve di Cadore 1487/1490 - Venice 1576). Italian painter. The most important master of the Venetian school and one of the geniuses of universal painting. He was nominated official painter of the Most Serene Republic.

carrer.name: Tigre, Carrer del
carrer.descripcio: Opened in 1847, this name was given to the street at the same time as two others were named Carrer del Lleó and Carrer de la Paloma. A popular account has it that these were the names of two dogs and a bitch owned by an orchard-keeper in the area. This person was possibly the proprietor of the estate that underwent urban development.

carrer.name: Til·lers, Passeig dels
carrer.descripcio: It owes its name to the linden tree. Thoroughfare opened in the Güell estate.

carrer.name: Timó, Carrer del
carrer.descripcio: It owes its name to the thyme plant.

carrer.name: Tinent Coronel Valenzuela, Carrer del
carrer.descripcio: Rafael de Valenzuela Urazin (1881 - 1923). Lieutenant-colonel of infantry killed in the African war, in the Tizzi Azza clash.

carrer.name: Tinent Costa, Passatge del
carrer.descripcio: Vicent Costa Blasco (Museros, Horta Nord 1888 - Barcelona 1938). Promoter of the Cooperativa de Casas Baratas (Cheap Housing Co-operative) for military personnel. The lane is to be found in one of the groups of such houses.

carrer.name: Tinent Flomesta, Carrer del
carrer.descripcio: Diego de Flomesta y Moya (Bullas, Murcia 1890 - Monte Abarrán, Morocco1921). Lieutenant of the artillery defending Mount Abarran. After an heroic resistance, and mortally wounded, he damaged the artillery pieces to prevent their passing into the hands of the enemy.

carrer.name: Tir, Carrer de
carrer.descripcio: The ancient Phoenician city of Tyre. It forms a group with the thoroughfares named Sidó (Sidon) and Nínive (Nineveh) in the same neighborhood.

carrer.name: Tiradors, Carrer dels
carrer.descripcio: It seems that the name, which dates from before 1579, comes from "l'Hort dels Tiradors", where there were the stretchers used by wool-combers and cloth-dyers (woolen textiles).

carrer.name: Tirant lo Blanc, Plaça de
carrer.descripcio: Novel in Catalan written by the Valencian knight Joanot Martorell, and, in the version which has come down to us, finished by the likewise Valencian knight Martí Joan de Galba. Published for the first time in Valencia in 1490.

carrer.name: Tirso, Carrer de
carrer.descripcio: Street opened in the lands of the Casa Móra country estate, the property of Eugeni Duran i Borrell at the time it underwent urban development. The name was given at the caprice of the developers. It could refer to a river in Sardinia, given that in this place there abound the most diverse names for waterways and springs: Riu de la Plata, Laguna de Lanao, Font del Remei, Font del Coll.

carrer.name: Tirso de Molina, Carrer de
carrer.descripcio: Brother Gabriel Téllez (Madrid 1584 - Almazán 1648). Castilian dramatic author, known as Tirso de Molina. Prefect of the monastery of Trujillo (1626) and of the monastery of Soria, and provincial of Castile.

carrer.name: Tissó, Carrer d'en
carrer.descripcio: Ancient place-name of the spot where the street which was also known as "torrent del Chicó" or "Xicu" was opened.
carrer.anteriors: T. de Tissó; T. del Xicu

carrer.name: Toledo, Carrer de
carrer.descripcio: It owes its name to Toledo, a city in Castile-la Mancha. It was the Visigothic political capital from the time of the establishment by Leovigild of the official court in the city.

carrer.name: Toledo, Passatge de
carrer.descripcio: It takes the name of the street into which it opens.

carrer.name: Tolerància, Plaça de la
carrer.descripcio: An enclave open to the public next to some blocks of flats in the Avinguda Meridiana, between the Carrer de Pegàs and the Carrer de Dublín.

carrer.name: Tolosa, Carrer de
carrer.descripcio: It owes its name to Toulouse, a city and the capital of Languedoc.

carrer.name: Tolrà, Carrer de
carrer.descripcio: Street dedicated to the man who was the President of the entity named Foment de la Barriada del Mont Carmel i els seus entorns (Advancement of the Mount Carmel neighborhood and its Surroundings), Antoni Tolrà i Fornés, proprietor of the land in this place from 1898. The dedication is in gratitude for his efforts in the development of the neighborhood.

carrer.name: Tomàs Mieres, Carrer de
carrer.descripcio: (Girona 1400 - Barcelona 1474). Jurist. Author of 'Dret de la Catalunya Vella'. Counselor and Prosecutor under Alfons el Magnànim. A defender of the citizens' liberties, he opposed the existence of serfdom in glebes.

carrer.name: Tomàs Padró, Carrer de
carrer.descripcio: Tomàs Padró i Pedret (Barcelona 1840 - 1877). Draftsman and painter. One of the best graphic artists in Catalonia in the nineteenth century.

carrer.name: Tona, Passatge de
carrer.descripcio: It owes its name to Tona, a municipality of the Osona region in Catalonia, and a street in Barcelona. In memory of the fact that this city requested, in 1401, union with Barcelona under the formula of 'carreratge', which considered the city as a street of Barcelona, and that its inhabitants therefore enjoyed the same rights and privileges as those of the capital.

carrer.name: Tonell, Carrer del
carrer.descripcio: A dead-end street with a restaurant at the end which was formerly a tavern. The name ('tonell 'or 'bóta') might have some relationship with the older establishment.

carrer.name: Topazi, Carrer del
carrer.descripcio: It owes its name to the topaz, the crystallized mineral used in jewelry. The name is one of a group of names of precious stones and metals used for the nomenclature of the streets of the neighborhood.

carrer.name: Topete, Carrer de
carrer.descripcio: Juan Bautista Topete y Carballo (San Andrés de Tuxtla, Mexico 1821 - Madrid 1885). Mariner and Castilian politician. He initiated the Revolution of 1868. Minister for the Navy and the Colonies. At the Restoration he was nominated Senator and Vice Admiral, in 1881.

carrer.name: Tòquio, Carrer de
carrer.descripcio: It owes its name to Tokyo, a city in Japan and the capital of the State.

carrer.name: Torà, Carrer de
carrer.descripcio: It owes its name to Torà de Riubregós, a municipality of the Segarra region of Catalonia.

carrer.name: Tordera, Carrer de
carrer.descripcio: It owes its name to Tordera, a municipality of the Maresme region of Catalonia.

carrer.name: Torelló, Carrer de
carrer.descripcio: A dynasty of proprietors of this place: Francesc Torelló i Pastó gave the lands in 1836 to Onofre Torelló i Marí. He in turn gave them to Onofre Torelló i Bonet, who sold them, in 1867, to Ramon Torelló i Oliva.

carrer.name: Torné, Carrer de
carrer.descripcio: Ferran Torné i Pascual was the proprietor, in the Coll Blanc area, of the half-'mujada' of land on which the street was opened.

carrer.name: Torns, Carrer de
carrer.descripcio: A dynasty of proprietors of the place which begins with Joan Torns i Vinyals, who died in 1826. His son Joan Torns i Prats succeeded him, and died in 1864. He was followed by Joan Torns i Casas (1830 - 1866), a weaver. He was succeeded by Lluís Torns i Masdefíol, who died in 1897. The brothers Pere and Joan Torns i Hortal were his heirs.

carrer.name: Torras i Bages, Passatge de
carrer.descripcio: Josep Torras i Bages (Les Cabanyes, Alt Penedès 1846 - Vic, Osona 1916). Ecclesiastic, writer, and philosopher. Bishop of Vic in 1899. He contributed to the text of the Bases de Manresa (1892) as a delegate of the Catalan nationalist entities of Barcelona, in which city he carried out a tireless pastoral and intellectual labor. He was a member of the Academy of Fine Arts and of the Academy of Fine Letters of Barcelona.

carrer.name: Torras i Bages, Passeig de
carrer.descripcio: Josep Torras i Bages (Les Cabanyes, Alt Penedès 1846 - Vic, Osona 1916). Ecclesiastic, writer, and philosopher. Bishop of Vic in 1899.
carrer.anteriors: Guardiola y Feliu; Iglesia; Salón Teniente Coronel Onofre Mata (between Palomar and Santa Coloma avenue)

carrer.name: Torras i Pujalt, Carrer de
carrer.descripcio: Joaquim Torras i Pujalt (Sabadell, Vallès Occidental 1855 - Barcelona 1937). Doctor of Medicine and Surgery. Husband of Josepa Ganduxer i Carrencà, proprietress of the lands where the street was opened.
carrer.anteriors: Torras y Pujalt, before 1900; San José

carrer.name: Torre, Carrer de la
carrer.descripcio: Named because of a tower in the street. It was demolished in 1977.

carrer.name: Torre, Plaça de la
carrer.descripcio: Named in this way because it leads to the Carrer de la Torre.

carrer.name: Torre Baró, Mirador de
carrer.descripcio: Named after the building known as "Torre Baró (to the detriment of the true Torre del Baró, which was demolished to allow the extension of the Avinguda Meridiana), which was the property of Manuel Maria de Sivatte i Llopart (1866 - 1931), the son of Carles Edmon, who had bought the estate of the Baron of Pinós.

carrer.name: Torre de les Aigües, Jardins de la
carrer.descripcio: Public area situated inside a block of buildings delimited by the Carrer de Roger de Llúria, the Carrer del Consell de Cent, the Carrer del Bruc, and the Carrer de la Diputació. Within it is preserved the water-tower which previously supplied the Eixample district of Barcelona.

carrer.name: Torre de Sansalvador, Camí de la
carrer.descripcio: A stately home constructed by the architect Antoni Coll i Font as commissioned by the Sansalvador family in 1905. The proprietors requested that the pathway be given the place name that is now has.

carrer.name: Torre dels Pardals, Carrer de la
carrer.descripcio: The origin of the Torre dels Pardals is, as is the case of many old Catalan farmhouses, a Roman villa, since in the eighteenth century some hot springs or Roman baths were found in its ruins. Constructed and reconstructed over the years, it is mentioned in documents of the fourteenth century. It was bought in the latter part of the nineteenth century by Josep Maria Valls i Vicenç, a Barcelona banker, and in 1915 it became the property of Joan Roig i Mallofré, a flour merchant from Reus. The Torre dels Pardals won a first prize from the Barcelona Town Council in 1918. It was afterwards demolished, and where it had stood is today totally built over.

carrer.name: Torre d'en Damians, Carrer de la
carrer.descripcio: A certain tower known as "d'en Damians" is indicated in seventeenth and eighteenth century topographical plans as one of the strategic points of the military defense of Barcelona, on the line that extended from the exit from the city to the summit of Montjuïc.

carrer.name: Torre Dulac, Carrer de la
carrer.descripcio: Name of a former manor house in this place, originally named "Torre Milans", and subsequently, "Torre Xifré".

carrer.name: Torre Llobeta, Plaça de la
carrer.descripcio: A farmhouse in the Gothic style dating from the fifteenth and early sixteenth centuries. Its last proprietor was Comas d'Argemí i Serrallonga, who ceded it to the Town Council to be turned over to social uses. Today it is one of the civic centers in the Nou Barris district.

carrer.name: Torre Melina, Carrer de
carrer.descripcio: Named for the same reason as is the pathway.

carrer.name: Torre Melina, Camí de la
carrer.descripcio: A stately home situated to the south of the Avinguda Diagonal and which was demolished quite thoughtlessly in spite of the commitments to restoring it and turning it over to social uses. It seems that the origin of the name corresponds the proprietor, who was of Genoese extraction.

carrer.name: Torre Vélez, Carrer de la
carrer.descripcio: This was the Vil·la Vélez, which no longer exists.

carrer.name: Torre Vella, Carrer de la
carrer.descripcio: Named after the old tower in the Vallbona area, on property which belonged to the Sivatte family. The name refers to the true Torre del Baró, which was demolished.

carrer.name: Torrelles, Carrer de
carrer.descripcio: It owes its name to Torrelles de Llobregat, a municipality of the Baix Llobregat region of Catalonia. It forms a group with the Carrer de Viladecavalls and the Carrer de Llerona, which are situated in the same neighborhood.

carrer.name: Torrent de Can Mariner, Carrer del
carrer.descripcio: Named after the Horta manor house which was the property of the Mariner family, and originally, in 1200, of the Ferrer family.
carrer.anteriors: T. de Casa Mariner; T. del Pont de las Vigas; T. del Coll del Portell

carrer.name: Torrent de Can Piquer, Carrer del
carrer.descripcio: In the Porta i Vilapicina neighborhood.

carrer.name: Torrent de la Guineu, Carrer del
carrer.descripcio: Named after the former Can Guineu farmhouse, in the Navas neighborhood of La Sagrera.
carrer.anteriors: T. de la Guineu (a section); T. de la Guineu

carrer.name: Torrent de les Flors, Carrer del
carrer.descripcio: The owner of the property (together with Masens and Rabassa), Manuel Torrente Flores (Ferrol, la Coruña, 1829 - 1916), implicitly renounced the direct transferral of his surname Torrente onto one of the streets in the area undergoing urban development. He did this in favor of a more popular and agreeable invention: the street-name "Torrente de las Flores", for which the city is grateful to him.

carrer.name: Torrent de les Roses, Carrer del
carrer.descripcio: This water-course does not exist: the nearest one is the Torrent de la Barrina. The name of the imaginary stream represents a modification and transformation of the previous name, Cinco Rosas.

carrer.name: Torrent de l'Estadella, Passatge del
carrer.descripcio: The ancient toponym for this place.

carrer.name: Torrent de l'Olla, Carrer del
carrer.descripcio: One of the old water-courses that crossed the town of Gràcia.
carrer.anteriors: Menéndez Pelayo; T. de la Olla

carrer.name: Torrent de Mariner, Carrer del
carrer.descripcio: It adopts the name of the property near the Travessera de Gràcia.
carrer.anteriors: T. de Mariné; T. del Coll del Portell

carrer.name: Torrent de Perera, Carrer del
carrer.descripcio: Named in this way because it crosses the lands of the property of the person whose surname this was.

carrer.name: Torrent del Remei, Carrer del
carrer.descripcio: In Vallcarca. This water-course descends from the Coll de Portell.

carrer.name: Torrent d'en Vidalet, Carrer del
carrer.descripcio: Named after Can Vidalet, a manor house.

carrer.name: Torres, Carrer de les
carrer.descripcio: It is named 'torres' for two reasons. In the first place because Joaquim Maria de Torres i de Fuentes (Barcelona 1785 - 1850), a landowner and head taxation inspector, was the proprietor of the greater part of the land which the street crosses. He married Francesca de Paula Cuyàs. In the second place the dedication comes from a popular source, because of the large metal towers which were situated in the middle of the street, with a square concrete base that stood 4.60 meters high. These towers sustained high-tension electrical wires.

carrer.name: Torres, Passatge de
carrer.descripcio: A lane known as "de les Torres" when it was opened in the Travessera, Torrent Pregon or Lligalbé lands, in reference to the stately homes still existing in that place..

carrer.name: Torres de Marina, Carrer de
carrer.descripcio: Small country houses built in the Marina de Sants area. They suggested the idea of giving the street the name that it has.
carrer.anteriors: Teresa Claramunt, 13/01/1933; Lletra B (b. del Puente de las Vacas)

carrer.name: Torres i Amat, Carrer de
carrer.descripcio: Fèlix Torres i Amat de Palou (Sallent de Llobregat, Bages 1772 - Madrid 1847). Ecclesiastic and writer. Canon in Barcelona, and a member of the Academy of Fine Letters (1816). Bishop of Astorga. Senator for Barcelona (1837 and 1840). He translated the Bible into Spanish.

carrer.name: Torres i Clavé, Jardins de
carrer.descripcio: Josep Torres i Clavé (Barcelona 1906 - Ebro war front 1939). Architect. One of the founders of the GATCPAC. He was a great master of Catalan architectural rationalism.

carrer.name: Torretes, Passatge de les
carrer.descripcio: A street whose first three houses are torretes, small country houses.

carrer.name: Torrevieja, Carrer de
carrer.descripcio: It owes its name to Torrevieja, a municipality of the Baix Segura region of Catalonia. The name "Torrevella", previously approved, was altered at the request of the Council of that city.

carrer.name: Torrijos, Carrer de
carrer.descripcio: José María Torrijos (Madrid 1791 - Málaga 1831). Castilian soldier and politician. He fought in the War of Independence against the French.

carrer.name: Torroella de Montgrí, Carrer de
carrer.descripcio: It owes its name to Torroella de Montgrí, a municipality of the Baix Empordà region of Catalonia.

carrer.name: Tort, Carrer de
carrer.descripcio: A lineage of proprietors which began with Antoni Tort i Torrents, deceased in 1862. He was succeeded by his son Marià Tort i Espigulé, who had the land built on in 1889. His heir was the grandson of Antoni, and was called Antoni Tort i Cuyàs.

carrer.name: Tortellà, Carrer de
carrer.descripcio: It owes its name to Tortellà, a municipality of the Garrotxa region of Catalonia. The street was opened in the lands of the Prat de n'Aloi estate, in the place known as "el Joncar". Its owner was Lambert de Fontanelles i Sala, Marquis of Casa Fontanelles.

carrer.name: Tortosa, Carrer de
carrer.descripcio: It owes its name to Tortosa, a city in the Baix Ebre region of Catalonia. Seat of the Iberian settlement which was the center of the large territory of the 'Ilergavonii'. The Roman conquerors called the place 'Iulia Ilergavonia Dertosa'. Conquered by the Arabs in 713 - 718, it became a 'taifa' capital until its conquest by the Almoravids in 1099. It was conquered in 1148 by Ramon Berenguer IV, Guillem Ramon de Montcada - the Grand Seneschal - Guillaume de Montpellier, a Genose fleet, and the Knights Templars.

carrer.name: Tossa, Carrer de
carrer.descripcio: It owes its name to Tossa de Mar, a municipality of the Selva region of Catalonia.

carrer.name: Tossa, Passatge de
carrer.descripcio: It owes its name to Tossa de Mar, a municipality of the La Selva region of Catalonia.

carrer.name: Tossal, Carrer del
carrer.descripcio: Named in this way because it was opened in lands that rose slightly from a surrounding flat area.

carrer.name: Tots Sants, Avinguda de
carrer.descripcio: All Saints. Thoroughfare in the Rectoret neighborhood, where in most cases the names were given to the streets by the residents.

carrer.name: Tous, Carrer de
carrer.descripcio: Nicolau Tous i Miralpeix (Barcelona 1817 - 1893). Promoter of Catalan industrial expansion. One of the founders of the factory known as La Maquinista Terrestre i Marítima.

carrer.name: Tradició, Carrer de la
carrer.descripcio: Name given to the street "because of the affection of the people of Sarrià for their particular traditions".
carrer.anteriors: Tradición; Tradición (Town Hall of Sarrià); San Benito

carrer.name: Trafalgar, Carrer de
carrer.descripcio: The naval battle (21st October 1805) between the English and the combined French and Spanish fleets, which took place near the Cape of Trafalgar. The victory of the former meant the beginning of England's maritime predominance.

carrer.name: Tragí, Carrer del
carrer.descripcio: Named in this way because there existed in the street an entrance-point for carts, and this entrance made way for carting to and from ('tragí') the Convent of Santa Caterina, which no longer exists.

carrer.name: Traginers, Plaça dels
carrer.descripcio: The name comes from the fact that in this place muleteers and carters were living, and that there had been a guild-house of the three trades dedicated to transport and to toing and froing in general, namely, the Ribera laborers, those who hired mules, and carters.

carrer.name: Trajà, Carrer de
carrer.descripcio: Marcus Ulpius Traianus (Italica, Hispania 53 - Rome AD 117). Roman Emperor. He was a general and the legate to Germania Superior.

carrer.name: Trajana, Via
carrer.descripcio: In homage to Trajan.

carrer.name: Tramuntana, Carrer de la
carrer.descripcio: It owes its name to the Tramuntana, the wind from the north, which makes its presence felt on account of the north-south direction of the street.

carrer.name: Transvaal, Plaça del
carrer.descripcio: It owes its name to the Transvaal, a province of South Africa.

carrer.name: Transversal, Passatge
carrer.descripcio: It crosses perpendicularly the streets of the Colònia Castells in the middle of the former property.

carrer.name: Trapani, Carrer de
carrer.descripcio: It owes its name to Trapani, a city of Sicily and a port which, in the Middle Ages, like Palermo or the Sardinian ports of Cagliari and Alghero, was one of the final points on the route of the isles, one of the bases of the maritime commerce of Barcelona and a stage in voyages to the Levant.

carrer.name: Travau, Carrer de
carrer.descripcio: It owes its name to Travau, a neighborhood and former village within the boundaries of Sant Sadurní de l'Heura in the Baix Empordà region of Catalonia. The street belongs to the Ramon Albó group of buildings, where the thoroughfares are dedicated in the main to places and villages in the province of Girona.

carrer.name: Travessera, Passatge de la
carrer.descripcio: A former stretch of the pathway that connected the road from Barcelona to Horta with the Sant Andreu pathway.

carrer.name: Travessia, Carrer de la
carrer.descripcio: A short street between the Carrer de la Costa and the Avinguda de la República Argentina. The creation of this thoroughfare meant the division of a long, narrow block of buildings, and facilitated communication, crosswise, between the above-mentioned streets.

carrer.name: Treball, Passatge del
carrer.descripcio: Named in this way because it opens onto the street which bears that name.

carrer.name: Treball, Carrer del
carrer.descripcio: In homage to labor.

carrer.name: Trelawny, Carrer de
carrer.descripcio: Henry Trelawny, an English officer engaged in the defense of Barcelona in the War of Spanish Succession (1705). His father gave the name of Barcelona to a place in Cornwall.

carrer.name: Trèmol, Carrer del
carrer.descripcio: It owes its name to the poplar tree. It forms part of a group of streets with the names of trees and plants.

carrer.name: Tremp, Carrer de
carrer.descripcio: It owes its name to Tremp, a municipality in the Pallars Jussà region of Catalonia.

carrer.name: Tren, Carrer del
carrer.descripcio: It leads to the railway station of Les Planes.

carrer.name: Trens de La Maquinista, Carrer dels
carrer.descripcio: In reference to the locomotives constructed by the firm called La Maquinista Terrestre i Marítima, which was established in this place in Sant Andreu from 1917 to 1991. The street is situated in the interior of the commercial center, between the Carrer de Sâo Paulo and the Passeig de Potosí.

carrer.name: Tres Creus, Carrer de les
carrer.descripcio: Three iron crosses marked the station of Calvary in the Way of the Cross that was established here in the eighteenth century. There exists an explanation of the name that is known through oral tradition and refers to three casualties in a battle between peasant farmers from Sant Andreu and Montcada, who were buried in this place with a cross signifying each dead man.

carrer.name: Tres Llits, Carrer dels
carrer.descripcio: Corruption of 'tres lleis', previously'Trium Legem', referring to the jurisdictions of the parishes of Santa Maria del Pi, Sant Jaume, and Sant Miquel (Pi i Arimon). Bofarull thinks that the name comes from a brothel, the most popular of the many that existed in the street. Other sources derive the name from 'tras litg', the change of law on the part of the Jews who converted to Christianity.

carrer.name: Tres Pins, Carrer dels
carrer.descripcio: Toponym referring to a popular area with three pine-trees and a fountain, where afternoon refreshments and outdoor meals were enjoyed. There used to be a shanty town here.

carrer.name: Tres Reis, Carrer dels
carrer.descripcio: Name of a tavern which had three kings as its sign: the king of spades, the king of diamonds, and the king of hearts, making it clear that the king of clubs was the owner of the tavern, as he used to exhibit at times of uproar - which were frequent in the tavern - a magnificent club in order to restore order.

carrer.name: Tres Senyores, Carrer de les
carrer.descripcio: The wives of Torrente, Masens and Rabassa: Mercè Frígola i Poch, Teresa Rabassa i Puig and Teresa Batet, respectively. On 29th April 1861 the said Torrente, Masens, and Rabassa acquired three blocks of land proceeding from the Alegre de Dalt estate. When the property was built on, the three men agreed to dedicate a street each to their wives. Given the proximity of the Carrer de Martí, some documents mention that the person involved was the wife of Martí. However, Ramon Martí i Dalius died in 1853 and his son Ramon Martí d'Eixalà in 1857, long before the purchase of the land and the launching of the urban development project.

carrer.name: Tres Torres, Carrer de les
carrer.descripcio: Toponym given because of the first three stately homes built in this place.
carrer.anteriors: Regina Pacis; Tres Torres; Regina Pacis; Parthenón; Virgen del Rosario (Town Hall of Sarrià)

carrer.name: Tres Torres, Jardí de les
carrer.descripcio: In the 'Catàleg de la sèrie de llicències d'obres particulars dels fons documentals dels antics pobles agregats de Sarrià i Vallvidrera de 1845 a 1922' reference is made to a permit for Messrs. Mas and Romaní to have three houses constructed in the lands adjacent to the Carrer Paralelo (Via Augusta) and the Carrer Pomaret (Doctor Roux) by the architect Bonaventura Conill, in 1903. From the Ronda del General Mitre the three houses could be discerned before their demolition.

carrer.name: Tres Xemeneies, Jardins de les
carrer.descripcio: In reference to the three emblematic chimneys in the Paral·lel of Barcelona.

carrer.name: Trèvol, Carrer del
carrer.descripcio: It owes its name to the clover plant. The genus of herbaceous plants with leaves having three lobes.

carrer.name: Triangle, Carrer del
carrer.descripcio: It forms a triangle with the Carrer del Corretger and the Carrer del Rec. The triangular block was authorized to be built in the mid-eighteenth century: it was the result of the demolition of houses occasioned by the construction of the Ciutadella fortress.

carrer.name: Trias i Giró, Carrer de
carrer.descripcio: Joan de Déu Trias i Giró (Barcelona 1859 - 1914). Jurist. Professor of International Law at the University of Barcelona. Defender of Catalan law.
carrer.anteriors: Juan de Dios Trías Giró; Rioja; Núm. 57 (Les Corts)

carrer.name: Trilla, Carrer de
carrer.descripcio: Antoni Trilla i Trilla (Lleida, Segrià 1741 - Barcelona 1801). Lawyer in the Royal Audience. Advocate of the poor. Widower after his first marriage with Magdalena Escarabatxeras i Blanch and married a second time to Francesca Pérez i Nogués, the widow of Xuclà. Proprietor of the lands on which the street was opened. Dedicated by his daughter-in-law Àgata Badia i Puigrodon when the Casa del Simó property underwent urban development.

carrer.name: Trilla, Plaça de
carrer.descripcio: Antoni Trilla i Escarabatxeras (Lleida, Segrià 1769 - Barcelona 1824). Lawyer and proprietor of the land on which the square was opened. He used to sign his name using the second surname of his mother: Blanch, instead of Escarabatxeras. In 1825 his widow requested the urban development of the Casa del Simó estate which afterwards was known as "Torre Trilla". The square was to be called Sant Antoni after the baptismal name of her husband, in the same way as she had the Carrer de Santa Àgata called after her. There were constant changes in the name of the square: it was called Reina Amàlia - after the third wife of Fernando VII - and Sant Antoni. Subsequent to the death of the former queen, it was called Reina Cristina, who was the fourth wife of Fernando VII. After the abdication of this queen the name of the square ended up being Trilla. We have respected the previous Sant Antoni as it seems that the intention was to dedicate the square to the husband of Àgata: Antoni Trilla.
carrer.anteriors: Reina Cristina, 1836; Sant Antoni, 1825 ?; Reina Amàlia, 1824 ?

carrer.name: Trillo, Carrer de
carrer.descripcio: It owes its name to Trillo, a municipality in the province of Guadalajara.

carrer.name: Trinitat, Carrer de la
carrer.descripcio: The name recalls the existence of the monastery of la Trinitat, of the Calced Trinitarian monks, today the church of Sant Jaume.

carrer.name: Trinitat, Plaça de la
carrer.descripcio: Named after the neighborhood of Barcelona that goes by this name. Toponym documented in 1260 and referring to the name of a hermitage placed under this advocation. It is mentioned in documents of the fifteenth and sixteenth centuries. The French burnt it down in 1808.

carrer.name: Trinitat, Nus de la
carrer.descripcio: Named after the neighborhood, an ancient toponym documented in 1260 referring to the name of a hermitage on the nearby hill of Finestrelles.

carrer.name: Trinquet, Carrer del
carrer.descripcio: The name recalls the former hand-ball court of Sarrià.
carrer.anteriors: Trinquete; Fleca; Trinquete; Fleca (Town Hall of Sarrià); Estrella, before 1888

carrer.name: Trinxant, Carrer de
carrer.descripcio: Francesc Trinxant i Morera (? 1793 - Martorell, Baix Llobregat 1871). Proprietor of the estate where the street was opened. He was succeeded by his son Josep Trinxant i Casamitjana (1825 - 1907), his grandson Pere Trinxant i Reixach, and finally Josep Trinxant i Bertran. The lands had been the property of the Marquis of Castellbell.
carrer.anteriors: Castilla (2nd section); Trinxant, before 1869; Núm. 51 (Cerdà plan)

carrer.name: Tripó, Carrer d'en
carrer.descripcio: A Catalan family surname, by which were known at least two streets of the old Barcelona: the one called "d'en Tripó de l'Àngel", which came out of the Portal de l'Àngel, and another called "d'en Tripó de Rere Palau", which today has the name without the additions which served to locate the street. In documents of the fourteenth century the Carrer d'en Tripó is already mentioned.

carrer.name: Trobador, Carrer del
carrer.descripcio: The name was probably given to the street in memory of the romantic drama of Antonio García Gutiérrez, 'El trovador', which supplied the subject-matter of 'Il trovatore', by Verdi.

carrer.name: Trompetes, Carrer de les
carrer.descripcio: In this street the town criers lived.

carrer.name: Trompetes de Jaume I, Carrer de les
carrer.descripcio: The two streets in Barcelona with the name of 'trompetes' refer to the salaried trumpeters or town criers who, with the appropriate authorization, shouted news around the neighborhood.

carrer.name: Trueba, Carrer de
carrer.descripcio: Antonio de Trueba y de la Quintana (Montellano, Vizcaya 1819 - Bilbao 1889). Basque poet and narrator of local customs, in the Spanish language.

carrer.name: Trullàs, Passatge de
carrer.descripcio: Jacint Trullàs i Payarol, manufacturer. Last century, a certain neighborhood was called "d'en Trullàs" or "d'en Trulla".

carrer.name: Trullols, Carrer de
carrer.descripcio: Street opened on lands which belonged to the Mas Besora estate of the Gualba family. At the time of this edition's going to press, it has not been possible to identify the supposed person whose surname was Trullols.

carrer.name: Tubella, Carrer de
carrer.descripcio: Joan Tubella i Soler (Igualada, Anoia 1877 - Barcelona 1925). Proprietor of the lands on which the lane was opened, and, by extension, the street.

carrer.name: Tubella, Passatge de
carrer.descripcio: Named for the same reason as is the street that it extends. Both thoroughfares are separated by the Carrer de Novell.

carrer.name: Tucumán, Carrer de
carrer.descripcio: It owes its name to Tucumán, a province in the northern part of the Argentine Republic. The street belongs to the Bon Pastor industrial estate, where the thoroughfares are dedicated to cities and places in Latin America.

carrer.name: Tulipa, Plaça de la
carrer.descripcio: Urban area in the Rectoret neighborhood, where numerous thoroughfares are dedicated to plants and flowers.

carrer.name: Túria, Carrer del
carrer.descripcio: It owes its name to the Túria, a Mediterranean river of the Iberian Peninsula. The street is one of a group dedicated to rivers: Segura, Jalón, Nerbión, Guadalquivir and Guadalete, in the same Polvorí neighborhood.

carrer.name: Turó, Carrer del
carrer.descripcio: The name corresponds to the situation of the street, which from the Carrer del Mont d'Orsa ascends to a small hill.

carrer.name: Turó Blau, Carrer del
carrer.descripcio: As in the previous case, but with a popular adjective, "blau". The former name of a mountain in the Collserola range.

carrer.name: Turó de la Peira, Parc del
carrer.descripcio: In reference to the Ca la Peira farmhouse which stood on the slope of the hill that belonged to the Marquis of Castellbell.

carrer.name: Turó de la Rovira, Carrer del
carrer.descripcio: A hill situated next to the domains of Pere Labèrnia i Carreras, the owner of the place.

carrer.name: Turó de la Trinitat, Plaça del
carrer.descripcio: Named after the Trinitat neighborhood.

carrer.name: Turó de la Trinitat, Carrer del
carrer.descripcio: Named after the Trinitat neighborhood, in reference to an ancient toponym documented in the year 1260.
carrer.anteriors: Cerro de la Trinidad; General Villacampa; Trinidad

carrer.name: Turó de l'Alzina, Camí del
carrer.descripcio: Pathway which gives access to the hill by this name.

carrer.name: Turó de Monterols, Carrer del
carrer.descripcio: Name of a hill documented in 987.

carrer.name: Turó del Puig, Camí del
carrer.descripcio: A pathway that begins at the crossroads formed by the Sant Cugat and the Salze pathways and which leads to the summit of the Turó del Puig, in that part of the mountain belonging to the Sarrià-Sant Gervasi district.

carrer.name: Turó del Putget, Jardins del
carrer.descripcio: Named after the place that we find written in various ways: 'Putxet', 'Puget' and 'Puixet', all of which are diminutive derivatives of 'puig' (from the Latin 'podium', mountain).

carrer.name: Turull, Passeig de
carrer.descripcio: Pere Turull i Comadran (Sabadell, Vallès Occidental 1852 - Barcelona 1924). Proprietor of the lands from the end of the nineteenth century, which he divided up into a magnificent wooded place.

carrer.name: Tuset, Carrer de
carrer.descripcio: The name comes from the Camp d'en Tuset, an old farmhouse and property. According to CC, 'Tusset' instead of 'Tuset'.

carrer.name: U, Carrer
carrer.descripcio: A street in the industrial estate of the Consortium of Barcelona's Zona Franca, where streets named after letters follow a North-South direction, and those after numbers, an East-West direction, with an odd exception.

carrer.name: Ullastre, Carrer de l'
carrer.descripcio: Named after this shrub (). A street in the Rectoret neighborhood, where there are a number of thoroughfares dedicated to plants and shrubs.

carrer.name: Ulldecona, Carrer d'
carrer.descripcio: Named after Ulldecona, a municipality of the Montsià region of Catalonia. The street belongs to the Eduard Aunós group of buildings, where the thoroughfares are dedicated to places and villages in Catalonia.

carrer.name: Unió, Carrer de la
carrer.descripcio: This street had been projected to link the Carrer del Marquès de Barberà with the Rambla dels Caputxins around 1836-1840. According to Roca i Comas, the name would "appear to respond to the yearning for unity and the end of the frequent and tragic quarrels of the time". But according to a municipal document, it refers to the Conde de la Unión, Luís Fermín de Carvajal y Vargas, who had been Governor and Captain-General of the Region, President of the Audiència (Barcelona High Court) and Head General of the Army of the Roussillon - a version considered to be more accurate.

carrer.name: Unió, Plaça de la
carrer.descripcio: The name is already documented in 1856. It is dedicated to the Unión Liberal political party. Francesc Castanys and Rafael Degollada, renowned leaders of the party, were owners of the land where the square was created.

carrer.name: Unitat, Parc de la
carrer.descripcio: A public area inside the block delimited by the streets named Canigó, Lloret de Mar, and Eduard Toda, and by the Passeig de Valldaura. The name was chosen out of a desire to unite the two neighborhood residents' associations, which, for political reasons, were traditionally opposed to one another.

carrer.name: Univers, Plaça de l'
carrer.descripcio: This name was given to this square on the occasion of the inauguration of the International Exhibition of 1929.

carrer.name: Universal, Passeig
carrer.descripcio: Simply an ambitious adjective. The opening of the street was approved in 1915.

carrer.name: Universitat, Ronda de la
carrer.descripcio: Built circa 1872 near the lands of the slopes of the Tallers Wall. Its name comes from the fact that it leads to Plaça Universitat.

carrer.name: Universitat, Plaça de la
carrer.descripcio: Named after the University building which presides over the square. The building is by Elies Rogent and was built in 1874. In 1536, the City Council (Consell de Cent) agreed to build the 'Estudi General' or University at the top of the Rambla, where the different faculties till then dispersed among the various lodgings of the Carrer Ripoll were brought together. Its activity progressed till 1714, when Philip V turned the building into an army barracks and forcibly moved the University to the city of Cervera. Barcelona regained its university in 1837, provisionally housing it in the Convent del Carme, until 1874.

carrer.name: Urani, Carrer de l'
carrer.descripcio: Named after the metal Uranium. The city's Urban Planning Commission approved the partial plan for Gran Via Sud, which basically developed the land devoted to industrial use. A series of streets were dedicated to materials of a similar nature, with industrial terms like steel, bronze, iron, lead, etc.

carrer.name: Ureña, Passatge d'
carrer.descripcio: Street opened through the land which used to be owned by Anselm Riu Fontanillas. At the time of going to press it has not yet been possible to identify the person after whom this street is named.

carrer.name: Urquinaona, Plaça d'
carrer.descripcio: José María Urquinaona y Bidot (Cadiz 1813 - Barcelona 1883). Bishop of Barcelona from 1878 to 1883. The square was built after the demolition of the bulwarks of Sant Pere and Jonqueres (1857). Its initial name, owing to the proximity of the square to the latter bulwark, was "Plaça Nova de Jonqueres".
carrer.anteriors: Obispo Urquinaona; Urquinaona; Ferrer y Guardia; Francisco Ferrer y Guardia; Urquinaona; Obispo Urquinaona; Nueva de Junqueras

carrer.name: Urrutia, Passeig d'
carrer.descripcio: José de Urrutia y de las Casas (Zalla-La Herrera, Viscaya 1739 - Madrid 1803). Army officer of Basque origin. Captain-General of Catalonia from 1794 to 1796. He reorganized the armed City Defenders corps throughout the Principality. He succeeded in ending the so called War of the First Coalition (1795). The farmstead in Badalona popularly known as "Can Ruti" was built by his father, the nobleman Juan de Urrutia.

carrer.name: Uruguai, Carrer de l'
carrer.descripcio: Named after the Latin American republic of the same name. It forms a group with the Carrer del Riu de la Plata, in the same El Coll neighborhood.

carrer.name: Utset, Passatge d'
carrer.descripcio: Josep Utset i Fonullà (Mataró, Maresme 1839 - Barcelona 1904). Silversmith. Married to Anna Romans i Jordà, proprietress of the land apportioned to her by her mother Francesca Jordà i Gelabert and her brother Eugeni in 1873. The land that used to belong to the Torre Xica estate had been previously owned by Ramon de Sentmenat i de Saenz, Marquis of Castelldosrius.

carrer.name: V, Carrer
carrer.descripcio: A street in the industrial estate of the Consortium of Barcelona's Zona Franca, where, with only a few exceptions, the streets named with letters follow a north-south direction, and those with names an east-west direction.

carrer.name: Vacarisses, Carrer de
carrer.descripcio: It owes its name to Vacarisses, a municipality in the Vallès Occidental region of Catalonia. The street belongs to the Torre Baró neighborhood, where the majority of the thoroughfares are dedicated to villages and places in Catalonia.

carrer.name: Valdivia, Plaça de
carrer.descripcio: It owes its name to Valdivia, a city of Chile and the capital of the province by the same name. The proprietors of Can Segalar had had some relationship with this city.

carrer.name: València, Carrer de
carrer.descripcio: It owes its name to Valencia, the principal city of the autonomous region by that name and the second main city in the Països Catalans, the territories historically associated with the Catalan language and Catalan culture. Valencia was conquered by King Jaume I in 1238, who created institutions proper to the city and parallel to those in Catalonia. He also repopulated the land with Catalans from the western zone of the Principality.

carrer.name: Valent Petit, Jardins del
carrer.descripcio: Named after a former farmhouse in La Bordeta.

carrer.name: Valentí Almirall, Plaça de
carrer.descripcio: Valentí Almirall i Llozer (Barcelona 1841 - 1904). Politician and writer. One of the most important figures in the political resurgence of Catalonia. In 1879 he began to publish 'El Diari català', the first newspaper in the Catalan language.

carrer.name: Valentí Iglésias, Carrer de
carrer.descripcio: Valentí Iglésias i Riera (Sant Martí Sesgueioles, Anoia 1844 - Barcelona 1916). Proprietor of the lands where the street was opened. His son Valentí Iglésias i Abelló, who died in 1966, was district councilor in 1922 and 1930.

carrer.name: Valeri Serra, Passatge de
carrer.descripcio: Valeri Serra i Boldú (Castellserà, Urgell 1875 - Barcelona 1938). A researcher into folklore, and a publicist. Creator of the Arxiu de Tradicions Populars (1928).

carrer.name: Valero, Carrer dels
carrer.descripcio: Family of Spanish actors associated with the theater: José (Seville 1808 - Barcelona 1891) his son Ricardo and the sister and brother of José, Josefa and Isidoro (the latter died in Barcelona in 1906).

carrer.name: Valeta d'Arquer, Carrer de
carrer.descripcio: Josep Valeta d'Arquer (Arenys de Mar, Maresme 1876 - Barcelona 1947). Lawyer. Proprietor of the lands that he turned over to urban development in the former estate of the Fontcuberta-Dalmases family.

carrer.name: Valira, Carrer de la
carrer.descripcio: Approved as Carrer de Balira, it is really Valira, a tributary of the Segre river flowing into it from its right-hand side, in Andorra.

carrer.name: Vall d'Aran, Carrer de la
carrer.descripcio: It owes its name to the Vall d'Aran, a valley in the Pyrenees in the far north-west of Catalonia. County of the Principality.
carrer.anteriors: Valle de Arán, 1939; Vall d'Aran, 05/09/1907; Merced

carrer.name: Vall d'Aro, Carrer de la
carrer.descripcio: It owes its name to the Vall d'Aro, a valley in the Baix Empordà region of Catalonia.

carrer.name: Vall d'Hebron, Parc de la
carrer.descripcio: Named for the same reason as is the boulevard. It corresponds to a wide area which, in 1987, was given over principally to sporting uses for the celebration of the Olympic Games of 1992.

carrer.name: Vall d'Hebron, Plaça de la
carrer.descripcio: Named for the same reason as is the boulevard.

carrer.name: Vall d'Hebron, Passeig de la
carrer.descripcio: Named after the monastery of Sant Jeroni de la Vall d'Hebron, which was promoted by Violant de Bar, and which existed between 1313 and 1835. King Fernando and Queen Isabel, known as 'Los Reyes Católicos', lodged there at one time.
carrer.anteriors: Valle de Hebrón; Ctra. Cornellá a Fogás de Tordera (a section)

carrer.name: Vall d'Ordesa, Carrer de la
carrer.descripcio: It owes its name to the Vall d'Ordesa, a valley of the Pyrenees, in Aragon.

carrer.name: Valladolid, Carrer de
carrer.descripcio: It owes its name to Valladolid, a city in Castile-Leon.

carrer.name: Vallbona, Avinguda de
carrer.descripcio: The Vallbona estate. It was previously known as Jorba. An historic feudal property. A direct dominion of the Marquis de la Manresana which passed into the hands of Manuel Maria de Sivatte i Llopart

carrer.name: Vallcarca, Avinguda de
carrer.anteriors: Ra. de Vallcarca; Ra. de Andala, Av de l'Hospital Militar 7/07/1942

carrer.name: Vallcarca, Viaducte de
carrer.descripcio: It stretches over the Vallcarca channel, which name is a contraction of 'vall càrcara' or narrow valley, through which flows the Merdançà water-course.

carrer.name: Vallcivera, Carrer de
carrer.descripcio: Glacial valley of the Baixa Cerdanya region of Catalonia (Lles). A street in the Ciutat Meridiana neighborhood, where the thoroughfares are dedicated, in the main, to places and geographical names of places of Catalonia.

carrer.name: Valldaura, Passeig de
carrer.descripcio: This name was given in memory of the former Cistercian monastery in the municipality of Cerdanyola del Vallès, on the northern slopes of the Collserola range, at the extreme of the Barcelona municipal boundary. It was a royal residence of King Jaume II.
carrer.anteriors: Ctra. Cornellá a Fogás de Tordera (a section)

carrer.name: Valldemossa, Carrer de
carrer.descripcio: It owes its name to Valldemossa, a municipality in the west of the island of Majorca

carrer.name: Valldonzella, Carrer de
carrer.descripcio: It recalls the Royal Monastery of Santa Maria de Valldonzella for Cistercian nuns, established in the former Casa de Natzaret as of 1670. It was burnt down in the disturbances of the Setmana Tràgica (Tragic Week) in 1909.

carrer.name: Valldoreix, Carrer de
carrer.descripcio: It owes its name to Valldoreix, a place in the municipality of Sant Cugat del Vallès. Traditional name derived from 'Vall Aurex' or 'Aurexio', of the tenth or eleventh century. A necessary replacement of the form 'Valldoreig', incorrect in spelling and in pronunciation.
carrer.anteriors: San Cugat del Vallés (1st section); San Vicente

carrer.name: Vallès, Carrer del
carrer.descripcio: It owes its name to the Vallès, a Catalan County, divided between Vallès Oriental and Vallès Occidental.

carrer.name: Vallès i Ribot, Carrer de
carrer.descripcio: Josep Maria Vallès i Ribot (Barcelona 1849 - 1911). Lawyer and Republican federalist politician. Deputy in the Constitutional Parliament (1873). President of the Centre Federalista. Founder of the 'El Federalista', 'La Voz de Cataluña' and 'La Región Catalana' newspapers.
carrer.anteriors: Dalmacio de Mur; Vallès y Ribot, 29/03/1922; Emporitana (without effectiveness); Santa Lucía

carrer.name: Vallespir, Carrer del
carrer.descripcio: It owes its name to the Vallespir, a county in the former Catalan territories in Southern France. It recalls the viscounty of Vallespir, of which Guillem I (died at some time after 1028), Viscount of Vallespir and of Castellnou, was a representative.
carrer.anteriors: Vallespir, 05/09/1907; Ctra. de les Corts; Colón (before 1877)

carrer.name: Vallfogona, Carrer de
carrer.descripcio: Vallfogona de Riucorb. A municipality of the Conca de Barberà region of Catalonia.

carrer.name: Vallhonrat, Carrer de
carrer.descripcio: A lineage of proprietors of the lands in this place. Pau Vallhonrat i Font (1763 - 1838), a farmer of the Marina d'Hospitalet neighborhood. Gabriel Vallhonrat i Casas (1797 - 1870). Joan Vallhonrat i Soler (Cornellà de Llobregat, Baix Llobregat 1839 - 1910). It is thought that the street is named after Gabriel Vallhonrat, as the name of the thoroughfare is documented very shortly after his death.

carrer.name: Vallirana, Carrer de
carrer.descripcio: It owes its name to Vallirana, a municipality of the Baix Llobregat region of Catalonia.

carrer.name: Vallmajor, Carrer de
carrer.descripcio: Rosa Vallmajor i Canet (Dosrius, Maresme 1778 - ?), wife of Magí Modolell i Negrevernis, proprietor of the land where the street was opened.

carrer.name: Vallmitjana, Carrer de
carrer.descripcio: Agapit Vallmitjana i Barbany (Barcelona 1833 - 1905). Sculptor. He created works for the 'Cementiri Vell', or Poblenou cemetery. According to RiC, the street was originally known as Carrer dels Vallmitjana, thereby honoring both Agapit Vallmitjana and his brother Venanci (Barcelona 1829 - 1919), the latter being the author of, among other works, the statues of Ramon Llull, St Isidore, and Averroes, that are situated in the vestibule of the University of Barcelona.

carrer.name: Vallpar, Carrer de
carrer.descripcio: Toponym for the Vallpar spring, renowned for the quantity of water that it gives.

carrer.name: Valls, Carrer de
carrer.descripcio: It owes its name to Valls, a municipality in the Alt Camp region of Catalonia.

carrer.name: Vallseca, Carrer de
carrer.descripcio: Gabriel de Vallseca (Barcelona ? - Majorca, fifteenth century). Cartographer and painter of Jewish origin. Maps of the world signed by him are conserved in Barcelona (1439), Paris (1447), and Florence (1449).

carrer.name: Vallseca, Passatge de
carrer.descripcio: Named for the same reason as is the street.

carrer.name: Vallvidrera, Avinguda de
carrer.descripcio: It leads to the neighborhood of Barcelona situated on the slopes of the Collserola range.

carrer.name: Vallvidrera, Plaça de
carrer.descripcio: The central square of the neighborhood, a former municipality incorporated into Sarrià in 1890 and, together with the latter, into Barcelona in 1921. The toponym Vallvidrera dates from at least the tenth century (987): certain documents of that year mention 'Sancta Maria Vallis Vitrariae'.

carrer.name: Vallvidrera, Drecera de
carrer.descripcio: It leads to the former village of Vallvidrera of the Barcelona municipality, in the Collserola range.
carrer.anteriors: C. del Atajo de Vallvidrera; Vallvidrera; Vallvidrera (Town Hall of Sarrià); Cº de la Costa

carrer.name: Vallvidrera, Camí de
carrer.descripcio: In reference to the former village of Vallvidrera.

carrer.name: Vallvidrera a Barcelona, Carretera de
carrer.descripcio: A road which joins the Sant Cugat road before descending to the city of Barcelona.

carrer.name: Vallvidrera a les Planes, Carretera de
carrer.descripcio: From the nucleus of Vallvidrera to Les Planes and the Rectoret neighborhood.

carrer.name: Vallvidrera al Tibidabo, Carretera de
carrer.descripcio: It goes along the crest of the Collserola range.

carrer.name: Vallvidrera al Tibidabo, Camí de
carrer.descripcio: Pathway along the crest.

carrer.name: Vapor Vell, Passatge del
carrer.descripcio: Literally, "The Old Textile Steam Mill", which is a tribute to the textile factory set up by Joan Güell in 1846, which specialized in corduroy cloth. It was called "old" in opposition to the Espanya Industrial Factory which was built later. It was productive until 1891, when, owing to labor conflicts, it had to close down and move to Santa Coloma de Cervelló.

carrer.name: Varsòvia, Carrer de
carrer.descripcio: It owes its name to the Polish city of Warsaw, the capital of the state.

carrer.name: Vayreda, Carrer de
carrer.descripcio: Joaquim Vayreda i Vila (Girona 1843 - Olot, La Garrotxa 1894). Painter. Founder of the Olot school. President of the first Assemblea Catalanista de Manresa (1892) and founder of the Centre Catalanista. He was a councilor for Barcelona.

carrer.name: Vázquez de Mella, Plaça de
carrer.descripcio: Juan Vázquez de Mella y Fanjul (Cangas de Onís 1861 - Madrid 1928). Lawyer, traditionalist politician, and writer. A great and brilliant orator.

carrer.name: Veciana, Carrer de
carrer.descripcio: Municipality of the Anoia region of Catalonia. The street forms a group with the others named Cardedeu, Manlleu, Palou, Capellades, and Montornès, in the same neighborhood. In the 1980 nomenclature, it was dedicated to Pere Anton Veciana i Rabassa (Sarral, Conca de Barberà 1677 - Valls, Alt Camp 1736). Mayor of Valls. Founder of the Esquadres de Catalunya (the corps which evolved into the 'Mossos d'Esquadra', the Catalan police force).

carrer.name: Veguer, Carrer del
carrer.descripcio: In the Middle Ages, this was an authority delegated from the Crown, with governmental, administrative, and judicial jurisdiction.

carrer.name: Vehils, Carrer de
carrer.descripcio: The lands where the street was opened were part of the area known as "Les basses de Sant Joan". These lands belonged to the Grassot family, and had previously been the property of the Marquis of Castelldosrius. The street seems to have been dedicated to Joaquim Maria Vehils i Fuchs (Barcelona 1857 - 1934). Musician. Conductor and also impresario of the Barcelona Liceu Opera House. It has not been possible definitively to prove this dedication.

carrer.name: Velázquez, Carrer de
carrer.descripcio: Diego Rodríguez de Silva y Velázquez (Seville 1599 - Madrid 1660). Painter of the Seville school. He was nominated Court Painter (1623), chamberlain of the king in 1643, and superintendent of the private works of the Crown (1644). Member of the San Luca Academy of Rome.

carrer.name: Vèlia, Carrer de
carrer.descripcio: Velia was a city in Magna Graecia, originally called Elea. As a consequence of the Greek maritime supremacy, the penetration of Greek commerce and culture into the Iberian Peninsula was very notable over a period of some three or four hundred years. The street is dedicated to the Hispanic Velia which, according to Claudius Ptolomeus, was situated in the north of the peninsula, in a strip of territory between the cities of Oviedo and Victoria. The exact site has not been found, but it is known that the city minted coins. The coinage is classified as Iberian, and is stamped with the name 'Kueliokos,' the Iberian translation of Velia. The figures of two dolphins which figure on the coins are of note in their proceeding from an inland people who in theory had never seen the sea.

carrer.name: Vell de la Pedrera, Camí
carrer.descripcio: It led to a former quarry.

carrer.name: Vell de Santa Creu d'Olorda a Vallvidrera, Camí
carrer.descripcio: It comes out of the Carrer de Mont d'Orsa on the way to the hill of Llavallol.

carrer.name: Vell de Sarrià, Camí
carrer.descripcio: The outline of this stretch of the pathway between the Carrer de Gelabert and the Carrer de Tarradellas is preserved.

carrer.name: Vell del Coll, Camí
carrer.descripcio: It leads to the sanctuary of El Coll, also known as the sanctuary of El Coll de Font-rúbia.

carrer.name: Vendrell, Carrer de
carrer.descripcio: Named after the Mas Vendrell estate, which is more than six-hundred years old. In 1893, the Vendrell de Pedralbes family sold the lands where the street was opened to Consol de Moragas i de Quintana, the Marchioness of Moragas.

carrer.name: Venècia, Carrer de
carrer.descripcio: It owes its name to the Italian city of Venice.

carrer.name: Veneçuela, Carrer de
carrer.descripcio: It owes its name to Venezuela, a state in South America.
carrer.anteriors: Venezuela; Almogávares (2nd section); Las Glorias; Lletra S (Cerdà plan)

carrer.name: Venero, Carrer de
carrer.descripcio: Antonio de Venero y Venero Borgoña Cosío de la Hoz. Owner of the lands. His son Francesc de Venero de Valera i Sisteré, a lawyer, sold them in 1889.

carrer.name: Vent, Carrer del
carrer.descripcio: A popular name given to the street because there was a wind that blew here which gave force to the currents of air that had to make their way around the nearby hill of La Peira.

carrer.name: Ventalló, Carrer de
carrer.descripcio: Ignasi Ventalló i Llobateras (1814 - 1885). Landowner. He purchased the estate between 1862 and 1864.

carrer.name: Ventura Gassol, Plaça de
carrer.descripcio: Bonaventura Gassol i Rovira (La Selva del Camp, Baix Camp 1893 - Tarragona 1980). Politician and writer. Minister of Culture in the first Govern de la Generalitat (Catalan Autonomical Government). Minister of Public Policy in the Catalan Republic. Member of the Spanish Parliament.

carrer.name: Ventura Plaja, Carrer de
carrer.descripcio: Bonaventura Plaja i Tapis, a landowner who was a councilor for the former town of Sants. The lands where the street was opened, in the spot known as "La Vall", were the property of Francesc d'Assís Carreras i Candi.

carrer.name: Ventura Rodríguez, Carrer de
carrer.descripcio: Ventura Rodríguez Tizón (Cienpozuelos 1712 - Madrid 1785). Castilian architect. In Barcelona he projected the Col·legi de Cirurgia and directed the works (1761).

carrer.name: Venus, Carrer de
carrer.descripcio: The goddess of beauty and love.

carrer.name: Veracruz, Plaça de
carrer.descripcio: It owes its name to Veracruz, a city in Mexico. An urban area situated at the northern end of the Bon Pastor industrial estate, where the thoroughfares are dedicated to cities of Latin America.

carrer.name: Verda de la Prosperitat, Plaça
carrer.descripcio: An urban area shaped as an irregular polygon located, on the one hand, between the Carrer del Vinyar and the Carrer de Tissó, and, on the other, between the Carrer d'Argullós and the Avinguda de Rio de Janeiro.

carrer.name: Verdaguer i Callís, Carrer de
carrer.descripcio: Narcís Verdaguer i Callís (Vic, Osona 1863 - Barcelona 1918). Lawyer and politician. President of the Centre Nacional Català, Vice-president of the Lliga Regionalista. President of the Societat Econòmica d'Amics del País and of the Acadèmia de Jurisprudència i Legislació. Councilor for Barcelona (1905 - 1910).

carrer.name: Verdet, Carrer del
carrer.descripcio: An alley in which there existed a copper sulfate laboratory ('verdet'). The lands had been part of the estates of Gaietà de Villalonga i de Marimon, Baron of Segur.

carrer.name: Verdi, Carrer de
carrer.descripcio: Giuseppe Fortunino Francesco Verdi d'Uttini (Roncole, near Bussetto, Parma 1813 - Milan 1901). Italian composer. Principal musical figure of the Risorgimento.

carrer.name: Verdum, Plaça del
carrer.descripcio: It owes its name to the greenfinch ('verdum'). The dedication of the square came about with the bird in mind and also in memory of the ornithological society of the nineteen-thirties which existed in that neighborhood known as "del verdú", as well as of certain vineyards which took the name of Verdum.

carrer.name: Verdun, Passeig de
carrer.descripcio: Named after the Battle of Verdun in the First World War (1914 - 1918). When reading the municipal records of the time one realizes that the Barcelona Town Council was deeply Francophile: telegrams inquiring about the state of health of Clemenceau, the head of the French government, after an assassination attempt; the nomination of the presidents of the councils of ministers in France and Great Britain as honorary citizens of Barcelona; monuments to the Catalan soldiers killed on the field of battle in France; assistance in the reconstruction of a French city; and approval for the naming of the Plaça de l'11 de novembre de 1918 (today Plaça de Ramon Berenguer el Gran), the Passeig del Mariscal Joffre (today the Avinguda de Borbó, a name which also belonged to the Plaça de Vázquez de Mella) and also the Passeig de Verdun. In the acts which gave approval to these names the significance of each one is not explained, as enough was already known about their origin.

carrer.name: Verema, Carrer de la
carrer.descripcio: The grape harvest ('vendímia'). An evocative name that refers to the vineyards that were formerly in this place.

carrer.name: Verge, Carrer de la
carrer.descripcio: This street, which dates from 1867, was opened to provide access from the Carrer de Valldonzella to the front courtyard of the monastery of Santa Maria de Valldonzella which existed between 1640 and 1909, in which year it was burnt down. The street is named 'de la Verge 'because the 'Verge del Cor' (Our Lady of the Choir) was the special protectress of that Cistercian community.

carrer.name: Vergós, Carrer dels
carrer.descripcio: A family of Catalan painters of the fifteenth and sixteenth centuries. The brothers Jaume and Francesc Vergós, their respective sons Jaume (Barcelona? - 1503) and Francesc, and the sons of this younger Jaume, whose names were Pau (? - 1495) and Rafael (? - 1500), were the last representatives of the Catalan 'Quatrecentista' style.

carrer.name: Verneda, Camí de la
carrer.descripcio: A forest of alder-trees. By extension, the banks of rivers covered in vegetation are called in Catalan 'vernedes'. Hence the name of the neighborhood that is on the right-hand side of the Besòs river.

carrer.name: Verneda, Carrer de la
carrer.descripcio: This refers to the name of the neighborhood.

carrer.name: Verneda, Passeig de la
carrer.descripcio: In the place occupied by the very ancient "Molí de la Verneda", the Verneda mill.

carrer.name: Verneda, Plaça de la
carrer.descripcio: Named for the same reason as is the street.

carrer.name: Verns, Camí dels
carrer.descripcio: It owes its name to the alder-tree.

carrer.name: Verntallat, Carrer de
carrer.descripcio: Francesc de Puigpardines, Lord of Verntallat and of Violant, Viscount of Hostoles (Les Preses, La Garrotxa 1444 - Barcelona 1500). Head of the retainers called 'remença'. Royal Captain of King Joan II. King Ferran II bestowed some houses in Barcelona on him (1488).

carrer.name: Verònica, Plaça de la
carrer.descripcio: It recalls the Palestinian woman who, according to the Gospels, wiped the face of Jesus when he was on his way to Calvary, to the effect that the image of Jesus remained imprinted on the towel.

carrer.name: Vesc, Carrer del
carrer.descripcio: It owes its name to the mistletoe. One of the streets in the Rectoret neighborhood dedicated, as are many others in that place, to plants and shrubs.

carrer.name: Vesuvi, Carrer del
carrer.descripcio: It owes its name to Vesuvius, an Italian volcano.

carrer.name: Via Làctia, Carrer de la
carrer.descripcio: It owes its name to the Milky Way. A street in the Rectoret neighborhood, where many of the thoroughfares have names suggested by the residents.

carrer.name: Vic, Carrer de
carrer.descripcio: Named after the city of Vic (from Latin 'Vicus'), the capital of the Catalan region of Osona.

carrer.name: Vicaria, Carrer de la
carrer.descripcio: There existed in this street a house named The Vicarage ('la vicaria'), where the priests carrying out parish duties in the Barceloneta neighborhood used to reside. The parish in the Barceloneta neighborhood used to be a suffragan of Santa Maria del Mar before being erected as the parish of Sant Miquel del Port (1835).

carrer.name: Vicenç Martorell, Plaça de
carrer.descripcio: Vicenç Martorell i Portas (Sant Feliu de Guíxols, Baix Empordà 1879 - Barcelona 1956). Army engineer and cartographer. He founded the City's Servei Parcel·lari, which was later known as 'Pla de Ciutat'.

carrer.name: Vicenç Montal, Carrer de
carrer.descripcio: Vicenç Montal i Artigas, stock broker and owner of the area since 1955.

carrer.name: Vicent López, Carrer de
carrer.descripcio: Vicent López i Portaña (Valencia, Horta 1772 - Madrid 1850). Painter. President of the Academy of Sant Carles (1801) in Valencia. Court painter. Curator of the Prado Museum. An artist very representative of the time of Fernando VII.

carrer.name: Vicent Martín, Passatge de
carrer.descripcio: Vicent Martín i Soler (Valencia, Horta 1754 - San Petersburg 1806). Composer. He fundamentally cultivated opera. In Italy he was known as "Martini lo Spagnolo". He is considered to be one of the best of the Neapolitan school.

carrer.name: Vico, Carrer de
carrer.descripcio: Antonio Vico (Jerez de la Frontera 1840 - Nuevitas, Cuba 1902). Andalusian theatrical actor. He performed in Barcelona between 1888 and 1890.

carrer.name: Víctor Balaguer, Plaça de
carrer.descripcio: Víctor Balaguer i Cirera (Barcelona 1824 - Madrid 1901). Politician, historian, poet and playwright. He acted as Maintainer of the Floral Games poetical contest and received the title of 'mestre en Gai Saber'. Journalist. He was Minister of Public Works and of the Colonies during the reign of Amadeo I.

carrer.name: Víctor Jara, Carrer de
carrer.descripcio: (Chillan, Chile 1938 - 1973). Song- writer and singer, and theatrical director.

carrer.name: Victòria, Carrer de la
carrer.descripcio: In the seventeenth century a chapel was erected on this spot dedicated to Our Lady of Victories.

carrer.name: Victòria Kent, Plaça de
carrer.descripcio: Victoria Kent y Siano (Malaga 1898 - New York 1987). Politician and jurist. In 1924 she started to work on her profession, and in 1930 she defended in court the members of the Revolutionary Committee detained after the Jaca events. Member of the Spanish Parliament in 1931 and 1936, she was appointed Director-General of Prisons, and of the Instituto de Estudios Penales. At the end of the Spanish Civil War, she went into exile in France, where she lived through the Nazi occupation, an experience which she reflected in her book 'Cuatro años en París' (1947). She later settled in Mexico (1945-1950), where she took charge or organizing a vocational school for women prisoners. She later worked for the UN (1950-1952) and edited the 'Ibérica' journal. In 1977 she came back from exile. The dedication of the street was suggested by the Grup Dona of Barcelona's Municipal Council of Social Welfare.

carrer.name: Vidal i Valenciano, Carrer de
carrer.descripcio: Eduard Vidal i Valenciano (Vilafranca del Penedès, Alt Penedès 1838 - Barcelona 1899). Playwright, politician and write. Member of the Academy of Fine Letters of Barcelona in 1898. He was a member of Castelar's Partido Republicano.

carrer.name: Vidal i Guasch, Carrer de
carrer.descripcio: During the first third of the twentieth century, the owners of the street were the brothers Enric and Eduard Vidal i Juan, and the sisters Maria and Alberta Guasch i Marcé.

carrer.name: Vidal i Quadras, Carrer de
carrer.descripcio: Aleix Vidal-Quadras i Villavecchia (Barcelona 1862 - 1940). Proprietor of the estate since 1900, after purchasing it from Miquel Campanyà and Antoni Brosa. In 1908 he sold the property to Carles Vidal-Quadras i Villavecchia (Barcelona 1864 - 1933), the banker. This land had formerly been in the estate of the Marquis of Barberà and Count de la Solterra. The other two brothers, Manuel and Lluís, owned land in Sarrià. They were all sons of Aleix Vidal i Ramon (Santiago de Cuba 1826 - Barcelona 1914), widower of Isabel Rabasa, and later remarried to Mercè Villavecchia i Busquets). By a decree of 25th May 1898 the Queen regent granted Vidal i Ramon the privilege of adding the surname Quadras to his first surname. The street is devoted to his memory. On the other hand, on 29th November 1866, the Sarrià City Council publicly thanked Manuel Vidal i Quadras, the proprietor, for having provided the public fountains with water.

carrer.name: Vidiella, Carrer de
carrer.descripcio: Carles Gumersind Vidiella i Esteban (Arenys de Mar, Maresme 1856 - Barcelona 1915). Pianist. He devoted his efforts to teaching.

carrer.name: Vidre, Carrer del
carrer.descripcio: Formerly known as Forn del Vidre, owing to a kiln for glass located in the vicinity which in addition gave name to the Hort del Vidre, bought in 1717 by the Capuchin friars of Mont Calvari convent to a man named Peguera, to build a convent there (1718), and which was later demolished (1848). The Plaça Reial stands today on that site.
carrer.anteriors: Vidrio; Forn del Vidre; Viladalls; Quintana

carrer.name: Vidriera, Plaça de la
carrer.descripcio: Agrupació Vidriera (1932-1992). This co-operative organization from Sants was constituted in Barcelona and its social see and factory were in the Carrer de Gayarre, nos 59-77, with the aim to improve the social and financial condition of its associates, and to obtain a greater yield for its non-profit work in common. To this end, the co-operative devoted itself to the manufacture typical of the glass industry.

carrer.name: Vidrieria, Carrer de la
carrer.descripcio: The glassmakers settled there in the thirteenth century.

carrer.name: Vidriol, Carrer del
carrer.descripcio: There existed in this street a factory of vitriol --also known as sulfuric acid.

carrer.name: Vigatans, Carrer dels
carrer.descripcio: In a document from 1492 there is a reference to the Carrer dels Bigatans, which in another document is spelt as 'Viguetans'. It is said that the name of the street could come from a hostel frequented by merchants from the city of Vic. What is not probable, given the suffix, is that the name refers to the builders of beams for coffered ceilings.

carrer.name: Vila Arrufat, Carrer de
carrer.descripcio: Antoni Vila i Arrufat (Sabadell, Vallès Occidental 1894 - Barcelona 1989). Painter. He taught engraving at the Escola Superior de Belles Arts de Sant Jordi in Barcelona. Member of the Academy of Sant Jordi and Corresponding Member of the Academy of San Fernando. He exhibitied on his own in Buenos Aires and Rosario (Argentina) in 1954, and in Barcelona and Sabadell on several occasions. He cultivated mural painting ever since 1925. He decorated the Sala de la Ciutat of Barcelona City Hall.

carrer.name: Rius i Taulet, Plaça de
carrer.descripcio: Named for the same reason as is the avenue.

carrer.name: Vila de Madrid, Plaça de la
carrer.descripcio: The capital of the Spanish state and of the autonomous community of Madrid.

carrer.name: Roses, Carrer de
carrer.descripcio: Named after the municipality of Roses in the Alt Empordà region of Catalonia. It forms a unity with Carrer de Garriguella, which runs parallel to it.

carrer.name: Vila i Rosell, Passatge de
carrer.descripcio: Miquel Vila i Boix (Torrelles, Baix Llobregat 1876 - Barcelona 1954). Tanner. In 1918 he bought the land to the widow of Antoni Rosell i Malpica (La Habana, Cuba 1854 - Barcelona 1918). The thoroughfare adopted the name of both proprietors.

carrer.name: Vila i Vilà, Carrer de
carrer.descripcio: Two names of two families owners of these lands. The saga of these families starts in 1741 when Josep Vila i Llabeyola bought this land. He was succeeded by his son Bartomeu Vila, who in turn had two children: Benet Vila i Calsapeu, who died in 1826, and Mateu Vila i Calsapeu, farmer, who died in 1840. They were succeeded by Benet Vila i Cuyàs and Domènec Vila i Jané, the children of the former. The children of Vila Cuyàs sold in 1879 a part of the central estate to the lawyer Francesc Vilà de Casanovas.

carrer.name: Vila Joiosa, Carrer de la
carrer.descripcio: Named after Villajoyosa, a municipality of the Marina Baixa region of the Valencia province. Subjected by Carlos I for having lent support to the 'Germanies' movement. The name was given after the fishermen and mariners from this town who came to settle in this street.

carrer.name: Viladecans, Carrer de
carrer.descripcio: Named after Viladecans, a municipality of the Baix Llobregat region of Catalonia.

carrer.name: Viladecavalls, Carrer de
carrer.descripcio: Named after Viladecavalls del Vallès, a muncipality of the Vallès Occidental region of Catalonia. A street in the Torre Baró neighborhood where most thoroughfares are dedicated to towns in Catalonia.

carrer.name: Viladecols, Baixada de
carrer.descripcio: Name of a Catalan family prior to the thirteenth century. A member of this family set up a bakery in the street to which there are documentary references from as early as 1281. This made the street to be called "Carrer del forn d'en Viladecols", and later, "Carrer" or "Baixada de Viladecols".
carrer.anteriors: C. del Forn d'en Viladecols; Vilatorta; Dressana Vella

carrer.name: Viladomat, Carrer de
carrer.descripcio: Antoni Viladomat i Manald (Barcelona 1678 - 1755). Painter. He cultivated preferably religious themes. Name suggested by Víctor Balaguer.

carrer.name: Viladrosa, Carrer de
carrer.descripcio: Josep Viladrosa i Fontanillas (Torà, Segarra 1872 - Barcelona 1950). Proprietor. He bought the land from Francesc d'Assís Planas i Buera.

carrer.name: Vilafranca, Carrer de
carrer.descripcio: Named after Vilafranca del Penedès, the capital of the Alt Penedès region of Catalonia.

carrer.name: Vilageliu i Gavaldà, Carrer de
carrer.descripcio: At the time of going to press, the dedication of this street was still not clear. In the 1980 edition of the Street Guide it is assumed that it is the name of the proprietor, a fact which has not been thoroughly confirmed.
carrer.anteriors: Vilageliu y Gabaldá, before 1925; Pje. de Garrofers

carrer.name: Vilalba dels Arcs, Carrer de
carrer.descripcio: Named after Vilalba dels Arcs, a municipality of the Terra Alta region of the Valencia province.

carrer.name: Vilamajor, Carrer de
carrer.descripcio: Named after the Vilamajor municipalities in the Vallès Oriental region of Catalonia (Sant Pere de Vilamajor and Sant Antoni de Vilamajor). Both Vilamajor municipalities are considered streets of Barcelona, as they requested unity with Barcelona under the formula of 'carreratge', in accordance with which the requesting town was considered a street of Barcelona, and its inhabitants could therefore enjoy the same privileges and rights as those of the capital.

carrer.name: Vilamarí, Carrer de
